For a two dimensional game, Terraria has a surprising amount of relatively difficult content, filled with several environments and a large variety of items, both cosmetic and functional, which allow you to create a perfect world, of sorts. Exploration, mainly below the surface level, can be a tad tedious, but it comes with a plethora of caverns of various sizes to explore.  There's certainly a lot of things to do, especially if you're a perfectionist, as the environment does involve over time, although it can be prevented for the most part until a certain boss is defeated. Afterwards, the game assumes a whole new depth, as your world becomes several times more dangerous while being much more difficult and tedious to contain, but the rewards come in the form of new, unique items, more challenging bosses and even a new environment to explore.  If you enjoy a challenge, the hard mode bosses will test your limits. If you enjoy building, there are many materials to choose from to create a modest home or a vast castle. If you enjoy mastering the very world, then you can, quite literally, build it the way you want, with enough time and dedication.  All in all, this game is certainly one that has hours of entertainment and has a little something for everyone, since it truly has some unique elements, despite being limited to a two dimensional plane, which actually ends up opening some unique possibilities that similar games simply cannot give without making them broken.

Judging by my play time, you can probably already guess what I think of Terraria. After all, how could I be negative towards a game I've sunk hundreds of hours into? But you really need to know just what makes Terraria such an incredible game and a shining example of what dedicated indie developers are really capable of.  If I was going to take points off of this game for one thing, it'd be the tutorial, or rather the lack thereof. The beginning of the game isn't very intuitive and will lead to you wandering around aimlessly, dying and just generally not understanding what you are doing. A quick read on a starter guide or a YouTube video will get you sorted, though. To put it simply, anyone who has told you that Terraria is just 2D Minecraft is a liar. To an outsider looking in, it may seem that way, but let me tell you, if you're willing to take the time and learn the game's mechanics, it has so much more to offer than simply a Minecraft clone minus one dimension.  Terraria, in my opinion, can be best described as a completely open-ended Metroidvania style platformer. You explore the world collecting valuable resources to forge better weapons and armor, and find hidden treasures to improve your character in various ways. Even though it sounds simple in nature, once you dive in, you'll have a hard time getting back out. Gathering the resources required to build your next set of shiny new armor can take a while, but you won't even notice because you'll just be having way too much fun exploring the caves. A one hour play session can easily triple or quadruple because you want to keep exploring to see what kinds of cool stuff you can find. Maybe you'll find a huge gold deposit to finish off your set of gold armor? Maybe you'll find some rare equipment that grants you a double jump, or lets you run super fast, or maybe you'll find some awesome weapon that will allow you to comfortably explore a new region that was previously too tough? The possibilities are endless and since each world you play through is randomly generated, you'll have a slightly different experience each time you run through the game.  Exploring to craft new equipment and find new items is all well and good, but what else is there? Simple: There's the boss fights, which leads to one of the most well-crafted and open ended parts of the game. Most bosses are summoned by meeting certain conditions, like expending an item that summons the boss, talking to a certain NPC, etc. Whether you choose to take on bosses right away for the chance of getting some nice loot earlier than usual, or wait until you're properly prepared, is all up to you. You can even go so far as to take advantage of the game's open world and construct a complex arena to take on the bosses in. The fights themselves are very well done, nice and challenging without feeling cheap. If a boss mops the floor with you, it's all on you; either you could have done a better job dodging and doing damage, or come better prepared with better items or an arena to assist with dodging and damage dealing. Another layer of complexity is added when you consider the different character classes, of which there are four: Fighter, Ranger, Mage, and Summoner. The best part is, you're not locked into a specific class because of an arbitrary choice; instead, you pick your class by equipping armor that grants you buffs and benefits for the class of weapons you want to use. So if you're typically a melee user and a boss or new area is giving you trouble, hang up the sword and shield for a while and get yourself a set of ranger armor and gear.  The world you explore is absolutely packed with content. Even on the smallest world setting, you can spend hours exploring and fighting bosses, and it is entirely open ended. If you feel like digging straight down to the underworld and taking on the Wall of Flesh within the first few minutes of starting a new world, go right around (just don't expect to get far unless you really know what you're doing). Whether you simply want to beat all of the bosses or have other goals like collecting all of the boss masks, acquiring every item or armor set, this game will make sure you have something to sink your time into. This is all without even talking about the game's online multiplayer. The implementation is a bit rough, as you'll have to connect to servers the old school way by inputting the server's IP address, but this still opens up a whole new realm of activities. Even if you're not interested in hopping on servers to meet new players and test your mettle in arenas or even against other players, this game is still a great time with a couple buddies, and the Steam integration means you can easily join your buddy's game without the need for exchanging IP addresses and whatnot.  If this review hasn't convinced you, the dozens of other reviews singing this game's praises should. I absolutely cannot recommend Terraria enough, especially if you're a fan of Metroidvania style games. It's packed with content and is just an awesome time all around. Plus, even if you don't like it, hey, you only paid ten bucks for it (seriously, that price point is insane for what this game offers), and it regularly goes on sale for less than that. What are you doing still reading this review? Go on and play this game already! You won't be disappointed.

Awesome game! Totally open world so you can run around and do whatever you like. Extremely addictive. Easy to spend a whole day/night playing without realizing where the time went. Dig holes, mine ore, build equipment, harvest plants, fight monsters, build houses, explore hidden lands, empty lakes of molten lava and relocate them, gather NPCs...the possibilities are limited only by your imagination.  However, this game does come with one very large detraction: Online multiplayer, while do-able, is a royal pain in the butt. It is a lot of fun if you can get it to work, but, unless you're pretty decent with computers, good luck with that. You have to link via IP address and there are all sorts of snags and complexities that, to be honest, I really don't understand. Something about ports, I think, and maybe firewalls. Someone else got it to work for me, since I had no idea what to do to fix it. Suffice to say, it was a pain.  That caveat aside, this is a well constructed game that offers a lot of replay value. My favorite game on steam - I really can't recommend it highly enough.

Introduction Terraria is a game developed by Re-Logic. The dev team are very active with this game, constantly supporting and adding to the experience, they are really great developers.  Gameplay Terraria is a sandox 2D adventure game that focuses mainly on exploration, building and combat. It starts in a procedurally generated world where the player is left with basic items to start the adventure and try to succeed in a very hostile and at times, unforgiving world.  In Terraria you will encounter many different enemy types from little slimes to huge mechanical bosses that are not easy to take down. The player can use melee, ranged or summoner to take out these beasts and the HUGE range of items and item recipes/combinations makes the game highly replayable.  Players house and interact with NPCs in order to progress through the world, with the first NPC being the Guide, whom can be used constantly to reveal all of the item recipes in the game.  Lastly, once you have become good at combat, you can try to become good at building, which adds a whole new element to the game, adding even more hours to your game time. You can build structures high up into the air that take up the whole background, or you can just build a simple lil house to go to sometimes in between fighting bosses, it's completely up to you!  Pros + Endless game time + Awesome weapons/items/enemies + Constant dev support  Cons - No REAL Story (you make your own adventure) - Online Multiplayer is too laggy   Result / Final thoughts For a game so inexpensive that can produce sooooo many hours of gameplay, it is crazy value for money. You won’t be disappointed by Terraria. It is my second most played game of all time (and I'm a Final Fantasy completionist enthusiast) and definitely one of my top 10 games of all time!  -MC

#Beat 'Normal' mode on PS Vita/PS4.   There are a lot of survival / crafting games on steam. Most of them are in early access and most of those will never get finished. Terraria is the exception. It is a COMPLETE game with a ton of content and is actually done. It is also easily the best game in it's genre out there (and if you like 2D crafting games, it is a must own).   The short version? Terraria is a game where you mine materials. Then build components from those materials. Then use those components to built tools and workbenches, etc. Then you use those to build better gear. Then you use that gear to go futher and beat bosses. And so on. It has a RIDICULOUS amount of content.   In addition:  - Multiplayer - Your character/world are seperate saves. So use an existing character in a new world or and new character in an existing world. - Bosses!  Game is just great. Some of the best money I have spent on any platform. And I own it on 3.

I’m not one to gush, and by this point, I’ve actually kind of moved on from this game, but I was writing a review for another one of those boring sandbox games (one in early access, no less) and I realized I hadn’t ever taken the time to write a review for Terraria.  This game cannot be recommended highly enough. It looks like Minecraft running on a Super Nintendo, which I personally find charming, and it has more soul than any sandbox game I’ve ever seen. I don’t think it’s ever been more than $9.99, and somehow manages to continue to update years and years after its release, to the point where it has so much content that anyone who didn’t play it from the beginning, and thus experience its grandeur in stages, will probably just go blind. Its creators will undoubtedly spend the rest of their lives desperately trying to live up to its majesty, and while they will inevitably fail to replicate Terraria, it matters not, for they have already earned their place amid the stars for this masterpiece.

At first glance, Terraria seems to be a lackluster indie game with a clunky, confusing interface and a list of crafting options a mile wide. Especially for you Minecraft transplants, you’ll initially find the flat, side-scrolling perspective a bit off-putting after countless hours having been spent in an immersive, 3D environment. Take some time to adjust your lenses, however, and you’ll discover a game that’s both deep and almost endlessly entertaining.  In Terraria, you are plopped into a randomly generated world, your only task is to explore, survive and thrive. Survival isn’t even top of your “to-do list”, as the minor penalty of losing coins upon death is nothing more than a momentary set-back for the most part. The real driving force behind Terraria is its amorous advances of exploration, drawing you in with suggestive displays of pots and vases in surface-level caves, before luring you deeper with promises of heaving chests and rich ores.  There is a wealth of fun to be had with this game, but accessing it can be an insufferable challenge to start out. Without any solid tutorials in-game, your left to wander the world, clueless as to what to do. The guide, a starting NPC, can give you useful tips here-and-there, but without any discernible goal to achieve, it’s hard to see the appeal at first. Building a shelter is a confusing chore, crafting weapons; an alien concept, and survival at night is a daunting task.   Plus, once you’ve mastered single player, you can take your character online, to tackle all the challenges the world has to offer with a few friends; or simply start from scratch and carve a new adventure (boss battles are certainly easier, but never-the-less challenging). For the small price to buy into this title, you’ll get more than your moneys worth in gameplay. (Available to buy through Steam)  Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got some Hellstone armour to craft, a Demon Alter to find and an Eater of Worlds to slay.  Score:  By yourself: 5/10 With friends: 8.5/10

A lot of people think that Minecraft is the only good survival-crafting game, but Terraria proves that wrong.   Terraria is a 2D platformer-style game that revolves around gathering materials, crafting armor and weapons, exploring, and fighting off hordes of evil monsters.  But, it's much more than just 'survive and thrive'. There are unique spells and enchancements that can be found to crush your enemies. NPCs may arrive at your house and sell items. New ores, new areas, new fun.  Also, there is a massive amount of bosses to fight, ranging from the frightening Eye of Cthulu, to the all-powerful Moon Lord.  There's a money system within the game that allows you to buy items from NPCs. Coins can be collected from monsters, bosses, chests, and more.  There's wide variety of things to do in Terraria, and trust me, you won't regret it.

Epic little game.  Grab your friends, or even adventure yourself alone, in the wonderful world of Terraria. Terraria is a really great game. There's a lot to do, and you should expect to have about 60 hours of gameplay per playthrough, which is a lot considering the game is so cheap. It's a bit grindy at times, especially if there's a certain item you wanna get from a certain NPC, or if you're looking to make armor with end-game ores. There's a really good amount of weapons, armor sets and bosses, as well as building blocks and furniture for the more creative people. There are swords, shortswords, spears, spell tomes, crossbows, bows, repeaters, staves, summoning staves, etc. There are armor sets that favor (offensive) magic, guns / (cross)bows / repeaters, melee and summoning as well, so you'll certainly find a set of weapons and armor that suits you.   The artstyle is pretty nice. Even though it's pixelated it's still one of the best looking games in my opinion. It's colorful, cheerful (sometimes...) and it just looks good.  I've never had so much fun with a game that's so cheap. I personally like to play it in multiplayer, but singleplayer is also pretty good.   I recommend it, absolutely. It has a lot of replay value to it, at least for me. And if you get bored of vanilla Terraria, there are a few mods that can really enhance your experience.

Terraria is a sandbox building indie video game written in Java originally by Swedish creator Markus 'Notch' Persson and now by his company, Mojang, formed from the proceeds of the game. It was released on May 17, 2009, with a Beta on December 20, 2010. Official releases for iOS and Android are currently in development to be released later in 2011 along with a full version of the game; the Android release will be temporarily exclusive to the Xperia Play. A version of the game for the Xbox 360 with Kinect support is under development by 4J Studios.

Terraria is your average run of the mill dungeon crawler where you mine, craft, survive, (sounds like a couple games I know if YOU CATCH MY COLD) and a whole load of other obscure things , like house rather different NPS in your own home or trophies from boss kills and other things! So I really like this game and I am going to go in depth with some of the features of the game and why I like it  The Farming: The farming in this game is just like any other dungeon crawler, but a bit more drawn out. A lot of the drop rates are super low for somewhat uncommon items, it would be understandable for that low of a drop rate for RARE items, but rare items have even lower drop rates. In the end, I always have the time to get the job done and get an item, but it does take a lot of time.  The Plot: Well, there is really no plot, other than the fact that you try to get to hard mode and beat all of the hard mode bosses, which are mainly based off the normal mode bosses, except they are mechanical, WOOW. All though they have as of recently added more bosses, which are indeed way cooler, like the golem and the plantera, the bosses are not that bad. Aside from that, like I said there is no plot, just like most dungeon crawlers and basic survival simulator games.  Customization: In this game there is a decent amount of editing that can be done in game, like make a mansion of epic proportions, edit your characters appearance with cool armor and other vanity items , and have different prefixes of your tools and weapons that can change the way the weapon or tool acts. Customization is not very big in this game although it is pretty good; then again, customization is never really big in dungeon crawlers so there was no need for them to set a new standard for dungeon crawlers.  Well that’s all I really want to say about this game. I love it; it is a great time killer. The price is $9.99, but if you wait around for sales you can get it for $5 or even $2.50 in special a sale (which is when I bought it). It is worth $10 if you are looking for a fun dungeon crawler for you to get sucked into. That is it, thanks for reading.

Terraria is a fun 2D sandbox game with good and varied combat. This game lacks a tutorial, but crafting recipes are shown when you have the right materials, and if in dire need, the Guide will most likely help you out (finally). So far, the game has received two major updates, keeping you on your toes even in the late game, which has been vastly improved over the course of the two updates, keeping it fresh for even longer.  The 2D view gives you a great opportunity to look at everything that happens around you due to the zoom level, and makes building that much more rewarding. It is easy to build good looking houses and make them functional as your main base of operations as well.  The combat is rewarding and never feels cheap. Normal monsters fit into a few categories when it comes to AI and patterns, but the game very rarely feels repetitive. The bosses are (mostly) hard (like the rest of the game), and provide a worthy challenge to everybody seeking to kill them and harvest their precious resources so that you can proceed.  Soundtrack is good and fits the game very well. Nothing else to say here.  Playing with your friends is highly recommended as the game might seem empty and boring by yourself, but can turn into something almost magical with your pals.

I absolutely love Terraria. Let me tell you why.  Pros: Lots of different types of Materials; I brought my friend who has only played minecraft into the game. You control how much hallowed is released by how many demon alters you break and etc...   The only real con I can think of is the fact that it's 2-D but I actually find that to be a pro because the '3D' games now a days like Minecraft actually make me sick with all the camera movement.     If you want to play multiplayer you just have to make sure you have a forwarding port open on your computer for Terraria. Then host the world ^_^ It's fun and just an overall great game...  10/10

Addictive, fun and freaking awesome. These are just a few words to describe such an awesome and epic game. Upon arrival you will be greated with a vastly expansive overworld. You will have to mine, build and fend off attacks off hordes of monsters to survivethe night. As you explore you will find new biomes and materials used to craf items. Crafting in this game is exceptionally clever due to it's mystery. There is virtually no crafting interface and you will simply have to explore and experiment to get extremely powerful gear. Though such a big world you will never feel lonely, as you can build houses or apartments for in game npcs that will show up upon completely a task of some kind. Furthermore the multiplayer is extremely easy to set up and playing with friends is a blast. Also the in game strategy guide npc is your main source of information. I won't ruin some of the really cool bosses in this game but let's just say that they are legendary, difficult and fun as hell to beat. Whether your mining deep into the underworld or braving the endless skeletol masses in a dungeon, this game will never run out of things to do (Just clear your schedule for the next couple decades).

This is a game that I have loved for the last 2 years. Terraria is a 2D expirience with you as the hero. You verse Bosses, and get loot directly from them, and use that loot to your advantage. You go mining underground, and the darkness around you really makes you feel uneasy and scared, but that makes you feel more empowered to go on and get all the ores you can! Even after you think you have beaten the game, the game goes into something called 'Hardmode'. New ores and bosses appear and it makes you feel like you just started the game all over again.   Everything is still there; your armour, your house, your tunnels, your loot, but the difference is this; new enemies appear in old biomes that are much harder to kill, new bosses can be summoned with old loot if you held onto it, and you can craft new armor and gear to take on the new bosses. Even after all of that, you can summon an event, as they call it. A bunch of either Halloween or Christmas themed enemies will attack your world, wave by wave, and you can get some serious loot and cash!  After all that, you can go online and look up some servers to play! There are PVP servers, minigame servers, and even some server that replicate single player, but with some friends by your side, and a bunch of plugins and commands to help you out along the way! Some of these servers even make the game harder for you, giving you more of a feeling of a challange!   For a cheap game, this one has really touched my heart in many ways, and I would reccomend for ANYONE who likes action to buy this game immidieatly! Hope you enjoy! Thanks for the amazing game Red!

People who say this is a ripoff of Minecraft are dead wrong. These games may seem similar but they are extremely different. -Terraria is based more on RPG aspects and non-craftable loot while Minecraft focuses on exploring and crafting -Terraria (in my opinion) is based more on the fighting and the bosses while Minecraft is much more heavily focused on building. -Terraria may not have infinite worlds like minecraft, but each world in Terraria is very unique (different ores, biomes, world setup, chests, dungeon size, proximity to certain biomes, world size, etc.), unlike Minecraft. -The biomes in Terraria have special mobs, unlike Minecraft. -Terraria does have a definite end to it, while Minecraft is open ended. -Terraria has more weapons and definite weapon classes, while Minecraft is limited to a sword and a bow (pre-1.9 update) -Terraria is more humorous than Minecraft, with all of its pets and references. -Minecraft is 3D, which may provide a bigger and more realistic scope of the world. -In Terraria food is not necessary.  Similarities -In both games you mine for ore, kill monsters for drops, and farm plants. -Both games have tiers of tools. -Both games revolve around the premise of exploring. -Knowing nothing about either of these games creates a steep learning curve for a new player.  Overall Terraria is more of an RPG-Sandbox game and Minecraft is a Survival-Sandbox game. If you enjoy exciting adventures, diverse loot, and epic boss battlles, then I suggest you pick up Terraria. I am sure you will not be disappointed.

I absolutely love this game.  There is always more stuff to do once you are finished. After beating the game once, how about beating the game with only bows? Or how about only yoyos?   - Pros -  Tons of difficult bosses with well done AI's. Lots and lots of weapons, so many class options. Many different materials to build with, leading to more creativity. Different difficulty options. (Softcore, Mediumcore, Hardcore, Expert Mode) Multiple different events to farm.  - Cons - There is only one thing that I hate about Terraria. The Corruption/Crimson spread, Even with the Clemtaminator, I can never seem to stop the spread. I have to take at least an hour in real time in order to go around spraying the Clemtaminator all over my world every time I play. I know killing Plantera slows it by 33 percent, but its just not enough.   I think that the spread of the Corruption/Crimson/Hallow should stop (or go back to pre-hardmode spread rate) after you beat the moon lord.

This is a wonderful time waster. The day flies by when I am playing this. A 2D platformer/building game that pretty much started the genre. Many people compare this to Minecraft as both games have a large portion of the game dedicated to crafting and building, but the two games are very different. Where Minecraft is almost totally focused on the crafting and buidling aspect, Terraria has a larger focus on the platforming and action side of things. There are a huge amount of monsters, bosses and other items in Terraria. From your traditional swords and bows; to magic spells and mystical weapons; to miniguns and flamethrows, to granades and Imp minions. Another great thing about Terraria is the developers continue to update the game with huge content patches. There is another one scheduled to be out next month.  One downside to the game is the multiplayer can be a pain to setup. It is available but it is not integrated to Steam and 3rd party programs are needed to setup dedicated servers. There is rumor this will change on next patch though, which would be great. I give the game 90/100, where 50 is average. Very very good.

An amazingly good game. Lost many hours with this one. The exploration and adventure factor in Terraria is among the best I've seen in any game. I honestly feel it's the best Metroidvania game out today.   Since this game was released there have been many similar games trying to jump on the bandwagon. Even the guy who did the original art for this game tried to start a similar game, which turned into a big fiasco. Terraria remains the most successful of the bunch.   Like it or hate it, one thing you can't deny about Terraria is that the amount of things you can do and make in this game is unparalleled compared to similar games.

Minecraft gets an update, it adds several new items and blocks. Terraria gets an update and adds a couple hundred new items and blocks, dozens of new enemies, several new events, and a couple of bosses to fight. The only thing minecraft has up on Terraria is a third dimension and a large modding community.  *Although to be honest the biggest similarities between the two end at blocks and squares. If Terraria gained a third dimension it would not be minecraft it has a focus on defeating bosses more than building. However, if Minecraft lost a dimension, wouldn't it just be Terraria without the bosses, weapons, or enemies?

I remember picking this game up a year ago and not really enjoying it much, though about 6 months later I tried it again with some friends and it was insanely fun.   Pros: - Engaging world gen. - Enemy variety. - Interesting armory and arsenal.  - Open to RP/ Themed characters. (In ex. I made Fujiwara No Mokou from Touhou down to the armor set and it worked.)  -Very, VERY LP-able for Youtube creators. - Incredible preformance even on Windows 8. - Not too hard or easy.  - The devs have an interesting sense of humor.  - Incredible soundtrack.   Cons (these are personal rather than preformance) :  - Some bosses/events require you to be in multiplayer due to the difficulty/intensity.  - Sometimes lag will make you fall to your death or phase into the floor.  - Starting speed is a little too slow, but I feel that's the point.   Things I hope to see in further patches: - Panda pet or mount. - Expansions of certain enemy types. ( Ex. Zombie types, Maybe a few youkai inspired enemies, more Pigrons)  - MAYBE expansions to the backgrounds to add more variety or small details.

I've been playing Terraria since 1.1 and my god has it changed. And now with the 1.3 update it's got even better.  Graphics - 7/10: Although the graphics aren't very high quality their level of detail makes them unique. It's no Crysis but it's still looks good.  Gameplay - 8/10 (6/10 for expert mode): The gameplay is quite generic at the beginning (eg. build house, get NPC's to move in, mine, etc.) but after you get some good armor and some decent weapons it ends up being more fun since you aren't constantly dying.  Replayability - 9/10: There are quite a few different ways you can play Terraria with the amount of content there is. For example you could play melee if you feel like wrecking everything in your path or you can play as a mage if you feel like healing others and supporting your friends.  Content - 10/10: The thing that kept me playing for this long is the amount of content. There are over 3000 items including blocks and weapons, 14 bosses, over 300 enemies, over 18 biomes and 25 NPC's.  Final Score - 8.5/10

Terraria is the BEST two-dimensional adventure game I've ever had.  It started out when I was playing it on my old iPad, but when I learned the PC had more content and better controls, I put it on my wishlist for Christmas... and fortunately, one of my relatives bought Terraria for me. It was also how I found Steam.  So I started playing Terraria, started exploring and cutting down trees, and building. While I was building, I kept getting mauled by flying fish and demon eyes. I kept playing, and then I was so alarmed to find that an 'evil presence' was watching me. Guess what, Eye of Cthulhu. I didn't think I would make it, but I slain it. I was so happy, and that was when my interest bumped from the typical 'okay' rating to 'I gotta play this all day every day!'  The only people that wouldn't recommend this game are 10-year-olds from the Minecraft fanbase. 'IT'S A CLONE OF MINECRAFT BUT 2DEE'

A wonderfull 2D version game quite similar to Minecraft. Build your own world, fight hoards of monsters, defeat bosses and mine down deep into the core of the earth. A big lack of anything to do after reaching the very bottom did strike me, but then again it's mostly a multiplayer game at that point. Good fun and cheap.

There comes a point in most any game when there's simply nothing left to discover, but that isn't the case with Terraria. While the beginning of the game can be somewhat frustrating, the deeper you go, the more rewarding it gets. The sheer amount of stuff to do and loot to find is impressive, and has kept my interest for longer than almost any other game.   There's really no story or conventional narrative, but there is always some sort of progression, something to work towards. The beauty in this game manifests as the freedom to choose what you want to do at any given moment. Certainly, there are surprises here and there which may catch you unprepared (you WILL die occassionaly), but the satisfaction of taking down each of the game's bosses is so worth it.   Before I bought this game, I watched a couple videos and didn't necessarily think it looked like my cup of tea, and I still don't own any other games like it. But I went off of a friend's recommendation and became addicted almost instantly. Even when it's not on sale (and it seems to go on sale rather often), Terraria is well worth it. The developers have clearly poured lots of love into this game, so even if you are a bit hesitant, give this one a shot.

This game is probably one of the better RPG's that i've played. All of the mining, smelting, and looting always makes you feel that you're progressing in a sandbox game, which is a difficult task to achieve. It also has a surprisingly good netcode over Steam. However, since the game's pretty loose on how it handles DRM, it's easily exploitable. You can get loot that you weren't even supposed to get untill 500 hours in at 5 minutes (which is why I think Steam Achievements are bogus). Overall, its still a fun game. Definitely reccomend for action-RPG fans and anyone trying to find their quick fix of Minecraft.

As a big minecraft fan, having played the game for many years, I have always dismissed terraria for it's similarities to minecraft, perhaps even looking like a 2D version at times. Picking up the game has been a great experience, and I definately recommend it, here's why:  +many hours of gameplay +great online support from the multitude of players on different websites and wikis +easy to learn and play +relatively cheap +beat up monsters +customisability, mounts, pets, and vanity items +bosses are tough to beat, but give good drops which instantly makes it much easier for consequent battles +many items to find and craft +tools and armor dont break +not very much farming and grinding needed +emphasis on improving and getting better gear to beat bosses +character can be brought to different worlds +lots of fun with friends(servers can be set up very easily via steam) +houses and structures are all built according to your own tastes and designs -game is hard to progress without help from reading online sources -less of an open world experience than other sandbox game -pixel graphics(though can be gorgeous at times)  TL/DR: Just try it. It's not very expensive anyways.

I've played over 400 hours of Terraria in 1.3 alone, (I made this account when 1.3 came out so I could record my time in this update alone) and ~3500 hours of the game in total over every update. Terraria has a masterfully balanced mix of combat, exploration, resource gathering, and branching progression. You start off with nothing and have to work your way up to face the next challange, whatever it may be, finding your own way to overcome it. It is a brilliant game with brilliant developers and an amazing community. The game is actively updated with new content as well. Just be prepared to lose yourself for hours on end, because you won't want to stop playing.

Terraria is like a 2D Minecraft, at first. Then when you get into the game and learn more about it, it becomes much more. Haters may call it 'COPY OF MINECRAFT', but I think it is much, much more. (This was later added on 11/20/15) I feel like Terraria has become too complicated. I always remembered it as a awesome, simple like game. Before there were tons of items, but it didn't take long to figure out what they did. Now it is impossible to learn everything about the game. If you look in a chest at ground level, you can find stuff that you will use until end-game, i.e. the item that shows mobs around you that I can't remember the name for. Anyway, I still think Terraria is a great game, but I think if they kept it a little more simple a lot of people would enjoy it much more.

I've played terraria for nearly 300 Hours, Not that long I know, But this is one of the few games I see myself coming back to constantly, I remember when I first started playing Terraria, I didn't Multiplayer and this was a long time ago, I played a mixed class to fight enemies, Best armor I could get my hands on, A bow, best sword I could grab, and some magic, I had alot of fun, now I play it with my friends all the time, So far I've played Melee/Tank, Mixed, Ranged, and now I am playing a Mage, I've gotten to Hardmode on most of my worlds, I've defeated the    MoonLord    4 times, I've gotten to Hardmode on 2 Expert Worlds currently, One of them I did on Mediumcore, and yet I still keep coming back to Terraria, I love this game, It's the best game I have ever played. 10/10, Would play again,  Although, I do wish that they would stop making that horrid 'Starbound' game and release some updates for Terraria, :p Get this game, It's filled hours of content, I mean hell, I haven't even done everything yet and I've played for almost 300 hours, Buy this game now!

A small green haired boy spawns in the forest with nothing but a copper pickaxe, axe, and a short-sword. After gathering wood for the majority of the day it rains. The young boy thinks nothing of it until the flying fish come and all he could do is stab horizantally at them. He dies, but through his death he has grown. He creates a wooden long sword to defend himself better. He triumphs over the flying fish. He builds a small house and begins to dig underground until he finds iron, once he reaches the surface he then realizes his life's purpose of building a town complete with trash cans, bath tubs, and sinks. The world he started on has run out of iron, so he travels to another. During his quest for iron to fully furnish each of his NPC's houses he defeats demons, finds mighty loot, destroys jungle beasts, and dyes all of his clothes and equipment. He unleashes the forces of heaven and hell upon the world, yet he continues. Every time it rains he remembers those first flying fish. 10/10 would serve the angler again.

Just imagine that you want to break somebody's window to get in their house (with nobody around or inside). You are given a set of things to use to break in but may only use 1 of the items. You have the really expensive tool that you don't know how to use, the choice of looking for an already open window in their backyard (that had an aggressive dog), and a low cost rock you found in the front yard. I picked the rock because of how easy it was to find and use. This game is that rock in which you simply use to break the window and hop in to take some goodies. Profit. Now take that rock and bring it to a home with even more goodies to steal. That's 1.3.  What I'm trying to say is that the game is on sale frequently and worth more than the given price (gameplay-wise). Play it til you're finished or bored and then mess around with the mechanics. Once that's done just wait for an update and then repeat the process.

Don't let my hours played fool you, I've played this amazing title mostly on console and I'm transitioning to the Steam version.  I learned that everything around me can be useful.  I've picked fallen stars up off the grass in the night.  I've cast topaz into a grappling hook and slung myself around caves like a spider.  I've slain undead and hostile creatures with bananas.  I've encountered and overcome countless, dark atrocities that threaten my world.  I've delved into the depths of Hell itself and challenged its master.  I've touched the very heavens using only a bottled cloud and a pair of rocekt boots, then survived the descent using a peculiar drink.  I've shaped mundane and mysterious materials into grand tools of righteous destruction.  I met a pink slime named Pinky and promptly gave it a proper resting place.  I discovered an immense underground beehive and was attacked by its massive queen.  I've tried to befriend a unicorn and was brutally mutilated.  I've struck at the very heart of darkness.  If my stories aren't enough to sway you to purchase this title, then please reconsider. Terraria is an excellent addition to anyone's game library, be you a casual player or full on gamer.  10/10, would seek fallen stars every night

Terraria starts like an empty box. You have nothing, you don't know what to do and the helper guy is just there to troll you along the way. But, suddenly you start to explore, you start to find things like flowers, pots, potions, gold and-SLIME! RUN YOU FOOL! I'll be honest. I originally also thought that Terraria was just a Minecraft clone. I figured, though, that since it was getting such good reviews, I might as well try it, and see what happens.  The next day I spent 12 hours on the game.  It immediately became one of my favorite games. The first time I beat the Eye of Cthulhu, I felt like I accomplished something. The first time I beat the Wall of Flesh, I was so happy that I almost forgot I was in the underworld with enemies that could kill me.  And I thik that might be what Minecraft can't just quite give me. In Minecraft, there are 2 bosses: the Ender Dragon and the Wither. But it's not like you get anything from them that will make the game more fun. In Terraria, there are 14 bosses! (18 if you count the solar, stardust, vortex and nebula pillars) And that's just in the computer version. And maybe some of the pre-hardmode bosses don't drop anything in particular, they still drop items to make good armor and such. In Minecraft, the closest to that is the nether star you get from the Wither.  When you beat those 2 bosses, sure you feel kind of happy, but all you really can get is a bunch of EXP and a beacon. And after that, there's really not much more. You could make things with redstone, but a lot of it is difficult to grasp for newer players. There may nt be very much wiring items yet in Terraria, but it's a lot easier to understand, and with the 1.3.1 update coming out, wiring will get more in-depth as well.  A big part of Terraria is the items. According to the Official Terraria Wiki, there are a whopping 3,646 items that can appear in the comouter version of Terraria. Is that not INSANE?? And each item is unique and has it's own purpose. There are tons of interesting weapons, tools and armor which are all fun to use.  My final verdict: I'd give Terraria a 10/10. I love the items, I love the bosses, I love the NPCs, I love the whole atmosphere of the game. I want to see more of it as well. I hope the developers keep creating more bosses and items and gimmicks and jokes and over all, just keep creating a great game.

Despite the overwhelmign amount of people who have no idea what they're talking about spamming 'OMG TERRYARIA IS JUS 2-D MINCRFT! U GA 4 PLANG IT!!!!!!1!!!' this game is as different as oranges and spanners. To those who have yet to defeat the first boss it may seem that way, but when you get well into the game you find that it actually bears more resembalance to Legend of Zelda.  However, it isn't like that either. Quite frankly, this game isn't like anything. Ever. This game is entirely unique. I'm not sure how a block-based 2-D RPG works, but it does and it works well.  It has somethign for EVERYONE, and I mean it. Heck, the game's wiki even boasts this fact.  The truth is, I cannot describe Terraria. It is something which has to be experienced. Any attempt t sum it up will only fall short of the true beauty.  So buy this game. And when i say that, don't buy it and then bum around for an hour before declaring 'IT SUX,' buy it and play it through.  I own Minecraft, Portal 2, Skyrim, TF2 Premium, Civ 5, and many other games.  Minecraft I have around 2,000 hours logged.  Portal 2 I have described as 'The Perfect Game.'  I have actually practically completed Skyrim.  I would say without a moment's hesitation that buying Terraria was the best money I ever spent.
A lot of fun for hours on end. The singleplayer mode is as intriguing as the multiplayer. Worth the 10 USD.

Empty the beach for sand Loot furniture and lava in hell Farm bosses Loot en masse Dig, Fight, loot, Build, repeat!    - while it uses some of the crafting/randomworldgenerator/sandbox aspects of minecraft it also adds great rpg elements which takes this game far away from being a 2D version minecraft!  So while it may not be for EVERY 19.696.862 (and counting) owner of minecraft they should all, imo, try out Terraria   - stylish oldschool 2D graphics, with modern beautiful lightning effects, actually some of my favourite graphics in a videogame, EVER!   - LOADS of items (2800, more when 1.3 drops)   - lots of debuffs/buffs/enemies   - extreme amounts of gameplay   - lots of cool ideas designed greatly   - 3 difficulty levels    - Rougelike elements including no quick loading, randomly generated worlds (of which you can go between at any time (in the main menu)) and (selectable) permadeath   - moddable (but not on steamworks (google it)) - including xbox360 controller mod (really great)    - multiplayer, both co-op and pvp   - what the devs calls 'the most amazing update yet to Terraria' coming June 2015 adding features, items, ui/crating optimizations and steamachievements    after 40+ hours I have little more than scratched the surface of what this game have to offer    42+/10 - would empty the beach for sand again    ... This game actually came out half a year before TES:V! I sooooooo should have been playing Terraria while waiting for skyrim. Playing it while waiting for Fallout4 though.

First let me say this. Buy this game. I don't care what you like, you need to buy this game. Now allow me to explain why.  Terraria is absolutely in my top 5 favorite games of all time, possibly even top 3. I don't have very good internet so I have a hard time getting into multiplayer games and MMO's (Not for lack of trying) leaving me to play lonely single player games. I find it very hard to get into games, even the thing I love most is growing tired. But Terraria, I always come back to Terraria. All my friends disagree and say that once you do everything there's nothing left to do. Well, they're all about 100 hours in (WHICH IS STILL A LOT.) but I'm still kicking at 700+. I remember back in the summer when I had huge groups of friends all playing this game, trading gear, trying to get farther. Sometimes one of us would get some awesome ♥♥♥♥ on expert mode and show it off. I could even do it with my garbage internet, it was like playing a Pokemon game.   After I defeated Moon Lord and got as far as I could on expert mode (Still haven't beaten expert Moon Lord) I decided I was going to collect every item in the entire game and build a museum to display it, and my friends could help me by trading me stuff. I eventually gave up because the game lost my attention, but resumed months later and was greeted to a corrupted map, meaning I had to start my museum all over again. Most people here would quit, but no, I would not. I vowed I would play through the whole game again with a new character on expert ONLY. I would rebuild my museum better than ever before. My friends came back to join me, also playing on expert and it was great fun...again! And now it appears that I'm about to start my fourth wind. It's time to get back in and finish the museum!   TL;DR this game has provided me with so many hours of enjoyment, and I always come back to it. Buy it, and buy it for your friends.

Terraria is a very creative and chaotic game. I first played this game and said 'What the fudge do I do?' Terraria forces you to learn what to do and what not to do from experience. This allows you to start your own little adventure throughout your world. I for one, enjoyed to beat the s*** out of the eye of cuthulu with just my bow. The multiplayer mode is very enjoyable since you can either work on defeating all the bosses or engage in pvp matches. Just be sure that your not that one guy fighting with a copper shortsword against a guy with a last prism. The only problem I have with the game is that there isn't much to do after you beat the final boss. Once I did that I felt that the game didn't have much to do left. The lack of replayability and bonus content is a bit sad but can easily be excused if you're a multiplayer person. Overall, Terraria is definitly a game you should try.

Beforehand: I'm by no means a native speaker. My english skills are merely enough to write stuff like this :D  I have heard about this game a loong time ago. When it was on sale I just went for it, and it was addicting. I basically played it for 70 hours in 2 weeks of holidays, but after some time it sadly became boring. I think it is a great singeplayer experience and worth the money if you are into build up RPG games. People often call it the 2D Minecraft, but it is more than that. It has way more depth than Minecraft and the 2D has a nice flair/touch. The fact that you can do so much at this game makes the game really challenging and you can learn a lot of secret stuff (sometimes the hard way).  Overall, from the scale of 0 to 100 I would give this game a  singleplayer experience of 78 and a  multiplayer experience of 86.  Seriously, this game is worth its price and if you grab your friends it is even more fun.

This is definitely one of my favorite sandbox adventure games of all time. The variety of weapons, armor, and just plain content is what makes the game so unique. I find this game a boat-load funner than plain old Minecraft, or even most other sandbox games. Unfortunately, after a few hours in the same world, this game might feel a little repetitive, and I find progress to get slow at some points.   Overall, an Impressive amount of content and gameplay, and the satisfying mechanic to turn any helpless critter to pulp by shooting Nyan cats at it.  So go on, give it a shot! I can see this game selling at $20 per copy, so you should feel lucky that it's only $10.  8.5/10 would get jump-scared by the flying skull guy in the dungeon again.

I don't know where to start with this; you're supposed to review a game based on gameplay, but I love Terraria for a lot more reasons.  Terraria was not the first of it's kind, but it has become the most defining title in it's genre. Do you know how you get people to buy a new 2D sandbox game? You tell them it's like Terraria.   Also, in an age where financial models are getting more sketchy by the day, Terraria serves as a reminder of what a caring development team can do. The game was originally released in 2011, and is still receiving free content updates in 2016.  I guess the point I'm trying to make; this is one purchase you will struggle to regret.

Ok, I honestly have no clue as to what to say about Terraria. It's beautiful. Yes, those 2D pixelated are EXTREMELY beautiful. Terraria is filled with challenges and mysteries. You have to defeat challenging enemies to obtain incredibly rare swords or find rare ores to make that special set of armor or weapon. There's almost always a challenge waiting for you; whether it be a boss, the dungeon, or even being invaded by martians and their flying saucers. I have played over 150 hours on my PC and at least 70 hours on my 360 and I STILL can't get enough of it. Each playthrough is probably about 60-70 hours on average which gives you and idea of how much content in the game. You also get to choose to play how you want to play. Whether that be fighting slimes with a wand that dropped from Santa Claus, shooting arrows out of you're newly crafted bow, or hacking and slashing at a giant eyeball. And these aren't permanent either, it's not like World of Warcraft where you have to stick to one class; You can switch between any of these 'roles' at any given point or you could just mix them all together. As you progress through the game, these choices become clearer. After about 25% of the game you get to really define these roles. These also can create some cool co-op combinations. You could have one of your friends play as an archer and shoot his bow at the enemywhile you charge in and tank the hits, or maybe you both wanna be a mage and cast spells at Snowmen! And with the addition of hosting a multiplayer server through steam makes it incredibly easy to play with your friends or some randoms you met on CSGO. Regardless, this game is absolutely incredible and I recommend it to anybody and everybody! :D

This game... I really don't know what I can say about it. It is a great game if you are the kind of person that likes side scrolling survival sandbox games. It is a great game to play with friends or alone, as I have put over 100 hours in just the single player. This game was the first game that I ever had on steam, and I am probably going to be playing another play through of it soon.   Okay now for the real review. This game for some people would not look very good, but fr me, I think it looks very good for the kind of game it is. It has so much replay ability that you will never get bored with it. There is so many bosses to fight, and so many different things to do. Things like getting NPCs by building them houses, making them look nice, and tons of exploration. There is 4 different classes to play, so playing with 4 people is probably the most fun I've had with it, but even playing single player and only focusing on one class adds a new challenge to the game. There is also a mode for the world called 'Expert Mode' and let me tell you, that is hard. It is by far way more difficult than the normal game, and I would only recommend playing if you know what your doing with the game. This game also has a great soundtrack, and you will always be listening to it. In terms of bad things about this game, I'm not sure if I can think of any. If your new to this game and are looking for a survival side scrolling game, this one is very worth the 10$. Other good ones that I have played are Starbound and Dig or Die, and they both were very good. But Terraria for me still tops both of them.

Terraria is a 3rd person and 2 Dimensional game which is recommended for reasons such as: Entertainment, Graphics, Survival, and Multiplayer. Terraria is reccomended for one reason: Entertainment. Due from Terraria's major updates, it allows the player to explore new things and discover more adventures. From the several bosses and varity of creatures, it gives the player a chance to face challenges and try to do new things. Terraria is also giving off many biomes or dimensions to let the player explore like the snow, corrupt or crimson, hallow, underworld, floating island, forest, mushroom biome and more other biomes. Mods are also avalible on the Terraria Wiki, allowing the player to gain new things and automaticly explore (instead of waiting for a update).  Another reason why I reccomend this game is the graphics. Although this is a 3rd person and low quality game, it alows any computer (And Phone :D) to play this game. It also gives the player a taste of a unique game style and graphics which are not used commonly.  Another reason why i reccomend this game is Multiplayer, the Terraria gives another gamestyle: To your play with your friends! It is exicting to play with many other people and have different fun on servers with new friends and fool around. You can also explore more and freely and are able to grab more supplies. Though they are a few bugs and glitches on this game, it is reccomended to people (especially with low quality computers or laptops). Remember though to check the controls of this game, for the controls like inventory is different from usual.

If you a game somewhat like minecraft (with the mining for resources and such) but more structured, then this game is for you. I love this game! There is occasionally grinding, but only at for end game upgrades. There is a ton to do in Terraria; the biggest pluses it has are the armor/weapon/character upgrades and the ability to build mostly whatever the hell you want. It is a sidescroller, and has a loose boss structure, but it is very open ended. The game can be challenging if you're into that, but it can also be very laid back. It's more fun if you play with a friend. After a couple hundred hours, I keep coming back.   Pros: Runs on ♥♥♥♥♥♥ computers, but still visually stimulating combines upgrades while still having to find resources plethora of enemies (including bosses) game gets significantly harder as you go on good with friends  Cons: sidescroller occasional bugs (so make sure you backup your saves a lot) some grinding near the end of the game  Overall, I'd have to give a 9.3/10.

Some people call it a rip off of minecraft but it not I can tell you that much and more. If your looking for more of a adventure Survival then this is for you, it may seem simpler then minecraft but when compared I find it more complicated. I've played it for a total of about 30 hrs. and I STILL haven't found out which armor is best or which weopons to use or what do i need to do to get that. That's the thing with Terarria it keeps you excited because I remember back when Terarria was simple and I had the best armor and weopons, now people pwn me in pvp, and it's not because of skills because I've killed most of the bosses.

First off, to anyone who is to call Terraria a rip-off of Minecraft, please go play nintendogs because you probably have little to no knowledge on gaming. Infact, the game has 100x more content than Minecraft so you really can't say that it copied it. About the actual game, I have been playing it for 3 years (happy 3rd birthday Terraria) and still get complete satisfaction out of it. I applaud Re-Logic for all of their hard work and really wish I could thank them personally. They went above and beyond with the updated to the game and really did improve it when I thought it was already good enough. The game's entertainment lasts extremely long. It already has so much content and each update contains a ridiculous amount of hard work. I can't wait to see how big the Lunar Update will be, considering this will be Red's last update. It is supposed to bring the big boss. When I saw Skeletron I was so amazed and thought it was the big boss. But then they brought Wall of Flesh later on in 1.1 and 3 revamped bosses in mech mode. I still enjoy fighting every boss in the game due to their differences. They aren't all similar replicas of eachother. Re-Logic continues to come up with some of the craziest ideas I have ever seen that work out perfectly. Then, there is the music. I feel that Terraria has some of my favorite soundtracks from every game I have ever played/seen. No other game has music like Terraria has. Then there are the graphics. The game is very beautiful and colorful, with a ton of detail put in to the design. Everything looks so polished and fresh while not being realisticly ugly like 90% of other games made nowadays. Of course, all of the adventure and action that is packed in to this game isn't all there is to it. There are so many creative things in this game that you can do. So many oppurtunities for building, with the large amount of blocks and decorative items that there are. Overall, Terraria is worth the cost. I really am surprised it doesn't cost more with the large amount of content there is. Paying 10 dollars for this is such an amazing deal. The gameplay is so extensive and fun even after you have done everything. I highly recommend buying this game, it is highly worth it.

When I first saw this game, I thought it was a 2D Minecraft clone, and while it does share the element of block building with Minecraft, it couldn't be more different. Terraria is a game that encourages exploration in a very unique way. After discovering how to survive the first night, I set out exploring the many caves and tunnels within the world. I found tons of treasure chest filled with amazing items that changed the way I played the game. Terraria gives the player an amazing sense of advancement and accomplishment as you gather more items. There are so many cool creatures to fight along the way, and bosses really help keep things fresh. Once I defeated the strongest boss, my entire world got 'upgraded' with more powerful monsters and greater challenges. One second I was feeling like an overpowered Terraria god, and next minute I'm barely able to keep myself and my NPCs alive. It was very exciting. I would recommend this game to anyone who loves exploration games, but also loves to see their characters grow with their world.  Be warned however, when you create your character, you can choose between Softcore, Mediumcore, and Hardcore. My first character was Mediumcore, and that means I dropped all my items when I died. This made me upset personally because I hate to lose progress, but the ability to customize your character to your preferred play style was nice to see. I chose to make a new softcore character which means I drop half my gold when I die but I keep my items. Hardcore characters, like the name implies, are unplayable after they die.

Introduction: If you can't see, this game is one of THE best games out there, loads of fun, servers that give you free items if you want to make a UIP Server and make the Buildings for it, with no effort! What's more is that Terraria is so much more fun on PC than Xbox or Playstation! You have dedicated servers to play on so you never feel lonely! Hours of fun and Great for the family!  SinglePlayer:  The SinglePlayer is very fun, the tasks that you need at hand are quite big, and gather ores to the smelt and make yourself withstand any enemy, is a challenge! Most people use duping to get through it quicker but it's not the way to go... The SinglePlayer is a great way to learn the game and experience what it's like to have to face enemies that are much stronger than you, mainly the Zombies and Demon Eyes on Night 1 or 2. The best way to start is to build your house first, on your spawn point, then look for a cave and go mining, resurface when it's day, see below for tips on timing, and then get as many NPC's inside ASAP. Mining goes slowly at first, but the best pickaxe will shred through any ore and block, leaving a easy way to get to Hell. Hell is a place where you should only go once you can defeat most enemies on the surface one hit, maybe 2. Hell is best used with potions that leave you invulnerable against Lava and Enemies, as they are very tough down there. if you end up with a Shadow Key, you can open ANY of the chests and get great loot!   MultiPlayer:  Most servers run off their host's router as many servers cannot afford to run without constant donations. These servers normally reward donators and give lots of benefits to new players, such as free armour and 'Gems' to buy better gear. They also Include a Boss fighting area, on certain servers, that allows you to fight many bosses and keep their loot! This is a great way to make friends and beat bosses in your own world!  Creating your server:  Terraria comes with a free Server setup that you run, select the world, and it will setup, the server allows for many more features like saying in the Console 'time' Will show you the Exact time of the world, and if you want it to be midnight, you can type 'midnight' and it will become midnight! other features are 'motd' for when someone joins, they get a message about the server and what is going on!   Conclusion: Gameplay: 10/10 Great way to waste time and have fun! Story Line: 6/10 Bit slow and not any quests! Fun: 10/10 Spent days on it on my old steam account Worth it? Buy this game now and you will NEVER regret it!!!

I'll have to go back and edit this review later on, but overall it's a good game. I recieved it as a casual gift and in no time flat i ended up becoming wrapped up in this game. There's no end to content you can explore, and even when you 'beat' the game just before the update, there was still more to be found such as rare mount drops, hard to obtain pets ( Guardian Pet... ) and more ways to challenge yourself. Or, of course, if you were strong enough, to just freely build. The replayability of this game is pretty good too, as each world you generate is unique, and can come as either crimson or corruption ( Of course you can import seeds to of the opposite kind to your world from another one and plant them... ) later joined by the hallow. With the update, even on the lower levels there have been alot of content levels added, and expansion on the tail end of the world game with the space event, and then, for those who are up to and probably barely capable of, expert mode. Then to add on that, while it may be 2-D art, the graphics for this game are still quite nice, especially compared to other games of its type, and, runs smoothly on most computers - giving you the option to adjust the levels if not, as some games of this type don't, or not to the extent this game does.  For those of you who have already played before, as Re-Logic told us, the update log was not complete, and there are some things which may take you by suprise during events or even underground. ;) Make sure to gear up.  TL;DR:  There's lots to do, and the game is fun and quality - you won't get bored unless you deliberately put yourself though like chopping down nothing but trees for an hour.  ( Although why would anyone do that and not explore? )

I thought I had played this game for a while, (20 Hours), but looking at the time some people have spent in this game, I'm obviously still new to it. I am still thoroughly enjoying it though, and I haven't even tried the multiplayer, which people are saying is even better. It is better than minecraft, in my personal opinion, but it's up to you to decide which one you like more. There is so much exploration to be done and so many dangers to face.  When you start this game you have to find some minerals and wood to make better tools out of and build a house, then you can be off and mining with your brand new equipment. Then you will likely run into a dungeon with a chest and some baddies. Use your weapon to fight said monsters off and claim the treasures in the chest. You'll get lost doing this so much that you will come back home only to find an NPC has spawned in your hose and is selling you eqipment, which you use your money to buy, and then go back to exploring the amazing world around you. Then it gets interesting.

The game was quite something before. The only problem is that... It got even more awesome! The new update of 1.3 has added so much more to the beautiful game we all know and love. It gave me another reason to actually restart and start a new life as a new character. Despite me looking for the same items since I always play the same 'class', it's still fun to go exploring again and find new things. More than that, the new multiplayer is GREAT! I can finally play with all my friends without downloading some other thing that basically makes me scream internally! Along with the new Expert Mode, it just gives me another reason to scream at my computer because of slimes that do 50 damage and catch me off guard.  There's so much more content that I can't even review it all. All I can say is that it's a great game, the early-game, mid-game, end-game, and post-game are all so much fun. Overall, it's a great game. 10/10, would get slaughtered by my gunzerking friend again.

Terraria is a strange and pleasing indie RPG game that offers wide, divese and almost limitless gameplay possibilities within reason.  Terraria is most commonly compared to the game Minecraft, this in my opinion is fairly correct as Terraria has taken certain influence from Minecraft yet altered it to make Terraria it’s own unique game.   They have retro stylised the game with 2D features. It supports an atmospheric upbeat tempo and feel during the day, and a sinister and dark atmosphere at night. Been able to battle boss enemies makes the game much better as well as harder.  Terraria is huge and vast even with small map, but at the start you may feel overwhelmed especially if this is your first time playing a game of this type. The main two problems, listed below:  - Laggy and somewhat strange enemy lag online sometimes gets me annoyed. - Load time, even with a fast computer deter you from just jumping in, jumping out  Overall i give it a very strong 9.4/10. Masterpiece in the work.

This game is just amazing. If you look on youtube, you might be mislead by the Minecraft fanbase (consisting of many nine-year-olds) which complain, 'There's no mods! There's no servers!' of which there are both of. Now, onto the gameplay. You start out with the simplest of tools. A sword, an axe, and a pick. You go around, chop down some trees, and build houses for certian NPC's. You can explore the Corruption, a purple, demon filled wasteland, or the Crimson, a red, blood-and-gore sort of place. Each is filled with unique, challenging enemies, and a seprate boss fight. After defeating one or the other, you may need to take on the Goblin Army. You can challenge yourself in the dungeon, where there is a large quantity of loot, or the Jungle, the overgrown mass of plants and bees. Each place has different, cool loot to dicover. Eventually, you unlock Hardmode, where you are opened up to a new biome, the Hallow, a unicorn and pixie filled dangerous area. You can fight Mechanical versions of the Pre-Hardmode bosses, with new A.I. and attacks. You can make gear with the souls they drop and the Hallowed bars. Then, you head over to the jungle. You will find a lot of new enemies, and a new ore, Clorophyte, that can be made into even stronger armor and weapons. You fight Plantera, a giant 'Overgrown monstrosity of the jungle', and (s)he? will drop a key, which opens the large temple that resides in the jungle. But, you should head back over to the dungeon, where hoards of new enemies can be found, and they drop even better loot then Plantera. You head back to the jungle, fight Golem, the boss of the jungle temple, and head to the ocean. There you can summon the lord of the seas, Duke Fishron. Then you go back to the dungeon, and destrou the mysterious cultists waiting there. From then, you will have to deastroy 4 pillars, Solar, Vortex, Nebula, and Stardust. You can make weapons with the fragments that they drop. Then, theres the Mood Lord. Final boss. Yep. Does this sound like it needs mods??? No. Does this sound at all like Minecraft? No.1

Terraria  is an ocean of content that can take some time to get used to but fantastic to play. It really gives meaning to the phrase 'Obsessive Compulsive Discovery' as you will find yourself dumping half of your life into it. Build yourself a home and begin making rooms for unique NPCs. It's nice living with such helpful people. If they die they will respawn which is fantastic, just with a different name. I have more hours than I care to admit in this game so I guess its about time I review it. This game is one of the best game I have ever played. If you are the kind of player who enjoys working hard and seeing clear progression in your game and unlocking new things all the time as well as collecting tons of loot you will get a lot of enjoyment from this game.  The game starts a little slow with lots of gathering and building and exploration. Then moves into boss fighting and upgrading. Then hardmode starts and you find yourself fighting and fighting and getting more powerful. Then you beat the final boss hang hist trophy in your house and sit as king of the world but there is always more to be done, even after 200+ hours.

What can I say about this game? Well... The first thing I liked off the bat was character creation. I always like character creation, as long as it has a large variety. Second, the combat is good with the MMORPG like system. Third, the weapons are awesome. Youv'e got swords, bows, guns, and magic. 'Swords and Guns'. Fourth, you can explore widely. Your exploration is limited... that is until you find Herme's boots. But then, maximize the exploration with wings. Yes, wings. And not just angel wings, No, more like all kinds of wings. Fifth, the bosses can be challenging. No hand holding. But the only problem I have with this game is creating servers. Why must I port forward and tear my comuter apart just so I can play with my friends? Most of the time it dosen't even work. Less games should do this, because i'm ALWAYS having trouble with it. It turns out to be a HUGE problem. I'd give this game a 7/10, must try.

Seriously though the amount of custom items in this game is ridiculous it's going to take me months to find every single one, not only is there tonnes of gear, theres decoration objects for your home, over 20 dyes including 'Foil' style ones. Different types of ammo, Potion Crafting, Fishing, Flying, Climbing, Mining, Epic Boss battles, Pirate Attacks, zombie hordes, evil rabbits and even a Mechanised Father Christmas, what more could anyone ask for?  Also with the soon (TBA Release date) to be released 1.3 patch we will get over 200 more items, new scroll-effect dyes like fire and a rainbow, new mounts including a digging machine, more fluid water and loads more.  The guys at Re-Logic have done an awesome job and its such a shame that 1.3 is going to be the end for major releases as they are moving to bigger things (Terraria 2.0 I hope :D ), go give the guys some support if you love the game as much as I do  Terraria  [terraria.org]

This game is amazing. I went through the liberty of making some pros and cons. Pros:  The graphic design is flawless. There is so much dyes and vanity, there is simply no way not to be unique. This is a very fun game to play with friends, even if you have already beaten the game. The amount of bosses is amazing. It adds so much more adventure and action into it. Even what I said above, you cannot simply beat Terraria. Every time you think you have beaten it, another opportunity arises. The community is very friendly and helpful. The music is very relaxing or very intense at times when you need it. 1.3 has added acheivements, to do something in your spare time. And much much more pros. There is just too many to list.  Cons: In multiplayer, it can get very laggy during events and boss fights, even with just two people. Some of the bosses require a lot of knowledge to the game to beat without dying. Most people who like Minecraft tend to hate the game for no reason. This is pretty dumb. Some people think its a time waster. And I agree, thats 500 hours of my life im not getting back.  That's all the cons I can think of. Tell me any cons if I left out any.

Terraria is one of my favorite games. For a very basic idea, think Minecraft but in 2D. However, there is much much more to the game than digging and building a house. If you build it they will come ... build extra rooms and houses and other people will move in to them, giving you access to buy and sell all manner of items. Craft hundreds of items on different types of workstation, combine them together to make even more effective tools. Don't want to whack monsters with a sword or axe ? No problem! Make a bow and shoot some arrows, or grab some precious gems and make a magic wand or staff to shoot them out of the sky. Trigger certain events and a Boss monster will show up, or a goblin raid, or meteor shower... and much much more.

I can't get enough of this game. It's simplistic style reminds me of the glory days of the NES platformer or RPG. But to my surprise there is ridiculous depth to the game. Every time I accomplished something another thing would pop up that needed doing. Fantastic overall.

Don't mistake this for just a simple Minecraft spinoff, because it has a LOT more to offer. Ever want to kill bosses for unique rewards, like a pair of goggles that spawns a flying bee you can ride? Maybe you want a charm that, during a full moon, turns you into a werewolf? Perhaps you are the dungeon-dwelling type, and enjoy the thrill of adventuring deep into the chasms, searching for treasure and imposing enemies alike? Maybe you enjoy creating your own little village, with little NPCs of all different kinds coming to join and live with you? This game offers all that and much, MUCH more.  I bought this game ages ago and made the mistake of not playing it for a long time. I'll tell you, I'm never making that mistake twice, especially knowing now I was sitting on such a Gem. Terraria is absolutely AMAZING if you have a group of friends and you want to do something. Sure, there are Minecraft mods out there that might offer some kind of similar items, etc, but believe me when I say there is no experience quite like Terraria with friends. Minecraft isn't the only sandbox survival simulator with mods, either! Terraria's community is equally as fascinating! The things they create are wonderful indeed.   In closing, this game is worth every penny they charge, and they STILL add updates for it, even though it's getting up there in the years. That's dedication you can count on! Thank you very much, Re-Logic, for making such an extra fun game!!

Wonderful game. Similar to Minecraft, Terraria encourages creativity and captures the fun of 8 and 16-bit platormers, Bosses become more difficult as the Player progresses and require them to seek out new gear and use different tactics. Different difficulty levels allow players to play the game how they want to. The sandbox world changes with each level creation and allows travel between. Younger players and others may prefer console versions ( Playstation / X-Box ) for ease of control, though said games are slightly behind in content updates.  All in all, this is a good game for ages 10 and up. Give it a try.
