One of the best games ever made, there is a reason its the third most played steam game. This game is truly inventive, inspiring, and creative to such a mass extent that this alone would make it a must have game.  The combat is also very creative, and you always have a mass amount of ways to take out enemies, and you will always be discovering new enemies that require new ways to fight it, or are too strong for you. If you were to play for a couple weeks all the time, you will still find bosses that would ultimately destroy you if you summoned them. From the beginning of your playthrough to the end you will have a lot of fun fighting these creative and challenging bosses, that you really need to develope strategies to fight, especially as you get to the harder bosses.  The gameplay is great, you will never find yourself saying 'Now what should I do......' like with most games. In Terraria you will have so much to do to progress, prepare, and just have fun you will never get bored, even after weeks of playing. Even then, once you fight the 'last' boss (which can be very challenging and impossible until you have loads of good gear and weapons) the whole world will be transformed and be added new deadly biomes that slowly spread, along with hundreds of new enemies, weapons, equipment, and bosses, and the world will become hardmode. During gameplay you will be forced to build protective forts, towns, traps, or however you want to build to protect your base, since unlike other games (Minecraft, Castle Miner Z, etc) creatures, and invasions occasionally come to attack you, especially when in hardmode.  The world and game in general is very inspiring with all of the different biomes and things to explore (like hell and the sky with sky islands), the theme of exploration, slaying bosses and invasions, the music, and even npcs make the world extremely interesting. One of the main stuggles of this game is controlling the evil biomes after a certian part of the game, The Hallow, Underground Hallow, and The Undergound Corruption/Crimson come into the world and very slowly spread, there are many ways to hold back, destroy, or purify the biomes and really intinsifies if you decide to ignore the biome and lately figure out that they have taken 25% more of the world.  This is by far my most recommended game for anyone wanting an amazing game that will give them hundreds of hours of fun, creative, and challenging gameplay.  10/10

TL;DR: Best $2 I've spent on Steam ever. Get it now!  At first glance, you'll think it's just a 2D version of Minecraft. However, there is a lot more to do and see in this game, to the point where it really can't be compared to it. A great game to play if you love crafting, building and exploring. The combat mechanics are great too. Also, do your friends a favor and buy them this game, you'll have fun for hundreds of hours together, guaranteed.  Pros: - A LOT of content (items, weapons, decorations, mobs, etc) - Wonderful gameplay - Outstanding pixel art and design, beautiful to look at - Playing it with friends makes it even better - Lots of replay value - Devs have not forgotten about this game and add more content on a regular basis - Very lightweight: you don't need a powerful PC to run this game  Cons: - No useful in-game tutorials for beginners (there is some sort of small 'tutorial' but it doesn't really help at all). You'll have to read many guides and wikis. - Even though you can host a server and have your friends join via Steam, this functionality is still not perfect and causes many issues. Using third-party applications (like Hamachi) or port-forwarding is recommended and, sometimes, necessary. - Lack of some server commands that you'll wish would exist (in the vanilla game). Nothing too important though.  Despite the minor cons, this is a great game you just shouldn't miss. Get it now! If you wait for Steam sales, you'll be able to get it for only $2! I highly recommend it.

Terraria is a great pixel art game, It's relatively easy to learn but hard to master. To those who compare it with minecraft, I would suggest that you dont since even though both involve the idea of crafting and mining, both game are very diifferent. But if you really want to compare it, I would say Terraria is superior since patch 1.2 expand terraria more than 2x the 1.1 does.  The core game mechanic is easy to learn, you would have to spend MANY ( and I say MANY in caps ) hours of grinding for the loot you want since this game have randomly spawn enemies of several types. Which is really good in its own way, make this game much more interesting and give the player wide variety of enemies to fight against.  I have put many hours of my life into this game just to try to beat the very last boss of the game for the first time. And I would say that It was definitely worth it. The bosses are nice and tough ( for solo ) and the game made an extremely great multiplayer experiences. I would not recommend the game for those with over 4 people party since it would take the fun of grinding and fighting boss away from the game since the boss's strength does not scale with the amount of players.  If you get this game during any of the steam sale for 2.5$, it's a bargain and you DEFINITELY should get the pack of 4 just to sent it to those who have yet to experience this game. The wiki is nice for those who have no clue on how this game work since it have no tutorial nor quest, but it compensate that with awesome graphic and design, along with fluid movements and machanics that you wouldn't stop playing for a while.

I cannot recommend this game enough. Yes, the learning curve is steep. Yes, if you want to do/find/experience everything, you're going to want to become intimately connected to the Wiki. Yes, you're going to die. A lot. But I promise you, it's worth it.   More so than any other sandbox game I've played, Terraria finds a perfect balance of digging/mining, exploration, building, and combat. There's no story to speak of, but what the game does have is a remarkable sense of progression, despite that. As you branch out from your starting position, your slowly uncover better materials, allowing you to create better armor and weapons and tools, which allow you to explore a little deeper, uncovering better still materials, so you can continue on your journey. Add into that challenging boss fights that consistently feel difficult-but-worth-it, a graphical style that hits me right in the nostalgia-feels, and platforming controls that actually manage to feel 'right' on a keyboard, and you have the recipe for a perfect game.   Just play it. Now.  P.S. - did I mention they're still making and releasing new, free content for this game?

For anyone who bought this game expecting it to be another minecraft rip-off, you'll be pretty surprised. Instead you get a fantastic game that's more akin to a Metriodvania game in some ways. One of the biggest parts of Terraria is slowly upgrading yourself with better weapons and armor until you can eventually 1-shot everything.  The game can actually be fairly difficult without friends, a lot of the later bosses require more than just a huge gun or sword. Of course, even with the guide NPC, this game is incredibly confusing at first. And the beginning can be a bit of a slog as you likely die repeatedly to some of the tougher enemies. But when you reach the end of the game have yourself all geared up with awesome weapons and armor, you feel like a real badass.  I would give it a 8/10

Summary: This game is nice. It reminds me the old days where I'm addicted to survival games and failed my exams. It's quite memorable.  Survival games are quite the entertaining sort of video games. Though, if you were to play alone, it doesn't have that much of fun as playing with friends. Building something that's unreasonable and laugh about it. At times, you have to get serious and farm for the items you need in order to beat the next boss. It'll take few weeks (even months) to get the required items, but with a friend or two along the way, this game will never bore me.  Now of course, every games have its own flaw. This game's flaw is the amount of materials you need to farm in order to get the full set of armor/weapon. It's a ridiculous amount for just a broadsword. Might as well just make this game into a farming simulator. But I guess that's the challenge of this game.  Another flaw, I believe, is the randomised boss spawning.   For example, the Twins.   I don't have the defense to survive their attack, nor do I have the damage. I wasn't prepared at all. I hope in the future, there will be requirement(s) for the boss to spawn   (For example, the goblin army requires you to have at least 200 health)  , maybe after you've reached a certain value of defense or damage.    Note: I do notice there's three difficulties (one required to defeat one of the bosses), and the difficulty for the Twins to spawn is only in Hardmode, meaning I could just farm for the armor in Expert mode. But really, the rewards in Hardmode are better than the ones in Expert mode (like, a huge difference between the defense the full set of armor gives). Why bother in Expert mode when you can get better stuff in Hardmode?    Overall, this game brings the excitement of what's coming your way in a new world with a new character. But if you know pretty much everything, there's the wikia page for you to research for all the items you could get your filthy hands on.

Alright, as I have over 450 hours into this game on record, I can give an in depth review of this game. Terraria is a great game with friends and alone. The amount of exploration you can do (primarily underground) is fantastic. You can run into dangerous traps, find epic loot in the strangest of places, explore crazy biomes unlike any other game. You can create housing for NPCs and trade them for some of the best weapons and crafting stations. The accesory system allows for some insane custimization options, while the vanity items slots allow you to have the best armor in the game and looks however you please. The sheer ammount of custimization alone and the options are impeccable.   I recently did an incredibly long run of this game with my cousin. We had trouble at first, even dying at the first boss: the Eye of Cthulhu (although you technically can fight the bosses in whatever order you please). We later got better suplies and, at the point we have gotten, can destroy the Eye with our eyes closed.  Yes, one problem with this game is the lack of a tutorial, but you can just get a friend who knows the ropes or watch a youtube video to learn the basics. You will have to looks up what some items do, but the game explains them pretty well.  The comedy with the NPCs is hilarous, the items can be funny, epic, and just plain silly. The bosses are tough at first, but once you get better items/skill, are fun and easy. Overall this game is unlike any other sandbox survival game out there, blowing Minecraft out of the water.  I cannot reccomend this game enough. Just buy it!

5 reasons why Terraria is a solid game.  1) Movement Control - Is perfect in many respects, because when you tell your character what to do, it just does it. Items that affect your jumping/floating/hanging abilities come into play early on, and wings are introduced later. Running, jumping floating, and flying become second nature. This needs to happen because you want your brain focused more on the boss and less on yourself, so that you may attack properly. For the most part movement can involve running a direction, jumping, jumping and shooting up with something else, and then jumping with wings and floating down.  2) Melee/Shooting Control - Is as far as I can tell also perfect. Your ability in this game is determined by how well you move and shoot or attack, and it is reliable for guns. A bit less for certain weapons which can prevent you from turning around while swinging, good or bad. Since you can move almost perfectly forwards and backwards, it is common to fight bosses by running away from them and facing backwards to attack nearly the entire time.  3) Armor progression - For certain characters, the armor you wear is critically important. Your armor goes from minor bonuses early game to amazing class set bonuses late game. The game divides bonuses into roughly 3 classes.  4) Roles -Melee, Magic, and Ranged. Melee is the brawler, not afraid of getting hurt, either healing themselves or just tanking and surviving. Magic uses spells, so the focus is MP and magic attack strength. Shooter gear will earn you movement upgrades and ranged weapon damage. You may mix and match various styles, but your armor will only specialize with a complete set for a specific class/style.  5) Weapons - Are just plain fun to use. Melee weapons go from simple sword swings to 100 mph returning tomahawks. Mixing and matching ammo and guns is a dream come true. The uzi or tactical shotgun with homing bullets. Tactical with explosive for a swarm explosive effect. Megashark with crystal to spam lots and lots of bullets that produce 3 more bullets each. Clockwork assault rifle with high velocity bullets to engage accurately from a distance while flying through the air. Other weapons and tools provide most play customization options. You can manipulate your ammo in your inventory to fire certain bullet patterns. For bosses, I use 10 Ichor bullets to debuff, followed by 40-50 other bullets, then repeat the pattern.  Maybe I'll expand later, but this is all I'd need to know for now. Watch videos. I haven't even touched creating things.

First of all, this game is amazing. It is almost perfect and you should buy it, 10$ or on sale for 2$, right now.  However, I just want to address a single, small complaint that I have for this game: The RNG (for dropping items anyway). Sometimes you can be trying to get an item from an enemy with a 1/100 chance of dropping. Except for the fact that you have terrible luck and you are stuck farming for 3 hours trying to get that item, and it can get super boring. Why not make it so you have a 1/100 chance of getting it, but on the 100th kill, it is a guarenteed drop if you did not already recieve it. That way you would never be stuck farming for long periods of time.  That is all I have to say. Please do yourself a favor and get this game right now if you did not already.

You could compare it to Minecraft... sort of...  Minecraft, to me, has always been about building super-cool 3D structures, and just going 'whoa.' Terraria never gives you that same 'whoa' for your buildings.  But that's okay: Terraria's not about buildings. It's about fighting monsters, and getting AWESOME LOOT... such awesome loot...  Minecraft could learn a thing or two about awesome loot from Terraria: Magic Mirrors. Hookshots, preferrably with many arms. Double-jump boots. Rocket boots. Sweet swords that call down stars from the heavens to slay your enemies.  Still, each satisfies different needs. And both are super-fun co-op.

Terraria is the best open sandbox adventure game I've ever played. Hands down. The extent of ways you can customize and shape your experiance is amazing. For instance, I went with an emphasis on powerful weapons, and armor that lets you tank, and I prefered melee. I went after all the bosses, and for the towns you can create for the NPCs, I went simplistic, and made a rectangular wood tower. However, if you dont want to challenge bosses, and would rather create an amazing city with all kinds of creative designs, you can!  Thats part of the beauty of Terraria, you can play in any style you want, and you can do almost anything you want. Do you favor ranged combat over melee? Cool, theres an enourmous ammount of armor, weapons, and items with buffs for that. Do want to create an underground bunker city? Awesome! You can do that too.  The possibilities are endless, and if you want to fight tough bosses, there are a ton of them, and you can alter your enviroment to engage them however YOU want to! Do you like to explore? Terraria has a ton of varied, interesting enviroments to explore. Terraria is a game I can come back to over and over and over again to try different playstyles, different structures, different worlds, and it all feels fresh and new, not to mention the fact that the game is still getting updated.  So in the end? BUY THIS GAME!!!!

I bought this game by recommendation by a friend and i am thouroghly glad I did. I went in with the same mentality as many other people in the fanbase of 'Oh, it's 2D Minecraft' but thats not entirely true. You stab things, build, explore, and hide when the nasties come out at night but thats really about it. I found it INCREDIBLY slow at first when I was getting myself established but now that i've gotten past that the game really perked up! My first real 'Wow' experience was my first cave which I found to feel more like a dungeon, and before I knew it, it had been 3 hours in that cave and I shut down. One of my original complaints of the game was that when you logged out you were sent to your spawn point, and I originally despised this as I would have to pop out and when I came back I was aaaaaaaaaall the way back at my house, but this aspect grew on me. It gives you kind of a drive to complete the task at hand, 'I need to get this shortcut', 'I need to get to the bottom of this cave'. My only other complaints is that the zoom is kind of wonky and it doesn't really immediatly grab your attention.  8/10 Would reccomend

This game has a LOT of content coming at it new. It is a simple sandbox game, you get materials and build. It's fun though! There's always more to it, like you're constantly trying to get the next level of gear or trying to kill the next boss. You're always trying to improve yourself and your team by building houses for NPC's, getting gear, and progressing in this game's 'story' (if you can even call it a story?).   However this is where the game has its fault. Like everything, there IS an end to this game. Yes, you can continue after you beat all of the bosses, and you can even face bosses over and over, but that's just it. There isn't anything else after that. All you can really do is start over. I've played this game through and through again, even on Expert mode. It's fun, don't get me wrong, but unless you've lost your memory on this game or are completely new to it, you will get bored pretty fast. I thoroughly enjoyed the game, but now I just can't. I know everything I can do and it can be done so easily, like a check list. It just isn't fun after that point, even replaying it.   But that could just be me.

I've had this game for 2 years and I'm still finding out new things about it. Although it can get a bit repetitive at times, I think it's a good game.  Thinks I like: You will never run out of things to do. Even if you think you've done everything, I can garauntee you there's something you didn't do.  Things I don't like: A thing I don't like about the bosses are that you have to fight them multiple times to get the things you need. It just ruins it when you feel accomplished that you finally beat the boss you were preparing for, just to realize you have to fight them again because they didn't drop enough to make the things you needed. I especially don't like this about the Moon Lord. It defeats the purpose of the final boss in the game when you have to fight it more than once.  Overall I'd give this game a 7/10 because while I like it, it gets repetitive and boring at times.

This game is absolutely Brilliant.  First of all, if you prefer Minecraft, ♥♥♥♥ you.  This game has everything you could ever ask of Mincraft and more. the only argument that minecraft fanatics have to stand on is that Terraria does sort of feel like you're in an antfarm. But nevertheless, let us continue.  Terraria has a hugely wide variety. Of what, I hear you ask. EVERYTHING. It has almost limitless types of ores and gems to discover, unlike the... what 6 materials of Minecraft? And it has actually limitless weapons and tools for you to craft and use. There are 15+ bosses and unique characters to defeat and triumph over, all with 5+ unique drops to show off to your friends.   With this and the recent update of achievments, you can prove your triumphs as well as utilize the loot.  The worlds are absolutely massive, but not infinte, which actually makes it really good because when you explore the whole world it gives you a sense of achievment and allows for there to be end of world biomes with some sick loot. It has infinite replay value and the wide variety of materials contributes to impressive and astonishing structures and sculptures.  On a whole, it is 2D Minecraft for non-12 year olds and a great bit of fun for you and all of your friends.

Alright, It's safe to say I like this game. I have over 300 hours clocked in, about 20 different characters, some where just jokes, like a captain of a ship named Captain Llamasamapop, or my main character with 200 hours on him. I have played enough of the game to say its my most played and probably favorite game. Thats why I recomend this game. This game is amazing, just look at my hours. 300 BIG ONES. This game made me not have a life, and still updating. When I first bought the game in 2013, I played minecraft a good bit, but i could tell the differences in these games. Still, even after beating the final boss about 30-40 times, I still play it, I adventure, I find secrets, create amazing houses, burn annoying guys named Jeff to summon walls of flesh and eyes to murder, I explore, relax, and mess around. Its a game that you can just continuously play, sure it gets boring sometimes, but I always enjoy it. And honestly, after all this time, I will still never realize why people think this game is similar to minecraft. They are way different in their aproaches. Terraria is a 2D pixilated adventure game. Sure it has building and wiring mechanics, but its central idea, its meat, its special sauce, is its combat, while minecraft is a building game, sure it has combat, but its a building game, thats it's sauce. Terraria and Minecraft seem similar in the way its presented, but when it comes to the hot sauce it keeps in its back door room guarded by a dude probably named Tom, they are completely seperate games. Thats why I give it the big thumbs up and recomend this game. 10/10 Would shoot Cthulu again.

Holy crud what a fantastic game. Easily one of my all-time favorites ever in the history of the world ever and forever.   Seriously though, this game has so much content. It's always fun to play, and there's always a ton to do. I can't help but keep replaying with new characters since each experience is so enjoyable. With that being said, my two favorite aspects about the game are its music and sound effects, which to me are what give the game its charm. I can't help but hum along with the main theme of the overworld and intently listen to the small sounds that're made when mining with a pickaxe of some sort.  Thankfully the game gives you something to continuously strive for over and over, rather than giving you a bunch of content but no motivator as to why you're playing the game in the first place. There are a multitude of bosses in the game, each as interesting as the last, and of course they become progressively more difficult to beat as you progress throughout the 'storyline' of the game (there's no real story, just a series of events that you have the option to take part in). Grinding is actually one of the most addicting things in the game. For a lot of games grinding is overly-tedious. Terraria makes grinding actually enjoyable, or at least for me. It's really hard not to love the crap out of this game every time I think about it and start it up.   Overall there is so much I could say about this game in terms of its vast amounts of content--including weapons, furniture, biomes, monsters, armor, blocks, etc., but I'd rather just tell you to go buy this game and play it yourself if you haven't already. I haven't written a review for years because I'm lazy, but this game has prompted me to write one.   <3

What better way to relax than to knock out a few hours playing this game? Either with some friends, or just going at it alone, this game provides you with a generated world that you can either tear down or add to in any way you like. Experience the different biomes which offer different enemies to slay, and different items to pick up to improve your stats. Don't feel like fighting for your life? Then why don't you take it easy and build a house, or a village, or a city, or perhaps a space station? The mind really is the limit with this game. The game is also updated regularly, and offers a holiday themed event during times such as Christmas or Halloween, complete with new items and bosses/legions to destroy. The gameplay has a modern touch, but the music and the graphics give you that good ol' fashioned nostalgic feeling from the 2-D, 8-bit era we all love, and that younger people will now come to love after playing this.

Terraria is a 2d survival, sandbox that involves spelunking and crafting.(also guns and magic)  It's one of those games with a lot of content, where you are always looking for that one thing that is better than what you have. That will deal more damage, gather resources faster or just just improve mobility. As you get better gear you will begin to fight harder and harder bosses and even invasions. Until you will find the most overpowered gear, but that is endgame and you have a long way to get there.  First thing to do: chop a tree, craft a work bench, craft a wooden sword, because your copper one is the worst.  1.3 adds new endgame items and new very hard bosses. The NPC feel more alive and can defend themselves. You have the option to stack the items in you're inventory into nearby chests with a click of a button. If you store you're money into the piggy bank it will show up at the shops. There are three new mini-biomes(marble, granite, Underground Desert) that don't add much. Expert mode where bosses drop a loot bag for each player and have one special item that is just for expert mode, also the game is harder.
I would recommend this game to anyone who likes exploring and/or fighting monsters

In the beginning, as a newbling with 100 hp and copper tools, you may find the game boring, but as you fight any of the 14 bosses and 5 invasions in the game, you will become more and more addicted to this lovable 2D sandbox game. If you think that breaking wood blocks with a pickaxe is illogical, wait until you near the end of this game. After you have triumphed over the half-living corpse of Cthulhu's supposed brother, you will find yourself with too much time on your hands, leaving you with nothing better to do than to swing around your yoyo and fire Nyan Cats from your sword, all while riding on your personal UFO that you stole from the Martians. Some other features of Terraria are: -2 Dimensions (Who needs 3D anyways?) -Over 2,000 Items -Over 20 NPCs -4 Classes -A lifetime of wishing the Moon Lord on Expert was easier  Overall, I would rate this game 9.9999999999/10.

Terraria is an amazingly fun game with countless hours worth of content and tons of ways to play. Starting out is a bit slow, but if you stick with it for the first hour or so it really picks up and is a ton of fun. The game is full of loot and a variety of bosses that never get boring. Although once you get really far in the game melee attacks become absolutely useless and you will get destroyed by bosses and hordes of monsters, but fear not, for there is a variety of spells to keep you interested. Guns are also a thing but they're mostly bland and repetetive, but they are arguably the most powerful weapons in the game with the right ammo. Overall the game is super fun and engaging with a few balancing issues.

Terraria as a whole is a really great game to play. Though its style is simplistic and 2D, it serves its purpose and executes it very well. There's always something for you to do, whether it's fighting a boss, building a castle, or finding all the necessary materials you need to make something. My only criticism is I wish that the multiplayer could continue to be optimized, since I'm currently playing the game on an old laptop. The singleplayer runs well, but multiplayer puts alot of stress on my laptop. The modding community is also very handy for when I feel like adding a little extra to the game. I haven't had much experience with the game since I just recently bought it, so i'm still learning everything. Another thing i'd like to mention is the settings menu. I honestly wish there would be more options added to help boost performance, but I have a feeling someone will come out with a Terraria version of Minecraft's 'Optifine Mod'  Overall, I'd rate this a 8.5/10.

This game is just so fun. There's a million and a half things to do for a very long time, the progress is noticable, the damage you're doing is satisfyingly significant, and you'll never be put up against something you can't handle if you just put yourself to it. Grinding is a major part in the later tiers of the game, but the things you're grinding for might just make for the most awesome magical, ranged, or melee weapon you've ever tried out! There is a great variety of bosses you can defeat, and you actually need to best them to move on in the game. To get a 100% is almost impossible, considering there are more than a thousand items in the game, and most of the time your favorites will only make up a hundreth part of that. Responsive controls, responsive combat, overall awesome combat style, gamefeel is great, not too heavy, not too light. Overall a very unique game.  (♥♥♥♥ Starbound)

Complete sandbox, really fun to play, especially with mods (don't get me wrong, the vanilla game is amazing, but this is one of those games, like skyrim, that is much better when modded, usually.) There is a huge modding community, but aside from that. Gameplay is relatively simple, simple, but amazingly fun. Start off with a pickaxe, axe,and sword, and make your living, each world is randomly generated, so every adventure is different, in the beginning it's quite hard to get started up, as at night zombies completely overpower you in the beginning, so set up shelter for the first night, or spend the night underground collecting material.  There's softcore, mediumcore, and hardcore, Hardcore will force you to play conservatively, and explore the aspects of the game much more carefully, as once you die as hardcore, your character is deleted. I just wanna say this is one of the most addicting games I've ever played; An intricate crafting system, wonderful gameplay, unique bosses, this game is incredible. Originally, I was a bit skeptical about it, and I thought it was mostly a Minecraft clone. I assure you it is not.

Yes, 2D Minecraft. What most people underestimate is that '2D' changes a lot of things, many of them for the better. It's more combat and world progression focused than Minecraft. You won't need a wiki to run all the way through the game, since there's help in-game for most things, and the NPCs do a good job of clueing you in. I found it fun, fun enough to sink 600+ hours into it and I plan to sink more when it updates again at the end of this month.  I would say the biggest con for me and my friends is that if the players are of very disparate skill levels the experience can be a little frustrating as there are many events within the game that completely change the game world and the difficulty of the enemies you encounter. Top players on a server will end up waiting around, and low players [or even players who like to take their time] will find themselves pressured to take handouts of gear and equipment just so they don't get slaughtered by the new tiers of enemies. The world being finite does also make it hard to find equipment if other players have raided dungeons already. Regardless, still best played multiplayer.  Edit: With the newest update out, better than ever. Fishing now ensures that a lot of pesky items are no longer so pesky, making some must-have items that were previously limited actually renewable. Very handy. I would say the biggest con is that the middle-end game is very grindy, whereas the newest endgame content is considerably less so. You'll notice a sudden shift when the game goes from tediously mining newly generated ores to doing wave-based events to obtain items from enemy drops instead, the latter of which is far more enjoyable. Worth a look now more than ever.   Expert mode is also very rewarding, but frustrating in single player. Expert mode gives every single player a set of boss drops, rather than players having to share or compete over boss drops. If you're gonna play multiplayer, I recommend expert, hard as it is.

First: It's addictive. It's just like it. 'Nah, another day playing Terraria, just some monster, digging pointlessly, and other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.' but (personally) I can't stop playing. So it's 'boring' and 'addictive' at the same time. (Maybe it's just me or something)  Second: Loadout System. Maybe the reason i like Terraria is the loadout system. You get feeling like 'HAHAHAHA IM THE GREATEST MAN IN TEH WORLD KEELING SUM MONSTERS SON OF A ♥♥♥♥♥ WITH MAI MIGHTY SWORD' when you get a overpowered Swords. And armors. And guns. And some wings.  Third: Comparison with Minecraft. Minecraft is a 3D Sandbox game with amazing creative factor. But with a crap weapon system. And the crafting system is confusing (for me). In Minecraft, for example, you can create 'TNT Cannon'.  Terraria is a 2D Sandbox game with amazing loadout system (including weapon). But with good but not as perfect as Minecraft, and simple crafting system. Altrough without recipe list.  So, what is the best? 'That is for you to decide.'  Conclusion: Its addictive.

Terraria is an absolutely wonderful game. People often compare it to MineCraft, and it does have a lot of features that MineCraft incorperates, but it's different in just so many different ways. While MineCraft focuses on creative thinking and design, Terraria focuses on dungeon-crawling, epic weapons, bosses, and collectables. The game also features a very different relationship between characters you play and the worlds you explore in. Any character you create keeps his or her data concerning their health points, mana, and what they currently have on them, meaning you can transfer things between worlds. You can go to different worlds to collect things! This is an especially great feature if you run out of room on your current world and want to make something more. This game is probably one of my favorite RPGs and I recommend anyone reading this to give it a try, especially if you like MineCraft. It was well worth my money and it is well worth yours.

And best of all, the game's only continued to improve, greatly deepening in new features, graphics, weapons, bosses, and even adding entirely new ways to play the game, years after the original release. What? I only played 795 Hours? I thought I played more than that... anyway. Terraria is the insanely awesome, highly addictive block builder I thought would have just been a cheap 2D knock-off of Minecraft. I was wrong. Its actually proven to be pretty dang entertaining. It's got an interesting group of enemies that aren't just pallet swaps, massive assortment of weapons and equipment with different effects, bosses that force you terraform the landscape to survive, and a good balance between fighting and creation. Without a 'creative mode' that hands you all the blocks you want or need like in minecraft, this game adds a real layer of challenge by forcing you to brave the wilds and mine that gold you want to build your extravagant palace out of.  So If you hadn't already got the game, pick it up. You'll enjoy it.

Ahh Terraria. A 2D Minecraft except there's a lot more to offer. A hell of a lot more. It's not just about building, you explore, fight, dig, discover, and find hilarious get rich quick schemes. Still, the positive side is that it will take you a long time to reach the end. Like, a really long time. There are tons of ways to forge new weapons, nearly infinite ways to build (if you're creative), and just like Minecraft, it's replay value is nearly infinite.  However, there is a down side, at least for me. Once you obtain everything like I have, you start to wonder if you should even be playing anymore. You end up starting a new character, decking him out with end game equipment and throw him into another world just to fight all the bosses again, and get more endgame stuff. On my console version I've even got unobtainable items including all the developer wing, the SDMG and entire chest full of platinum where each stack is nearly 27,000 platinum coins. Did I cheat? No, they were gifts from other people, and the platinum was made by duping, as well as duping other end game stuff to profit off of other people on xbox live.  Oh yeah that's another thing, once you discover these get rich quick schemes, the game kind of ceases to have anything left for it anymore. At that point you've already beat it, and memorized the entire game, as well as every boss and how they fight. For it's price, it's worth the entertainment, and it will keep you occupied for weeks, possibly even months. Go ahead and play, it will keep you distracted for a very long time, and before you know it, you have to file your taxes again.  Hell I'd recommend Terraria on the grounds that it has something a lot of other mainstream games are missing. Color. It's one of the most beautiful games to look at and better to see than most gray brown loads of blow. Like COD, or Battlefield.
This game is both addicting and fun, and it doesn't get boring because there's always something new to do/create. I highly recommend it to ANYONE and EVERYONE.

One of the greatest 2D sandbox adventures you can possibly have in a game. This game is filled with treasures and mysteries for you to uncover.  There's loot (armor, weapons and items with various stats) and a lot of materials and resources that you can use to craft tons of things. Many monsters to fight, many environments to discover. You can build villages and NPCs will come and sell you things.  Digging may seem a bit tedious at first, but it gets better as you progress. Also, bring a friend and you're in for a great time.   For anyone who would say 'this is just a 2D Minecraft', you are wrong. Minecraft feels pointless compared to this game. Uh Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead  Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons sugar 1 tablespoon baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg 2 large eggs, at room temperature 1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature 1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed  Now to make it 1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg. 2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla. 3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat. 4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed 5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed. 6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

This game has a few similarities to vanilla Minecraft, such as mining, building structures and tools, and fighting off monsters. But Terraria is far from just a 2D clone of Minecraft focusing more on Adventure and exploration, while also containing the building aspects (And expanding on it!). From day 1 and onward you begin to discover all of the new and exciting things this game has to offer, but not until you get later in the game do you really understand how much content this game contains. There are over a hundred weapons and armor, and even more enemies and bosses. The ammount of content in Terraria can only be defined as 'Incredibly Massive'.  The single-player mode in Terraria is a lot of fun, but when you play with a friend and discover all that Terraria has to offer, the fun and replayablity doubles. If you're going to play Terraria, i highly reccomend to play on Multiplayer. The multiplayer mode of Terraria requires port-forwarding to play with a friend, I haven't set up many servers before, but I can say setting up a server in Terraria is a piece of cake.  The art-style of this game contains stunning 16-bit graphics that are very reminiscent of the Super Nintendo or Sega Genesis. It's beautiful to look at, and if you look closely you may find plenty of details hidden in it's animated sprites.  If you're into awesome 16-bit survival RPG adventures, you should buy Terraria right away. And if you're not, then you should definitely buy Terraria right away, because that would mean you've never played one before.

At first, we had some stone bricks, a couple swords and a gun or two. Then we got an update. We had spells, a new biome and a whole other half of the game to complete with bosses, both remade and new, as well as a new variety of weapons and armor. Another update. We got another new biome, a stubborn boss, more weapons and...well, more everything, really.  Terraria is a somewhat unique game (That has a second game running alongside it instead of a sequel(al?)!) that places you in the wild of a procedurally generated 2D world. At first, your aim will be to kill a zombie. Then a worm. Then a flying ghoul thing. Then... yea, you got the point. You are always able to find something, weather it be rare minerals and materials, new adventures and bosses, or tactics and strategies to take down mobs...and your friends!  Terraria is easily a great game that, even though the updates aren't constant, they are MASSIVE. Sometimes bringing in over 800 new items, several bosses and hundreds of new possible ways to die...by new mobs, atleast.  Underwritten review, inexpensive, and age friendly. Gibberish/10.

Well, time to write a serious review for Terraria, none of that random crap that doesn't really help someone in their purchase. Firstly I'd like to say anyone with a fixed mindset of this game being a '2D Minecraft' obviously needs to look at Terraria's insanely high rating of 96% positive reviews - This game is good, not some cheap crap made to ride another game's coatails.  Maybe you've read the description of this game which lists only 3 features, or have seen some older reviews for this game and thought - 'This looks like a game that is way overhyped and doesn't have that much content,' well luckily for you, this game isn't the old v1 it was ~5 years ago, no, it is now the glorious v1.3 Might not seem like much to the uninitiated but as you may have seen already I have poured hundreds of hours into Terraria and I have still defintely discovered everything. Terraia has a ****load of stuff to do and merits putting many hours into the game.  The gameplay is nothing hugely advanced and innovating, but the combat is truly fun and the game's use of accessories, weapons and amours allows for multiple classes. Building is simple, and is only on two different planes but the vast range of blocks and walls which are availible leads to a vast potiential of things to build. Progression works well and the best part of the game comes into Hardmode where you begin to fight the more challenging enemies and bosses. Expert Mode provides a  real challenge  is hard as nails. Multiplayer is very fun and works well, but isn't particulary well suited to very large groups or public servers (world gets overcrowded/greifed). The main issue with the gameplay is it can sometimes become tedious. Spelunking for hours to get those rare hardmode minerals or grinding a boss to get a specific drop can be painful, but doesn't generally last long, and there are usually alternative solutions to these issues.  The graphics are again, nothing particulary innovating but still look fairly nice and work quite well (unless you have some wretched hate for pixel graphics) and the music is nice but nothing particulary memorable (unless again you for some reason hate 8-bit style things with a passion). The sounds were a bit loud for me but you do have the option to change the music, sound effects and ambience. You can customize you characters hair, clothing eyes and skin upon creation, and clothing and hair can be changed during the game if you wish to using the Stylist NPC and the dresser furniture item. Dyes are also availible, whihc change the colour of your armour and/or accessories while eqiupped, giving you a wide range of aesthetic customizablity.  The NPCs are a key part of the game, enabling you to purchase a wide range of goods and services. Most NPCs are merchants for a specific type of good, but others also provide special services such as the Goblin Tinkerer, who reforges a accessory's or weapon's prefix to give different stat changes. Also prefixes - these give buffs to weapons and accessories that the base item do not have, this gives even more customizablity for your character. Each NPC is worthwhile and sells useful equipment or materials for a player to use.  To give you a scope of the huge amount of content there are currently 24 bosses in the game, along with 11 minibosses, 9 biomes (10 if you include The Underworld) which have four different layers corresponding to depth. There are over 1000 items in the game and hundreds of enemies. There are 25 different NPCs within the game.  Bottom Line If you're interested, buy it. If you hat grindy games, keep your distance. If you enjoyed Starbound, Edge of Space or Minecraft you'll most likely enjoy this game and with it's price reaching $2.50 on sale and hundreds of hours of content, the game is defintely worth a purchase. If you are unsure of a purchase, maybe look up some gameplay of Terraria, but with it's latest 1.3 update, I, along with thousands of others, can hardly get away from playing this game.  (It has a 96% positive rating, it's a damn good game)
For the price I paid while it was on sale, it is one of the best games I have ever played.

As an RPG loot loving type of player I found myself quite at home scavenging for resources and enemies to drop rare gear from their corpses. The game plays well, has Co-op, & is a fun experience when played with friends. My only gripe i have with this game is the absence of how to make certain NPC's to spawn into your world, how to craft certain items, and what my next goal is. Although you can easily offset this by using the wiki/forums to find answers to those questions. Overall I love Terraria and am still trying to craft my own mighty Terra Blade!

After around 550 hours of game time, I can definatly vouch for this game. If you go by, 'The price of the game is 1$ = 1 hour of fun' then you will be sorely dissapointed to figure out that this game breaks that rule. The game play is a lot of fun, if you like to fight things, bosses, events, pvp, a ton of awesome weapons to wreak havoc and several setups to suit your playstyle. Like to explore? The worlds are expansive, even on small. I have yet to explore an entire world. Like to build? There are hundreds of block types so that the only thing limiting you is what you can collect. Character customization is amazing, vanity armor sets, dyes, the ability to change the appearance of your character ingame. If you like to play with friends theres the new steam servers, but its also really easy to set up a dedicated server using the official items. Over all it has been a very enjoyable 500+ hours, and I will continue to pump hours into it.

Terraria is a great sandbox 2D adventure with heavy focus on crafting and building.  It's one of the most popular games on Steam for a good reason. There's a huge variety of things to do and there's something for almost everyone. You can either approach the game as a pure sandbox experience and keep exploring the massive map and building stuff. Or you can slowly upgrade your gear and work your way through the progressively more and more difficult bosses.  Either way it's a rather addictive experience. Terraria has received a huge amount of free updates along the years, and these days the amount of content on offer is pretty staggering. For me personally, the exploration aspect of the game was the most enjoyable part.  It's by no means a perfect game, however. Despite the huge variety of weapons combat itself is a rather shallow affair. This was most noticeable during boss fights, which often felt rather gimmicky. And finally, while hardmode isn't a bad idea in itself, I found the actual implementation more grindy and tedious than fun.  Despite these minor flaws Terraria is still a great game and I'd recommend it to pretty much anyone.  The good: - Addictive gameplay - Huge amount of content - Lots of cool items, NPCs and enemies - Massive procedural maps to explore  The bad: - Hardmode is grindy and rather tedious - Shallow combat - Not a big fan of the boss designs - Lots of obscure mechanics that are really hard to figure out without Wiki/googling

But then when you unlock hardmode (Not hardcore mode) you are imediatly back down to the bottom and must advance again, but now with new mobs and items that you have never seen before! You can go through the game with swords, magic or ranged weapons, whatever your comfortable with. Multiplayer is really fun, and it's worth making a server to play. No matter if you like building, exploring or fighting, you are likely to enjoy this game.

Terraria is excellent. It's an open world that you get to explore and create, all the while completing a quasi-hidden storyline. You get to create villages, fight killer bees, make penguin exhibits for your houses, chase after mutant fish for an angler, triple jump using a fart in a jar, and so much more! Best of all, you get to invite your friends to play on the worlds you create and vice versa! I highly recommend purchasing this game, provided you're not worried about easily sinking over 100 hours into a game without realizing it.

I don't know why I haven't writen a review for Terriaria yet, it was one of, if not the first game I got on steam, and I'm still playing it in new and interesting ways. Basically if you're on the fence about this game I'd instantly push you off onto the side where you buy it. It's really not that expensive for the content and hours of fun it holds. I've had this game and played it ever since it was 1.1.x. The devs added way more content with each major update, most recently fighting horrifying cultists, space pillars, and the new dreadfull final boss 'The Moon Lord.'   Terraria is a fantastic game that's really similar to Minecraft. There's a bit less to do in terms of creative sandbox (in that there's no creative mode) but there's more story progress related content. Bosses, events, challenges, hell, and fishing! There's so many different enimies that procedurally get harder to fight as you progress through the game. So it's never truly boring unless you're taking your time mining ores or chopping trees.   One of my favorite things about this game is magic. Unlike some sandbox games there are staffs and other magic items you can use to attack enemies and *bend the world to your whim. (Slight exageration but you can use say the dirt staff to modify the world.)* There's multiple class based ways to play that aren't locked on your character in any way. You'll just need to do some farming to get those items. I personally enjoy going a more mage setup but then again I like minions and robes. :)   Who else can argue when its got Multiplayer, an extremely challenging Expert Mode, and small game file size with 8-bit like graphics. It's very much like Minecraft but in a more platformer style with more world progression. There's a reason me and my friends have 700+ hours on this game, and though you might not be as enthralled I'm sure you'll still enjoy it and at least make it to hardmode (where the real fun begins).

Terraria is one of those rare pearls, you can be very fortunate to find in the vast ocean of games. It is charming, fun, challenging, multi-player friendly, immersive and random as hell.  To start of with, you can choose how you want to play the game. If you're the type that just like to build, explore and occationally try a boss, you can choose the easymode and no penalty death options.  If you like me, love a challenge, a rough start, boss fights that makes the sweat run down your forehead, then you can choose hardmode, which not only makes the game extremely challenging, but also super fun.   Talking about the randomness, as you progress in the game, you never know when a solar eclipse, will spawn all the monsters from your nightmares, that will swarm your little village, having you and your NPC's fighting for your lives.   Sometimes a little drone will come flying, show a few colours only to leave again in a mere moment, which result in a huge alien invasion, with UFO deathrays, beamguns, strange aliens jumping, exploding and running.  Maybe the pirates will come around, to try and steal your treasures, with flying ships, cannons, parots and everything else that belongs.  There are tons and tons of items, secrets and stuff to explore in the randomized world, that changes every single time you start a new playthrough. And trust me, if you pick a huge map, you will have HOURS upon HOURS to explore, dig your way down to the pits of hell, if you can manage to get through the desert, snowden, mines, ruins, jungles, oceans, underground shroombiomes etc. The items are so much fun and inventive. Everything from the famous portal gun, to swords shooting rainbows, miniguns, explosives of every kind, mounts to ride, wings to make you fly, the secrets of the sky-islands....  I could literally write so much good about this game. It has given my hundreds of hours and I still have many more to go.  9.5/10

Terraria is a great game, just awesome. The game has a sense of progression, the worlds are big, and if what we've heard of Terraria 2 is any indication, the next game will be amazing with infinitely large worlds. Like most exploration crafting games, you begin with the bare essentials to what you need to get going, in this case that's a short sword, a pick axe and an axe. You need to use your pickaxe to mine for soft earth (dirt, mud, sand) and minerals (stone, ore, etc). You use your axe to cut down trees which you need for the wood to create certain things like work benches.  Using these starting resources you craft a shelter and start on your journey down the rabbit hole to see how deep it goes. The game has some basic enemies at first, with the most dangerous enemies coming out either at night during a blood moon or underground. As you fight and kill more enemies they will drop special equipment which will help make you stronger or provide you with a piece to craft a better piece than you already have. I would say that the combat of Terraria makes up for 75% of the gameplay, with the exploration being the other 20% and 5% left for crafting and building. You can't progress the game without fighting, you just can't.   When you reach a certain threshold you will be forcefully invaded by a boss late at night, if you win then you won't be invaded again. If you lose, you will be invaded again .. eventually. When all is said and done, there are up to 5 bosses that you may progress and fight. And then there's one other boss, the Wall of Flesh. Defeating him will take guile and skill, as you will have to do so in the depths of the underworld over top of a river of lava. Defeat him and you win .. and then hard mode begins, and everything I just told you goes out the window.  My suggestion for anyone new and starting out with this game is bring snacks and drinks, because it will be a LONG play through, and you will likely take at least a week to finish all of the content. If you choose to use a walkthrough or a wiki, that's up to you, but I would suggest not doing so.

Terraria is a 2D adventure survival game developed by Re-Logic. You explore your world, loot the hell out of it until it's nothing more but a dead husk, and then consume the next world on harder diffiulty. Of course I doubt anyone really cares whether Terraria is an actually good game or not (trust me it is, and I'll get into that). But people are far more concerned as to which one they should buy- Minecraft, Starbound, some tiny indie devs trying to be like Minecraft Starbound or Terraria, and finally Terraria.  My objective here today is to write this review to settle some potential buyer's worries or to just flat out tell them that THIS IS NOT ♥♥♥♥ING MINECRAFT! Terraria is kind of hard to define for me because it can be many different things depending on how you want to play it. For some, it's just a simple PVE game. A side scroller. A PVP game (rarely). A looter. An adventure game. A co-op game, etcetera etcetera.  There are of course limitations to this freedom, but overall this game will give you a mountain of content to chew through. There has to be at least over a thouand different items and armor sets to collect. That isn't even counting the costumes and accesseories to collect as well. So, does it hold a candle to other games like it? Well let me put it this way, it takes Mojang about a year or more while under Microsoft just to throw in a new animal or monster. Meanwhile Terraria invites several different mobs with other additions along with the update if that isn't enough to fix your belly aching.  Though I'm going after little fish, Minecraft lost it's place in the survival genre race years ago. Starbound basically takes the base of Terraria and adds several more layers to it. Granted, it lacks the diverse and crazy loot Terraria has. But if you ever wanted a game about exploration, narrative, and has Terraria's base gameplay, then that's your winner winner chicken dinner.  Terraria has everything it needs to keep itself floating above the ground. But with Starbound fully released it needs to bring out the bigger guns. Right now Terraria has a very empty late game. Once you beat the game, and you craft the strongest weapons and armour, there is absolutely NOTHING you can do with that new gear besides fight the final boss again on a harder difficulty. Not too long ago they released a horde mode event based on the Dungeon Defenders game to remedy this issue. But I have gripes with it (mostly the difference in artstyle with Terraria's and the new mob's competing. They just look out of place).   I can get over the artstyle, but nothing excuses the fact that horde mode (especially at the rate you get Defender Points) is tedious. This isn't end game content that will keep people busy. Which is why I think people are doing the same thing as myself, play Starbound until the next update for Terraria comes. And I really can't blame them. Because the biggest question you shouldn't be asking at the end is not 'Well, now what?'  So which do I think is better? Both Terraria and Starbound have pretty major flaws making both games equals, but neither is better than the other. What do I personally suggest you do? Get either one or both. Both Starbound and Terraria have enough content combined to keep you busy for months. If you still aren't convinced, wait for a sale and try it out yourself.

So you're interested in building blocky structures with interesting mechanics? You want to kill random monsters, and have the occasional boss fight? You like levelling a character, but sometimes just long for the freedom of the old days - when levelling meant going up in health and maybe getting new gear?  Perfect. I have the best game for you.  There's always something new to explore and see. Randomly generated worlds offer variation while allowing for familiarity with the mechanics as you progress. Your characters can easily move from world to world, without having to even open their last one. You can even have one world that you slowly tear apart to acquire the materials to build your dream home on the second one.  You can create machines, host a capture the gem competition between yourself and a dozen close friends, or battle giant flying skulls with arms, aliens, a wall made of flesh, or spiders bigger than your head. You can make armor out of gold, bone, or mythical metals. You can fly a giant drill that uses lasers to tear up the ground in wide swathes. You can build a city full of merchant's shops and homes for those aforementioned capture the gem friends. You can make giant billboards, a computer, or death traps for when the Blood Moon rises and the zombies come to eat your brains.....  You can dye your hair a literally sparkling purple. You can build a tree for the holidays. You can wear an umbrella on your head or dress like a wood nymph. And so many housing styles - dungeon, wood, ice, marble, the list goes on. Seriously, I could keep going on about this game for days....  What? Stop? Never.  Well, fine. But, only because I'm going to go play the game now.  10/10

Best game I've played so far. I love all the different items you can get. You can choose different paths everytime you play, switch between classes if you like to (ranged, magic, summon and melee). You can play it slow or you can rush through it if you want. You can fight and have a lot of action and/or you can build nice things for hours with hundreds of materials and furniture. This game is among my all-time favorites. It hits the perfect balance between linear progression and freedom to do whatever you please, and given the infinite configurations of worlds to explore and multiple ways to approach the game, the enjoyment of playing and replay value are through the roof. I still get a kick out of trying new ways to play even after beating the game nearly five times. All stages of the game have their own unique feel and charm, from just starting to explore your world all the way to becoming an absolute juggernaut capable of one-shotting everything in your path.  Highly recommended to anyone into building/crafting games and deeply complex character customization. Also hugely suggest bringing some friends along, because though playing solo is a deep experience on its own, having multiple skill sets and personalities to play off of gives the game a whole new layer of complexity.  Again, absolutely recommended. Fantastic game.

Terraria is fantastic and worth every penny. The game is cheap, it's fun and engaging, and there is a delightful amount of content. So, I've had this game for quite a while now. It was a gift from my brother as one of my first steam games. It quickly became has continued to be one of my favourite games of all time.   I've always been a sucker for games where you can shape the world and build fun things like minecraft, so even a 2d creative game like this would pull me in.  Another thing I really appreciate about this game is the combat. Normally I'm not much of a fighter. In fact, I'm pretty terrible at games with a lot of combat. But, for some reason, I really like fighting in Terraria. Maybe it's the 2d style that makes it easier for me, maybe it's just the wide variety of weopons and enemies.   Mostly though, this game just sucks me in to the point where I forget about time. I can play for hours when I'm into it.

Terraria is an adventure game about trying to survive and build. The gameplay is fantastic and the 1.3 added LOTS more items including the portal gun. It also included new bosses, and 'expert mode'. So I give the updates a 9.5/10. The updates are good, but they take time to be released.   Now, the building aspect of the game. The building looks pretty good, but can get a bit boring if you want to build something big. So a simple house would be fun! So I give the building 9/10; building something big, like an adventure map, will be boring and take hours to make, but once you've finished it will be fun and worth it!   Now, Multiplayer. Multiplayer can be fun, for a while. if you are building something, it will get boring very quickly, but like I said, it will be worth your time. Despite the fact that this is my favourite game, I didn't really enjoy the online servers. I did like the PVP servers, but they got boring after a while. I give the multiplayer 8/10.  Now the end-game. When I finished the game, I was satisfied! Even after you finish the game, you can still try to get all the items, try all the character modes (softcore, Mediumcore and hardcore). Even after that, you can still finish expert mode. End game: 9/10  Overall I give this game 9.5/10. This is a MUST-BUY for all steam users!

In Terraria, you start off by cutting down a tree and get wood from it. You build a house that's (hopefully) good enough to block out any hostiles. You start to mine and get small upgrades. Over time, your armor and tools will be powerful enough to fight a boss. You likely fight the eye of Cthulhu first, it being the weakest. You probably die and have to try mulitple times but eventually you defeat the boss. Same goes on with the many other bosses in the game. Once you've beaten the final boss, you kinda win. Of course, however, the game is so addicting that it sucks you in so that you can get all of the achievements. After that, you still play for thousands of hours because the game is simply fun. There is fishing, too. You can have pets, mounts, grappling hooks and a whoopie cushion... yeah. Multiplayer is also supported if you would like to play with your friends. As many as you want, I think. Anyway, great game, would reccomend,  Note: This game is a literal time machine. I played for what felt like 2 hours and instead 7 hours went by.

So, i guess now with the steam nominations, it's time to actually review a game or 2.  Well, terraria, where to begin, how should i tell you what adventures me and my friends went through? It'll go through a simple Pro & Cons schematic, like most reviews. I'll do warn you, walls of text are inbound.   Pro's:  - Loads of content: Terraria has alot of content, from day 1 it was released and now on this day, with probably 3 times as much content as before and probably still increasing with every update. You'll probably be busy with 1 character/world for around 20-80 hours, depending on expertise with Terraria itself.  - Character and worlds aren't linked: So you have a good character, with good gear, but a totally ruined world and want to start a new world, but you want to keep your character's items? Well, no worry, as this game got you covered and let's you carry over all your items your character has on them from world -> world.  - Character customisation: The character customisation is not all the fancy stuff with sliders and stuff. But, you'll have a large choice of haircuts, 3 sets of clothing themes, and you can colour all possible options with 3 primary colour sliders. It's a small thing, but it can make all the difference to a game like Terraria.  - Easy to get into: Terraria is easy to get into. You won't get stuck on what to do as you will always have an array of multiple things to do. Bored of building? Let's go cavemining, go fishing, or even try that boss which you just so happened to get the spawn-item for.  - Great with friends: This game just gets better with the more friends you have on 1 server. The help with bosses, the hijinx about who gets what loot and the question: 'where did all the iron in the chest go?'.  - Has lots of replayability: Bored of 1 world? How about you start another on your own, or with friends. The worlds are always randomly generated and you'll never know what will happen on your playthrough, except ofcourse, the boss battles. Which will stay the same throughout playthroughs.   Cons:  - Not that many, actually!: Terraria had some cons, back in the day, as you would have needed to host a private server before you and your friends could join eachother. But nowadays you can join eachother through steam. Furtheron most bugs got fixed and it's a fluid game overall.  - Endgame is actually the 'END'game: Once at endgame, after defeating all the bosses, best loot, best enchantments... Well, there isn't actually much to do anymore expect brag your character to your friends and continue building in your world. As there isn't that much more progress to be made with your character.    TLDR;  Go get it, now. Or when it is on sale. You certainly won't regret it. It's a great game with almost no negative aspects to it.

I have 1,500+ hours sunk in to Terraria, across three platforms. I've been playing it since a month after it originally launched before the game was available on Steam.   Terraria is an 2D Sandbox style ARPG with so many features that I'm not going to list them all. Every aspect of the combat and controls are amazing, the world is vast, its inhabitants diverse, and it is flush with different world/environmental mechanics. Enemy difficulty has a wonderful range. Add to that a dedicated developer that has continued to support the game well past its 'prime' with tons of new content, and this is a must buy for any fan of the genre.   Even without friends, the game world is still compelling and fun. Buildings and structures take a back-seat though, since you won't have anyone to show your rad accomplishments to. Best playing online with friends, but a supportive and vibrant online community make the game very playable to this day.

Terraria is an amazingly huge game that you can easily spend weeks or months on (I've racked up over 300 hours, probably the most I've ever spent in any game). And that's for two reasons: There's a huge breadth of things to do, and the game progression is such that starting over with a fresh new character in a new world is *fun*.  There's infinite worlds to explore, a mind-boggling variety of items you can use with different effects (with armor and accessories tending to boost one of four archetypes you can switch between at will), and tons of enemies and bosses (over 20 unique bosses!). You can build elaborate (or simple) houses, towns, arenas, item-farming areas or more. Dress up your character in costume outfits and swap out armor dyes. Summon harmless pets, aggressive minions or helpful mounts. And if you 'win', or get bored of your world, you can just generate an entirely new world and/or start all over! Your new world will probably even have a couple features that didn't generate at all in the first one.  The difficulty starts simple and scales up for a very long time as you progress. Exploration, combat and building are both fun. And best of all, the developer releases huge *free* updates every so often with lots of new content (new bosses, events, areas, entirely new game mechanics like fishing and expert mode). I've seen paid expansion packs with far less content than these guys add for free every six months.

This game is AWESOME!  I like how you don't level up but you choose your own path and do what you want. So many enemies, bosses, items, and NPCs to move in. You can pick whether you want to do mage, melee, ranged, yoyo, or all. You can choose expert mode for a fun challenge, but better items as well. Each boss has a unique attack sequence. They are more optimized; you can attack from far or get close for some melee hits. Many town NPCs will sell you useful items for copper, silver, gold, and platinum coins. The Tavernkeep will sell some things for coins but mostly for defender medals.  Lastly, there are many biomes to explore like the forest, corruption, and the underworld. They have unique enemies and bosses, along with items.  Terraria is worth the money you pay, and there are no in-game purchases. You can also get Terraria on console and mobile, but Steam version is much more optimized. Good luck, Terrarians!

Terraria at first glance seems to be a 2d format of Minecraft, however, once playing, you'll release the focus on combat in Terraria, as well as upgrading your character and obtaining the best gear for whatever role you may want to play - whether it be a warrior with their expertise in close quarters combat, hilariously boasting some of the more powerful weapons in the game in the form of yoyos, the ranger, carrying many guns and bows, accompanied by grenade launchers, etc., or the mage, who has a wide array of spells useful in niche situations, allowing you to create an arsenal perfectly suited for your playstyle, whatever it may be.  This game has amazing value. Even at full price (only 9.99$), this game may end up being one of your most cost efficient purchases. I bought it for full price, and as this review, I've sunk over 300 hours into the game. Almost 100 of these hours were just in the past 2 weeks, due to a huge update the game recieved. It says something good about the developer to STILL be updating the game over 4 years from it's release.  Terraria is easily a game worthy of a perfect 10 for a score.

Dig, Fight, Explore, Build: The very world is at your fingertips as you fight for survival, fortune, and glory. Will you delve deep into cavernous expanses in search of treasure and raw materials with which to craft ever-evolving gear, machinery, and aesthetics? Perhaps you will choose instead to seek out ever-greater foes to test your mettle in combat? Maybe you will decide to construct your own city to house the host of mysterious allies you may encounter along your travels?   In the World of Terraria, the choice is yours!   Blending elements of classic action games with the freedom of sandbox-style creativity, Terraria is a unique gaming experience where both the journey and the destination are completely in the player’s control. The Terraria adventure is truly as unique as the players themselves!   Are you up for the monumental task of exploring, creating, and defending a world of your own?   Key features:  Sandbox Play  Randomly generated worlds  Free Content Updates

Terraria is an advanced 2D sandbox game with many similarities to big hits of a similar style like Minecraft. This game takes you through a large variety of different and challenging biomes in which you have to improve both your character stats as well as armor and equipment to survive. You build houses to create NPC villages in which you can buy and sell items that can be found by exploration or dropped by one of the many mobs! There are seemingly endless boundaries to this game that one has to cross in order to take that step from survivor to champion. From becoming a predator in different biomes, conquering the caverns and the underworld, to taking down bosses and surviving goblin, zombie, pirate, slime invasions and many more hoardes!  I would highly recommend this game to anyone looking to spend endless hours on grinding either solo or online with your friends for a relatively cheap price. This game takes a twist on sandbox survival that I have not experienced in any other big games of the same genre.
Worth every penny.

TLDR; Cute Minecraft-esque game but 2D. Only buy to play with friends.  Ah,   Minecraft in 2D  . How I love you so much. I best be honest here, I haven't actually played Minecraft - due to   refusal to jump on the bandwagon   or some such ♥♥♥♥. But honestly, it's a good game.  A friend purchased this for me during a sale Steam had a while ago (Review written on 16/12/2014, so not the Winter Sale, whatever was before) and the attitude I approached it with was 'Right, it's one of   those   games. Y'know, crafting games.'  And to be fair, it is. You mine blocks, the those blocks are in the inventory, place them. You can build shelters/structures. You can be really creative, or really minimalist. There's is a learning curve involved.   The memories of being bitten in the ♥♥♥ will haunt me forever  . I've been better, but coming from a background of avoiding Minecraft/associated block-building games altogether, I thought '  Why the hell not?    The download was quick, the music is fitting - but after a while, it does grow tedious. I highly recommend YouTube in the background. The graphics are, well, 2D. The   content   as in - block-building - I can take, because it's 2D, and you get that vibe. I think I can't take Minecraft like I did Terraria because it's 3D, but that's just my opinion.  I highly recommend it, but only using Skype/Teamspeak (if they even do a room or whatever) and a service like Hamachi or Evolve to be able to play and chat with friends. I imagine the single-player grows stale pretty quickly, but you might be into that sort of thing.  If you're more into numbers - 8/10

Terraria is one of the greatest games this decade. Hands down.   Rarely does any game allow you to create as well as it challenges you. There's always something to do, see, create, fix, build, fight or experience. It's truly a transcendent product that spans all interests and genres. There's not much I can say which hasn't already been said. This isn't just Minecraft. It is a very distinct product and everything from how you gather resources to the boss fights to the building is different.  It's not hard to learn. In fact, 10 minutes on YouTube will teach you most everything you need to survive. But there's always the next step, next goal and that's going to take some effort. But if you put forth the effort it will be rewarded.   There are countless reviews that talk about the gameplay, so I'm not going to do that. I'm just going to talk about what appeals to me. The graphics are adorable and the music great. I spent probably 5-10 hours just crafting my own little village and another dozen creating a fort to protect myself against invasions by goblins, monsters and other creatures. I built a massive water tower, a tunnel all the way to the bottom of the world and I flooded hell. I built an underwater glass tunnel through a massive hole that I cleared from corruption. I created a cloud world. I created my own personal pyramid. I created my own stadium to have boss fights in.  It's that combination of creativity and challenge that is so very rare in gaming and Terraria has it in spades. The highest recommendation I can make is simply this: there are exceptionally few games that belong in everyone's collection. They're so rare they can probably be counted on two hands. Games that offer something to everyone and do so well are incredibly rare. Pac Man. Mario. RollerCoaster Tycoon. Games that can appeal to people from 5 years old, hardcore gamers and your grandmother. Terraria belongs on that list and it belongs on yours.  Moreover, years later there are still patches and content enhancements. You simply can't lose buying this one folks.
Just get it and play it already.
