I recommend this game for a few reasons. Firstly, this game is just pure fun when you know what you're doing. At first, it is frustrating to no end when you've only got your copper shortsword and just the bare basics. Once you dig your first hole that goes STRAIGHT DOWN (yes, I said straight down, 'cause this ain't minecraft) and you throw your rope back up to the surface, you're on a roll. It's pretty easy and straightforward after that. Next, the multiplayer in this game is just awesome. You can run with a pretty crap internet connection and host a server with no lag for your friends. This game is at least 10 times better when you're playing with friends. You can collaborate and be more powerful - and be very successful. Just all around amazing. Last time I played this game was November 2012, and now I'm playing it again in January 2014, and I'm totally in love with this game. 10/10 I'm addicted, just as I'm addicted to the Call of Duty franchise. Buy it now!

This game... Is an experience, a very positive one at that. Unlike starbound you don't have much direction, and this is what i love about it, you aren't told 'select a class' or anything like that, as you are free to mix and match classes, with capabilities of being a summoner/warrior, mage/ranger, and everything in between. Full list of pros/cons:  Pros: -Mix and matching classes -Too many bosses -Moonlord battle is ****ing awesome! -Variety of play styles -Isn't generic RPG/Sandbox hybrid #2 -Little guidance -Most computers are capable of running it Cons: -Some weapons are OP, this is especially bad when joining a PvP server  9.99999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999/10, not enough potatoes

'its just minecraft in 2d' no, no it isn't.  Terraria is a diverse and branched RPG with many different play styles and thousands of items.   Unlike most games with a construction element, in Terraria you always build with specific purpose. It could be to house a vibrant castle town full of NPC's with names and unique dialogue, it could be to prepare for a boss fight or it could be to create a farm of a specific biome.  Terraria always gives you goals, always rewards you and has a good concept of difficulty. Everything is possible, its just not normally easy.  I love this game.

Terraria...Well firstly if you haven't heard of it then just leave...yep click that button to return to the store where you can buy your type of survival...Crappy Dayz :D  Anyway, I was skeptical about this game when I first looked at it. Graphics aren't the best, but hey I've grown to love the funky art style.   The first time I loaded in; I had my wiki page on stand-by to cater for my every enquiry...and trust me there will be lots. The learning curve is steep but climbable as you can quickly adapt and learn the different behaviours of the so called 'Mobs' or monsters if you will. The building part of the game is fun and works with ease; come to think of it every part of this game is somehow enjoyable in it's own little way.  The only downside Terraria has is that it may become tedious: Clicking at blocks to dig endless tunnels...Yes, this may seem boring and at times it is and you may feel about holding alt and slaming your angry finger down on f4 but no. The reward is much much better...I managed to build a skyscraper and a village surrounding it by plowing through the 'boring parts'.   Now when I spawn in and see my work, a smile shines on my face...This smile never appears in other games quite as much.  Now this Review is getting long (giggady) <--*sorry I had to* so I'm going to shorten the other sections.   Multiplayer is bloody marvolous! Single Player is Fantastic! Terraria: best side-scrollin' survival? You bet your sweet sorry ♥♥♥ it is...  'IGN 10000000/10000000 would play again'
This Game Burned MINECRAFT!!!! 10/10 Whould Play Again

To be honest, the trailers for the game makes it look a lot more lamer than I thought it would, and I especially think that this game has a LOT more than the trailer shows, all there of them ( until they make a newer version ).   But, of course, I'm not one to judge, but this IS a review, so meh.. The way I see this game is not just the bosses, NPC's, and the creativity of it, but mostly how Terraria is put out overall, mostly the story. Since I am a guy that loves anime and RPG's, you'd think that I'd would just hog over just one game and call it a day. Well, no, I have played many other games alike to this one, and especially Starbound. But for this game, it'll hold a special place in my heart because this is how I actually gotten into games in general, and the other fact that I have played this for four years now, it's quite amazing that I have known of it cause of a friend introducing it to me.   When I was first introduced to this game, I thought that it would just be another game alike to my first PC game experience, Minecraft. And even to this day I still love it so ever much. But when I played this game in a first-person view, I was more than captivated to find out this game really does have an opportunity for it in my life, so I continued to play it until my demise.   From what I'm trying to get at is to not just judge this game by its cover, mostly. And there's a difference between trying it and dislike it, or just watching others play it and give up on it. That's mostly all I gotta say for now, and if this review helps you, but you don't have enough money for it, I'll be more than happy to buy the game for you. So thank you so much for taking the time to read this, and I'll see you in my next review, toddles~
Just buy it.

Honestly this is one of the best games I've played. I've played this on console and mobile, but never on PC until now. The PC version is way better than the console and mobile versions. The console and mobile versions are still stuck on 1.2.4.1 while pc is on 1.3.1.1. The console/mobile exclusives while great do not match the quality of 1.3.1.1 items. Ocram is a failure of a boss. His spawner is very expensive, he's hard to beat, and honestly he should be nerfed. People at RE-logic what were you thinking when importing Terraria on the console and mobile. Don't get me started with the exclusive armor sets, they are very expensive to craft and compared to the buffs and set bonuses they provide I don't think they are worth considering. Even after the 1.2 material requirement reduction of the hallowed armor, the exclusive armors are still very hard to craft and that's even if your world gets blessed with the right ores to craft the armor sets for the exclusive armor sets. If your world gets blessed with a hardmode ore that's not an ingrediant for an armor set for the exclusive armor sets you will have to make a new world and convert it into hardmode, farm Ocram for the exclusive armors or fish for crates. It's literally like you guys at re-logic just slapped in some incomplete ideas when importing terraria on the console and mobile and sticked with that. I've been playing terraria on pc for awhile and I say its way better than on the console and mobile versions. The Lunatic Cultist boss while difficult he isn't broken like ocram. He is very fun to pick with. The lunar events following the Cultist's death is OMG amazing 24/7. It really challenges the player alright with unique enemies with unique abillities and debuffs. The moon lord is wow. This boss is so amazing and awesome. This boss is the real challenge to the player. He looks disfigured, he has eyes in his hands, His brain is exposed, he has an exposed spine and no legs. Re-logic this is a masterpiece of a boss. And of course the drops, don't even ask, cause they are so OP. The items of 1.3.1.1 are awesome. The yoyos, the fragment weapons. The informational accessories, the endgame armors and weapons. The players on console and mobile are really missing out on this. I would recommend this game greatly and to any gamer and especially the pc version. This is my review of Terraria and rant of the Terraria exclusives. Hopefully you enjoyed reading my review of Terraria and maybe consider buying this game for yourself.

I'm going to be honest; I really didn't give a crap about Terarria at first. It basically just seemed like a game that was trying to be different by saying 'HEY, LOOK AT US, I'M NOT MINECRAFT! BUY ME!!!!'  But then once I actually started playing the game and taking my time with it, there's a surprising amount of depth into this game. If you're looking for a game with loads of content and a long campaign to keep you busy, look no further than this.  Unlike Minecraft, this game has guns, NPC's that don't all look like Squidward, mobs out the wazoo that are all creative and sometime a really pain in the ♥♥♥ to deal with, much more powerful weapons, the list goes on. It's worth it's bargain bin price tag, especially if you have someone to play it with.  5 McLovin's out of 5

Terraria is a game full of fun and adventure (I HATE to compare this game to Minecraft but I will for this review). Terraria is a sand box game mixed with a bit of an RPG or Adventure based game. There is tons to do from building cool structures to fighting bosses, and exploring your world and the Tempels and Dungeons of your map. This game fully uses every part of your pre generated map (It is still randomly generated but it makes the whole map before you play your world) to make you explore every part of your world.  Pros: +Bosses and Dungeons provide for things to do and a guarantee 50+ hours of playing +Crazy amount of items +Armor and wepons all scale well to diffrent times in the game depening on your progress +This game does not cut short on any part of its self, like the potion making etc. is very in depth +Very fun to play with and without friends +Very original and creative +Tons of content +Great price, even better price if it is on sale for 80% off +Good world and player system, they are kept seprate and no player is linked to no world  Cons: -The ♥♥♥♥ing chest system sucks ♥♥♥♥*FIXED -The game most likely will not get more up dates -Can take a lot of time to get started into some real fun -Mining for ore was annoying -Not a lot of cons to put down  SO SHOULD YOU BUY IT !??!?!?!??! I would highly reccomend buying it. Does not matter if it is on sale or not, buy it (Although I bought it on sale because I'm a Jew and I want my monney but it goes on sale fairly often). This game will provide for lots to do and will keep you entertained for some time for a vey cheap price.

So, you want to see if this game is good based on reviews, eh?  I have a great idea. Look at my playtime. Now scroll down. Look at other people's playtime. Look at the extremely majority of recommended reviews. Now look at the negative reviews. That's right, they are all either trolls or people complaining about preformance. Now look at yourself. And back at Terraria. and back at yourself. Imagine yourself with Terraria. Now imagine yourself with three billion dollars and the world's largest mansion coated in three inches of pure gold. The images should look the same.  So what's the next step? Hit buy. Buy this game. Buy it again. Buy fifteen copies, just in case.  Now quit your job. You will no longer have the will to get up and leave Terraria not being played.  Just. Buy. This. Game. Bathe in it's glory. In it's contribution to the game world.   You can thank me later.

Uh Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead  Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons sugar 1 tablespoon baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg 2 large eggs, at room temperature 1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature 1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed  Now to make it 1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg. 2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla. 3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat. 4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed 5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed. 6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

8.5/10  Great game, good music and very immersive. There are many Minecraft clones out there, this is not one of them. It is a stand alone game. Very intuitive controls and very good artwork. Redigit shows both his skills as a developer, and his humor as a gamer in this game: Mourningwood, Golden Shower, Master Bait... Many references are made in this game to other games as well that just give you an ah ha moment. The scaling in this game is the one quirk, it is really not an issue though. For example when you first start a world you are fine, you mine ores etc and rank up. Then after defeating the    Wall of Flesh    and entering    Hardmode    you get reKt by everything, but after putting enough time into it your items become so God-like any boss in the game becomes a cake walk. All around well done, this game constantly goes on sale for close too $2, it will most likely be the best $2 you spend for 100's of hours of gameplay. PS Austin loves men.

If you're looking for a positive review, then you're in the wrong place, HOWEVER, if you're here for a tremendous chicken Stir Fry recipe, THEN LOOK NO FURTHER!  - Serves 4 - 10 mins to prepare and 10 mins to cook - 325 calories / serving - Healthy  INGREDIENTS:  - 1 orange, zested and juiced - 2tbsp soy sauce - 2tbsp sesame oil - 250g (8oz) tender stem broccoli - 5cm (2in) piece root ginger - 1tbsp sunflower oil - 1 garlic clove, finely sliced - 1 red pepper, deseeded and thinly sliced - 150g Straight To Wok Noodles - 400g (13oz) chicken fillet, cut into thin slices  METHOD  Step 1 - Mix together the orange zest and juice, soy sauce and sesame oil and set aside.  Step 2 - Blanch the broccoli in boiling water for 2 minutes, then drain well and set aside.  Step 3 - Finely shred the ginger. Then heat a large frying pan or wok, add the sunflower oil, heat it until sizzling, and fry the ginger till it's crisp.  Step 4 - When it's done, remove with a slotted spoon. Add the chicken and garlic, and stir-fry until just browned. Remove the meat using a slotted spoon and set aside.  Step 5 - Add the red pepper and broccoli and stir-fry for around 2-3 minutes until it's just tender. Add the soy sauce mixture, bring it to the boil then return the chicken to the pan and heat through. Serve with noodles.

You're probably here to look for the counter-arguments against Terraria, but is frustrated to find only dumb or fake reviews telling you 'just buy it/what are you doing viewing negative for terrria lmao lol kk'. Well, I'm here to tell the truth, and while there aren't many cons to terraria, the three main things you need to take into consideration:   - Dies out kinda fast when playing alone. A lot of the replayability comes from the fun of playing with another person, trying community maps, etc. May not apply to everyone, but applies to me and my friends so I would take that into consideration if you intend to only play Singleplayer.  - Poor compatibility with new OS versions, frequent break reports every time a new OS version is released.  - Requires guiding from the internet or another player because just like Minecraft or Garry's Mod, it has no intent in helping you whatsoever. May not be a negative if you like that kind of stuff, but it does require commitment and some people don't like it so it's good to take that into consideration.  Just taking this out of my stomach. This is not a negative review per se, I still think Terraria is an amazing game despite these three flaws (look at my playtime!), but this ♥♥♥♥ is seriously ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.  Oh and By the Way... The game is pretty good as well.

This game is one of my favorite games all time, specifically because it has features that most games don't. On top of being a super fun game with a really high replayability, it has an extremely large fan base. The developers of the game actually listen to suggestions made by terraria players in general, and make sure to give good progress reports when it comes to spoilers for upcoming updates. I've never had any problems with the game crashing and no issues with FPS fluctuation or lag of any kind, which is surprising considering the fact that I play on a relatively old and slow laptop in general. Whenever I feel burnt out on other games I always put in a few more days worth of gameplay into this game because it never gets stale. In a few years' time when Terraria 2 is released, I'm more than likely going to put hundreds, if not thousands of hours into playing it, guaranteeed.  Overall, I would give this game a 14.5/15.  Would give it a 15/15, but I've been going insane waiting for Terraria 1.3 to come out. The loss of half of a point represents my sanity, but that's more of a personal issue than anything and has nothing to do with the gameplay in the slightest.  Well done Re-Logic.

Though it can be tricky to understand at the start with weak tools but as you progress it actually becomes really fun and i enjoyed the experience of the game and i can think of reasons why it is great to play.  1: Before you play the game you can customise your own chartacter to whoever you want him to be and different style of clothing and hairstyle colours.  2:At the beginning of each world that you create you get guide to help you on the course of your journey to for example he can tell you what to do next and show you any crafting recipes.  3:When you make houses with some decorations and some furniture it can sometimes attract other NPCS who can benefit you if you meet certain requirements for example the merchant requires 50 silver coins and a suitable house to attract him.  4: There is alot of varity on this game: different enemies, bosses, NPCS,biomes and ores and minerals.   5:Sometimes you get different events happening which can bring advantages and disadvantages like the bloodmoon which can increase the spawn rate of other monsters and can break doors alot quicker but if prepared it can bring you so much coins.  6:You can be creative and change the biomes if you got certain items so it suits your style of your world.  7:You can choose how you play the game so you can be a warrior and ranged person or a mage.  8:The game dosent end there is no ending so possibilities are almost limitless.  9:You can bring friends over to join you for great gameplay and coop to survive the night and build and explore  10:you can also have PVP worlds to test your skill against other players.  However the one drawback i also like to mention is that it can be hard on the start if you wonder to far to different biomes which can limit your exploration.  But nevertheless it is a amazing game i am giving this a 8/10

Oh man... This game... When I first made a steam account, this was the first game I got. It was amazing when i got it and is still getting better and better, I absolutely love this game. If you don't know what Terraria is, it's a 2D sandbox-exploration game where you can be a multitude of classes such as Summoner, Mage, Ranger, or Melee. Each class is very different and you can switch classes whenever you want (If you farm the gear). With different biomes based on what world you get, and different ores for each world, the replayability can last forever. Oh yeah, and you can have your world on either Normal or Expert mode. On Normal... it's Normal, the way it was meant to be played. But on Expert, the Bosses and mobs get harder, smarter, and more Loot-Droppier, along with specific Expert mode items and feature, such as an Extra accessory slot.  I have played too much of this game already, and I expect I will continue playing this game too much for a long time.

You can be a werewolf riding a unicorn while shooting rainbows from a gun. You can build teleporters, find a hair dresser in a spider cavern, and get a sword that shoots cats. You can take on the lord of the moon using a yoyo, summon a sharknado minion that shoots sharks at your enemies, and find sky temples where air wyverns spawn. You can buy a music box from a wizard and go record the music that you like the most so you can have it playing in your base whenever you want, and then you can go build a castle made entirely out of white marble.   It would seem the only thing Minecraft has over this game is 1 dimension. Summary: Terraria is a 2D platformer, where you mine blocks and craft and build. People like to compare it to minecraft, but I think that's ridiculous. Terraria, is very different from minecraft, It has a focus more on fighting and crafting, Minecraft has it's focus on building. Terraria still has amazing building mechanics, and thousands of blocks to choose from. And it has thousands of weapons and armors, and lots of ores to mine.  Complicated or simple? Terraria is both complicated and simple. The crafting is complicated and hard to get used to, but after a few hours, you get used to it. The fighting is quite simple, click to attack, mouse to aim, even though it's simple, the fact that there are so many weapons make it pretty complicated.  Choice or confinement? Terraria gives you a lot of choice, so much choice, that at times, it gets overwhelming. There are so many weapons, so many ores, so many NPC's, so many classes. But after a while it becomes obvious what class fits your playstyle. Terraria also is really big on exploring, the world is big, and there are lots of cool things you can discover.  Who would I recommend this to? People that like options. People that like tons of bosses. People that like a game that lets you set your own pace.  Who do I not recommend this to? Anyone that is not willing to spend an hour to learn the crafting system. Someone who likes short games.  Rating I would give Terraria My rating of 9/10

EDIT: Well I now have over 100 hours in Terraria and I have to say that every second is worth it. I picked up most of these hours with the 1.3 patch. The devs have been great at adding content into this game which by the way are FREE patches that come with all sorts of new things to do and craft. I would still recommend this game any day and can't wait for the next patch to come out.  EDIT 2: I nominated this game for being the game I'll always come back to!  First off, I have few hours on the Steam version of Terraria, but I have sunk a lot of hours into the console port and this game is amazing. You start off small with just a few tools. You start to chop down trees and fight off some slimes. Then you can go mining which is where the fun begins. You pick up new materials to build better tools and fight off more enemies and explore the depths of caves and biomes. You can travel east or west for quite a distance (depending on world size) and one of the sides will be a surprise for you, but don't attempt to go in. Break the curse at night is all I will say. Bosses in this game can be hard and you will have to actually get better gear and armor and maybe even set up a special arena.   This game has a ton of content to keep you playing. I would give this game a 8/10 as there could be a few minor improvements (in my opinion) which may even be addressed in a future update.

This game is amazing in all aspects of a two-dimensional sandbox game. One can become a fierce Warrior with multiple swords and heavy-duty armour, a Marksman with guns, various bullets, and bows; a Wizard or Mage with numerous spells, a Wizard Hat, and Robes; a Miner with the highest quality Picks and Drills; a Demolitionist; an architect; Etc. You can be all of them at once, if that suits your fancy. You can be an Angel of the Hallow or a Demon of the Corruption. You can make your world what you want it to be. You can build mansions the way you want it to be. This game is about what you want. And, if it couldn't get any better, one can play with friends on a multiplayer server that is very easily set up. So, if you want an adventure of spelunking and fighting, building and mining, or even flying and running around, this game is for you.

Terraria is a feature-rich 2D Action-RPG with an incredible amount of depth, and I don’t just mean vertically. Many people like to compare this game to Minecraft, but I feel that this is an incorrect analogy. Terraria very heavily encourages combat, fighting bosses, exploring, and “leveling-up” (done in the form of collecting heart crystals and stars to increase health and mana). There is a metric-ton of things to do, items to craft, etc. in this game. In fact, there is so much stuff that ironically you wind up wondering what to do. Terraria’s greatest weakness is too much content and not enough direction. If you plan to play this game, you should just go ahead and bookmark the wiki, because you’re going to be going there every five-fifteen minutes trying to figure out where to get this component or why this summoning item doesn’t work. But don’t let this discourage you. If you put in the initial time, you will get an incredible amount out of it, especially since its always going on sale for $2.49. It seemed for me that my enjoyment of the game would come in stages. Sometimes I would wake up and all I would want to play was Terraria. Other times, I could let it sit for days without so much as looking at it.  The start is slow, progression sometimes confusing, but ultimately this game is just incredibly fun. If you are interested in this game, I would definitely recommend it, especially if it is on sale.

I could make a joke here saying 'It's ok' or words to that effect But honestly this is the best game I have ever played  As others have mentioned, Terraria is just full to the brim of content. The end boss was literally only added in the last update, and that sounds like a bad thing but it's just because of how much is added every single time. I have never played a game with such dedicated and thoughtful developers, who listen to the voices of their fans and have a legitimate relationship with them. So hats off endlessly to the Re-Logic team, who make all of our lives better. Who allow us to ride unicorns looking like a pumpkin whilst rolling a yoyo on the ground ahead. Whose bosses range from an Eldritch Horror to a mechanical Santa. Who allow us to fight a giant robot worm with an army of cute little pirate minions. The game isn't perfect, there are a couple of things that I feel need to be balanced (F***ing Shroomite) but that's the thing, the development is far from over. And I cannot wait to see what is in store for the future

Called by many 'Minecraft in 2d', but it has way more emphasis on rewarding exploration (Overworld, underground caves, underground jungle, underworld, corrupted areas, floating islands & the dungeon) and combat (different enemy types in different regions & even boss enemies, some with multiple phases) - with tons of craftable items (ranging from pickaxes, swords and bows to light sabres, guns and grappling hooks) even more items that can be found in chests (which randomly spawn when you create your world) which improve your stats, give you more hit- and mana points or grant you new skills (double jump, increased attack spead, ability to swim underwater and so on). Obviously, there are also building elements - build yourself a shelter to be safe from enemies and store your loot! You can also attract NPCs when you build houses for them which offer services and allow you to buy & sell items you find.  The option to host/join multiplayer servers is available, too and is easy to use.

Very fun inovative game as even though its a mining based game (odd enough thats a running theme for indie games nowadays) it breaks away from the usual 'gather materials to build your phallus shaped fortress' method but instead focuses on the battle mechanic as there is numerous bosses and even more enemies some of which appear at certain areas and events which encourage you to play the game to find out what they are exactly.While the gameplay mechanic does encourage you to go deeper underground to mine rare'er materials to not only gather your ore's to make your '♥♥♥♥ Everyone' power armour along with your 'Kratos God Killer' wepons but as far as I've found right now two of the bass fights actually require mining to be done such as the alleged 'King Slime' which took no more than the tactic 'Wait for him to jump stupidly high then make a break for your fortress to smack him in comfort with your sword while you kill his occasional childen and then teabag his eventual corpse while looting all the gear he dropped',and then theres the 'Wall of Flesh' boss which took the better part of 5 gold's worth in ammo and a really ♥♥♥♥ing expensive pistol to take down along with the tactic 'Run the ♥♥♥♥ away in the never ending plane of terror while being chased by a wall of ♥♥♥♥'.While yes most bosses (I think including Skelletron Supreme) require a little bit of digging to be done to find the 'Demon Alter'(F.Y.I it's probably spelt wrong),the mining aspect is thrown out of the 100 story apartment block like a pile of rubbish which the fat ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ responsable was too lazy to go to the rubbish shute convinently placed outside of his apartment.But in all fairness the game is addictive and if you like mining games(not neccisary) or a game with tremendous replay value then this is the game for you.

It encourages creativity, which is the true nature of a sandbox in my opinion. 'What can I build next?' and it's as simple as that to get me hooked and working my way into building something awesome. The gameplay is great as well. Bosses, monsters, rewards, a large (and I mean HUGE) array of weapons, items, decorations, you name it. There are also biomes (environments) to make everything more interesting. The developers really put a lot of thought and time into this game and despite the small price tag, it's given me a huge amount of playback value.

Terraria is a 2D sidescrolling game with so much more content than Minecraft. Even though it uses the build and mine sort of thing from Minecraft it has more items than Minecraft. There are ALOT of swords and armour to collect as well as bows. There are around 10 types of arrows in the game. You can collect rare items that are only obtainable from monsters (Like a gun that shoots RAINBOWS. Amazing.) But its not all sunshine and bunnies in this land... Evil spreads from across the land and these places are only known as the corruption (Purple) and the Crimson (Red) You can craft many decorations for your home and can even collect banners and (if you`re lucky enough) a trophy from one of the many bosses that await a challenge. In every world there is a deep dungeon that will test your survival skills. If you get past the guardian you can venture downwards into the depths of the dungeon and find loot. (There is alot of loot in this game... Alot.) If you happen to defeat the tough as hell boss in hell your world will change into hard mode. In this mode new monsters appear and the old ones get stronger. New bosses can be fought and much more loot can be found. Plus there are alot of items you can only get in Hard mode. But once you activate Hard mode the Corruption and the Crimson will spead even faster. But a new biome will spawn. One that is the opposite of the Corruption/Crimson. And is literally sunshine and rainbows.  So... Thats my 'brief' overview of Terraria.  Plus you can make shades. 11/10

It's exactly what it promises, and perhaps quite a bit more. I blew an absurd amount of time on this, and managed to get it on sale...so my opinion is colored by that quite a bit, perhaps.  It's 2D Minecraft: you build a base, explore caverns to get more things for your base, and kill monsters while doing so. Occasionally a boss will show up, which is pretty awesome.  Key points:  The graphics are quite simple: I don't think that's a serious drawback, given the nature of the game.  The crafting mechanic is much better than in Minecraft: you don't have to worry about the specifics of crafting, but rather only that you have the materials and crafting station necessary to craft the thing you want. That said, it's not always true that the thing you need is in the game world you develop, which is a little annoying. It's not a major deal-breaker, though.  I am somewhat sad that your base can be made absolutely impenetrable: enemies cannot break blocks, so unless you're facing a boss, you can just hole up in your house and not worry about monsters invading your house *ever*. It also makes it unreasonable to *want* to build your house out of harder-to-get bricks.   There's also no creative mode. :(  Nonetheless, it's an incredible game: you have quite the expanse of regions to go through, there's a lot of adventure to be had, and it's overall the best bang for your buck you are going to get on Steam. (At least, until Terraria: Otherworld comes out.)

I felt Terraria was worth my time when it first came out--and I enjoyed it! But, since then, the team added so many features, it seems like it is 3x the game that I loved. This game definately altered the minds of the Miners and Crafters out there and I have never appreciated a 2D game that much--for it has reimagined this genre.  Terraria has different difficulty settings, so there is no steep curve. The same concepts are re-used throughout the game, so once you master it early on, your focus is set on three things. Building, upgrading, and exploring. The weapon variety is decent enough, that you can choose the weapon (or tool) to defend yourself.  Don't go back to 3D sandboxes after this.

I've nominated this game for the 'Test of Time' award, because no matter what this game suddenly gets an update or I keep coming back to it.  Just when you think the updates are done for, and when the dev team splits or says they are done with updating it... They come back. It's probably my favorite game I've ever played, and has everything you need to keep you hooked for a long time.  I don't think I can think of an element of the game that is bad, from the soundtrack to the art of sprites, mechanics and the wide variety of weapons, armor, equipment, vanity items, building blocks so many you always discover a new one you didn't think existed before. Events, amazing biomes and world generation and exploration, pyramids, caves, undiscovered shrines and floating islands... I'm getting excited just by writing about it.  There is not a single person I wouldn't recommend this game to, specially with the low price and the constant sales it gets.  I think my playtime can say a lot, and I'm pretty sure it's going to start going up again, since just writing this review made me want to boot it up again and cancel all my plans tonight.

Had been avoiding this game in favor of Minecraft for a long time, thinking that a simplistic 2D game would just be far more boring and less rewarding.   I couldn't have possibly been more wrong. While this might not offer the same sort of multiplayer experience as Minecraft does, its experience while playing solo or with a couple friends is astounding. For the price it is undoubtedly worth it. I figured I'd play it 5-10 hours and get bored of it, and yet here I am with 40 hours played and still finding myself discovering new things every time I leave my home.  If you're looking for a very cheap way to burn some useful hours of your life away, this is the game to do it!

Terraria, a game that I have 1,300 hours on.  This game is a very controversial topic because a lot of people think its a ripoff of HINT HINT THAT OTHER REALLY POPULAR BUILDING/BLOCKY GAME. However, I'm not saying that Terraria doesn't have similar features to Minecraft. Yes, you cut trees, yes sand has gravity, yes this game has iron and gold, and yes, there is a Creeper costume. The first part of this review will be a little ranty, I'll just be talking about how Terraria is different from Minecraft.  On the first note, trees are well... a common natrual resource, even in real life there are trees used for building things (WOAH I DIDN't KNOW.) Sand that has gravity, alright, this could be directly inspired by MC, but c'mon, it's just one thing. Third, there being iron and gold is also similar to number one, iron is used for a lot of things in real life. Gold... although both games do have gold, and real life has gold, we don't use it a lot...  Alright, what is Terraria? Terraria is a 2d Block Based RPG. You are placed in a world with yourself and 3 tools, a pickaxe, axe, and a copper shortsword. Using these you must build yourself up and eventually reach endgame. Unlike other games, Terraria has no end, you just might run out of things to do. The game has RPG elements, different style of gameplay, (e.g. the basic classes of Warrior, archer and mage.) There is also a lot of building, but in my opinion if you aren't a pixel artist or some sort of talented architect, there's less excitement in it than for instance, dungeon delving or boss fighting. Terraria has lots and lots of NPCs, of course there's your typical enemy NPC, but there's also friendly NPCs, which serve as special functions. Terraria has a randomly generated world, but it's not infinite. In fact, certain game mechanics would be impossible if it was.   Now, this game also has a multiplayer, which is basically just like the singleplayer but with other people, I've spent probably 95% of my time on multiplayer, for me singleplayer gets boring.  In my opinion, Terraria is a great game, I recommend this.

This game is a mix of an RPG and a survival crafting game. You can do all sorts of things such as fight huge bosses, or go mining in complex caves. You can pimp your armor and weapons as you go along with the game and prepare for the fight of a lifetime, which makes this game hard to get boring. The game MAY start off boring, but trust me it gets better. Although this game may get boring, it will still be fun with friends!

The game's graphics are retro-style, representing those old consoles, and with a whole new array of weapons, items, blocks, and more, the game is just seeming to get better and better. However the game's developers do not release updates often, and the game is too strict of housing, however it is easy to build housing for people to come in and sell you items. Overall, it's good, but most people consider this a '2D Minecraft ripoff'.

I really like this game, and how easy it is to learn how to play. My friend got the 4-pack while it was on sale so him, my other friend, and I could all play together. We spent about 2 hours playing together before my friend had to get off, but we enjoyed it. We all have Minecraft accounts and that's what got us into PC gaming, as it was the only game we played for a real long time (I don't know what my time in that game would be, but it's probably somewhere above 2,000 hours) and we all agree this feels like a heavily modded version of Minecraft since it's so awesome and has the same feel we get when we play Minecraft, but this game does a better job of teaching us how to play. You learn the basics and controls fairly quickly and we learn through playing instead of, like Minecraft, constantly watching other videos and looking on the Wiki. I could play this 24/7 if I didn't need to sleep/eat in real life

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Overall, this is a very good game that is worth it's money. It is NOT a copy of Minecraft, they are both very different games. Overall, I like Terraria better. I played Minecraft for a few months, but quickly got bored of it. The only time I actually PLAY Minecraft is if I go on a server, but they are not all reliable. Some of them allow you to cuss, and I had to learn that the hard way. Terraria has 14 Bosses, but Minecraft has 3. Terraria has over 50 different sets of armor and swords, but Minecraft has 5. Basically, Terraria is good for looting, fighting, and advancing in game. Minecraft is good for building and sharing with friends. Overall, I like Terraria better. Wait, this is a Terraria review, not a Minecraft review. Moving on!  Here is what this game is about. You start out in a custom world where you have to advance in game and fight to survive. Along the way you find some computer characters to help you advance in game. You build, fight, loot, and survive! This game consists of several bosses and enemies, which is what i like about this game most.  This is a very fun game, but there are a few questionable things about it. First of all, I'm christian, so I don't like all of this stuff about Demons and Voodoo Dolls. I kind of wish they could change that, but it's too late now. Also, some of the bosses are pretty gross, such as the Brain of Cthulu. At least they have a setting for shutting off Blood And Gore. I'd say this game is more for teenagers, not for children.  Besides that, this is a pretty good game. But I wouldn't recommend it for young ones or Christians. If you're neither of those, then BUY THIS GAME IMMEDIATELY!

Terraia, well, this is a heartfelt topic for me. This is the game that brought me to steam, without this game, I may not own a steam account right now... What is there to say about this game that hasn't already been said? I don't know, but I will try, sorry for any possible repetitions:  +Terraria is a Adventure/Sandbox style game, based more around fighting, adventure and loot, instead of building, like in other sandbox games, +Terraria boast a large amount of unique weapons ranging from Ice bows, to Guns that fire explosive bunny rabbits, with large diversity, you can play the game in your own style, no two attempts are the same! +Terraria has a vast vanity system, with all types of items paying refernce to many popular icons,  Terraria is a huge time eater, you can start playing and only stop when light creeps through your curtains and you question yourself, thinking 'Why has there been two sunrises within an hour?' +This large amount of time feels more like an investment rather than a waste, as you feel like every kill, every ore, every drop brings you closer to your ultimate goal of being the best, almost every enemy has it's own unique drop that you can get, so attacking the same enemies never feels dull or drab, especially with the 1.2 random enemy generator, that makes all the common enemies have multiple style and appearances. +Terraria holds many milestones and bosses for the player, beautifully spaced out so that the player will encounter one after the other, but not so close as to overwhelm the player. +NPCS! You can build yourself a merry little town of people who will help you along your journey, each with there own shops that get set up after certain goals have been attained. Giving the player a break to build a village if they tire from slaughter,  Art style, Opinions of art styles vary hevily from person to person, in my opinion I feel terraria makes an excellent job at capturing the 16-bit vibe, with excellent chip-tunes backing up the whole ensemble, making an altogether memorable experince. -While there are many, many things to do in Terraria, if you get stuck on a boss, which you will, it takes a very long time to get into a position where it is possible to defeat it, while I have complimented the progression above, It does have it's flaws, later in the game you will encounter a hard mode, while hard mode on it's own is well built and challenging, the difficulty curve for the bosses is unforgiving, The hard mode bosses are nigh-on impossible in single player with the best gear available at the time, as these bosses can encounter the player at any night after the first in hard mode, the player can be caught heavily off guard and could lose some villagers.  All-in-All I could not recommend Terraria more, this is a solid purchase! I give complete recommendations to buy this if you have even the slightest of interests, you will not be disapointed, especially at the great price point!  ~Clawedcrab☺

Do you remember Digimon World 4 on the PS2, Gamecube, XBOX? No? Oh well, anywho, Terraria is a 2D sidescroller with a heavy emphasis on exploration and combat rather than the grinding and repitition of other games in a similar genre. With absurd amounts of content already in the game, and more on the way in the 1.3 update (Of which is now here, and awesome), you wil be playing for quite a while. Albeit it does have both crafting and mining, it is not the 2D Minecraft everyone (Who played Mincraft + was under 12) was screaming it was when Terraria first released into beta (Or was alpha the first public release? if someone could clear that up in the comments, that would be great).  For the MMO players out there, there is a soft-classing system (No actual restrictions), as specialization to a certian weapon type can be benificial. Servers are able to be extremely large, and group play is common.   Combat is non-targeting, so you must aim your shots, with the majority of melee weapons being the exception, most of them swing where you are facing. Very few ranged weapons are hitscan, as most are projectile based with travel time. Guns have no arc of fire, while bows and most throwing weapons do. Grenades are also a thing. Movement is extremely important when fighting, as enemies and bosses do a great deal of damage and knockback. IMO, it's quite fun.  NPCs can also a thing, and will move into homes that you have built for them. Having NPCs allows the purchasing of basic equipment, equipment you can only get from them, construction/destruction/terraforming items, and healing. NPCs also stop enemy spawns near your town.  Overall, it has a great deal of exploration with a focus on combat. I would recommend it to anyone interested in those things, and can tolerate the lack of almost any story whatsoever.

A game that i can recommend fully.  Story: Terraria really doesn't have any story. You spawn in (for me, a forest), and you can see your guide. Talk to him and he'll give you tips on how to play the game. There is somewhat of a goal, you can create multiple houses for people to move in which can benefit you.  Gameplay: Gameplay wise, Terraria plays very similiar to Minecraft, but in 2D. You can craft items, build houses and other things and explore caverns and dungeons. It's very fun.  Graphics: Terraria's graphics remind me of Super Nintendo, with their retro looking style. New gamers might be put off by this, but don't turn the game down because of that.  Music: Terraria's music is well composed, i've enjoyed every piece of music so far the game has played for me. I really liked the snow world music.  Overall, i give the game 9/10. It's well worth every euro.   It also has trading cards. :)

I was already a fan of the creator's (Redigit) previous work which was a fangame called 'Super Mario Bros. X' Years ago (2011), I learned that Regedit released another game known today as Terraria. I was hyped and bought this game on the official website. It was everything I thought and more and I was deeply in love with it. I stopped playing for a few years just so I can see it evolve more and more. In 2016, I got this game as an early birthday present and started playing again. Hyped for what this game has become, I played a few hours of single player. The game felt different, and in a bad way. Everything that made it simple and fun now is grindy and complicated. In this 'new' Terraria you basically grind to get better 'toys' Everything seems too complicated and you need a guide for everything. The game isn't beginner friendly and you can become overwhelmed by the amount of things that you should be doing. The game punishes you for being ignorant, and only the wise ones can actually enjoy the game.   I really (really) tried to like this new Terraria, but it never satisfied me like the old version. Rating: 6/10

*I edited the review to remove the snark.  I accept that this is a popular game, but I personally couldn't get into it. The 2d presentation and combat came across as overly simplistic. I found the constant bombardment of hostile monsters to be an annoyance, even though I didn't have any trouble killing them.  Lastly, there wasn't enough explanation as to what I was supposed to do. For example, you've built a 2d house with a tiles to the left, right, and above you. If nothing is walking behind you and you can't move off that single 2d plane, then how would you intuitively know that the house requires a background wall? Especially since monsters can still spawn if the background wall is 'natural' as opposed to placed there by you?  The guide is a joke. His tips are useless and he actually got me killed by opening my door and leaving it open at night, hiding behind me while the monsters that followed him into my house beat me to a pulp. Getting killed by the dude that was supposed to be helping me adjust to the world is what caused me to drop the game.  Just not for me.

Edit: (New Review because i compared it too much to minecraft) Basically Terraia is really nothing more than a grindfest in about everything involved with it, Mining, fighting, etc.: grindfests. Due to this and the low replay value, the game gets boring fast when all the content is discovered through endless grinding of course, which is probably the reason why the developers decided to add in all the conetnt in it in the first place because its as if they knew it would be the game's only backbone, as evident from the fanbase when they use this trait as their main argument of the game being worthwhile. On other notes the 2d nostalgia-dependent graphics harms the games buidling aspect as you are limited to a side view which gets quite annoying, as for the combat which is heralded as the game's main selling point against minecraft *drumroll*...... is basically just like minecrafts combat system, they both require spamming the attack button to defeat enemies which is again. boring. the only difference really is the gunz and majuks but you still have to spam. But to sum it up its basically zelda/final fantasy turned into a sandbox, which explains why it would have never appealed to me in a artistic sense. I can see where people would like the game if they had enough tolerance but definitley not me

'The only ores which will always spawn naturally in any given world are Meteorite, Obsidian, Hellstone, and Chlorophyte. All other ores are paired off so that only one out of each pair will spawn in a world. For pre-hardmode ores, this is determined at world generation; for hardmode ores, this is determined when the first, second, and third Demon Altar or Crimson Altar is destroyed. Within each pair, each member has an equal chance of spawning. Which ores are paired together are shown to the right. Only one of the hard mode ores will spawn, so multiple worlds might be necessary to get a certain ore(Adamantite for Suspicious Looking Skulls).  In all cases, equipment made from replacement ores will be statistically slightly stronger than equivalent equipment made from the original ore.' - Taken from  terraria.wikia.com   I really liked this game up until the devs did this. Basically, the new ore types they introduced to the game weren't simply added to the word generation, which is what I thought, because that would MAKE ♥♥♥♥ING SENSE. Either the original ore will be generated in your world, or the equivalent new ore, but never both. You can have copper or tin, but not both. You can have Adamantite or Titanium, but not both. A lot of items can be crafted by either equivalent ore types, but the items crafted out of the newly added ore types will -always- be better somehow. Even if they're statistically identical, the items made out of the new ore types will still sell for more. Basically in order to craft the best items in the game you'll probably want to generate multiple worlds just for mining. It's possible to obtain an ore type that didn't spawn in your world by using the extractinator, but who wants to do that? This is ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

The game progresses in a very linear way, so there is virtually no replayability. The combat is not good at all, and it takes hours of mining to get good enough things to fight a boss, and then you have to mine to get new things to fight the next boss, and it goes on and on. It gets to a point where you have to kill enemies over and over to get an incredibly rare drop to make something that gets you a bit stronger, so you can even attempt fighting the next boss. The building is not fun at all, because in 2D, it is extremely difficult to do. You will end up building a wooden box as a house. It gets boring (and annoying) very quickly.

I just dont understand. What is the appeal of this game? You dont like all the freedom and user friendly interface of minecraft? You hate knowing what anything does? You hate playing with other people?  So i created a character and a world and poped in to start a play session. There was a guy walking around an some pots to my right. Video game insticts kicked in and I started destroying pots and getting stuff. From the moment I started the game there was a slow stream of slimes coming from the left side of the screen that I had to deal with. I press every button to figure out how to get to my inventory before just giving up. Then I hit escape and realize my inventory opens. What the ♥♥♥♥? Why did they think that was a good idea?? It also acts as the options screen as there is a small settings button in the bottom right corner that you probobly wont notice.  So I started looking at all the stuff from the pots when I started thinking, 'What am I supposed to be doing here?' I walked up to the guy that was walking around figuring he was there for a reason. After 5 minutes of fumbling around with him I figured out right click is the interaction button! Come to find out this guy is the tutorial. He has a handful of short messages that I guess are supposed to help you know what to do. Before I could finish reading all his stuff night came and a metric ton of floating eyes and zombies swarmed on me. You do so little damage to them and they kill you very very quickly. The eyes are also very hard to hit. So for about 15 minutes I would spawn, and die over and over until day came.  Then I decided to build a house. A staple for these types of game you would think. And thats when I realized. 'What the hell can you do with a 2d house? ♥♥♥♥ all is the answer to that question. After fighting with the interface to build a simple house I decided to start mining to see what I could get. The sprites are so small compared to you that it becomes frustrating to click all of the tiny crap so you can mine. Not to mention its hard to gauge the depth you are digging for stairs. In minecraft you know to dig 1 down because you can only jump 1 block high. Here however, you have no idea. My stairs ended up looking all deformed and messed up because screw trying to count each little sprite.  I then made a crafting table to try and craft something. I put one down and right click on it an nothing happens. After a while of fumbling about again I realize that you just stand next to it and the recipes show up in the player inventory screen. I just dont understand how people find this game entertaining in the least bit. Maybe they have never heard of minecraft?  After the crafting fun I start digging some more. A slime drops out of nowhere on my head and kills me.  I cant even bother trying this game again. It may get better after a few hundred hours and reading a bunch of guides but who the hell would want to do that? Ill just keep building massive cities and castles and going to the moon and messing with crazy mods in minecraft.
Thought this would be better than Minecraft. It is not. Bought a 4-Pack and didn't even give the last one.

At first I was drawn into the game by the cute graphics that reminded me of the old SNES days, the very cheap price and two of my other friends owning it (But one just had it gifted to them and didn't want it). After some playing through the single-player portion (And a run-in with a very toxic and hostile online group, L6D's Community Server), this game just is not very fun. Not much direction on what to do in the single-player mode, and joining a new community puts you in a killzone where you are forced to be slaughtered four dozen times while community members tell you to go slit your wrists in real life.  I've came across some games before, that focus more on multi-player than single-player. That, to fully experience them, you have to play among friends or play online. Terraria is clearly one of those games.  Just it is not a very fun game. The only benefit is I spent only 2 bucks on this.

Multiplayer is confusing as hell. Several of my friends and I all own the game, and we have yet to figure out how to play together. Basically, you have to host a server, and then your friends have to join by entering your computer's IP address, plus some other port address, and it's not explained anywhere within the game. In otherwords, you have to know exactly who you're playing with before hand. You can't just go looking for a random server to make friends in. Single player is relatively fun, but without other players you'll likely find yourself becoming bored rather quickly. Assuming you can get the multiplayer to work, however, you can carry the same character over from server to server and use all of the same items you previously collected. This was really a game meant for multiple people, but they went about it in a very poor way. Overall, I would say don't get this game if you wanted to play it with a friend.

Terarria is a pathetic little side scroller that doesn't let you have any creative freedom. Can't wait for people to dislike this automatically. BRING ON THE HATE, I HAVE AN OPINION.  Terraria is interesting, to say the most. It has more charm than minecraft, but like minecraft, it's boredom central. Oh, yes, there are plenty of things to do, but holding down the mouse for two hours to end up attacking the occasional zombie that crosses your path just to mine again gets so boring. I suppose multiplayer is more hectic and livelier, but the single player is very dull. It's a very good time waster, I'll give it that; when waiting for things to happen to me in real life I might play this for a bit, as it certainly distracts you from things, but it's just not something I want to play all the time.  My problem is not the graphics (although pixel based games are oversaturating the market) and it's not the sound (which sounds boring, but gets the job done). It's just the gameplay; Minecraft and this game share a lot of the same problems; HOWEVER, Terraria has way better combat than Minecraft, and it's NPC's are better as well; they have actual pathfinding, unlike Minecraft, in which enemies simply walk in a straight line toward you. Crafting is weird, and I have to say it is better and worse than Minecraft; it tells you what you need for an item from the getgo, but the way you craft seems unweildy (having to press esc and scroll through a very small menu at the bottom left).  All in all, I had more fun with this than Minecraft, but I still didn't have a lot of it. It's probably worth it to every single other person other than me, but it just isn't my thing.  BUT HEY, $1.99 ON SALE, CAN'T BEAAAAAAT THAT!  pickaxe/10.

Oh man...words cannot express what happened to me after eating these. The Gummi Bear 'Cleanse'. If you are someone that can tolerate the sugar substitute, enjoy. If you are like the dozens of people that tried my order, RUN!  First of all, for taste I would rate these a 5. So good. Soft, true-to-taste fruit flavors like the sugar variety...I was a happy camper.  BUT (or should I say BUTT), not long after eating about 20 of these all hell broke loose. I had a gastrointestinal experience like nothing I've ever imagined. Cramps, sweating, bloating beyond my worst nightmare. I've had food poisoning from some bad shellfish and that was almost like a skip in the park compared to what was going on inside me.  Then came the, uh, flatulence. Heavens to Murgatroyd, the sounds, like trumpets calling the demons back to Hell...the stench, like 1,000 rotten corpses vomited. I couldn't stand to stay in one room for fear of succumbing to my own odors.  But wait; there's more. What came out of me felt like someone tried to funnel Niagara Falls through a coffee straw. I swear my sphincters were screaming. It felt like my delicate starfish was a gaping maw projectile vomiting a torrential flood of toxic waste. 100% liquid. Flammable liquid. NAPALM. It was actually a bit humorous (for a nanosecond)as it was just beyond anything I could imagine possible.  AND IT WENT ON FOR HOURS.  I felt violated when it was over, which I think might have been sometime in the early morning of the next day. There was stuff coming out of me that I ate at my wedding in 2005.  I had FIVE POUNDS of these innocent-looking delicious-tasting HELLBEARS so I told a friend about what happened to me, thinking it HAD to be some type of sensitivity I had to the sugar substitute, and in spite of my warnings and graphic descriptions, she decided to take her chances and take them off my hands.  Silly woman. All of the same for her, and a phone call from her while on the toilet (because you kinda end up living in the bathroom for a spell) telling me she really wished she would have listened. I think she was crying.  Her sister was skeptical and suspected that we were exaggerating. She took them to work, since there was still 99% of a 5 pound bag left. She works for a construction company, where there are builders, roofers, house painters, landscapers, etc. Lots of people who generally have limited access to toilets on a given day. I can't imagine where all of those poor men (and women) pooped that day. I keep envisioning men on roofs, crossing their legs and trying to decide if they can make it down the ladder, or if they should just jump.  If you order these, best of luck to you. And please, don't post a video review during the aftershocks.  PS: When I ordered these, the warnings and disclaimers and legalese were NOT posted. I'm not a moron. Also, not sure why so many people assume I'm a man. I am a woman. We poop too. Of course, our poop sparkles and smells like a walk in a meadow of wildflowers. Thanks for all the great comments. I've been enjoying reading them and so glad that the horror show I experienced from snacking on these has at least made some people smile.

Terraria is that lightning in the bottle game you always wish would get the recognition it deserves, frequently bought for it's price and forgotten to the bottom of steam libraries. This game starts slow, feeling like a minecraft clone in 2D, slowly though, you uncover more and more to this game. 'Oh, there's magic?' Yup, 'Boss fights that feel like Super Metroid or Castlevania?' Uh huh 'Hold on, there are firearms including a minigun?' *Grin* you ain't seen nothing yet.   Terraria opens itself up slowly, it's a nesting doll of excitement, just when you think the game has gotten ridiculous enough it just keeps adding more. From star cannons, to chainsaws, to spiderman web throwing. That is what makes this game feel so big while being so small. If you are a gamer that likes to mod to add more content, flavor, or mechanics. This is the game for you.

I must admit that when I first heard of 'Terraria' from my friends I discredited it, assuming it was a '2D rip off of Minecraft'. This is what most people would usually think upon seeing the game. However, after being finally convinced by my friends to buy the game I found later that I couldn't get enough. It does mirror Minecraft in a handful of terms of gameplay, but it has its own kinks, gimmicks and charm that seperate it from any other games. I also love how it takes a very interesting spin on various mythologies, with the common pop-culture Zombies to the classic myth of Cthulhu. I have only begun my Terraria adventure, owning the game now for less than a month, and I already need to write a review like this. Trust me, as a huge game skeptic I can honestly say that Terraria is much, much more than 2D Minecraft and definitely worth checking out.

Build a town, mine, rescue NPCs, invite other players to party with or participate in PVP, build whatever you want, etc. Terraria is sort of an open world sandbox with only a few ways to progress in the game. Along the way you may encounter and defeat bosses which will help move the game along, but all that does is bring forth new challenges. Terraria is a game that goes at whatever pace the player wants it to go. This does not mean there is no chaos in this game. Upon nightfall zombies will attack you instead of the usual weak enemies that attack during the day upon the surface. When digging deeper underground you will come upon bosses and more powerful enemies, as well as traps that may kill unsuspecting players and deep drops into the abyss ending your life. This game is the perfect blend of hardcore and casual gaming. You can even enable things like perma-death upon choosing the highest difficulty setting in the game. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ assessment : 10/10

Terrraria is an incredible deviation from what you expect in side scroller games. While many will make the comparison to Minecraft due to the shared theme of building, Terraria has a much deeper level of progression and an actual ambient overworld full of bosses and enemies. The game feels like a private mmo with almost infinite potential to build in.  The game has seen a number of updates over the past year, adding a huge variety of features to further expand the items and materials available. If you 'flattened' out Minecraft & added some more adventuring content, you would get Terraria. Terraria is a 2D adventure game where you explore the world, venturing high in the air as well as deep underground to see what you can find. Anyone who calls this game 2D Minecraft to discourage people from playing it needs to rethink their strats. While there are many similarities (sandbox/crafting/building/tool progression upgrades) Terraria is strongly focused on exploration, combat, and unlocking bosses and NPCs as you go. The weapon/tool progression is basically genius. For EVERY better weapon you find, you think, 'Wow! Coolest thing ever! I'm never getting rid of this!' right until you find the next best thing, then it starts all over again.  The progression is quite consistant until you get to the extreme late-game. Once you're there, you WILL encounter a couple difficulty spikes that are very disheartening. I almost quick playing when I went up against one of the end game bosses because he was that much harder than the previous portions of the game. There are other parts of the game that are just crazy-grindy. You wil learn to hate chlorophyte (not spelled right) but you need it to stand a chance against the next guys. And don't even get me started on the stupid Truffle Worms...  Anyways, if you've been avoiding the game because someone said, 'Oh it's just Minecraft 2D' go ahead and slap them for me. or just buy the game and play it, you'll probably like it quite a bit.

I bought this game years ago. At first I played it for about a month. Stopped playing for no real reason. Picked it up again. Stopped playing. This has gone on to this day! Everytime I go back to this beautiful game I am overwhelmed with how much greatness was created.   Endless playability comes with this outstanding game.  - Dungeons and bosses are fun and challening for new players, and fun and challenging for veterans, like myself.  - Crafting is simple to pick up, and you don't need the wiki to figure out how to build things.  -Thanks to the handy-dandy Alt key you can enter an 'easy build mode,' as I call it, and allows you to build structures in minutes.  - I have close to 180 hours in this game, what more needs to be said?  - The level of customization that is here, for not only houses and playstyles, but outfits and trinkets you can aquire and wear to make your little sprite look snazy while taking down those damned Wyverns to get some Soul of Flight!  Finally, I state it here that this game is so worth your money, and, in my honest opinion, is worth SO much more than a mere $10... Anyone looking to have a game that you can either invest your time into fully, or play for an hour or two then come back later, this game is perfect you... It's actually perfect for everyone! Heck, even little kids will enjoy playing this with their parents and they'll have a great time!

Terraria  is a great open-world, sandbox game. I personally enjoy the pethora of things you can do on  Terraria , ranging from building pixel art, leveling up your characters gear wise, or even exploring the world and mining! When  Terraria  first came out, the crowd said things like 'It's a rip-off of  Minecraft !' I say it's more than that. I think  Terraria  utilizes the good points of  Minecraft  and adds so much more.    Overall:   I'd give it a 8/10. There is so much to the game, but there can be more. Unfortunately the main developer of  Terraria  is stopping the updates on his side, but the other developers are going to continue to work on it!    Controls & Handling:   9/10. The controls are great, easy to pick up, but however it's tedious to jump over and over to get over ledges 2 blocks high. They recently changed the motions to allow your character to walk over 1 block differences, but it doesn't change much. Once you get into late game and   you get wings   it doesn't really matter.    Graphics:   8/10. The graphics are supposed to be two dimensional and blocky, but some times there are graphical glitches and what not. There are a lot of different lighting options for you to choose from, but they are miniscule and are hard to notice.    Storyline:   There is no storyline, so I can't grade this. However there is progress through the game, and there are multiple ways to progress such as fishing, mining, or killing. Usually the fastest way is to do all three.    Music:   7/10. The music ranges from peaceful to pressing and it really sets the mood, however it can be really, really repetitive if you've spent nearly 1000 hours in the game, but that would happen to any kind of music.
