(Please note: This guide was written during Patch 1.2.4; a Patch 1.3 is upcoming)  Terraria is a side-scrolling Retraux game, in which you can do pretty much anything you want.  You're given a pickaxe, an axe, and a shortsword and 'The World is Your Canvas' according to the official slogan. Said slogan is quite accurate; you can take blocks and then place them anywhere you want (there are a few rules, but the game is very generous).  My Ratings for this game:  Graphics: 8.0. The graphics are done in an oldschool 16-bit pixel style. Some people might love this (I do) others might hate it. What it does have, however, is nice bright colors, the items, weapons, terrain, and various artwork is well-done in the style that it was done in, and the game is very realistic about how light behaves.  Sound: 8.0. The game has a good variety of music and in-game sound effects are solid (though I cannot stand the male character's pain noises). There's unique music for most biomes (area types), with the same theme being repeated only for Underworld, Meteorite, and Blood Moon (all three using the same theme, the latter two are somewhat rare).  Story: N/A. There's not really any actual in-game lore or story involved in Terraria. You're dumped on a procedurally-generated world, with meager equipment. The NPCs have little snippets of things they say to you and you find things in the world that allow you to draw your own conclusions. Some people who look for gameplay-heavy games will like this, while others who prefer lots of lore might not. The fact you can fill in the blanks with your own ideas allows you to come up with a story about your own world and your own character, so that could be a plus if you're into that.  Replayability: 9.5. This game highly encourages you to replay it. From the fact you generate procedurally-generated worlds, and the fact that they are still updating the game years later, there are many reasons to start a new character on a new world. Each playthrough is different from the accessories you find to what features your world has, you can always try building a different type of base, you can decide to go magic instead of melee or vice-versa, or perhaps focus on ranged weapons through the playthrough. Always reason to start a new game if you're at the end of your current one. Whenever major updates are released, many new world features are not accessible in previously-made worlds, encouraging you to start yet another world and character.  Gameplay Mechanics: 9.5. The game has very tight controls, your character is very responsive to what you tell it to do, hit detection is very good. The only times I've ever felt that hit detection was off, is when slopes are concerned. Slopes are a somewhat new addition to the game; I wouldn't be surprised if the coming 1.3 update didn't make tweaks to how the game handles sloped surfaces. Otherwise, the gameplay is very solid. I would have to give kudos especially to the attention-to-detail having to do with the liquids which behave very realistically for the most part (liquid graphics are going to get an improvement with the upcoming 1.3 release). Lighting is very well done as well. Some players may find gravity mechanics to be off-putting if they were looking for an ultra-realistic game; gravity does not affect blocks that are 'placed'; you can make things such as houses hovering in midair for example.  Combat Mechanics: 9.0. The game has a robust combat system with a ridiculously varied weapon selection. There are a LOT of weapons in Terraria. Everything from the shortsword you start with, to magic wands, to items that summon minions to fight for you, to laser guns, to machineguns, bows, swords that shoot projectiles, knives you can throw, bombs, rocket launchers, and nearly anything else you could possibly think of -- and more.  Crafting System: 9.0. The game has a very well-tuned crafting system as well! You can make lots of potions that do a large variety of things, anything from combat-oriented things to things that help you build better, to things that help you explore the world better. Whatever you would want to do, there's probably a potion that can help you do it better. Nearly all of your armor is crafted, many weapons can be crafted, building materials and furniture can be crafted, and much more. Crafting is one of the main cornerstones of Terraria. But yet, crafting isn't very grindy and there's no leveling to do. As long as you have the items and the appropriate crafting station (such as anvils for metal objects), you can make the item. No grinding to raise levels required.  Game Balance: 8.0. Overall, the game is mostly balanced well. There are a few fringe examples of things that could use further polish, a couple annoying enemies that I consider to be somewhat overpowered, a few weapons that are probably too powerful for when you get them, some that could be buffed, but these are all minor nitpicks to an otherwise well-done game. The fact that there's an upcoming update means that some of this stuff could very well be fixed soon; the Online Community Forums are very active and the developers are hearing feedback regularly from the players there.  Intuitiveness: 6.0. The game's one flaw, is the lack of early-game help system. The game gives you an NPC right from the start. You can ask this NPC for help but he gives very vague clues as to what you are supposed to actually be doing. He also allows you to show him an item and he will tell you everything that can be crafted from that item (provided what you showed him is a material). Otherwise, the game tells you absolutely nothing. I highly recommend going to the TCF over at  terraria.org  and looking up some guides (shameless plug for my own guide, which you can find there) on how to get started.  Challenge: 7.0. Please note that the developers have announced an upcoming way to tweak challenge in Terraria for Patch 1.3. This was written during 1.2.4. In 1.2.4, the Challenge is somewhere in the middle -- not so easy that you'll breeze through all the bosses on first try, but yet not so ridiculously hard like some of the other NintendoHard games out there. To up the challenge prior to Patch 1.3, you can try turning on MediumCore or Hardcore modes to increase the death penalty, or you can simply choose to use inferior equipment if you are finding things too easy. If things are too hard for you, chances are that you can make it easier with some proper terrain preparation (such as building nice flat places to run around, placing campfires or heart lanterns, making more potions to use, using better accessories, etc). I gave it a 7.0 becuase I felt there could have been another 'challenge mode' but like I said: Patch 1.3 is bringing more challenge options to the game so chances are this will be addressed when that patch arrives.  Multiplayer: 8.0. I've dabbled in this only a bit, but I've heard and read things from other players who say that Terraria's multiplayer works fairly well. Before one of the 1.2 patches, Multiplayer was difficult for some people to host due tohow difficult it was to get the game's client to actually host properly (lots of NAT and port forwarding issues). They have since fixed this, or at least fixed a lot of issues. Prior to the 1.2 patches, I could not host a Terraria game at all despite me attempting to forward the proper ports. It works flawlessly now for me after said patches.  Pricing: 9.0. For $10, this game is a steal already. It frequently goes on sale for $2.49 (and sometimes cheaper!). Even at the original price of $10 I'd highly recommend this game. For $2.49 or $3 or whatever the price is when it is on sale, it is simply a no-brainer if you enjoy sidescrolling games whatsoever. I can't think of any possible reason why someone would Not want to buy this game cheaper than an average lunch.  Overall: 9.0. Great game that I'd recommend to anybody who likes this sort of game.

Terraria is a rare gem among the sea of minecraft clones roaming around the internet, it developed a style on its own that its already being cloned too, the Terraria clones.  Even though it clearly takes many aspects from Minecraft, it adapted them to 2D masterfullly and we are presented with the many possible outcomes from our actions. The player feels like he can change the world and explore it on a Metroidvania style, the player needs to dig deep so he gets new abilites to dig even deeper, finding new challenges and ways to create and develop his world, reaching new challenges and new powers on the progress.  - On character management The ways that characters are not tuned to a world is a cool feature, since the player can join PvP or other servers with an already developed character that doesn't need to go through the basics every single time he joins a server. I, myself, have 2 characters, one for single player games, and one for random multiplayer services, though I'd be able to use my single player character on the multiplayer whenever needed.  - On crafting and player creation The crafting system is really good, you have lots of possibilities (not so many as minecraft) among the insurmountable amount of materials waiting to be discovered, players are able to build freely into the world and reach for the skies or under lava if they want to. Buildings never really feel complete since you'll be discovering dozens of ways of expanding and making them better fitting for your game, you can get new types of blocks, mechanic and electrical connections through your building, defensive measures against waves of invading goblins, armor racks, useful NPCs living with you etc.  - On multiplayer Now, for the bad parts, the multiplayer connections are just through direct IP, just like Minecraft and old games like Starcraft and AoE2 you need your friend's IP so you can play with them, there's no features to create servers inside the game's UI, so you need to do it all manually. This is not so bad since a small team can hardly have budged for a network-guy to manage complicated IP distribution and web connections.  - On advanced aged world The game sometimes feels like 'lacking space', if you play in a world for too long, you feel the world dying around you and non-renewable materials get more scarce, with time, you are obligated to build another world and save your stuff on the character so he can rebuild his life in the new world. This bad point can be a little directed to humanity and our future, but still, it makes the game feel limited at some point through your advancement.  as of my final verdict, I would give it 9/10.

This game has pretty much everything. There are all sorts of enemies, biomes, NPC's, weapons, armor, items... the list goes on. I reccomend this game because there are unlimited possibillities. You can do almost anything. It is the kind of game for many types of people; you can make and find crazy structures, you can purify your world, you can fight bosses, explore dungeons, get to hell and back, and so much more. Plus, the characters can go between worlds. You can even have different hairstyles!   The game is pixelatied and 2-Dimensional, but that only adds to the fun. At night zombies and flying eyeballs come out. In the daytime there are forest critters, bugs, and slimes spawn. The list of biomes is: Forest, Desert, Corruption, Ocean, Jungle, occasionally Crimson, Space, Underground, Cavern, Underworld, Spider Cave, Underground Jungle, Glowing Mushroom. The lis of structures is: Lizhard Temple, Jungle Shrine, Dungeon, Desert Temple, Floating Island House, Underground House. I may have missed a few.  One of my favorite aspects is floating islands. You can find them by building skybridges, drinking Gravitation Potions, or flying. You can mine out cloud blocks to make your own floating islands, and there is cool furniture, banners, blocks, and walls in the house that is built on the island. There are always cool items and weapons in the chests there. You can fight harpies in the air and on floating islands, and you can even fight a Wyvern after you beat the Wall of Flesh.  I highly reccomend Terraria, but only if you have plenty of time on your hands. This game can also easily suck you in, so be aware. Go Terraria!

This game is the epitome of sandbox. Not just in building, but in every aspect. There's nearly a limitless amount of possibilities that can be achieved through Terraria. 'There's something for everybody' is the best way to describe this game. After the initial grind of setting up a character, which is a maximum two hours for a new player, you're able to do whatever you want.   Do you enjoy building things? Creating castles as tall as the skies? Or maybe you'd prefer a bustling modern city. A dwarven cave dwelling with minecarts as transportation? Heck, you can go above and beyong in this and build ANYTHING you wish! Traps for your friends to fall into, a fortress to protect your loot, a magical floating city high in the clouds, where gravity is low and you can feel the cold air of space itself. Even the depths of Hades aren't safe, if you feel yourself the hardened kind to conquer the dangers deep below.  Or maybe you prefer a game that lets you fight, and test your skills! This game offers that to you, from melee, to magic, to ranged. Any play style is accomodated, with an ample variety of weapons and spells. Burn your foes with fire, cut them to pieces with swords, pierce them into a monster shish-ka-bob with spears, or snipe them from afar with bows and guns. With thousands of items in the game, you can gear up to do what you wish. Maybe you'd even prefer to be a jack of all trades? That's always an option as well! Accessories and armor suits help you improve your statistics and build yourself into the perfect soldier.  You'll never feel alone in Terraria either, with plenty of NPCs to keep you company, though you may find yourself questioning their motives and interests. If you ever find them suspicious, though, there's always the option to kill them, too! After all, you bring them into your world, you're completely capable of taking them out of it! Don't let the power get to your head, however, as there's always something ready to stab you in the back.  This game does it all, and there's nothing I find negative about Terraria. The music is splendid, the items are plentiful, and the action is packed.
200+ hours well spent. Highly suggest buying this game

The game is amazing in it's own regard. Comparing it to minecraft however, is not something players of these awesome games shouldn't do. both games are unique in their own regard, and I feel minecraft is simply slower paced, and more relaxing. While Terraria is more action packed, and steeper in terms of options (not counting mods). There are a handful of things that make terraria execptional, and especially fun, while there are a few things that might take away from a perfect 10/10. I give it a 9/10.  Pro's: The game is especially fun for new players who have large amounts of gameplay to explore. Fun for replaying, since some things are only available on seperate maps. Gives you a chance to create lots of awesome things! Houses, castles, and challenges for friends! Multiplayer is awesome!  Cons: Once you played it a really long time, you tend to know what is really good and tend to avoid even farming or looking for some items, since they can be skipped with itnent of getting the better ones. (Makes for less intense gameplay, or rather- less grinding, which was partly the fun of the first few playthroughs). If you can't stand grinding, don't play this, since grinding is a part of the fun! (Spending hours underground is normal, right?) There are soemtimes too many options item wise, and I often find items and think, (Man, if only I had this before....)  Notes: (Spoilers)   I wish there were attribute stats, levels, or something like this. But although these things are not in the original game, there are mods for these.

Yes, it's kind of like Minecraft. In my opinion, though, it's better than Minecraft in many ways. 2D perspective makes exploration less frustrating - your base is in 1 of 2 directions at all times. Combat is a lot more interesting - mostly because of items. More of an RPG feel, progression-wise. Bosses also make combat less repetitive. The Ender Dragon can't measure up to the Wall of Flesh or Plantera. Building possibilities are restricted because of the 2D, but this makes it easier for people (e.g. me) who are terrible at Minecraft architecture. Mod support isn't nearly as extensive, but it's a more complete game for non-modders. Potentially hundreds of hours worth of gameplay. Highly reccomend.

ike minecraft, if minecraft was a game... or good  Terraria did not stop at simply crafting and building, it has a proper combat systems too. When you've got your sword swinging, it plays much like a clunky-er Ghouls n’ Ghosts as you defend yourself from one-eye freaks, and Jell-O-blobs, that lurk about the night you reap their spoils. Those spoils allow you to craft better stuff. Things like armor, weapons, furnishings, tools, etc. Combat remains to be Terraria’s stand-out trait from the competition, giving the player more vibes of action-adventure RPGs than any other genre-heavyweight I’ve played.  It’s no lie this game is systems-heavy, so if you enjoy bouncing between complex systems Terraria has you covered. The joy of this genre is exploring, uncovering secrets, and discovering systems you never expected to exist and as such it’s a disservice to the product to overly explain everything it has to offer. But, what is safe to say, is that the game will constantly surprise you as you delve deeper into what is possible both with building and exploring. Of particular note is your buildings actually serve a purpose to house NPC's, rather than just being yet another abandoned wizard tower in your Minecraft world, and much, much more. Yet, with all this praise, Terraria still has a lump to complain about. Surprisingly enough, it’s not in the control department either. The virtual controls worked perfectly fine for me, after a bit of practice, with little to no hiccups.  Fun as ♥♥♥♥ to play with friends.

As a guy who completed the original Terraria and is still chiseling away at the latest update, I can guarantee you that any fan of either the platformer genre or the sandbox genre will not be disappointed in this title.  Terraria, in a nutshell, has been compared by many to Minecraft meets Mario, and they're not wrong to make that comparison. While both games have had different origins, playerbases, and different update rates (Minecraft being the most dedicated, while the MASSIVE and thankfully so update for Terraria was more of an afterthought after years of abandonment), they both inherently have that sandboxy voxel feel; the kind you get when playing a game of Legos.  Thankfully, that's where the similarity ends, or else this game would not have been as successful as it is now, and I wouldn't have bothered either getting it or making this review. Where Minecraft has immense modding potential, Terraria has a load of the variety in gameplay that I crave right out of the box. Where Minecraft has just one kind of zombie, Terraria has several variations of the same, including ones I've aptly named the Baldhead, the Slimeface, the Pincushion, and the Raincoat just to name a few. Where Minecraft has several small updates that add various new content that many will love and several will question (1.8 adding banners, sea ruins, and new water mobs, and many questining what purpose banners will provide to the regular sandbox), Terraria's rare updates are immense, massive, and add so much new stuff that it's literally like a whole new game, to coin the term.  Granted, Terraria's not better than Minecraft; both games hold their own with ease. Minecraft is easily moddable, 3D, and has a massive community with many, many, many adventure maps to their name, while Terraria restricts you to a flat horrizontal by vertical plane and its developers sort of gave up on it up until the very latest update, and something tells me we won't be seeing another update anytime in the next year or so. But Terraria is definitely worth the buy, and well worth the price. You'd be having a load of fun playing this game either by yourself or with friends, and that's guaranteed.  Pros:  + 2D sandbox that holds its own + Fun gameplay that while not necessarily innovative definitely holds out on its own + Many great environments both above and below ground to have fun with + The latest update added a TON of new stuff, adding a lot more replayability especially if you played the original  Cons:  - Not as popular as other sandboxes like Minecraft - There isn't a whole lot of modding content or adventure maps - The developers aren't nearly as dedicated, which was why the last update came to us all by surprise  Do I recommend it? Yes I do  -Kerian

Did you play Minecraft for a while and say, 'This is a great sandbox and all, but I want a world that will satisfy my desire for fantastic adventures; full of monsters, magic, and loot.'?  Terraria is the sandbox for you then, unlike Minecraft, adventuring has a larger role in Terraria. Featuring an array of weapons, gadgets, and materials that are oriented around a fantasy adventure. For example, the luxurious Mahogany wood can only be harvested in the Jungle, where unique monsters thrive, and in order to get at the riches of the Dungeon, you must prove yourself by beating a monsterous boss enemy.  So if you want a building sandbox to play with friends, but want the thrill of defeating mosters to supplement your base building, Terraria is your go-to game.

Terraria is a 2d Platformer sandbox game with RPG elements, you dig, you craft, you fight and you die. (and you will die too at the very beginning as it's kind of difficult for beginners.)  The game comes equiped with a full day and night cycle and fully destroyable enviroments. There are bosses in the game that are pretty cool indeed. The game has a really cool artwork(I'm very fond of it).  There is armor in the game aswell as weapons: Bows, Swords, Spears, Machine-guns, Sniperrifles, Rocket launchers, and Magic weapons (like Things that richet off walls)  The game is very number based as new weapons will do lower/higher Ratios  It has a Armor system and a Vanty system so you can truly customize your character by putting your favorite Armorover the Armor that is better. You create your character when you start too, Though it is very limited as the game is very pixely. Keep in mind that the game was made by like 4 people.(Don't quote me on that) The game has an normal mode and a hard mode after you kill the final Normal boss I.e The Wall of Flesh* The game Enters hard mode where pretty much everymonster has been modified, Upgraded or replaced with harder enemys.(Including the bosses)  This game has 13 bosses so far and is about to have a 14th one there is 100's of hours here and my only thing I dislike is how the corrupition(Just go look up terraria for this) Spreads in hard mode and covers your Buildings and world like a freaking Ant bed... But it's not game breaking and I wholeheartly recommend this game to anyone.  P.S Sorry for bad English :P

Terraria is by far one of my favourite games. A lot of people may consider Terraria a cheap rip-off of Minecraft, but they are wrong. Minecraft is a building game with RPG elements thrown in, were as Terraria is an RPG game with building thrown in. Terraria stars off a little slow, without giving you much direction (the guide helps, but he has his limits) but it picks up in pace. Its boss fights are filled with wonderful music and lights, the enemy’s all feel new and unique, and seeing what was once a little wooden shack turn into a small town really gives one a feeling of accomplishment. Once hard mode starts, the game really picks up in pace and that’s when the fun begins. My only problem is you basic need the games Wiki up at all times. The guide helps, but he cant tell you everything. All in all, I have to give this amazing wonder a 9/10

My first thought was, that this game looks a lot like Minecraft, as a 2D platformer though. Just like in Minecraft you have almost unlimited possibilities, and the great addition which kinda remains (remained until a recent patch) in Minecraft, is a sort of storyline, where you get access to the better materials, as you advance in health as well as mana and strength of your weapons. The NPC's and the money system adds a whole new aspect, and the various kinds of crafting makes this game unique, while the huge amount of different materials in the game, leaves it with a lot more entertainment than the popular 3D-version of this game. This game deserves 8.5/10 stars. The remaining stars are for the lack of originality and the fact that they have stopped patching the game. However I still recommend you buying this, even though you got Minecraft and think you'll prefer that at any time, you'll think twice about that!

A great game to play with a bunch of friends, or by yourself.  I realise that to a lot of people, at first glance, this looks like a 2D ripoff of minecraft. This is not at all true, as this game has a totally different focus, much less based arround building, and much more along the lines of combat and exploration.  The sheer number of enemies to face is pretty impressive, there are a nice selection of bosses, with gradually increasing difficulty, and a huge variety of environments to fight them in. There is also a wide selection of items, armour / weapons / trinkets / etc. to help you in your task.  There's also a huge selection of building materials and items, which allows for a pretty huge range of ideas to be built.  Overall, definitely a game I would highly recommend, it's very cheap, and if you're a trader, it shouldn't be too hard to get yourself a copy of this for a single key!

'Ay is jus a chep rip-of miencwarf'  Ha.  Haha.  No.  Terraria is a 2D blocky sandbox game with a randomly generated (but not infinite) world that has lots of stuff in it, you get wood, you mine stone, you make a workbench, you make wood armor and weapons, you mine iron or something else, you make a furnace, you know, your usual thing, but holy crap does this game have more than that.  I'm not going to go too deep into gameplay because it will be pretty obvious as soon as you start the game, but, I'm going to tell you a story about how I first beat The Eye of Cthulu.  It was the middle of the day, I was playing Terraria, alone, having only recently gotten a stronger long-range weapon (A Handgun) some decent armor and a few health upgrades, I was feeling confident in myself, and I hoped that I wouldn't get completely destroyed.  So I grabbed the boss summon thing out of the chest and waited a bit for night to fall...I summoned the Eye of Cthulu.  I was so damn focused, my hands were shaking like crazy due to the twitch-based movements I had to make so I could jump without getting hit, I kept shooting and shooting and shooting, only stopping to heal for a half a second and then continue shooting, the boss was low on health, 40-60 HP remaining, I ran out of ammo, and I had only one potion left, I healed, and went absolutely ballistic, I killed the damn thing with only 10 HP left, I felt like a god.  I went on a online server later and got my ♥♥♥ kicked by dudes with Hardmode gear, 9/10.

Soooo, this game... I bought it for like 5 buck's expecting not too much from it, thinking it was some kind of 2D minecraft ripoff. Well it's NOT, yes capital letters NOT.  I've put over threehundred hours in it. The game feels smooth and finished (like any game should feel). The game has a learning curve (and because of insufficient experience in games with steep learning curves I'm gonna say it's average). I spend a lot of time on the wiki to find out what to do next to progress. Sometimes a boss was too hard (or I was too bad who can tell).  This made the game very interesting to me, because bosses are supposed to be hard. The game has found a good balance between difficulty and anxiety (in my opinion). A lot (a ton, a huge amount wichever you perfer) of items are ready to be crafted or collected by you (some require grinding but it has always been worth it for me). In some cases this game can be pretty grindy, I once spend about 30 minutes for one item I needed to craft something. This was not my favourite moment in the game, but the soothing melody in the background pulled me through. Now I mentioned it, The background music is dynamic and always appropriate to the location.  The bosses sometimes have some funny lore which is always a good thing (found on the google/mozilla/opera, yes keep an internet tab open cuz you are goin' to need it). There are about 20 bosses (hmm, twenty felt like more). But since i'm new to the whole review thing, I'm gonna end it here though I feel like I still need to say more. I pretty much finished the game (about three times now). Just two more things to go and I'll be done with it... feels odd though, leaving it. The game kinda... kinda...  CONSUMED MY SOUL...  Just kidding of course, but if this kind of game is even remotely your thing you should really pick it up. It's a steal at it's price. I never really play multiplayer (tried it once and a few times with friends), but it was fun with friends.   Well thanks for reading my review, hope you liked it. (and of course helped you make a decision, that is probably why you red it in the first place.... right?) :)  Have a splendid day, CoreZebra

Kicks A**  I've been playing this game over the past week (not on steam though) I figured this game is WELL worth the money. There's much to do, and it's like everytime you think you've found everything... NOPE! there's something else brand new you havent seen yet. There are bosses that you can summon (Except one that i've seen that will summon itself after your stats are high enough) that drop some pretty good stuff. not to mention there's a massive boss too. I won't spoil too much but first thing you would want to do is give the guide you start off with a shelter so he can be safe. Go mining to get materials for better weapons and items. Make sure you check what the Guide has to say before looking everything up on the internet, he can help you out quite a bit, though sometimes you'd wind up looking info online. the Crafting help is pretty important too for upgrading your gear. It's even better on multiplayer too since the Co op is a blast. It is often comparable to minecraft (It's similar, not the same) it's different enough to be it's own. It's worth checking out. trust me.

Remember when the Wall of Flesh was the final boss?   This game has grown so much with so many new weapons and ways to play the game. The building options let you craft very complex buildings and fun projects that are either just recreating video game sprites or creating entire murals with the materials you can get from the world. There are so many enemies that come at you in swarms, and some bosses even produce more enemies to come after you! There are so many options for weapons/tools/play styles like being a long ranged gunman, a close ranged tank with incredibly strong melee, a magic user who can rip apart enemies with strange powers, and a summoner who can bring other monsters to fight for you and even distract enemies so you can take them out with no problem! It's so much fun!  It was so much fun to play the game with friends but in the past the only way to join friends was through a peer to peer program or having someone shell out money for a 24/7 server. Now that downside is literally gone because you can now join people's games through Steam! It's got so much to show, and offer, and secrets.   There's so much to explore and I have fought many of the games hardest bosses, but I have yet to find the enchanted sword hidden in the game world.   I recommend this game highly! If everything I told you about does not interest you, you can catch bugs and fish! Hooray!

Great game that has a lot more than initially meets the eye. The first time you start playing it might seem slow, but give it time. Once you start learning the ropes and learning how to upgrade and progress, the game is hard to put down. Finding all the cool things you can defeat, craft, or collect is just one of the many features this game has to offer. Even better experience when you bring friends. If you like upgrading your character from a wimp to a god, defeating bosses, exploring a sandbox world, building homes and shelters, fishing, riding unicorns, shooting rainbows, summoning dragons, casting spells, shooting arrows, firing guns, or flying high in the sky with wings upon your back in a 2D, 8-bit environment, this game might interest you.

Not for everyone, but fun for those who don't mind some grinding/constant difficulty spikes.  Terraria, to me, is a mixed bag. There's fun to be had in exploring, and unlocking new items/armors/beating the bosses. But Terraria also suffers from only a limited amount of building options. Sure, you can build a bunch of buildings, but they're all going to be rectangles, squares, and various oblong shapes.  The real pain is the switch from the starting difficulty to 'Hardmode', which happens after a specific boss is defeated. EVERYTHING gets stronger, and monsters WILL kill you, even if you have the best pre-hardmode armor.  Between each boss victory is the grinding of materials and weapons for the next boss, which are only unlocked by beating each prior boss. So there's also a constant grind for new items.  It's fun, but that grind for materials and weapons isn't for everyone.

Honestly, it competes with games Like Megaman X for being my favorite game of all time. It is so good that I can't even describe how awesome it is without writing a friggin' masters thesis on it. I'll try to keep it short and to the point.  Start a character, start a generated world, mine generated ore, find generated treasures, survive whatever the night throws at you, and build build build!  Whenever you seem satisfied with your caharcter and world combination, start over again! One of the BEST features of this game are that you can transfer your character inbetween worlds.. so share your equipment and items between worlds as well.  Bosses are what balance the game. If you can't defeat a certain boss, you cant progress into certain areas and evolve your world any further. Prepare!  For newcomers, it might seem tough and confusing at first, but make a few worlds and play to your liking. Hopefully you can find a Magic Mirror and a few +4 Defense accessory equipment for the first few bosses and goblin army.  Some other notes for newbies: (I know that this doesnt belong here but I'm not going to write a guide) - Play the tutorial! It only lasts 5 minutes or so, and it teaches you some very important aspects, like making proper houses for merchants and other NPC's.  - Harvest Mushrooms and Daybloom Immediately!!! They make important battle potions like Ironskin potion (+8 Defense) and Health regeneration potion.  - Use the Guide (In-game NPC), he's spawns right beside you when you start a new world. You can show him any item and he will show you what it can be crafted with, and crafted for.  - Defeat bosses multiple times. They drop very useful ores and weapons, as well as some fancy vanity equipment.  - Don't rush to 'Hard-Mode.' make it easier to get around your world with either teleporters, super highways, and/or tunnels and elevators with proper landings. Placing campfires and heart lanterns around custom made boss arenas, the jungle, and the dungeon will make it a lot easier when it has morphed into a hell realm.  I could go on and give some more tips, but a lof of Terraria should be about discovery.  It's too bad that looking up a few things online is essential to know everything about the game.  I have a few peeves about Terraria, but they are very minimal and don't change my opinion of the game at all. As I said in my first sentence of all of this, Terraria battles a few other games in my opinion of possibly my favorite game of all time. I recommend it to anyone who has the slighest knack for videogames.  ENJOY!

This is a lengthy review, so heads up.   You've probably heard that Terraria is like Minecraft, except it's a little different and it's 2D. If you haven't, there's good reason for people to say that. Terraria is, indeed, not your typical block-based builder. While it DOES share some of their traits - such as the need to mine, smelt, craft, and whatnot - it manages to less emphasis on this and more emphasis on building. It does this with its unique side-scroller perspective (think 2D but with backgrounds).  Terraria has a goal, but not necessarily an 'ultimate goal' or a game-ending objective. That goal is to craft your world to your likings with what you find in it, whether it's the bones from your enemies, golden bricks from the caverns below, or simple wooden houses. Terraria is a mix of Minecraft mechanics and typical RPGs. Speaking of such...  Terraria has some basic RPG elements in it as well. Scattered throughout the world, there are items that increase your basic resources, health and mana, that come in handy when fighting terraria's some 10+ bosses. Additionally, there is the option to craft unique armors, each with their own boons and benefits, and weapons that range from a wooden bow to a minigun made out of shark fins to the legendary sword Excalibur. There are even quests to partake in, which result in helpful rewards.  Then there's the aspect of creating your own little 'civilization.' As you progress in the game, you may find that you require tools or weapons to help you complete your projects. As you build on to your home, NPCs may move in, offering their services to you in exchange for a place to live and a fee (which varies... greatly). Demolitions experts, arms dealers, nurses, steampunkers, and even witch doctors are just some of the NPCs that you may eventually house.  VERDICT: Terraria is a great time killer. If you want to play a game that has a lot of heart, or perhaps you just want to build a tower made out of cactus, fire, and glass without the worries of impending doom, Terraria is just the game for you.  10/10 Would get crushed by a boulder again.

Terraria can be an exciting adventure, or a rewarding building experience. Strting from the bottom, you are a tiny entity in a large and dangerous world with diverse enemies and ever encroaching threats. You work to strengthen yourself by acquiring strong weapons, good armor, a community that can provide services, and fantastical items that provide greater control over the world around you. ANd then, when you have grown enough, it becomes more about fending off dark influence that spread through the very essense of the world. It is a unique game that, though it shares many similar mechanics as Minecraft, is very unique in it's in depth gameplay.  It is an adventure that one simply must experience for themselves, and then experience it with their friends at their side.

But dig deeper, and you will go where no one has gone before.....

This is a game worth buying even at full price.   I only bought Terraria because a friend recommended it and I didn't expect to play it much beyond our co-op sessions, but even now I can't stop playing. The gameplay is deceptively simple, under which a surprisingly complex and engaging boss and gear progression system hide. I have found myself making new characters just so I can enjoy that progession again and again. You move from a horribly vulnerable character to an unstoppable killing machine in small increments that make it hard to realize just how powerful you are becoming.  The true beauty of this game is uncovered when playing with friends. Having other people to play with can make those earlier, slower nights much more fun. Getting a group together to build awesome creations or try to speed run the moon lord is endlessly entertaining. PVP is also a great way to pass the time.  It's simple enough where it can entertain people who have little interest or experience in video games whille still being fun for the hardcore gamers. It introduces new mechanics slowly so as to not be overwhelming. Each boss acts as a good skills check, as they are a decent challenge to even those who are adequately geared as the battles do require a good amount of tactic to win. While in the late game raw power can overcome many obstacles, most of the game does require you to play smart. The game also contains a fairly fulfilling potion/alchemy system which can be completely ignored if that's not your play style. The item crafting is exceptionally fun as most items you pick up can be crafted with something else, combining their powers and some items have rather extensive crafting trees that might as well be side quests (I'm looking at you Cell Phone).  It's worth every penny and if you don't have any friends who have it, pick up the 4 pack and gift some copies as it's definitely worth sharing the fun.

Too often I see Terraria dismissed as '2D Minecraft'. In fairness, it starts very similarly. You start by chopping down trees (though with an axe. What kind of idiot chops down a tree with their fist?) and building a wooden house to protect yourself from zombies at night. However, Terraria quickly distinguishes itself from Minecraft, mainly due to the gameplay.  Terraria, like Minecraft, is a sandbox adventure game. You collect items to craft new items, and to protect yourself from the monsters roaming the world. Mining plays an important part as well, most ores and enemies are found below the surface of the world. However, while Minecraft is a much more creative focused game, Terraria focuses on the adventure element.  For example, there are 4 main types of weapon in the game: Melee, Ranged, Magic and Summons. Each of these has several different weapons of varying styles. For example, the Ranged class contains both Bows and Guns, as well as a few other unique weapons. Each weapon may have an effect, such as the Molten Fury, a bow that turns your arrows into Flaming Arrows. Want to shoot flaming arrows with other bows? No worries, you can craft Flaming arrows separately. What's more, certain armour sets can boost certain weapon types, and later in the game, you get armour sets with 3 different head pieces to boost different weapons. You can also reforge your weapons and accessories (which are also plentiful in number and variety) for better buffs, or sometimes even combine them to get better weapons or accessories altogether.  But this weapon system would be useless without an array of enemies to fight, and Terraria has them in spades. Throughout the world, there are many biomes, ranging from the simple Forest biome, to the Dungeon, to the Underground Corruption, to Hell itself. Each biome, as well as having it's own blocks and materials, has its own unique set of enemies. Some biomes are tougher than others, such as the Corruption vs the Forest, or Hell vs the Dungeon. And it is all to easy to die. But the game never feels unfair. If you die, it's because you ventured into an area you weren't ready for, or you didn't pay attention to an enemy, or you simply got cocky. And despite constantly upgrading your equipment, there will always be a new set of enemies in the next biome to push you to your limits.  You never feel without direction either. You start with a single NPC - the Guide. He is invaluable to newer plyaers, as not only does he give you advice on what to do next, but also can show you what you can craft with materials, and what you need to craft with it. Crafting is also very simple. When you open up your inventory, your crafing menu also appears alongside it. Your crafting menu shows what you can craft at thie current time. Simply click on an item to craft it. If you need to use a specific crafting station, all you have to do is stand by it, and the additional crafting recipes will appear.  There are other NPCs you can get aside from the Guide, such as a MErchant, and Arms Dealer, a Demolitionist - and those are just the start of many, many NPCs who will come to your base. All you have to do is prepare a room for them, and fulfil their conditions. They're pretty simple, and for the most part you'll just get them by playing the game. For example, to get the Arms Dealer to appear, you first have to find a gun. What's more, the NPCs can sell different things at different times.  That's another thing Terraria has - time and events. Whilst the progression of the day is nothing spectacular, Terraria has a load of random (or triggered) events that can challenge you if you're not prepared. Such things include the Blood Moon, which causes Zombies to be able to break your doors, or the Goblin Invasion - that one speaks for itself. Several of these events have unique drops from enemies, or other effects in the world.  The bosses are also all epic. Even the first one, which you'll likely encounter randomly, is a sight to behold (fans of the game will aprecciate the pun there). They're all a challenge when you first encounter them in a playthrough, and will have to be refought several times if you want those rare drops. Most of the drops from bosses aren't TOO rare though, that would be cruel. And their music... oh their music is sublime!  In fact, all the music is. It's superb, spectacular! It flows seamlessly from one biome to the next, from a calm forest background music to the tense chords of a boss theme. It's all epic.  And all of your work pays off in the creative department. So many blocks, most of which can be fashioned into background walls, and many havig a furiture set. There's wooden, honey, steampunk, cactus, flesh, gothic... the list goes on. You can place mechanisms in your creations too, with the 3-colour wiring system.  This does bring me to some of the negatives though. First up, the wiring system is not as flexible as Minecraft's, and no way to move blocks with mechanisms. You can 'actuate' them, putting into and out of the background, but that's it. You can also teleport NPCs and mobs around using teleporters, but again, not blocks.  It can also be hard to find specific materials sometimes. Even in a small world, where the materials are in lower quantities but higher conecntrations, it can be difficult to find what you need. That's not to mention how you need at least 2 worlds to find all the ores and unique biome materials.  Farming mobs and bosses is also practically required to get rare drops, particularly if you're going for specific classes. For example, the eaarliest Summoner weapon is the Slime staff, which you get by defeating slimes. However, the staff has a drop rate of 1/10000. Even with an AFK farm, it can take up to half an hour to get. And if you have to farm a boss for a rare item, it can get tedious, particularly since you'll have to farm for the materials to get the boss summoning items.  It can also be difficult for a complete beginner to know how to do things and what's dangerous, since aside from the guide's general advice, there are no in-game instructions, and while basic control is simple, things like opening the housing menu are a bit cryptic to newer players.  That being said, the pros WAY outnumber the cons of this game. In fact, several of the cons are going to be removed in the next update, such as being able to select items that you don't want to deposti in chests with the deposit all command, or being able to use items in chest for crafting - or most importantly of all: Steam integration!  My advice is: get this game, play this game, then play it several more times. It may have one less physical dimension than Minecraft, but it's gameplay has several more to make up for it.

This is a fantastic online multiplayer RPG sandbox game. You get to create and explore as you dig, fight, build, craft and play online (or alone) as you upgrade your own or other's worlds.  This is how the game starts. Before you even start playing, you have to create your character. There are many styles of hair and you can have a custom color for any part of your body. You start out as a person with nothing but a pickax, short sword, an ax, and the clothes on your back. You begin attempting to survive. It is necessary to begin collecting resources to begin crafting tools and building your shelter. As the game progresses you keep upgrading your pick to get better ores. Eventually you can start building houses for NPCs.  When you complete certain tasks certain NPCs will start moving in to houses you have built. Each one has a different services. For example the Demolitionist would sell explosives and materials needed to make explosives, or the Hair Stylist can change your hair. This can be a pain building their houses within the requirements and waiting for them to come.  There is a second half to the game. This is called hardmode. Hardmode is activated in a world when you defeat (arguably) the hardest boss before hardmode - The Wall of Flesh. This is when new ores spawn into your world. New enemies come to life. The Hallow appears and the dungeon gets new loot. It's almost really like starting the second game.  This game is even more fun is you play it with friends. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a crafting-building-fighting-mining sort of game, which's fun multiplies with friends.  Final Rating: 9.8/10

Terraria-  Terraria is a 2D Steam sandbox game that can be purchased and played on PC, Mobile, Ps3/Ps4 & Xbox360/XboxOne.  Now I’ll start my review off with the first time I played, I remember building a box house and I couldn’t work out how to get the NPCs inside the house, Later on I realised there was no walls & no chair, so I added them in and still it wouldn’t let me add NPCs into the home, I ended up getting frustrated and so I left the game and didn’t play for the rest of the day- The end P.S I figured later on the house was too small.  I also remember my first time going onto a server. I was stuck and couldn’t work out how to speak I was trying to ask but I ended up looking on Google, That was the noobest thing I probably ever done…  Me and my friends also put Terraria on the School computers and play it together so we can be entertained during recess and lunch, lol. Just to clarify we don’t hand out terraria to other students as I tell them that I don’t want to rip Re-logic off.  Terraria is a game where the world is your canvas and you can create anything you want, such as Houses, hotels, carrots, mines, tree houses & Whatever you can imagine. Although it is hard to build great stuff it’s still fun exploring, digging and killing some of the plenty of mobs the game provides.  I have heard this game is getting a major update soon and the update will add plenty more exciting things for your 2D character to do.  I do have one downer for the amazing game- When you try to communicate with devs they completely ignore you, now this may be due to the fact that most people are asking for release date. If any of the Terraria Devs see this review please contact as I have serious ideas and things you could add into the game, not peasant & petty ideas and I do not take rejection emotion ever so feel free to turn me down. Thanks for reading my review for terraria and I hope it helped you.  10/10

Playing this from a single player perspective it's not a bad game at all. There is plenty to do and a lot to see. The game is like most crafters in that you make tools to get to the next tier to tools to get to the next yadda yadda ya, but Terraria focuses more on combat than just hunting for ore. For example every single 'boss' in the game drops special things you either need to move up a tier or just some really cool gear both cosmetic and not. For example you need to kill the boss of the 'evil zone' (there are 2 different ones you get one randomly on world generation) to get the goods needed to smash altars to progress the game. you can also collect throphies and banners as rare drops to show your dominion over the mobs. You can really relax and explore the world, gaining townspeople and making your home look fancy and have a good time for the genrally low price since this is on sale all the time   the negatives  This game is in some ways a 2d knock-off of minecraft which is evident in it's emphasis on gather ores and the like, it's block-based building and the crafting using workbenches however the thing that turns most people i talk to about is the music. the music is very hit and miss, while some love it some find it grating on the ears. Along with all of this some actions in the game are LOUD i had to mute the game because putting down minecart railing was so loud it was playing over my headphones and into my mic across the skype call. Oh and of course the game has zombies which is pretty generic

I wish I could fill a fishtank with zombie heads then sit in a lounge chair drinking bourbon while one of my (zombie) kids plays with her food (a bowl of fingers). Except in this game there is no feature for that, so I think that needs to be added.  There are a few things this game needs in terms of getting up to speed with the whole post modern fiasco we find ourselves in because of right wing conservativism having such an iron grip on our day to day lives...... There should also be a safe place where you can go in the game to talk about your feelings without it seeming like the Ice Eskimos are laughing at you. It gets cold in the snow biome, and just having a secure place to vent would be a great way for the developers to express that they are not only interested in their customers, but accomodating to their 21st century ego driven needs.  Not to mention the lizard people. When I was playing this game suddenly lizard people came running out of this hole in the ground like the Dulce Base and I'm suddenly Phil Schnieder but instead of a nine millimeter and a head full of geology information I have a sword made out of meterorites and less than half of all my hearts. In case you're lost this basically means I'm ♥♥♥♥ed unless I get saved by some macho civilian contractor with an assault rifle. That didn't happen. I died, and I lost my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gold and had to go all the way back there to get it. Eventually I just ALT+F4d my whole afternoon away and went to have breakfast.  so all in all this game is pretty good. i recommend it if you have time to REALLY devote because honestly I walked around with a wooden sword chopping at bugs for about 15 hours before I realized I could build a better sword.  P.S. this is a crafting voxel game.... hope you like material collecting because that's how you lose 282 hours of your life if you're not careful.

Too-lazy-didn't-read? Overwhelmingly positive (as of this time), cheap during sales, lots of content (building, combat, crafting). Just. Get it.  Terraria is one of those games that you can easily get in to. It's very casual but you can easily sink in a huge amount of time (for its money) due to the large amount of content and the ability to let your creativity roam free. Just remember that there really isn't any particular tutorial or guide/indicator on the amount of content, so you may need to look-up some wiki on the internet. Looking up some online guide shouldn't be particularly a problem as this game is great to be played in non-full screen mode and you can easily keep a browser open next to the game-window. So, what can you do in this game?In Terraria, the emphasis is laid on crafting, terra forming and boss monsters. The re are a lot of items to craft (and spend time to discover). You can alter the landscape rather drastically as the entire world is made up of removable objects and you can fill it in however you want. You can build using a large variety of blocks/furniture. The combat in itself is rather simple, but there are a huge variety of different effects from multiple weapons and their types (spells, swords, grenades etc) and each boss monster has an own attack pattern and several other gimmicks which makes it feel less repetitive. If you are the kind of person who wants to quickly complete the game by killing all boss monsters, then you will probably still spend a day or so to do this, which is great. If you are the kind of person who wants to casually stroll along, play a little bit, build a bit and kill boss monsters whenever you feel bored, you will find yourself spending a lot of hours in this game. There are also random events throughout the game, which either ends up in you fighting large hordes of monsters or allows you to mine special stuff. After spending more than 100 hour in it, I still find myself occasionally coming back to finish a building project I was doing or to do another playthrough through the boss monsters. So yea, its recommended.

Minecraft or Terraria?   If you were to ask me this, I would 100% say Terraria, and this is why.  The variety in Terraria alone is awesome. There are so many different items to use to craft with, so many items to craft, and so much to explore. Not only is there a vast ammount of items, but the items themself have such awesome unique abilities on certain ones that really make the game have it's own unique awesomeness. For instance, finding a pair of boots that make you fly into the sky, finding an item that helps you scale walls easier, and armor that regenerates your life quicker.   Not only items, but bosses. There is quiet a good variety of bosses in this game as well. For the first time playing, it's incredible to discover everything that this game has to offer. The reactions to the world as you start to effect it by your actions are also very interesting. Including events that randomly happen, such as goblin army attacks. Terraria literally makes you feel like this is a real living world.  I also like the simple touches, like how you can create your own character, and take it's items anywhere you want. The feel of being able to do all of this in a 2d platforming style is 75% the reason why I love the game the most though.  If you are hesitant at all on this game, don't be. There is literally always something to keep you interested to play. The initial price of 9.99 is purely worth it. If you see the game on sale any lesser, then please do yourself a favor and buy it.

Really good game, especially if you have a friend or two who want to waste a lot of time. I only have two complaints;   1) When youre trying to fight the controls arent responsive enough. It might be on purpose but you (maybe just me) simply can't switch weapons fluidly.  Example: I was clearing wall (using a hammer) to see if it kept spiders from getting to you (it, in fact, does not). Got jumped by an enchanted sword and a zombie skeleton. My hammer is like the 4th tier so it isn't even remotely capable of hurting hard mode enemies. Literally spamming 1 for the first couple of seconds to switch to my gun. No go. Perhaps I'm out of ammo, I thought. Start spamming 4 for my sword but I'm still just using the hammer. Maybe I should learn to use the mouse scroll but I feel that when I hit the key that is assigned to a certain tool the game should switch.   2) When you are at base you can be harrassed by enemies. Inventory management is a huge part of this game and it's not a hassle-- when you aren't being attacked. I had based during a goblin invasion after collecting the hell ore (hellstone maybe?) and was preparing to make stuff at base.. but I couldn;'t because these godamned goblin sorcerers teleport to you and shoot you through the wall. Annoying as that is, you can't stop them until you defeat the army. I was the only one at base at the time so I had to deal with them, returning below surface wasn't an option because I had a full inventory that I could not sort due to through the wall harass. I suppose I could quick dump into a chest but at the time none of my chests were empty and I am loathe to mix up chest categories.  regardless, i've spent probably 75% of the last 3 days playing this game and it has been a really fun and incredibly frustrating experience. (frustrating in the way that difficult and slightly unfair games are)  If Terarria even looks remotely appealing to you then you should probably try it.  Oh, synopsis of the game.. mine stuff, kill stuff, collect stuff, craft stuff- do stuff to spawn bosses and whatnot.  **3) Why can't the developers just make it so that you can place blocks as fast as you can run? (like when making a bridge)

I bought this game for 2 $ and have spent more time in Terraria than any other game I've ever played. It has similar mechanics like Minecraft (or Starbound) but for me Terraria has that funny aspect. First items are standard swords, bows, and so on, but as you discover more and more you find some flying mounts, combat and non combat pets, magic weapons and lots and lots of accessories. There are several bioms in the game and after you kill a boss (Wall of Flesh in Underworld) all the bioms change as Hardmode has begun. Lots and lots of content, and devs update the game bringing you content that they easily could have sold as DLC. Highly recomended. One of the best games I've ever played.

I dont know what i can say that hasn't already been said. This is easily my favorite game on steam, possibly my most played although i'd have to check my other playtimes. I adore exploring the world, fighting everything possible and recruiting NPC's to buy and sell things to and from.  Recently ive been playing on a server and its great to log on after some time away from it and see how far your friends have advanced, or what theyve built. It's normally things i'd never have thought of or just something built with one of the hundreds of blocks I've never thought of building with. Coming back to finding a house made of honey you can barely walk through is seriously great. The combat feels balanced to me, although im not great at fighting things. There's a massive amount of weapons for the combat type you want to use. Swords, boomerangs, bows, shuriken, muskets, pistols, staves, books and so many more. My personal favorite is summoning weapons that spawn helpful minions. The boss fights are tough but not unfair and are able to be progressed at your own pace or not at all. This can help you gain more helpful NPC's or better equipment. It's a great idea to look up the wiki on the game if you don't understand something as it can be very complex to summon a boss more than once or to figure out how an NPC spawns. Simply put I've bought this game at least 12 times, although I'd estimate I've actually bought it 20 times and would happily buy it again. A great game and if its on sale its a massive bargain as i consider it cheap at its full price for the amount of time I've put into it.  A definite good buy.

Don't let the 'simple' graphics and the obvious catchphrase 'Minecraft in 2D' fool you. Terraria is its very own thing, a genre-blend with a ton of content, and a surprisingly deep and challenging game.  Stranded on an island floating in an endless ocean, you're... well, free to do whatever you like. Terraria is a sandbox game, and no matter what you're looking for, chances are you'll find it here. There's combat, there's loot, there's bosses. There's collectibles and rare items. There's crafting and potion brewing, there's magic and mechanisms. There's pets and hats. There's all that and more.  Par for the course you start as a weak, ill-equipped dude (or lass) with just a few basic tools and the company of a knowledgable 'guide' who spouts advice and also knows every crafting recipe there is. From the very first minute you'll feel the danger of the world, too: Slimes will mercilessly pounce at you, and the first of many deaths will probably happen sooner more than later.  You make the sandbox your own by harvesting blocks, crafting stuff out of those raw materials, and upgrade to a point where you can feel save- a small house maybe or a makeshift shelter to spend the night, where the undead come out. Your first metal bars will see you getting a better weapon, faster tools. Soon the world will be yours for the taking, right? So far, so good, so Minecraft? Yes, a bit.  After a slow start, Terraria quickly shows its true colours though. Combat is a much bigger factor in this game, and the 2D nature makes it simple and enjoyable to fight a hodgepodge of monsters with sword, bow, gun, magic, or any combination. Exploring the finite world will often lead you to another chokepoint where your equipment doesn't cut it and even skill can only get you this far- it's one of those games where your skill is a factor but your stuff is slightly more important. And only exploring will net you new materials- the amount of blocks you can harvest and refine is amazing; if you wish you can create some truly beautiful structures and deck them out with tons of decorative items, all themed and occasionally crazy awesome. Want your furniture made of ice? Sure thing, why not? Or maybe simple wood? Gears, maybe? It's all there.  Still deeper in the game you'll face unique boss monsters. You could stop right here and say, yes, that's enough for me, collecting all these awesome things and building and fighting and all. But it doesn not stop there. If you take on a certain final boss you put your world into a special mode and even more crafting, looting, fighting, exploring options unlock.  And even that is not the end. This game is literally as endless as you want it to be.  --  So, yes. This is a 2D sandbox game that often feels like a MetroidVania game where you're free to (re)build the level yourself and make it as epic as you want. As you make progress you're also able to lure NPC characters into your world by building them shelter- Merchants, a nurse, your ever-faithful guide and more all offer certain services for hard coin. There's a ton of collectibles, from clothes to pets to legendary items. Building a museum to showcase everything would probably take a large world just because there's so frikking much of it. On day you may leave your awesome castle, decked out in the best armour and wielding the best weapons and knowing every nook and cranny of your realm, and THEN you'll find something you had no idea was there.  It's that kind of game.  --  If anything, after the time it's been around, and after two very beefy updates (the 1.3 one hit just a few days ago), Terraria starts to feel extremely manic. There's just so much of everything and while I really dig the 'patchwork' approach some may be put off by seeing traditional fantasy stuff blended with steampunk, magic, and the odd pop culture reference. I mean, you can go out and kill Cthullhu's Brain. With a yo-yo. While wearing a Creeper costume. In an arena made of confetti.  It IS that kind of game, if you want it to be :D

When I first started playing this game (on non-steam) I absorbed my life. I   dreamed   about Terraria. I think I studied more about my upcoming Skeletron battle than I did for any test in school. So you could imagine the ecstacy I had when I finally defeated him. It was   all   worth it. And the rush of a battle you've been preparing for for several days is unrivaled. Not to mention the creator keeps doubling the content (weapons, armor, bosses, NPC's) about every 6 months, leaving you with an endless pursuit for the newest shiniest loot. On top of that, there are a seeming infinte number of building blocks and craftable decorations so you can craft a home with almost anything you dream of. If you don't mind losing a few dozen hours of your life, and a bit of grinding here and there, this game is definately worth considering.

My first impression of the game was an exceptionally poor one. I was overwhelmed with what seemed to be a good deal of tediousness, and very little pay-off. You see, my first experience was spoiled because I came in with the expectations and preconceptions of one who had played another-game-which-is-often-compared-to-Terraria for a good deal of time. The blocks here seemed too small. One of the (virtual) dimensions seemed to be lacking. The amount of time it took to hack away dirt walls from a cave nearby my starting point made me nauseated. Then I cried myself to sleep over my loss. I had nightmares of tiny blocks pelting me, and of being unable to build massive structures in five minutes. My sleep was light, and I woke up the next day traumatized, in a mental fog.  Just kidding about the crying myself to sleep part. I don't cry. And the nightmares, too. I'm too cool for them. Also, I'm always that way in the morning before I have my cup of coffee. Coffee is my only friend in the morning.  But I did try and play it a few more times, just to get my dollars' worth on it. Then, the transformation began to happen. I began to despise the simplicity of said 'other game', its lack of technical rigor, and armor made of diamonds. I had been blind to the wonders of living in a two-dimensional world, and the effort required to craft -- truly craft -- a satisfying RPG character. About eighty hours of gameplay later, I've not regretted my decision to purchase this game. My interest in it has only grown stronger.  If you or a loved one has been traumatized by preonceptions about how Terraria should be experienced, please encourage them to press forward. It's not so bad once you get tools that aren't terrible.

Having put over 500 hours into this game, it's safe to say I enjoy Terraria. At the time of writing this, the game is going to be updated in the near future, so I expect to be playing it a bit more as well.   Calling it a '2d Minecraft' is an over simplification, but not inaccurate. It does have it's crafting, digging/mining, building, mechanisms, and enemies. However Terraria has a much stronger focus on combat, especially PvE. With hundreds if not thousands of weapons across multiple combat styles, several tiers of armor with effective set bonuses, and plenty of potions and buffs, Terraria has options.   There's a bit of grinding to be done early on, but it goes faster when playing with others. I've gotten a few people I know interested in playing, now we're getting ready for v1.3 to be released.

THIS ISNT JUST MINECRAFT IN 2D. nO, IT IS NOT, AND IT IS NOT A GOOD COMPARISON AT ALL.  This game has building and mining and farming aspects like Minecraft, but they are no where close to being utterly similar as some people seem to say. The objective of this game is to keep on egtting bigger nad better gear in order to continue the fight in this world. You create a character and a world, and it can either be softcore (dont lose items if you die), normal-core (lose items if you die, but you can retrieve them back), and hardcore (character gets deleted, but world is still there). You you drop something, it stays there FOREVER until you leave the world. You need to continue fighting in order to advance your weapons and armor and other 'stuff', like aesthitic items for a base or items that you can equip to mke your character look better or get stronger. There are two 'modes': easy mode, and hard mode. The only way to get to hardmode is if you beat the hardest boss on easymode. This will turn your world into a nightmare, as very hard enemies begin spawining, as well as openeing up new ores and materials to further your adventure. It is sort of an RPG because you can be a mage, a fighter, or a ranged person, but you can also build structures like houses, farms, etc..  I recommend buying this game. I have been playing since 1.1, and I rate this game a 10/10, if not higher

Terraria is a land of adventure! A land of mystery! A land that's yours to shape, defend, and enjoy. Your options in Terraria are limitless. Are you an action gamer with an itchy trigger finger? A master builder? A collector? An explorer? There's something for everyone.   Start by building basic shelter, then dig for Ore and other resources. Discover and craft up to 300 weapons of magic, ranged, and melee varieties, as well as armor, and use them to battle hundreds of different enemies. Soon you'll be going head-to-head with any of a dozen enormous bosses. Go Fishing, ride a Mount, find Floating Islands, build Houses for helpful NPCs, and much, much more. Way Way more fun than it really should be. Often immitated, but never yet equalled. I joined the Terraria bandwagon late based on recommendations from guys at work. Not disappointed. Combat is well balanced even at the ridiculous super boss levels. Holiday content and outfits, coupled with housing to display said things brings for hours of tweaking. The NPCs walk around and providing a nice back drop of activity. Crafting in many dimensions, coupled with switches and the ability to shape the environment brings the sand box alive. Reading the wiki is a must, as there are very few in game clues to indicate what you should do next. However the crafting treadmill in the wiki gives lots of planning options. If only the discovered and shared details were part of the game, or accessible in the game to help formulate plans and activities from inside it, rather than needing to flip outside of the game so often. This is an amazing game that I think anyone would love. Terraria has many things to offer for many kinds of video-game players. If you like building games, Terraria has loads of different building materials including wood, bubblegum, slime, glowing blocks, and even candy canes! If you like exploring, Terraria worlds are full of surprises when you load them up. Don't even get me started on the caves. If you like fighting bosses and other enemies, Terrearia is packed with hundreds of creatures hostile and friendly including unicorns, skeletons, goblins, snowmen, bats, and all sorts of strange made up creatures such as a 'Derpling'. Terraria has many bosses, each very different and challenging. You can fight with all kinds of weapons and have minions help you! Fly on a U.F.O or glide around on wings to find floating islands guarded by Wyverns(dragons)! Explore a vast dangerous jungle or the fiery depths of the underworld! If it's too much to handle, gather your friends and take on the world of Terraria together! But beware the Crimson and Corruption, pure evil that will take over your world. Build houses for NPCs to move in to help you along the long journey to defeat the Moon Lord and obtain the most powerful weapons and armor in the game. You can fish or sit around playing with Teleportation potions, you could do anything your imagination tells you to do in this wonderful game! When it's time for the holidays, special things happen in Terraria during Halloween and Christmas. This is an absolutely amazing game and I suggest you buy it. The only limit is your imagination. Let it take flight with angel wings or something. Just get that imagination running, because you need it to play this game. Thank you for your time.

Terraria is a standout game in a world filled with Minecraft clones. While there is definite similarities between Terraria and other games in the genre, there is so much more for the player in Terraria. The game has a unique take on style and customizability that really caters to the player. There is a great sense in which the game wants to be on your side. In normal mode there is the risk of losing money when you die, but there is no item loss and this makes the game extremely friendly to the casual player. For those looking for a deeper challenge, hardcore mode makes adventuring under prepared extremely risky for the player and all of their items. All in all for playability, accessibility and freshness, I think Terraria deserves your love and affection.

Terraria is by far one of the best games ive ever had the delight of stumbling across. I only have 40 ish hours on pc because ive completed this game countless times on the console versions. The game had a bit of a rough patch where the developer left it seemingly forever but i was still interested so i found out a massive update was coming out for the game. I was expecting a lot but not as much as we got, more biomes, seemingly hundreds of enemies, weapons, armours, bosses, npcs. This game and the updates by the developer never seem to dissapoint. Ive soaked hundreds of hours into this game all together. The only complaint about it is that it doesnt have steam workshop support but to be quite honest you can replay the game 5 times gathering thousands more items along your journey, with or without friends. Being able to switch your class as you go or just not have a class at all and have a sword on one slot with a magic weapon in the other. The graphics and soundtrack are so beautiful and unique and each weapon post early game does something new and you can play it however you want and with no disadvantage. Still has some bugs and loads more on other platforms but the game on pc is truly something to behold. Would recomend to anyone. If you havent tried this game out yet then where have you been? The game is as good as it gets. Such an amazing game... Seriously. I used to play Terraria on a cracked version, because I didn't have a credit card or whatsoever to actually buy the game. A friend of mine and I have played this game for so long! Update after update. We kept checking out the new things and it kept getting better. New bosses, new events, new items, new features, more awesomeness! My friend has a record of about 380 hours on this game and we kept playing together on a server of his, so I definitely have more than 350 hours spent on this game as well.  Pros: + Beautiful soundtrack. + Nice pixelated 2d graphics. + A lot of cool bosses. + Cool different events, such as the Blood Moon or the Pumpkin Moon and the temporary Christmas event. :D + Lots of different materials to build with. + Awesome decorations. + Different classes: Melee, Ranger (arrows or bullets), Mage, Summoner. Note: You're not stuck with a class or something. You're free of how you want to play. You can, for example, have armor for Melee, but still use magic attacks. + Cool NPCs. + Awesome random features such as fishing. ''wow, fishing... so amazing'' Seriously, it's quite fun. You don't expect what you'll get. I for example got myself a cool red beard. o: + Awesome random items, such as the red beard I got while fishing. + One of the best games to play with friends. :) + No lag at all. - I used the most crappy laptop ever which has about 0-15 fps on Minecraft and crashes when I send a message through Skype. + More amazing ♥♥♥♥ to come!  Cons: - Well... Y- ..... Ehh.. I have no idea.  69/10

I own this game for PC and XBOX, and It's an amazing title! A lot of people try and say Terraria is just a Minecraft clone in 2d, but that just isn't the case. Where Minecraft is mostly focused on the buiding aspect, Terraria allows for that kind of play, but it's main draw is the hundreds of things (probably thousands at this point) you can find or make for your own character. I first started playing in the 1.1 update, and there was something so fulfilling about making toons for each of the end level play styles. Haven't played the latest update yet, been trying to get through some of my library (love those steam sales :-D), but I've always loved coming back into this fantastical world of epicness with a dash of silly mixed in. 9/10  Side note! if you're still on the fence, take note of the reviews 'overwhelmingly positive'. Now, go take a look at the negative reviews... It's hilarious!
