Where to begin... Terraria is a game that can be slow to start but once you gain some traction is immensely addicting. The game's deceptively pleasant background music will catch you off guard and will be echoing in your head at the most inappropriate times. I've happily come to accept it as white noise at this point. As far as the gameplay is concerned it is by far one of the best sandbox games I own. You can choose to collect cool weapons and armor to defeat powerful enemies or focus on crafting new items and terraforming. I actually really enjoy the simplicity of this 2D side-scroller and don't view the lesser graphics as a negative. That being said if you’re looking for cutting edge 4k content this game won't quench your thirst. This game is best played with a few friends that can help you get some of the key items otherwise it takes a bit more grinding. The game can be frustrating at times, but that is part of its charm. Looking for new ways to overcome difficult obstacles is very stimulating and rewarding. Endgame content is scaled appropriately with new updates being added to enrich total content on a regular basis. My only critique is that the developers created some items in the game that only their personal avatars could obtain and even went so far as to ensure your death if your player were to somehow obtain them through non-standard means. Overall, I would give this game a 10/10. I personally love this game and I hope my review convinced you to give it a chance.  -Drake

This was sold to me as 2D minecraft. Stop right there, it isnt!  Terraria is a Side on RPG where you have the freedom to (eventually) mineor collect everything on the map. However, that is not the objective. Terraria is played in two sections; Pre-Hard Mode and Hardmode. It is important to note that both of these sections are essentially one game.   You start out with nothing, and you have to slowly explore and collect enough good and resources to build a village/castle/glorified hotel for the collection of NPC character that you will amass. These NPC's are useful tools throughout your playtime and shoudl be looked after. Don't worry if they die, a new one will come back.   As you progress through Pre-Hardmode you fight a series of progressivley more difficult bosses untill you are ready to face the Wall of Flesh. Once this is defeated you enter Hardmode where the enemies are toughter, there are more random events and you gain access to the end game material.   =========================================  To wrap up quickly: Terraria allows you to explore, progress, collect, build and kill through as many hours of gameplay as you wish to put in. Made better by multiplayer, either co-op or PvP (optional), each world will be different and can be exactly what you make it.

Terraria is basically 2D Minecraft, but better for multiple reasons.   1: Updates come out regularly. You know, Minecraft has updates with, like, 10+ new blocks and maybe a few new items and mobs once about every year, but HOLY. COW. Terraria's last update, 1.3, Added 900+ items, 100} mobs, a few new biomes, and a boss or two! That's obviously better than Minecraft, right?  2: Since your not already convinced, heres some more information for you. Ok, the worlds aren't 30 million blocks in every direction like Minecraft, but Terraria has worlds that will take you awhile to traverse. With the option of having Small, Medium, Large sized worlds, plus the option of Expert or Normal difficulty worlds, it has 2 different kinds of worlds with HUGE differences, (The Corruption and Crimson) which I won't be going over.  3: LOTS of things to do. I've played this game for about 175+ hours, and I haven't even gotten to The Moon Lord yet! (Well, don't blame me, I do restart alot...) Plus, there are enough blocks in this game to play with. Go play with your toys, why don't you?

'It's a Minecraft clone' 'If so, it's probably the most greatest clone ever made'  Alright, let's be serious, and not act like a comedian. This is an amazing game, especially after 1.3 and the support for Mac. I might have only had this game for a year, and wasted a ♥♥♥♥ ton of hours on it because who needs life, but already, I'm in love with this game. And here's reasons why:  -It's a sandbox, so basically your imagination is the limit, and the lack of a 3rd dimension -Unlike Mindraft, or whatever it's called, this game is mostly based on adventure, discovering. And it's pretty much a strong aspect of the game -The music, despite it sounding very bit-like, is amazing. Not a big aspect, but it's great to play a game without an annoying soundtrack.  -The difficulty is just right, whether you're an easy-going gamer or a hardcore gamer And a few other reasons I couldn't add because I'm too lazy  Now, of course, there's flaws:  -The difficulty, even though I said is just right, could use more variety, especially in expert mode -The soundtrack being a DLC is alright, but having it the same price as the game? Seems a bit too much. Sure it's not used that much, but still, maybe tone it down to like, $5 to $7? -The backup, like everyone says, is broken. I find this small, but with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC most people have, it could use more fixes. I'm aware there's a backup program. -The steam intergration, sorry if it's harsh, is ♥♥♥♥. Absolutely ♥♥♥♥. Even if you have great wifi, and a beefy PC, it's still bad. Too many glitches, lags and dropping out randomly. You can use hamachi or other things to host servers, but I find 'steam intergration' useful, and quick, but still, fix it please  Other than its flaws, it's still a fantastic game. Great job Re-Logic, and keep up the great work!

So a story: When i first played this, i was a super noob. I died from every single mob at least once. (Looking back on it, i call myself an idiot often.) The Guide was an ♥♥♥, but the kind of ♥♥♥ that knows that he still has a reason for living so you can't kill him. (Until later...) I kind of pretended that everyone who lived in my house had a kind of soap opera drama going on when i was out killing and mining. It was pretty funny.  So when the Guide said that i could summon a powerful monster, i got excited and jumped right in to the fight. I died in less than ten seconds. It was awesome. So i got better gear and later on pwned the boss that killed me earlier. And when i got back home and talked to the guide again, he then said that there was an even more powerful monster i could fight.  Rinse and repeat a bunch of times until now.  The point is, if you're looking for a game that constantly challenges you and kicks your ♥♥♥ until you finally learn what to do and progress, then this is the game for you. And also, i prefer it over minecraft mainly because i can see what is going on around me instead of getting paranoid and looking around everytime i leave my house to go get stuff.

A lot of people say that this game is a rip-off of Minecraft. Minecraft has two bosses, weak enemies, no special events and about 6 ores. Terraria on the other hand has more then ten bosses, loads of weapons, Blood Moons, Slime Rain, huge dungeons with chests everywhere. Does Minecraft let you ride a unicorn? Does Minecraft have a rainbow biome? Does Minecraft have a lot? When you strip it down to the bones, this is what Minecraft is: crafting, building, fighting, boss, nether portal, boss. However, this is Terraria: Spawn, spend five minutes running about in confusion, build better weapons, night falls, die, die a lot, go looking for better gear, get better gear, become good at not dying, dig down into hell, kill a wall made of flesh, fight off an goblin army, fight off pirates, shoot bees out of a gun, ride a unicorn, realize that hard mode really is hard, die even more, get even better at surviving, get all achievements.  Comparing Terraria to Minecraft is like comparing a shark to a goldfish, you just don't want the goldfish but sometimes you want a break from the sharks and then the goldfish seems alright.

As a game from the view of casual gamers this game gets a lot of hate. It is regularly compared to minecraft which is a game in its own field which Terraria should not be compared to. Infact the backdrop to the majority of the hate this game gets is that its a 'bad 2d version of minecraft'. This is what keeps this game as underrated as it is. I have known many people, myself included who viewed this game as bad and then, once i played it, we realised how good it was.  This game is more like a co-op rpg sandbox game with an enjoyable gameplay, challenging bosses and a ruthless environment where the player must survive. The game gets progressively more insane with bosses that, if your friend told you about them, would seem completely unbelievable. An advanced weapon range, amazing bosses (especially for the graphics resolution used) and an all out challenging experience make for possibly the best sandbox Rpg of its aspect.   Even if you are repulsed by this game, give it a try. I most highly reccomend it.

VERY good game to play with friends & family. It took me a very long time to start playing bc I hated the way it looked. I have never been a fan of platformers. I had also been big into MC for years, and I didn't think I would like playing something that looked to me, like a bad 2D MC clone.  I was very wrong about that btw. Terraria is NOT very much like MC at all. Whereas I thought I would not like it mainly bc it was 2D, I did not realize just how much Depth this game has. Once I finally let my son talk me into playing this with him, my enthusiasm soon outstripped his. While he focused on advancing us thru the many stages of the game, preparing us to summon & fight each successive boss and unlocking the next level of content, I focused on exploration and building us a nice base.  My recommendation is if you have friends who play Terraria, ask them to let you join them. This will help get you acclimated to the game and help get you drawn into it. Once you get a feel for the game, you can make your own world and immerse yourself into the adventure-driven progression and then move along at your own pace.  It's a sandbox yes, but it does have many many bosses. Also, when you start playing, you are in the 'Normal' mode, which is actually called 'Pre-Hardmode'. There are 5 or six bosses you can summon to fight or farm for loot, and a final boss called the Wall of Flesh that once you kill it, you enter into the next world phase called Hardmode.  Hardmode unlocks new mobs, bosses, crafting materials, gear and a whole lot more. Normal mode is a vast game in itself. Hardmode is a much bigger game.  You owe it to yourself to get it on sale and try it. It really is a very fun game, and one you can lose yourself in for many many hours.

An absolutely beautiful game filled with nearly infinite amount of things to do. I'd love to make a top-notch review, but I'm not sure where to start.  This game is what sandbox games should be. There's a beginning, a middle, and an 'end'. Most of the enemies in this game are original and creative. There are bosses that you must defeat to gain access to better weapons and equipment. The game continues to get harder as you get stronger (in a good way, not a 'we'll make the enemies the same level as you so there's an illusion of difficulty' way). The music in this game will be stuck in your head for weeks, up until you're browsing YouTube for remixes and 1-hour loops, and then you'll get those stuck in your head. There's options for whether or not you want to go in balls deep with a character that dies permanently, or one that just drops a certain percentage of currency he or she was carrying. Did I mention character customization? Simple crafting mechanics. Easy structure building. An (optional) smart cursor that predicts what and where you want to pick with an pickaxe or smack with a hammer to make demolishing a thing much more simple and faster. Updates that add in new content such as new bosses, new goals, and new weapons. Interesting NPCs. Fishing. Humor. TONS of references to other games, books, and movies. Tired of being on land? Build a tower to the sky and live in space. Tired of being ontop of the world (literally)? Dig your way down until you find (literally) hell itself. Want to make your house out of clouds? You can do that. Want to make your house out of clouds that are constantly raining? You can do that. Want to re-summon a boss that you really enjoyed fighting? You can do that. Do you like a certain piece of music and wish you could take it around with you? You can do that. Events such as Blood Moons and Martian Invasions will occur spawning tough enemies that threaten not only you but the NPCs that live there. Virusus such as the Crimson or Corruption will try to spead across your world, infecting the land itself turning it to the darkest gray or the thickest of blood....  Cthulhu. AND his brother. Need I say more?

I have played the game a lot at a friend’s house and finally decided to buy it. I start up my first world and start collecting resources. Many game days of mining later I have finally got enough platinum to create a slime crown. I sort out my inventory with that and some suspicious eyes. Am heading off to create a boss arena when a message pops up in the chat: ‘You feel an evil presence watching you. I run to where I want to build it but get confused why he hasn’t spawned yet. ‘The eye of Cthulhu has arrived’.  “Oh crap, oh crap!” I start frantically building the arena but his attacks soon knock me into a pit where he annihilates me. I rush back but he has already de-spawned. I spend the rest of the night and the following day finishing the arena and building a small house underneath so I can spawn there. The arms dealer immediately spawns and decides to make this his house. By this point the day is over and I can no longer spawn the slime king. The next day I spawn him and manage to trap him on the other side of a door making him an easy picking. I then try digging through the wall of the house so I can shoot him from below even when he is jumping. He is on very low health when he glitches under the door frame into the ground and kills me because I can’t get away. Because I destroyed the wall of the house I spawn back at the start point and he de-spawns before I get back.   When it is getting close to night I am very frustrated and start mashing the button to spawn Cthulhu. The night starts and two messages come into the chat. ‘The blood moon has risen’ and then ‘The eye of Cthulhu has arrived’. I manage to defeat him even while dodging zombies and normal demon eyes, quickly grab the loot and sprint back to my base. All the doors are open and on the ground floor my merchant, Frank, is on very low health. It’s hard but I manage to fight off the zombies. I sit back a moment, victorious and watch the rising of a beautiful new morn.  ‘A goblin army is approaching from the West’  “Oh come on!” I try fighting them off but soon Frank is slayed. And the base is getting overrun. I try to draw them away but they only seem to spawn near the original spawn (the same place as my base). I think that I’m getting towards the end and don’t think the forty or so enemies I faced really counts as an army. Then five more come all at once and I realise that was only the first wave. The battle continues all through the day and into the night. I now have to contend with goblins, zombies and low visibility. Finally when I think the waves will never stop coming: ‘The goblin army has been defeated.” I collect all the loot and have doubled my money. I dump it all in a chest and set out on a nice relaxing fishing trip.  10/10 would definitely get trolled by this game again.

Ever wanted to have an awesome adventure? No contrived railroaded story, endless dialogue, and arbitrary skill points? Just you, in a wonderful world, for you to explore, overcome, and craft to your heart's content? Look no further. Ride your unicorn into the floating robot skeleton as your bees bite away at the robot's laser and your ball of flame slams into the eyesocket. Jump around the underground jungle with dungeon chains like spiderman to escape the mile-long vines of a massive flower who is intent on eating you. Ride a hoverboard into the interdimensional elementary pillars as your magic rays blast them to pieces.  Most adventure games promise an 'adventure', which is usually just a story in a pretty skybox. This game let's you make infinite adventures, that truly feel like the come organically from your actions. You are truly the ultimate cause of everything that happens in this game. Between the immense variety of items, worlds, enemies, and bosses, this game turns in the most unpredictable ways to show every 'adventure' game out there how a true adventure is done. Nothing is impossible, nothing requires you to repeat anything. You are truly alone in a world out to kill you in any way it can. And there is nothing stopping you from turning any tables you find. This is not the developer's story that you have to sit out. This is your story. This is a world you can truly immerse yourself in. If you want to do it, you can do it, given you are strong, fast, clever, and determined enough. There is nothing to wait for, there are no glass ceilings, experience points, or skill caps. There is just you, and the world out to get you. Go and show it what you're made of.  Oh, and there's multiplayer. Yeah, if you're playing with a buddy, take everything I just said and raise it to the power of 2.  This is the best adventure game you will ever find.

WARNING: YOU'LL PROBABLY NEVER SEE THE SUN AGAIN OR SLEEP FOR A LONG WHILE.  When you first start the game, life is tough and things will probably move very slowly especially if you're completely new to the game (or when you start Expert Mode with new characters and completely forgot how to basic) but once you get going you'll plow through events and bosses like nothing. All 3 mech bosses at once? EASY! Soloing the entire Lunar Event, and eventually farming the entire event (ML included) 40+ times with little to no effort? EASY! Restarting in Expert mode with new characters? EASY......somewhat....okay well thats a lie but at some point I'll edit this and say its easy.  -Lots of weapons/tools/armor/accessories etc. of various materials and rarities that can be built, found, or dropped (Laser Drill, Laser Minigun, Phantasm, Terrarian, Nebula Blaze&Arcanum, Solar Flare, Daybreak, and Last Prism just to name a few.) that can be reforged (giving a prefix to an item which can buff or nerf your weapon).  -Quite a few different types of enemies and a few minibosses (Slimes, Zombies, Wyverns, King Slime, Queen Bee).  - FOURTEEN BOSSES  -a few different types of biomes (three of which spread overtime, two are considered evil)  -lots of building materials/decorations etc. (Martian, Cobalt, Mythril, Adamantite, Palladium)  -plenty of things to do, countless hours of fun with your friends. (surviving your first night, building stuff, exploring, fighting bosses, fishing, fishing, fishing, catching butterflies and various critters?)  - Events! Some of these events are things that will happen at random times of day. For example. Blood Moon happens during night time. The Moon is blood red, water turns from blue to red, bunnies turn from adorable little fluf fballs to nasty little devils, increased enemy spawn rates and in some cases blood moon exclusive enemies, enemies can open doors, etc. Blood Moon is the first 'natural' (I call it natural because it happens naturally and can't be triggered) event a player will encounter which happens once a player on the server has over a certain amount of health. A Solar Eclipse is the daytime version of a Blood Moon except a lot tougher this event is natural but can also be triggered (Solar Tablets) and is Hardmode only. Also during Winter/Christmas you get special mobs!  I do want to mention that once you beat the final boss/every boss in game, if you're sticking to one character and one world (chances are you won't be sticking to one character/one world)....you'll be bored out of your mind. You can continue to build megastructures like one of my friends, or go fishing....until you get the achievement for 200 fishing quests....then you're either building megastructures, going on a vacation/retiring, or starting a new life in a new world on a different difficulty. There are some really talented people out there who can make some amazing feats of Terraria engineering (Shoutout to DicemanX's Moon Lord AFK farm map) so if you're into making cool and complex structures, go nuts.

I don't think you understand how great this game is. Sure, you may have heard from folks that it's fun, maybe that it's addictive, that they keep adding content and expanding the game, but it's more than that.  The visual style is on point. They sat down and really nailed a good pixel-art style. Then, they added music. It's great music! This area is, I feel, all too often ignored in games. Not so in Terraria, my friend! And thi si good because you're going to hear this music enough to memorize all of it.  As for the meat of things, the gameplay is pretty solid. The controls are mostly intuitive and it's very easy to dive right in. The setting and story seem to be absent at first and while this sometimes works with other sandbox games, Terraria has taken a really good alternate approach: The Guide. They have given you a guide to get you started on this journey and to whom you can turn if you ever aren't sure what to do next. You are supposed to make use of him. Really, he's a pretty good alternative to wikis and spoiler sites. If you want to be a purist like that, go for it, you are totally able!  Finally, the thing that has kept me coming back is the sheer amount of raw content. They just put out another large update and heaven knows I'm about to generate a new world and start again. There is enough gameplay elements to keep you going through the main 'story' (read: 'sequence of boss monster fights') for dozens of hours. And unlike so many other titles out there, the balance is pretty excellent. The bosses are tough but vastly rewarding. There can be grinding if you need but more than likely you'll find most if not all the resources you need just by exploring the world and discovering new things. If you're a collector or a completionist or a packrat, get yourself some supplies because you'll be here for well over a hundred hours.   And once all that's done there are mechanics for multiplayer games like capture the flag and PvP fights. Not your thing? Don't sweat it. The game will also encourage you to build a beautiful, grand fortress in which to live and house your small nation of NPC's. Heck, if you're really proud of what you've built, put a picture up of it online. There are currently tons of images of outright works of art that people have whipped up. (I myself was/am pretty proud of Candycane Keep.) There's really something here for almost any kind of gamer.  Tl/dr; This game is highly polished, has lots of attention to detail, has tons and tons of content, and is just good enough at balancing challenge and reward to keep you coming back over and over again.

I admit, I feel a review at this point is kinda redundant, given how old and how many times this game has been on sale. Nevertheless, I do think this game is very well worth it if you have not picked it up yet. Granted, I have not played much of the more recent updates, so this review could very well be out of date.  Despite the cheap price, there is a fair amount of content in the game, such as varying monsters to hunt down, invasion events, and bosses to kill. As well as plenty of building blocks to give you a chance to build almost anything you want.  The game can be played in multiplayer, but multiplayer is not necessary. A solo player can still find a good amount of enjoyment, even if they are playing alone. Friends would make the game a bit more easier and perhaps more fun.  Combat is basic and easy-to-reasonable for the most part when not taking expert mode into consideration, but that mode is more for more 'experienced' players anyways. Not to mention that since this is a sand boxy game, it gives you options to kill the bosses and monsters in a variety of ways, such as making an arena for the boss so you have more options to move around or making a lava area for some invasions.  I do admit though, there are times in the game where it feels like it has a painfully slow start till you can start killing and mining things at a resonable pace, specifically the first and middle parts of the game after you beaten a certain big boss. The game CAN be pretty grindy at times, especially when RNG is not kind to your character.   It's also a really heavy 'wiki' game. Meaning, you would probably want to look up in a wiki to gather most of the information, such as loot drops from enemies, how to craft a particular item, how to summon a particular boss, how housing mechanics work for npcs, ect. I recommend using the Official Terraria gamepedia wiki for this game. A minor nuisance really.  Another bug bear for me was expert mode, it felt much more grindy than an actual challenge. Maybe this changed with the more recent updates.  All that said, for me the above were not deal breakers, so I would still recommend this game, especially to those that like exploring or are looking for a reasonably priced game.

Terraria is a 2d exploration/adventure/crafting/building game that's often compared to Minecraft. To me, the only similarities between the two are the fact that you can mine ore and craft better tools/weapons/armor, and the necessity of building shelter to survive the night.  You start off by creating a character, with the option to select hair styles and clothing styles. After you have your character, you have the option to select a large, medium, or small world. Characters are not bound to a specific world, you can take any character to any world you like. Worlds are randomly generated, with many different biomes such as deserts, forests, sky islands, and even a dungeon biome. There are two special biomes, Corruption and Crimson, only one of which will be generated in a world. These two special biomes will have certain enemies and equipment only found in that particular biome, so you will have to take your character to new worlds to experience everything.  Terraria has a strong progression system, mainly centered around defeating bosses. And there are MANY bosses to fight. There are many npcs you can find and unlock. Every npc will need a house built for them before they offer you thier sevices. You will find yourself needing to upgrade your equipment pretty regulary, by mining/crafting, finding treasure chests, and defeating enemies/bosses. After defeating a certain boss, your world will enter 'Hardmode', which introduces several changes, making it feel almost like starting a new world.  There are literally thousands of different items to collect in game, ranging from weapons and tools, to armor sets, to cosmetic placeables. Four different combat styles are available: Melee, magic, ranged, and summoning, with hundreds of weapons for each. Outside of combat, there is a staggering amount of different building materials to use in creating your own base/town/castle/etc. There is also a wiring system available that can be used to create everything from drawbridges to flashing lights to deadly traps.  Terarria is one of the very few games that (in my opinion) approaches perfection. There are, however a few things I can be critical about. The soundtrack can get a bit repetitive, along with certain sound effects. Drop rates for a few items are a bit ridiculous, but that's only really a problem for completionists. I personally think there's room for improvement with the inventory and crafting systems. Even with these slight flaws, I would give this game a rating of 9.3/10. I seriously can't recommend it enough.

I have had this game for years, and replay it at least once a year. It's fantastic alone, better with friends. Has a crafting/building system that is not clumsily shoe-horned in. Interesting weapons and armor that have unique effects and are fun to use. Added difficulty if you want it with expert mode. Perhaps the best game I've ever played.

I played the game for the first time roughly 4-5 years ago and... it is no longer the same game. It has expanded at least 3-4 times to become the most content rich game on Steam PERIOD! There is not a single game that has as much content as this game on Steam; there isn't one unless you count creative games where you basically get to write the game's code but that award goes to Minecraft alone.  But this game does so much more than what Minecraft does, it has for an example: + A real combat experience with A LOT of different weapons and styles of combat + Insane variety of enemies to fight + Fair boss fights that can prove challenging at times but never losing their 'fair' component (altho' they will brutally murder any new player who starts up having never played Terraria before) + A VAST world to explore... 'EVERY' single time you generate a new world + Outstanding community tools to learning every nuance of the game + A LOT of variety to create amazing pixel art and structures that are just stunning to look at (no 3D models as everything is 2D but this game proves that you just need to be able to go Left, Right, Up and Down and still create amazing art) + You can set up dedicated servers so you can make it really, really easy to play with friends online but... + ... playing on your own is also exceptionally rewarding albeit with a certain requirement to set up your own goals or else it might be a bit overwhelming + HUGE custimization options both for the world generation, the difficulty and character creation Downsides: - I guess it takes a few minutes to install the game?  Do I recommend this game? I will say this much: If you like survival games where you get to loot, mine, fight, craft or any of these things... you are making yourself a disservice by not owning Terraria already! Stop reading! Go buy it! If it is on a sale... WHY ARE YOU STILL READING THIS?! BUY IT!

Mix up minecraft, a incredibly well designed metroidvania experience, spinning turtles and unicorns that will murder you in cold blood and epic boss fights. This is probably what you'll get.  Terraria, started it journey in 2011 and since then the devs have been updating the game with chunk loads of stuff and no DLC whatsoever.  It's an amazing experience for and incredibly low price and immensely more fun if you mix it with some friends.  Most of the bossfight difficulties are just right, the perfect point at which you'll have to repeat the fight a few (but not too many) times in order to get better, analyze the mechanic and innovate new techniques in order to succeed.

Five years of fun! I've been playing Terraria for years, off and on, and it's still as fun to pick up after an update and play as it was five years ago. Actually, it's even better! Amazing, way to go Re-Logic!

Already a complete game when it came out 5 years ago, Re-Logic has come back time and time again to expand its content even further. The game is far above the 'dude, look! 2D minecraft!' people once saw it as.  The gameplay starts out nice and simple, with platforming, collecting resources, and a bit of combat to spice things up. When you collect enough resources, you can summon powerful bosses to fight, and cause events that add new challenges to the game. Having new places and things pop up and npc's moving into the houses you build for them really bring the game world to life. There's lots of room to explore, and with all the content added since launch, you'll constantly be finding cool new things.

OK, I'm not only playing Terraria. I play BROFORCE and other stuff. Just a warning to not say that. I may compare Minecraft and Terraria a bit. (insert baby don't hurt me meme here)  It all started in March 27, 2013. The day I found about Minecraft: The game everybody talked about. So, I research it, and eventually get it. I begin getting mad at my hand-me-down laptop for not launching the game. I eventually went out to Wal-Mart and got a Windows 8 laptop. This is where FNaF comes in, but not now (that game is terrible in my opinion). I went back home and set the computer up, and then buy the game for $27 AGAIN. Download, and then it works and runs great! A few months later, I met my bud Ju1cy Ju1c3. He showed me some Skyrim gameplay, and Just Cause 2. We eventually discussed a game in his library called 'Terraria' Now, I never knew how cool it was until he showed me gameplay. I told him 'Terraria is dumb' And this was a guess. I never had seen gameplay, and eventually we can back to this discussion shortly after I got Castle Crashers, another big thing. I asked if he would show me some gameplay for a few minutes. I researched it later. On Nov. 25, 2015, I bought this game and Garry's Mod, a new big thing. I started up Terraria, and it ran smoothly. Eventually I discovered MULTIPLAYER!! Now this helped tons. We eventually beat all pre-Hardmode bosses and we progressed further in the game from here on. However, there was a little moment we got mad at each other. Coming back to it, it's kinda funny. Ju1cy was trying to kill me, and fell down and received his death. I laughed and eventually he said 'if you laugh house go BOOM' That was when I got the thought of a house that took 7 hours blowing up and being a pile of ashes. And that was avoided. Now that I have the drill mount, it's gone and all that remain are chests. And my dresser. The reason why is because of Crimson. It blew everything up there so my hotel could be safe.  Red, Cenx, D-Town, Loki, and everybody else, I thank your for this game and I feel that this game was meant to be made. It is 2D, yes, but it's better when it's like a throwback to NES and the SNES. I can't wait for Terraria: Otherworld. Take your time on it. Expect me to buy it whenever it's available. This does deserve a Steam Award as this game has hours worth of content and is as awesome as Ocarina of Time (I'm a Zelda nerd). With it's Metacritic score of 83 this game has amazed me by far.  111111111/10

People say Terraria is like Minecraft 2D but it's just so much more than that. I personally think that Terraria is far more combat and survival based than Minecraft, sure there is no hunger system, but that's something that actually ruins a lot of fun in Minecraft.  Terraria allows players to embark to completely player-made worlds where obtaining the best gear you can get and fighting the most insane bosses brings that true grind yet fun to the game, it's not a game you can blaze through, you will need time to get to where you want to get in all servers, including your own in single player. There will always be a higher rank you can achieve, there will always be some form of currency that you haven't obtained as much of as you wanted. You might not have the items you want, the bosses you want to fight, or even the right tools to survive, but that's all part of the struggle in Terraria, it challenges you to act fast when encountering an enemy and how to fight them and what is the best equipment to fight them with.   There is a huge and diverse amount of mobs in the game that Minecraft cannot really bring to the table, each with their own fighting strategies and mechanic kits. It is up to you to outsmart the enemy and surprise them with the killing blow and earn your sweet sweet rewards.  How, when and why you fight is completely up to you, you could be running in and out of dungeons, being chased by huge worms underground in the hole you dug, you could be trying to loot some materials, trying to kill a boss for a drop etc.  And just like a lot of RPG games, the drops are RNG, so don't think you'll always get what you want, because this game will challenge you and make the hair of your arms rise until you've gotten out of that dungeon with your measly 10 health.  I definitely recommend this game to anyone who wants to try it, it is definitely worth the money and will keep you entertained for years to come.  ~instant classic.

Terraria is probably one of my most favorite games. For those who like Minecraft, many will feel at home here. But before you write it off as a 2D minecraft, read on.  I started with Minecraft. I played it when it was in alpha. I loved it, and I still love it. But Terraria has stolen me away from it. Terraria has irresistably fun action, especially in the epic boss fights. And there never seems to be a 'best strategy' in the game- no stopping at diamond gear (well, there is no diamond gear, to be honest). Even in the first, easier difficulty half of the game, you've got numerous guns, bows, spears, swords, magic swords, boomerangs, explosives, spells, staves, armors, tools- the list goes on.   And then there's the building. Oh, the building. A bit harder to slide into at first than Minecraft, what with missing a 3rd dimension, but once you get the hang of it, you can build some BEAUTIFUL creations. It's probably one of the most overlooked things in this game, as most people play it just to get through the game and beat all the bosses. But, I want you to go look at some of the pictures of what people build in this game and tell me it doesn't look like something you wish you could do.  And finally, there's the collecting. I'm a completionist, so I've set out to experience every inch of Terraria that I can, and it hasn't failed me thus far. So much to see and collect. For some, you may see a lot of this as grinding. But those fellow completionists, this game is for you.  The enjoyment only multiplies with friends, in every aspect.  For $10, this is a must buy. And if you can't hit that number, the game often goes on sale for a quarter of the price.

This game is just... wow. You'll play it until the end of time, then come back to it a couple weeks later and notice something you didn't before and keep playing. Or they'll update it and you'll come back for the update. Ten bucks... well spent. Unless you hate the graphics and 2D - I will admit I came from the days of Pokemon Red and Blue. The bosses they added in the latest update are insanely hard to kill alone (minus the Slime King, he's laughably easy), but up to that point the game shouldn't offer insane difficulty unless you dig too deep too early. Starts you off with a sword, a pickaxe, and a hatchet, and you work your way up from there, finishing with a Hamdrax (Hammer/Drill/Axe, all the best tools in one), a flamethrower, a powerful and oversized sword, and the most awesome house ever to exist if you bother to make it. Just don't make it in space, monsters spawn when you're higher than 700 feet that you really won't like. Ruined our space station.  EDIT: They changed the wyvern spawning. Building in space might be safe. In some areas.  EDIT 2: Okay, the Hamdrax isn't even close to being the best thing in the game anymore and the progression will keep you occupied for a couple months of addiction, and then you'll start building things and finding all kinds of building materials and you'll be addicted for a couple more months making your server look fantastical. Even more worth it now. Buy this.

I write this review presuming you've never played it elsewhere, and know nothing about it.  At first glance, not having seen actual gameplay, you can easily be forgiven for being put off a bit by the graphical choices of the game- 2D pixel art is a dime-a-dozen thing in this day and age of photorealistic graphics, made mainly by people who would simply wish to harken to a simpler era of graphics.  I could even forgive you handily for thinking it was just another run-of-the-mill sidescroller from the PR they've released- like Minecraft, this is a game that truly deserves to be played to appreciate fully, which is the mark of any well-crafted game.  The fact of the matter is, even just under three years after its release, there is still not a single true equal to the splendorous open-book journey that is Terraria. The goofy name is fitting- this game has numerous quirks in how things work, and you'll find over time that it's chock-full of references from pop culture and even other games.  My apologies for all the hyphenated phrases, there's a fondness I've had for this game from the moment I played it. It makes that immediate connection with you- paints your situation so clearly in just the first few minutes whether or not you decide to do the tutorial. This is, first and foremost, a sandbox game, but whether you thrive or simply get by will depend entirely on your ability within the game.  The first thing you'll notice is that unless you are ridiculously good at the gameplay mechanics, a better weapon has to be just on the horizon. Inevitable as it may be, everything in this game is randomly generated by an ingeniously-coded world generation engine that will keep you on your toes as you explore.  This is where the game differs heavily from Minecraft, where you can go to ridiculous lengths without ever truly needing to upgrade unless you want the extra goodies- you'll have to fight for your resources here, be it against hostile terrain, enemies, or Mother Nature herself- there are things that go bump in the night, and the more sinister elements of the game will consume a good portion of your world if you don't keep them in check.  Yet again, Minecraft comparisons beg- you don't find that vast an array of weaponry usable there, but in Terraria, you name your poison, and it's quite possibly attainable. Classic chivarous combination of sword and armor? Check. Guns that shoot various types of ammo? Check. Lightsaber-inspired? Check. Magic-using wands and enchanted weaponry? Check. A baseball bat? Maybe on the horizon, but I think you get my point.  Exploration is far more focused than Minecraft. As you have a 2D plane, it would also initially appear more limiting, but the game will remind you time and again why you keep coming back for more- these worlds are absolutely massive (even for just being a 2D plane), and will satiate even the most curious minds for countless hours. Once you have defeated certain key bosses, new mechanics of the game will rear themselves and again threaten to bring you back for ever more difficult fun.  Overall, this game is a wonderful, constantly evolving experience, and I could not recommend it enough for a PC owner happy to dig into their chair and play something worthwhile.

Terraria.  Thats all I need to say. Of course this is a reveiw, so Ill say more.  A Sandbox game with a hint of RPG added to it and a whole lot of action, you go around and mine blocks to make equpiment to get more blocks and stuff from the monsters as you go deeper. Sounds like Minecraft? probably. Is it a different experience? Oh Hell yeah.  Thing I gotta say now is, the best part about Terraria is the fast-paced yet balanced gameplay that makes it so fun. Getting better weapons and armor quickens the gameplay, making every new world a whole new experience. Unlocking new tiers of stuff also gives even more xciting gameplay, and it gets you into the game once you start playing it. Heck you will probably want to make a new world once you pretty much got every item there is in the game.  Next is the content. The developers have made so many diffrent kinds of enemies, enviorments and challanges for the player to explore. Many bosses await, and with the recent updates much more content mas come up. Theres still a little Terraria waiting to be shown, but it's still worth the buy, since its got multiplayer as well, all of this for $10. Go buy it. It's worth it.

With over 1200 hours, I think this is an honest review.  Terraia isn't a Minecraft ripoff, or another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 2d sidescroller. Terraria is a game where you gather, build, and explore a vast world filled with the expected, unexpected, and everything silly inbetween. Terraria's graphics are at a level that keep immersion, but allows the game to be ran to older PC, that maybe don't have the graphic capability of newer computers. Terrarias vanilla game content is what truely make this game beyond the rest. Unlike Minecraft, with a interesting, but short vanilla progression, Terraria has hours of vanilla game content. In vanilla terraria, you start in normal mode, which will easily kill the unprotected noob, but a smart player will find their way around the ropes. Also unlike Minecraft, Terraria has several bosses that make progression difficult, but still playable. After killing the Wall of Flesh, which is considered to be the main boss of Terraria, you enter hardmode. Hardmode has new ores, mobs, and area to discover.  Fastest Terraria playthrough: 6:45:00 Fastest Minecraft playthrough:1:27:00 Those are just the basics of the game too, Terraria has so much more than just that, which could easily last you up to 20 hours per playthrough. Maybe more if you truely expand your horizons, you can play for as long as you want.

Its hard to understand the potential of a title like Terraria if you havent played it yourself, and I hope that I can convince you to do just that. Seriously, try it.  On its first day of release, back in 2011, Terraria kinda shook the way we think about 2d open ended sandbox games. Then, it was an excellent game, well rounded, with a decent amount of content. I reckon I put 200 hours in on the original release version, and there was still plenty that could be done.  In 2013, Re-Logic announced that there was to be an update - update 1.2. From that moment on, with no extra charge to the people who had already bought the game, patches came regularly. In game content has been doubled, hundreds more items and variations and possibilities have opened up. New bosses, yadayada ya.   This game is one which should not be missed, nor forgotten.

'Minecraft in 2D' is what immediately comes to mind when seeing this game, but after playing for a while you begin to realize that the two are markedly different.  Terraria has a much higher focus on combat. You start off fighting slimes and zombies with wooden tools but quickly discover bosses, rare monsters, and dangerous dungeons. The game becomes progressively more difficult and more interesting. New players will progress at their own pace, but experienced players starting a new world can jump straight to endgame if they choose, or ignore the advancement criteria and remain in early game for a more relaxed experience.  There really isn't much grinding to be had in this game. Character progression is driven by gear rather than arbitrary experience points, and gear is typically crafted with small amounts of very specific materials, meaning it is ultimately driven by exploration rather than staying in one particularly profitable spot for the entire game. Bosses and rare spawns also have rare drops, making it a treat whenever they show up.  Creatively, Terraria is somewhat limited in comparison Minecraft due to having one less dimension, but it makes up for it with its myriad of building blocks in all colors and textures. Furniture from beds to chandeliers to pianos can be crafted out of various types of wood and metal, and you can further customize your living quarters using paint and colored lighting. Hammers can also shape the terrain into slopes and half-steps, allowing for a more natural look.  If 'Minecraft in 2D' sounds appealing to you then this game is definitely worth buying, but be prepared to receive something much more.

I'll be honest, a big reason I purchased Terraria was because I'd had such a high interest in Minecraft. That and because it was incredibly cheap during the winter sale.  As someone who has spent zero time playing Minecraft, but half a lifetime watching let's plays and other content related to the game I've always wanted to give it a go myself. But for some reason (I'm cheap) I've never went ahead and purchased it. The biggest reason probably being that I was afraid to get too addicted.  I didn't have that fear with Terraria and I have no idea why because it IS addictive. I tried the terrible free demo on my phone and was happy to finally play the real game. It's fun, very fun. I didn't catch the bug as bad as someone else who I'd convinced to play with me, but that just means they get all the cool stuff while I'm not online and have it there waiting for me when I'm back. It's fantastic.  Though I've definitely put my time in. It's hard to imagine that only a couple weeks ago I was getting slaughtered by Skeletron when I accidently clicked on the word 'curse' and now I'm summoning Skeletron Prime just for the drops and the giggles.  I actually would complain about the game having TOO MUCH... but that's such a weird thing to complain about. You'll be working towards a weapon or armor for so long and it'll stop being relevant after an hour or two of playing with it. There is just so much stuff that's great for a short period of time or for one specific purpose. It definitely keeps the game interesting, but it's depressing shoving armor in a chest that you love but that no longer makes the grade.  That being said... this game is awesome. Give me more accessory slots!

Terraria does what Notch failed to do with Minecraft for a long time: connect a sandbox building environment with a role playing adventure. The two-dimensional nature of the game helps with this, bringing it closer to platformers as well.  Like Minecraft, it creates a random world with dungeons and biomes featuring unique material blocks. Unlike Minecraft, Terraria places unique enemies, loot and even some special buildings (akin dungeons) into these worlds, randomly generated, but following certain rules every time. The game has a huge lot of content - be it purely aestethic or actually equipment-wise. Every once in a while you will need to defeat a certain boss to get further in the game, gethering more crafting materials as well as armors and weapons along the way.   The game uses a nice crafting system with similarities to the Monster Hunter series, which finds a perfect way to make you want a certain piece of equipment enough to warrant some grinding for it. The armors also work similar, granting special abilities (mostly passive effects) when full sets are in use. The weaponry is divided in three playstyles: - melee combat uses lower ranged weapon (at the start) with nice damage (swords for example). - ranged combat features guns or rifles to shoot enemies from afar, consuming ammo and mostly hitting only one enemy per bullet  - spellcasters use magic to hit multiple enemies at once; this however requires mana management nad big loads of mana potions later on.  Once the entire world is explored, defeating a certain boss transforms the entire world into a different state, much more difficult to navigate due to new, stronger enemies. This includes additional bosses and equipment, too!  All in all, the game was a very engaging experience for me - you constantly try to improve, gaining new gear or spells to defeat that next boss. With the shiny and flashy, fun to use weapons and some relatively hard events, the game's content can bring new things for a very long time.

So a review for Terraria.  Gameplay: Just as games like minecraft you are dropped in to the randomly generated world and the first thing you should do is to build a home. To do this you gather materials. You also gather materials to make all kinds of stuff like weapons, armor, furnature you name it. You start with an axe, a pickaxe and a sword. Enemies do not just show up at night there are silmes and other nastier stuff to fight the further in to the world you go or the deeper you dig.  Enemies: Alot of enemies are very easie to deal with specialy at the start and if you take it slow and gather everything you need before you advance you should have no problems dealing with them. But then you have the bosses. Most of them will be a pain to deal with the first time you meet them but when you learn their attack patterns they are also pretty easie.  NPCs: Throu out the world you will find friendly NPCs that even can move into your hause or hauses you make for them. Most of them are murchants of diffrent kinds but there are other useful NPCs as well. It is also good to know that when you have achived some things NPCs will show up of you have a spare room so always have one just in case.  Co-op: This game will always be most fun with friends, but what game isn't? Personaly I couldn't get it to work and yes I know there are way to fix that but I tried them and it still didn't work for me so do not have any experience with the co-op.  Summery and personal thoughts: So this game is a builder/servival game. It if fun and creative and if you like these kinds of games this is a most buy for you but personaly I do not like them without friends. If you pick this up good luck out there and do not dif to deeply or to greedly you might regret it.

Terraria has to be one of my all-time favorite games. Not only does it have a wide variety of of furniture and building materials to make amazing structures, but it also has a very creative and very enjoyable combat system. There are many different enemies that all have amazing special drops which remind myself a lot of the Metroid-Vania (Castlevania: SotN) games I've come to adore. There are also many challenging and fun bosses to fight as you create yourself a fancy home and a growing arsenal of weaponry, be it melee, projectile or magic. Alongside all of these there are vanity sets of apparel which can really make your character stand out, not to mention the character customization of many hairstyles, skin colors, default clothing colors and more!  There's way too much to say in one recommendation, go buy and play this game to see it all for yourself!

This game is one of my personal favorite sandbox games out there, let me explain to you why. Terraria is a 'start fresh - figure out how to play this game' kind of game. Upon making a new character, with the newer updates, you are able to choose from a male or female character, as well as change the hairstyle from near three dozen styles, as well as choose the colors of your clothes. Be warned that not all colors translate perfectly when playing the game, so be warned (hues aren't on point in the character creation screen versus the game, but its a minor detail that should be overlooked because it isn't too important).  The game dumps your character in a world with three simple things; a pickaxe, an axe and a shortsword, and with only these you will be able to reach leaps and bounds in the facets of weaponry, tools, armor, furniture and items. The game has a day and night cycle, so you must quickly make a shelter with the tools you were given before the zombies and demon eyes show up at night. Be warned, the presence of stronger enemies, especially in the beginning of the game, gives the player a sense of urgency to make fortifications before nightfall.   The combat evolves to use more than a shortsword, to spears, flails, magic items and guns. The simple 'stab a zombie with the shortsword' doesn't get old like you would imagine. The combat involves balancing your health with the style of play with the weapon you are equipping, and this all varies with each enemy (of which there are many), so fighting enemies doesn't get boring. Each fight can go different ways - it doesn't pan out the same everytime, which helps with combat replayability.  Crafting is a big part of the game too. You must mine for resources and build newer and stronger tools to advance your ability to make stronger armor and weapons, to survive stronger enemies and fight stronger bosses. The only caveat is there are rare items, that are the pinnacle of weaponry, that drop with a small fixed rate (~0.1% or whatever it is). You will be grinding specific types of mobs to farm these items to get the weapons. This is the only thing I dislike about the game, if you choose to go all the way and get these items, the likelihood you will replay the game is low, because it takes such a long time to get these weapons you will not want to do it all again.  The game was awesome before the newer updates, and has lost a bit of replayability after them, but still a good game.  8.5/10

Notorious for being the 2D Minecraft clone, this little gaming jewel is not really little and definitely not an amputated version of 3D Minecraft. There is vastly more random generated stuff to be found and explored. Several boss monsters will hinder your way through the world and a lot of events will provoke your detours in a refreshing way. With consistent updates, which always had a huge impact on the gameplay so far, there will always be something new, implemented in an interesting way. Terraria shines when played with friends online and using its player versus player option to have multiple teams struggling for survival and item hunting. 'Just one more cave to explore...' ; 'Just one more gold vein...' would be phrases heard often and it truly is the hunger for more different discoveries and collectable goods what makes this game a must have. For 10 bucks there is no way around this gem.

Hello, if you're viewing this then hopefully you're contemplating buying Terraria. If you are then please let me inform you. Terraria is nothing like Minecraft, regardless of what you have heard. It's a 2-D sidescroller however you will at least get used to if not prefer that camera angle. You can also get alot of things in Terraria that are fun like boss trophies or mob banners. You can also get many types of armor and weaponry, from your normal iron armor to molten lava and even an armor made of turtle shells. The weapons can be amazing for example the Crystal Storm or the gun shoved down a sharks mouth, the Mini and Mega sharks. I have played Terraria for a long time and even after getting all of the best things in the game and having hundreds of hours under my belt I can safely say that it is still entertaining. If you happen to run into any problems I, or many others, can be of service. Just Private Message me and I will help. All in all I think you should buy Terraria as the game is worth more than $100, 10x its original amount.

Terraria is the definitive side-scrolling sandbox. The game is fun and imaginative, the play is smooth and fairly intuitive- you might get a meny popping up in your face when you're starting out, but it gets easier. Thousands of bosses and billions of things to try; it just never stops. You'll be building your own cities, which will subsequently be populated by NPCs with the ability to help you in various ways. Addicting, but I found myself losing touch with it after about twelve hours of gameplay- then regaining touch, and losing it again. Terraria is what started me into the sandbox genre, and therefore holds a special place to me.

With an entire world for you to explore. Terraria will grant you many hours of fun gameplay that will keep you entertained for a long time. With different in-game biomes such as the forest, jumple and desert, this game may seem similar in style to the critically acclaimmed Minecraft by Notch and Mojang, but I can promise that you will have a much different experience. Whereas Minecraft is more based around the sandbox style (mining, crafting and building), this game is much more centered around action and exploration. With areas such as the Corruption, the Crimson and the Dungeon, all the way to the fierce Underworld, this game will definitely keep you on your toes as you advance through the gradually more challenging places you can go to. There is a very fun action system in the game that allows you to carry an assortment of different weapons, such as swords, bows and explosives, such as bombs and grenades, and the variety of the enemies is truly stunning. There are multiple types of weapons of one category, as well-swords. for example. have four main types: weaker yet faster shortswords, middle range braodswords, powerful but slow greatswords, and the almighty automatic swords. You can build a variety of different things in Terraria with the use of axes, hammers and oddly, pickaxes. You can chop down wood with an axe and then use it to create homestyle lodges, or you can go further and make a pimping gold brick house, assuming you can gather enough gold ore to make that many blocks to actually build it. The explorationm aspect of this game is one of the best I have seen in a 2-D action game, or any action game for that matter. First off, you have the overworld, which will contain areas such as the desert, forest and winter biomes, but once you start to travel underground, that's when the real feel of the exploration kicks in. There are many layers to the underground areas, such as the ground layer and the stone layer, and each of them have their own specific things about them that change the gameplay dramatically.  All in all, I'd say that if you're looking for a game with lots of exploration and action, you should definitely pick up Terraria.

Terraria is a neat little gem. As with any other RPG, the freedom to do what you want knows no bounds. This game takes that statement a massive step further.  While at first the game can seem a little bit daunting and perhaps frustrating, Terraria really begins to open up as you advance. The equation of 'risk = reward' brilliantly stands out, for if you dare to venture down into the caverns and dungeons below the surface, the loot to be discovered is fantastic.  With almost two weeks worth of gameplay put into it, Terraria has unveiled a fantastic adventure for me, which is saying much considering my anticipation for a $10 game was exceedingly low. Now I regret even thinking of such a statement. However, while I can throw hundreds of words of praise at it, there are some flaws, but for what it's worth, they can be easily ignored.  In short, Terraria is worth every cent for people who love to build, adventure, and prove to themselves that they're really a hero in the making.

I wish I could write about everything I think this game does right in a post-minecraft world, because comparisons are likely to be made, and minecraft is the end all be all for casuals and children everywhere. This game is like a fine sand paper has been taken to that game, and certain features removed for the sake of there being a game hidden under the engine. This game still involves the cutting/digging/collecting philosophies of Minecraft, but with better variety for every aspect minus a large moding scene, character equipment and trinkets, the ability to increase character health/mana, mobs that are not completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and will fight you to the death, or swarm you to death. A fine survival game hidden beyond completion of the game, I would recommend this game for anyone looking to move beyond the child-like, dull experience that is minecraft.

Many people akin Terraria and Minecraft. And it's true, they are both voxel based mining games. However, Terraria tones down a lot of what Minecraft is in building and creativity, then makes up for it in the exciting combat and boss system. Don't get me wrong, you can still build interesting and exciting structures in Terraria, but the awe that some Minecraft creations can inspire is not found in Terraria. If you prefer emphasis on combat, boss battles, and equipment upgrades, but still want to be able to mine resources, create defenses, and terraform to your desire, Terraria is most certainly a good fit. There's a reason it's my most played game on Steam, and even as I write this, I have the game open on PSN to play with my friends.

It's basically a 2D Minecraft, with some unique features.  Here are some of the things to expect from the game: - Tools - Stuff to 'mine' - Crafting materials, equipment, items, etc. - Day/Night cycles, with different set of 'creepers'  - Shape the world into almost anything - and so on.  Protip: Immediately grab your axe and start hacking at as much trees as you can get and make a house before night time. Ah, old fashioned 2D sidscrolling bliss. This game makes me nostalgic on so many levels it's hard to describe. But even if you're a 'new-school' gamer you can probably still appreciate the innovative and captivating (i.e. addicting), yet simple and easy to grasp gameplay that Terraria brings. It's a mish-mash of sidescrolling platforming, world building, and action adventure with some RPG-like elements tossed in for good measure. The randomly generated worlds you start with give you wilderness, caves to explore, materials to acquire to build more things in the world (like structures and items for your character) flying islands to conquer etc., not to mention tons of loot and treasure for your exploration efforts. You can also connect to a friend manually via IP and play their world (and they can connect to yours), always giving it a persistant feel as you watch it evolve in between your own playtime. Overall, great value for around 10 bucks for many different types of gamers.

Terraria is a 2d take on the sandbox survival games that started popping up soon after Minecraft's success. The concept is very much the same when it comes to exploring and surviving, and although it is 2d, Terraria attempts to be more combat oriented. The addition of boss monsters and a wider array of monsters in general is one of the only main differences from Minecraft. Those who have played Minecraft first will be able to get the hang of this game rather quickly, those who have not however, will find a rather steep learning curve that depreciates the value of the game to new players very quickly. Personally, I would much rather just play Minecraft, but if you are a fiend for combat, this might be your cup of tea.

Terraria, is an absolutely fantastic game. A lot of people will call this a 2D minecraft...and while I don't think they're wrong, there's a lot of similarities... I actually don't think they are right either. There's a lot more depth than an alternate dimension of an existing game.  Terraria has a greater focus on the character, and the gear & loot you collect. Your character is free to move between worlds, joining friends, and roaming across new lands in search of rare chest finds, like the Toy Sled or Lava Charm. You level them up with Mana & Heart Crystals, and ever so slowly become a god.  And that in my opinion, is the greatest part of this game. The sheer power you evolve into. In some games, you get bigger numbers, bigger damage, or some nice little new ability. Terrarias progression is a cliff you bound up. The accessories and weapons you gain continously get better and better, you can feel the difference as you grow. I have rarely had a game that has made me feel so powerful.  Which is good, because make no mistake, this game is hard. Unless you're Yrmrir, you are going to get utterly destroyed. The Zombies and Demon eyes pose a real threat on the first night... by the tme struggling against Eaters of Souls is a fading memory, you're getting incinerated by Diabolists and ransacked by Solar Eclipses.  Terraria offers an almost absurd amount of content, and the combat offers many playstyles. I would heartily reccomend this game to anyone.

Terraria takes a lot of the mining & building aspects from Minecraft, and expands upon it. Not only can you build more stuff, you can also get NPCs to move into your town, who all have different professions such as nurse, who will heal you, or a merchant who will sell you stuff.  The game also gives you lots of good reasons to go out and fight monsters, besides all of the awesome loot that they'll drop, there's also a wider variety of monsters, and there's even boss monsters.  Between that & the townspeople, It gives you a goal in an otherwise open-ended game, and gives the whole thing a lot more structure than something like Minecraft, highly reccomended to anybody, especially fans of Minecraft.

An excellent alterative to Minecraft!   Terraria is definatly Minecraft-inspired but not by any means a ripoff. Being a 2D voxel box platformer style is unquestionably one of Terraria's main difference. But it's surely not Minecraft slapped into 2D. The crafting and mining system is different. Gererally how you explore and exploit resources differs as well. And beyond any doubt there's numberous variations of enemies and bosses to battle! And though the game is geared more to exploring the landscape and battling, there's definatly a wide option for creativity as well! And with the 1.2 update implimented with more block types and the ability to change their shape and colors undeniably opens up more possibilities!  Simply put, It's very addictive when playing with friends! And without question my favortive Voxel Box game! And the 1.2 update surely makes things 20% better! I highly recommend it!

You can build anything as long as you have the materials.

While Terraria shares much of the draw of Minecraft - digging, exploring, building - it also features a wide variety of weapons, enemies and bosses. It is very much more a progression-based RPG than Minecraft. It takes more resources to build your gear, but your gear doesn't wear out and there's a lot more of it.  Being entirely in 2D gives it some advantages. For one you can see a little ways 'into' walls and the ground, but the biggest disadvantage is you can only build 2D structures which feels a tiny bit limiting in that respect. All in all, a game I've sunk hundreds of hours into and for the price tag is one of the best buys I've ever made.

*initial warning, this is not minecraft* anyone who likes the idea of minecraft but overwhelmed by its size, or underwhelmed by its graphics, should check out Terraria. This indy gem takes everything good about minecraft and turns it into a 2D platform, adventure game. mine for resources, craft items, build endlessly, battle exciting creatures, explore the depths for lost goods, do it all alone or with friends online. This is a greatly overlooked game that is near and dear to me. buy it!

Oh, ho ho ho ho! This is a little bugger...Seems all simple and nice in the beginning, but that's merely a lure to trap you into an ever-expanding adventure from hell (and to Hell, actually). The bosses are actually hard in a level-appropriate way...which is something you can't say for every game.

First off, what an amazing game and the price that is offered to purchase it doesn't even do it justice. As you can see, I have put a lot of time into this game. It's addicting, fun, and the creator finally realized what a hit it was and has been consistently adding new updates to it every couple months. It can be as challenging as you want it or as easy as you want it, whether you choose to be the adventurer gear heavy type or just the casual epic housing builder or BOTH, both will occupy your time to the point where you don't even realize how much time you've been at it! Dungeoning, challenging monsters, good crafting and gear retrieval system, epic housing and building abilities all at your disposal. Only down side I say is the difficulty it takes to set up multiplayer. I had to use a 3rd party program every time. I don't know if they have fixed this yet or not, but other then that, I thoroughly enjoyed the playthrough of this game.

'It's a clone of Minecraft, just in 2D, that's desperately trying to be different from Minecraft' -- is what I was told when I asked about this game. My mistake was I didn't take it seriously.  The further review is only for Single Player mode, maybe Multiplayer has some charm in it, but I wouldn't know.  So, this game is mediocre, you walk around and dig for stuff. For no real reason that I could find other than to pave a road for yourself when you fall into some pit. So, you walk left and right (because it's only 2D, remember?) and do what? That's the question I couldn't find answer to. At times you get attacked by some monsters that come out of nowhere. They come in swarms and they're brainless - even flying ones have single pattern of movement. You gotta fight back. You have a sword, a shovel and an axe. The best option is obvious - you shovel flying ones to death, because sword and axe are useless against them (wut?).  And that's about all there is to this game. I enjoyed oldschool DOS version of Prince of Persia more. Personally, I believe buying it even on a sale was a mistake.

Why do you need to read reviews about Terraria, dood? Get it! It's an awesome game.   But if you need to know more... fine.   Terraria is a 2D Minecraft-like game that has the genres of action, adventure, platformer and open-world. It's a game that lets you craft your dreamworld of 2D goodness, explore randomized caves, underground places, and other weird places, find treasures that will make people jealous of you (like the Magic Mirror, which my character has now! YEAH!), fight bosses like a BIG DAMN EYE, fight slimes, make bombs, make a mansion, construct minecarts to make easy passage to home, fight demons, make armor, etc...   Terraria is just... it's hard to describe. At first, it seems like this Minecraft clone made in 2D. But as you play more, you realize there's a lot to do in the game. It's just awesome. The game will make you laugh, cry, happy, sad, enraged and all other kinds of emotions. Then when the updates came in, the game was like getting little DLC. And even better, once update 1.2 came in, EVERYBODY was happy because many bugs and glitches were fixed, a lot of content was added and then came 1.2.4 where MINECARTS ARE NOW INCLUDED! FISHING POLES NOW INCLUDED! NEW BOSSES!   THIS GAME IS AWESOME I TELL YOU. Just go get it man, it's worth your time.   plus, YOU CAN DRESS UP AS A UNICORN WHILE WIELDING A GODLY CACTUS BROADSWORD ;-D   11/10!

I'm gonna be honest; if you're new to this game, the early stages WILL feel slow and difficult. However, once you begin to get going, it's a lot better (although, if you have friends to play with, it's a load of fun).  Terraria is, simply put, actually a more in-depth game than Minecraft, and (for me) that makes it all the more enjoyable. Yes, world size is limited and yes, there's a lot more to get your head around, but it feels much more rewarding than Minecraft when you begin to reap the rewards for your continued efforts.  That said, this game does have the issue of poor online. Servers are horribly difficult to set up (though it can be fixed with Evolve), but LAN parties work like a dream.  Overall, I'd actually recommend this to anyone who feels Minecraft has run out of appeal (or think it's too 'casual').

Where to begin...  Terraria is a 2D adventure game, with gorgeous pixel-esque  graphics. in my eyes, anyway. You create a character (with moderate customization tools), and a world. You spawn, and then you're off. Mobs, bosses, NPCs, tools, weapons, armor... Whatever happens first is all up to you. Every world is generated randomly; there is no 'seed system' as some may call it. This meaning that the experience is never exactly the same.   Conclusion: Terraria is worth your time. Sure, games such as Minecraft (which this is not a ripoff of) might boast 3D worlds. But does minecraft have over 750 different mobs to kill, over 1,000 items to collect, and, better yet, UNICORNS?  I didn't think so.

Terraria is another side scrolling sandbox game very reminicent of Minecraft. It can be easily compared to junk jack on ios, but, is, in my opinion, a more comeplete experience. While the ever popular Minecraft features very cubular Nintendo 64 style graphics, Terraria takes on the look of a Super Ninendo game graphically. While minecraft is a more creative oriented experience, Terraria is largely based on survival, with a more vast variety of enemies and craftable weapons, armor, and tools. Terraria also has a complex npc system, involving building houses and having them move in at a certain point in the game. Now while Minecarft has only one boss (the Ender Dragon), Terraria has a larger array of bosses to fight. Terraria also has something called hardmode, which is triggered, per world, by defeating the Wall of Flesh (WOF for short). Hardmode worlds have an even bigger variety of enemies and bosses. Terraria also has alot more craftable items, from furniture to weapons to armor to tools, theres no end to the crafting fun. There is also alot more crafting stations, with the crafting system alot eaiserto use. Its does not involve arranging items of a grid (thank god), so there is no need to remember a recipie. Just click and craft. So is Terraria better than, lets say, a game like MInecraft? Well they are both unique in their own ways. So the verdict: it depends on your own personal preferences. In my opinion, they are just as good as one another, but i wil give Terraria a perfect score. definetly a 100/100, and i hope relogic will keep up the good work.

What do you invision in a game? Constant battles against unholy beings? Dangerous caves and chasms to explore and conquer? Whatever your tastes may be, Terraria satisfies them. A very expansive and diverse world sees you mining through caves to discover treasure, fending off zombies and demonic eyeballs to protect your home by night, and constantly staving off the Corruption which threatens to engulf your world at any moment. As one of the most satisfying experiences you can have, Terraria is laden with endless possibilities and exciting gameplay elements that just can't be passed up. If you have some cash in your Steam Wallet, I would definitely recommend at least giving Terraria a chance. It's one of the greatest games you'll find.

While at first glacne one could dismiss this game with a 'lulz it's just a 2D minecraft clone' (I'll assume that's not you discerning review reader) but this quirky little game is truly so much more. However Terraria does a fantastic job of stifling those feelings by offering you the tools in the art of murder like a minigun crammed inside a shark. There are few games that can really suck 200+ hours of life out of you for just $2 (on sale), yet this little beauty can.   And really, what's going to give you that much satisfaction per unit money? Nothing. So leave yo girl, quit yo job, and do nothing but play this game.

There has been a long war about which is better: Minecraft or Terraria. I believe that the two are incomparable because there are terrible amounts of differences. This game is not just '2-D Minecraft'. Terraria has an exhilarating single player experience, with a world full of precious treasures for you to procure, and a hoard of bosses to try and squish you into the ground. The bosses definitely provide a fair challenge, and once you defeat the Wall of Flesh boss, your world is converted into a Hardmode world, offering even more challenges and bosses. There IS, however, a point which you will not have a whole lot left to do. But I will say that the money you spend on Terraria will not be wasted. At all. Add it to your wishlist, and get it if it's on sale.
