The general object of the game is survival.   Find and gather resources, build a home and new tools with the gathered resources to ensure your survival, but the game is more complex then this. There is dungeon hunting and looking for treasure, fighting monsters and improving your character.  At night time the darkness comes, Zombies and other monsters come to attack, which goes back to the point of survival. Building a Shelter keeps you safe from the onslaught of endless undead and demonic creatures.  With no script to follow or directions to dictate your path, the game is very open ended so you can play however you like.  Build your viliage and people will move in, different NPCs being shopkeepers or other merchants providing different services.  Comparisons to Minecraft are there, but Terraria has it's charm with lively 2D animation and platform style gameplay.   Highly recommended!

Awesome game. People seem to think this is a knock-off of minecraft. It's not. At all. Just because art style is similar doesn't mean its a knock-off. This game receives lots of updates and special events (Holiday's, in-game events such as blood moon), sometimes the special events even bring new limited time bosses and gear. One major drawback for me is that this does not support linux. It can be run with relatively low system specs. Mods are available as well. Gameplay is awesome, Terraria has non-stop adventures and boss fights, all of which are entertaining and very enjoyable. It would be nice if the server/multiplayer aspect of the game was spent a bit more time on. I could not figure out how to setup a server and attempting to do so crashed my pc or the game more than a few times. This would be really fun in multiplayer. In conclusion, I would recommend buying this game (especially if you have friends that play) as it is very fun and enjoyable for all ages. If you catch it on sale for less then or around $5 definently do yourself a favor and go for it.

An charming romp with so much customization it's staggering. The freedom even on small maps feels endless. I built sandstone tree houses copper towers and whale shaped jungle bungalows just to name a few. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys variety and acquisition in their gaming experience. I found myself tunneling and gunning and enjoying every new little mystery or opponent that showed up!

Probably one of the most enjoyable sand-box style games I have ever played. There is so much to do in this game and so many ways to play it. You will not regret buying this game in the least. The game remains fun and entertaining regardless of whether you are playing it alone or with friends.

Mining. Buildling. Crafting. Killer bunnies. There is all of this and more in Terraria. Terraria is a sandbox adventure-RPG that has something to offer to almost any type of gamer. Do you like building? Interior decorating? There are thousands of different types of furniture and tons of tilesets to play with. Do you like killing? Hundreds of pointy and shooty things await your use on the dozens of bosses and endless enemies. Do you like friends? Terraria is multiplayer, and whether it is coop or competitive is up to you. Be careful if your friend says he's going to bring his single-player character. Don't give that guy dynamnite.  I've got over 150 hours on Terraria, and I cannot say that I've never gotten bored of it. However, when I did, it wasn't long before another update came out and doubled the content of the game. What are you waiting for? Buy it.

149 hours of awesomeness. Honestly, I expected something similar to Minecraft when purchasing this game but honestly, it's not comparable at all. Terraria focuses on an RPG themed sandbox survival. In other words, pure awesomeness! The worlds are randomly generated, there's a LARGE amount of weapons, there's NPC villagers (that creepily start living in your house...) There's a lot of different entities (including bosses!). Another thing I really enjoy about the game are the little secrets. The worlds are polluted with these little treasures. You may find a pair of running shoes (herms boots) that make you run REAL fast to finding a teleporter that brings you back to your spawn. I love that game and I've suggested it to many of my friends :). Definitely worth the price!

I bought this game through the Summer Sale because so many people were recommending it. I didn't think much about it at first, expecting it to be some cheap Minecraft/DF clone and hoped I could get the $2 value out of it. I discovered to my surprise that the game was well worth my money and time! There are massive dungeons/caves to explore, and the RPG element mixed in to the procedurally generated sandbox world makes Terraria a very fun and enjoyable game. And that's just the single player part; I can't even fathom how much more fun this game will be when playing with your friends. Wholeheartedly recommended!

I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who wishes deep in their sould to live off the fat of the land, but is also aware that leaving their airconditioned apartment would be distasteful to their sensibilities. My honest opinion of this game varies of positivity and negativity. When I first began to play, I was terribly confused and quite put off by the game due to how different it is to Minecraft. Of course people judge Terraria as a worser version of Minecraft, but I'd actually have to disagree after playing Terraria more! After the confusion phase, I became more comfortable with the game itself and how to play it properly. I think what makes this game better than any other Sandbox game, is that the goal is mainly to defeat all of the bosses, climbing the ladder of difficulty modes. This is a change from Minecraft as the goal is to survive, whereas in Terraria, when you die, you lose nothing. I think this is a great feature as it definitely prevents player rage!   If you do decide to purchase this game, beaware that when you first begin, you won't want to carry on. Don't let this stop you playing! Once you get used to the gameplay, you will definitely find this game worth the cost!

No other video game has unleashed my creativity like Minecraft. I've spent countless hours chipping away at blocks, gathering the necessary materials to complete the next masterpiece that would otherwise only occupy my mind's eye. I've also spent just as many hours exploring, spelunking and slashing my way through monsters with bravado. My character – my entire Minecraft world – constantly evolves into whatever I want it to be. I tell my own stories, I write my own destiny and I bring my fantasies to life one brick at a time.   Minecraft stands out not only for the way it inspires me creatively, but also because of its unique aesthetic. Look, I know the visuals look dated and a bit silly, but few games have visuals so endearing and charming. I know I'm not the only one who feels that way either, or else Minecraft's graphics wouldn't be so iconic. Could you take a texture from Gears of War, Halo or Uncharted, put it on a shirt and have players identify it? I doubt it. The looks just work, giving the game a super unique appearance that's memorable, and brings up a bit of nostalgia in me for 8-bit era games.   I love creating in Minecraft, but my gratification is due, at least partially, to the fact that I have to earn everything. Survival Mode generates a random world with nothing to your name, forced to gather resources in order to construct food, shelter and tools. By the time I crafted and installed a wooden door in my first mud hut I felt a sense of ownership . Other games let you buy a home with the money you earn, but none of them really challenge you to forage for the materials and build it yourself. When I look at my home and see every piece of furniture and wall is exactly where I wanted it, I love it all the more or change it at my whim. From the moment my home was built, my mission was clear: tunnel into the earth in order to get whatever I needed to carve out a fortress in my little part of the world.   Creating items in Minecraft is one of the most important actions you do. The problem, though, is the necessary information isn't found in Minecraft. The first time I beat my way through some trees and gathered wood, I had no clue what to do with it. Thankfully, like many Minecraft players, I had a mentor who pointed me to the various online forums, communities and wikis. I have pages that I return to all the time, often tabbing out of the game itself when I can't remember exactly how to craft an item. For many this is just a rite of passage, but mostly it's an obtuse way to handle crafting. I'd love for the recipes to be integrated into the game somehow, even if I had to find them throughout the world. There's not much of a sense of accomplishment in reading a wiki and just following instructions verbatim.   Even after you find a good resource, it still takes a lot of effort to learn everything. The sheer amount of recipes and items you work with in the game is intimidating and time consuming to learn. Many games have poor documentation, but Minecraft has none at all, and what's available isn't easily digestible.   But Minecraft is still more than fun enough to warrant the learning curve. The addiction, though, really begins as you craft items and gain mastery over your surroundings. Suddenly night time, when monsters spawn and take over the unlit portions of the world, isn't as scary. I mean, it's always a bit scary, but having a sword in hand – even a simple, wood one – instills a sense of power. Like a caveman whittling their first spear or stoking their first fire, building simple tools and torches in Minecraft makes me feel safer, like I am the master of my fate because I have the power to create the items that can save me. Beyond safety, crafting creates a whole new set of goals in Minecraft. I crafted items as needed (tools and torches), but eventually I expanded my repertoire to include superfluous pieces. To finish my first stone keep I had to craft stairs and ladders; simply jumping up a simple series of platforms was unbecoming of the king of the land, after all. Crafting slowly became something I did less to survive, and more to complete the next big project I set out for myself. Creating panes of glass didn't really give me an edge in my world, for instance, but it did make the viewport of my scale Star Wars AT-AT look a lot more badass. Crafting even gets more complex if you want it to. You can create tools and buildings or elaborate self-powered rail systems, taking you from the stone age to the 20th century,, and making you feel like the fate of my world lies squarely in my hands. It's exhilarating, and instills a sense of power that I rarely feel in games.   After I secured a plot of land in my world, my intentions during a session with Minecraft changed. Each session became an adventure, wherein I challenged myself to go exploring for the next crucial component parts needed for the next recipe. These self-imposed quests are why I sometimes venture into the Nether, a hellish other world where monsters – who just so happen to drop precious materials – live. Other times I venture into dark caves, donning crafted armor and enchanted weapons so that I can tackle whatever enemies I come across. I don't know what exactly I'll find, or what terrors I'll face, but I do it all in the name of finding precious blocks – and the thrill of the experiencing the unknown.   That thrill, that experience of unplanned and unpredictable adventure, makes every session with Minecraft exhilarating. Sometimes I might end up spending the evening doing mundane activities like farming or hunting for food, but other nights I might end up stumbling upon a gigantic, randomly generated mine that's full of monsters and treasure. Because each world is procedurally created, I never know just what I'll stumble upon next. One day my character may be a simple builder, the next he's a dungeon conquering hero who slays horrors in the dark.   Of course, adventuring is always better with friends, and Minecraft's multiplayer is great fun if you can get it working. It isn't broken or a completely buggy mess, but requires a lot steps to get started compared to most games. If you want to start a game you'll need to download additional software, and go through all kinds of online tutorials to get it working. Players who just want to join a game have to know the server's I.P. address, since there is no server browser built into the game. Still, annoyances and tedium aside, if you have the option to play with others you definitely should; exploring, adventuring and building up epic structures is a lot more fun with friends. Besides, if you're going to spend hours of your life building gigantic monuments, you might as well have someone else to show them to. You can post them in online videos, but it just isn't the same as having your friend right next to you sharing in your accomplishment. Or, even better, having them log on after a period of inactivity to be stunned at the marvels you've built in their absence.   If you're not the type to play with others, and you don't want to earn all your materials, you can always jump into Creative Mode. In this world you're invincible, and have access to every item in the game. It's great if you want to, say, create a gigantic Wampa from Star Wars, but it doesn't give me the same sense of reward or accomplishment I get when playing Survival since I don't have to earn the blocks or fend for my life while doing so. Many blocks take considerable effort to acquire (some even make you journey into monster filled labyrinths), so when I build them in my Survival Mode it's a lot more impressive. Still, it's a fun distraction.

Out of so many games on the market that call themselves and adventure game this one truely stands out among them as an adventure game. The devs have not only given us free content over the years and still plan on adding more to the game to this very day, but the customisation of armor and the plethora of things you can build. From city skycrapers, Dr.Willy's lab, floating wizards towers, and straigt to Dracula's castle from Castlevania. The imagination can run wild in this game.    Also the amount of time you can spend playing with friends in this game is mind boggling. You and if you have friends will set out to find resources and have stories of crazy things, funny accidents, and epic tales of battle between you and a piranha or that annoying flying fish when it rains, who some how got into the house.    Is this game worth getting? The answer is yes sure some might not like games like this but once you really get into it, it becomes almost a journey just to see what's next after mining that first ore or getting that first new trinket with a cool new wand for magic.

Terraria is a game chalk-full of adventure, having followed Redigits previous work I was informed that he was working on a new title through his YouTube channel. I was immediately interested to see that he was making a newer, larger, better game, that was going to have its own steam release in 2011.   I made my Steam account for this game alone. I stuck with it for a long time and played again after every update came out, It quickly sold over 1.6 million copies. To my suprise Redigit gave the news that he was working on a larger update to surpass the legacy of the already classic game. After this there was supposed to be over 1000 items in the game if my memory is right. The update added several changes to the game including colored lighting and a new hard mode that would be activated after defeating a new boss in the game.   Some time after (a year or so I believe) another large update came which added even more content and further expanded upon the ideas that came out with the previous large update along with the news that Redigit would no longer be working on Terraria updates because he was having a child.   He raised his child for a long enough for him to be able to concentrate on work and gave his fans hype as he was working on a large update to finalize terraria with more features and mechanics than ever before. 1.3 was released long after he began it as his time to work with the game was now limited as he had a child to take care of.   Terraria is one of the best selling indie games of all time, at the time of this posting having over 12 million copies sold. The game is well worth the money as the developers work hard and really earned all the money they made, you can really tell how much effort they put into it after playing 50 hours or so. Now we all wait for Terraria other world.  If you have not yet purchased a copy of Terraria I highly reccommend it as it is very easy to get into and is quite simple if you consider yourself to be a noob its well worth the low asking price of $10 but if your tight on money the only thing that waiting for a sale of $7.50, $5, or $2.50 will hinder is the proggress of your creation.

For thous intrested in buying this game I would honestly say yes, yes you should by this game. Though I will say that if you want to buy this game because it's like minecraft, well I'd suggest reading a bit further.   First off Minecraft and Terraria are two completly different games.  Of course they share a crafting system, and a randomly genrated world kind of nature, but how they play and how they are paced are completly different.  Terraria is a 2D game, that is more foucos on dangerous exploring, loot drops, and boss fighting, if not in your 'home base' you will be almost always fighting some form of enemy, day or night. While Minecraft has more 'space' and biomes, it doesn't have the same density as Terraria, and Terraria also benifites from it's slightly planed out spaces.  Minecraft is about building, shaping, and creating structures and places, where terraria is more about adventureing, dungenireering, and the mastery of the land itself. In Terraria your fight is truly againest the world, and you have to scrap out a home fast, dig deep, craft and get stronger or you will die over and over and over again. This is a game more focoused on survial, than just building, though you can do both at the same time.  For new players I'd suggest either going to the wiki first or talking to the in game NPC guide for help, and maybe even doing the turtorl first just incase. First night is hard, but in all honesty the nights to come will be harder.

What can I say that hasn't been said already? For being less than a fifth of a gigabyte in size, this game is MASSIVE and addicting. While people often compare it to Minecraft, it's more 'Metroidvania', meaning there's emphasis on exploring, backtracking, and bossfighting. Unlike Metroid/Castlevania, you craft your own gear, summon the bosses when you're ready, for the most part, and build your own town in a randomly generated world, which is what draws the comparison to Minecraft.   The only gripes I have with this game are small. Something Minecraft did right was the bed 'mechanic'. You could sleep at night to fast forward to daytime, assuming there were no enemies nearby. Here, beds only serve to set a respawn point. You must wait the full 10 minutes or so 'till daybreak. Considering some events only happen at random nights, it's frustrating having to wait day after day to see it will happen. Another thing is console commands. Some may call it cheating, but for those of us who like experimenting with items or want to relax and build a town, collecting rare materials, making farms, hunting bosses, and so on can be very time consuming. While there are ways to add items to your character, these can be risky. And if there is a legitimate way to do it, I apologize for not having found it.   Overall a great game. The massive updates show just how much love the devs have for it, and for 10 bucks, it's more than worth the nit-picks.

This game is an extremely solid choice if you want to get lost in it for a couple days. For those who don't know, this is a 2D, sandbox~based, exploration game. Akin to classic NES - SNES titles mixed in with modern procedurally generated content.  -The combat relies on stat based matchups and positioning, which can make it fun to play against other players, but the AI is quite dumb. That being said, while the AI may lack strategy behind it, they ramp it up with damage, and hordes of enemies to ward off, making it satisfying when you overcome what's thrown at you.  -Item progression is tied directly to combat. The main game revolves around building up your character to be ready for the next fight, and the next tier of items. Honestly, I would have liked it if there wasn't a (literal) wall between you and unlocking the rest of the game. Add to that a frustrating lack of diverging paths to the destination, and it ruins the experience. Luckily, the payoff for completing tasks is almost always rewarding. There is tons of content hidden in this, but it takes a LOT of legwork to get to.  -Exploration takes you from field, to cave, to ice, to jungle, to desert, to hell, and to the sky. While the world itself isn't infinite, there is plenty of stuff in it so there's something new to see. Much of the world is divided by different boss encounters and what kinds of items you have. Certain items deal with enemies from a certain place better than those from another. It's a good balance, but it can be quite evident where the lines sit for where you need to go next.  -The inventory is VERY nice. Simple crafting, and equips make it one of the most well designed things in the game. As with most sandbox games, inventory clutter is an issue, but easily fixed thanks to the trash can slot. Being vain, I would have liked if you had the option to hide armor sets like you could with accessories. It got to be a pain sometimes when I wanted my character (Wii Fit Trainer) to be able to show her hair, or her starter clothes. I am not a fan of how they dealt with hair in this either. All characters with long hair would have their hair invisible when they're wearing a helmet, and then some of the hats are unwearable because the hair you're using just doesn't match it. There are many options to customize though. That's what makes the system great.  Overall, without jumping into spoilers, it is a very good game. I would recommend going to the wiki if you're stuck, but otherwise try to stay clear of it. It is extremely fun to descover new things in this game. Knowing all the end game stuff can ruin your perception of the cool stuff you may get now, and that's no fun.  Would I recommend it? Yes. If you're just a fan of 2D combat, this is a great buy. If you love exploration, then this is your package. It is honestly one of the best games I've played in a long time, despite my nitpicks. I'm sure in later updates they could get fixed.

I once played Terraria a few years ago and it was alright, but kind of frustrating and not too much content.  4 years later...there's a truck-load of more content and lots of little improvements that make the overall experience far more enjoyable. Notably with chests, you can name them, and with one click you can quick-stack all extras of items that you have in your inventory, directly into the chests. This makes a HUGE difference as there are well over a thousand items and you used to have to micro-manage it all.  Difficulty is fairly well balanced into the late game, and there's a variety of bosses and other challenges. Although,  Expert mode bosses in multiplayer  (specifically) are a bit insane. Not impossible, but it feels very grindy to ensure your team's survival.  The 'system requirements' on the store page are NOT accurate as of this writing. With the 1.3 update, things can get very tense with lots of objects and collisions on screen, and it doesn't feel very optimized when that happens. One example was during the Pumpkin-Moon event, performance got so bad that I was dying as soon as I spawned, while the screen was practically frozen. I don't have a high-end machine but performance got a lot worse further into the hardmode events and boss fights.  If you want to just have fun outside of the natural adventure mode, there are downloadable worlds that have all the items available. Just Google/YouTube for them.  As of the 1.3 update, a very polished 2D adventure/crafting game that excels with multiplayer and definitely worth the price.

It looks ancient, and overly simple, and you'll think to yourself, how could that ever be fun?  And that'll be after you spend three days of your life playing it. It's surprisingly entertaining, and fairly diverse. Additional content still being made for the game as well. (03Jun11)

Terraria, a game that has evolved so much over the years. This game was initially regarded many as a minecraft rip-off. It definitely wasn't a rip off then, and it definitely isn't a rip off now.  The game throws you into a randomly generated world to survive on your own (or with others) against hordes of zombies, eyeballs, spiders and 100+ other creeps and weirdos. The game caters to everyone! If you enjoy fast paced action, Terraria has it. If you enjoy being creative, making massive build projects, Terraria has it. If you want to have fun, Terraria does it.  If you haven't purchased it already, buy it! It often goes on sale.  Buy it and prepare for the 1.3 update. :D EDIT: Post 1.3 Now that 1.3 is out, you have no reason to not get it! For me, it gave me well over 50 more hours and counting of gameplay.  It's only $10, so why not? Oh and the game goes on sale a lot, so if you aren't too sure, wait until then. :)

RATING - 8.5/10 One of the best 2D action-filled, creative, and progressive games. From exploring underground caverns, to evil dungeons, to the very depths of hell (and walls of bacon), this game never fails to keep you on your toes and begging for more!   Pros: Wonderful progression system based around armor (and later on what type of character you prefer playing. Warrior, Mage, or Archer). An extensive list of different accessories, weapons, and armor that will make any completionist want a manequin of every set in the game. Action packed with over a dozen different bosses and three times that for different monsters. Creative reign over the world's difficulty. On softcore, You drop a portion of your money on death. Mediumcore, You drop everything on death. Hardcore, You die for good. . . but you get to float around your world as a ghost. Now has seasonal 'events' which will change your world around a bit in terms of dropped items, and adds hard mode events as well! The game will always keep you on your toes, and is loads of fun with friends as well as solo.  Cons: While the game keeps you on your toes, it's also hard! It's recommended to play Softcore until you really get the hang of it. NOTE: Some people might like/dislike hard games so this isn't a major con. Will keep new players on the wiki quite a lot. While the game has a guide built in for crafting, he doesn't help too much in terms of direction and how certain mechanics work and where to go. Similarly on how the guide doesn't give much direction, much of someone's errors in the game will be unavoidable just because you won't know how something worked in the first place. I can't tell you how many times I died just running straight into the dungeon at first before 'certain things' were achieved. No built in creative mode for the more buildy type peoples (like me).  ---  Overall, it's a wonderful game. Not to mention the amount of multiplayer pvp game modes and goof offs you could make are endless with how many different weapons & armor (and costumes) there are in the game. If you are into getting ripped apart by derplings, slaying harpies & wyverns with your laser rifle, or just building amazing works of 2D art (as people have), Terraria is for you!

Terraria is a very fun game, to me atleast,it has a lot to offer, it is a sandbox-adventure whatever, it includes a sort of, how do i put this, class system? But not really, there IS classes, but its not forced. You can be all four a once, there is just different sets of armor to boost a certain class, so if you want to be summoner focused then get spooky armor or stardust. If ranged, shroomite or vortex etc. There are lots of bosses, and mini-bosses. And by mini-bosses i mean unique and powerful enemies that arent your run-of-the mill zombie,(or in Hardmode,wraith/posessed armor),i.e Wyverns,Medusa etc etc etc. This game (since 1.3) has great multiplayer that is seamless, just go to your friends profile and hit join game, while they're in a multiplayer server thingy. The game when released had tons of content, but every big update 1.1/1.2/1.3 ++++ adds tons of content. It also now has difficulty levels, Normal/Expert, expert buffs bosses, adds new unique 'Expert' items that are dropped from the bosses, i.e shield of cthulu, worm scarf etc etc. Terraria has lots of different ores that are randomly chosen, so you either have iron or lead, cobalt or palladium or mythril or orichalcum etc etc. There are a few biomes like Purity which is basically the normal foresty thing, then snow, crimson, corruption, jungle, desert, and sea, all with (besides purity) corruption/crimson counterparts. Along with hell and floating islands theres tons to do. 11/10

Where too begin, where too... begin... Let's see.  Terraria, I picked up pretty much on release date and played it for quite awhile. Found the bosses and got myself the 'best' gear for the time, and felt like I had mastered the game. Put it down for awhile. Fast forward a few years, hard mode is released. 'hard mode?' Go down to hell, summon wall of flesh. 'WHAT THE FU-dead.' Gather up all my gear, fight him, hardmode unlocked. 'what mode? hey a unicorn!-dead'  Fast forward again, just picked it back up after... 2ish years? I think...?  ...Fell in love with it all over again. I tend to be a fighter in games and this game delivers on what I enjoy, combat, in a style YOU prefer, and can switch to any type you want on the fly. Swords, bows, guns, yoyos, staffs, boomerangs, miniuons, cannons... so many different things to use!  and NPC's can fight back!? THEY CAN DEFEND THEMSELVES NOW!?!?! Sound the holy chorus! they can fight back a goblin invasion! Seriously everything about the game has just... roof? Do you see a roof? No? it got BLOWN THE **** OFF BY THIS GAME. Castle, huts, cities, characters, painting, accesories, designing, modding, bosses, monsters, dungeons, randomly generated worlds. There is so... so much content.  And now... Expert mode... yes, all the yes. If you thought, you had mastered Terraria, could dominate it's bosses without breaking a sweat and could no longer die? Try this on for size, and cry all over again. Bosses that you could beat with a simple back hand will now pummel you mercilessly. I got killed by an expert mode skeletron while using post-golem equips (hardmode against normal mode boss) on expert mode, with a friend. and friends don't make bosses easier anymore, oh no. The more players in your world, the more health that boss has. Ever see the eye of cthulu with nearly 10k health? When normally he bairly has over 2k? That's when 4 people are on. FOUR PEOPLE. Imagine a whole community!  What can I say, my love for this game has sparked, and now that multiplayer is supported Via steam allowing ME to finally host with my friends, without needing any fancy program to allow me to hold a server on host, the game has more then lit the candle, it god darn lit up my whole castle with ice torches of awesomeness. Because Ice castles are awesome. I could never recommend this game enough.

Let me tell of a recent adventure I had while playing this with my friend...  We started on a large island. Wasn't as large as I thought it would be, but it was large enough. Of course, we started gathering woods first, so we could have a shelter for the first night. Whereas my friend focused more on the framework, I focused more on making our shelter look pretty, by adding a Japanese-themed roof. Once we placed the last chair, the Guide rushed towards our newly made house and declared it his.   Our first night wasn't bad. We just stayed inside, made a second floor while we were fighting off hordes of zombies, and eventually turned it into a temporary shooting range! So for the whole night, we shot zombies with our bows and arrows.  The rest of the game was spent doing pretty much that. We collected woods (and sometimes stones), improved on our shelter (which eventually turned into a tower), and eventually mined. We kept mining a specific network, which in time lead us to the Underworld. Now mind you, we played on Hardcore. So if I died, then I die for good on that server. Anywho, our first trip to the Underworld wasn't too bad. We made a hellevator, and rode it down to the Underworld. We scouted for a bit, until we were attacked by demons. When we lost more that 50% of our health, we knew it was time to go back. And so, we teleported back home with our magic mirrors.  So from that day forward, our mission was to mine the Hell out of Hell. Now this is where the story ends. I thought for sure that I would have died from a demon, or fell and slipped into lava, but no, it was from something else entirely. I decided to discover more of the network of caves, and hope to find treasure chests here and there. But no.   I stepped on a pressure plate, and a boulder fell on me. I died, while my friend laughed and stole my items. That was when I stopped playing Terraria. Then update 1.3 came and I was like, 'Yipeee, I wonder what other deadl y contraptions Redigit has in store for me!'   -pls excuse bad inggris.

So here's a legit full review.  This game has had STABLE updates(more or less) from day one. and my god, it has come a long frikin way. every update keeps me comin back to it everytime with something new to discover each time. As you have probably noticed i have ♥♥♥♥♥ load of hours logged in this game. To make matters better it now has Steam integrated multiplayer, which for the longest time it didnt have, and made playing with just one or two friends and chore to set up. Now with steam integrated multiplayer its easy as hell!  Lets discuss gameplay and mechanics. At first glance it gives you the impression its just a minecraft clone, but once you actually get into it its actually more of an action platformer with crafting and building mechanics. It also does a good job of never getting boring on you cause there is always something to do in the game, such as bosses, dungeons, nightly events, seasonal events and a plethora of kickass weapons, i couldnt list them all if i wanted to. it controls just how you expect although there isnt any gamepad controls, it doesnt really need it nor would it feel comfortable. The combat is also surprisingly well done, save for pvp of course, and makes boss fights mega intense. all in all, just a fun game to play. Now for level design. The world you generate usually has five or seven biomes each with their underground variants for the first part of the game. Each biome has significant materials, ores, items, enemies, and bosses to accompany them for variety. after you get through the first part (post wall of flesh) you will see more biomes added, new enemies, treasures, new events ,and even more ores to mine. Everything thing gets increased in its own right.  Final Verdict: This game is a must own, if you are the kind of person with a creative side, who likes survival games like minecraft. i can easily give this game a 10/10. true its not a game for everyone, but it is a game you should at least try. and for that price? hell yeah you should buy it. like i've said, there is always something to do.

Terraria... It's like a 2D Minecraft, with a lot more to do. I will make this review simple.  Pros: *Can build beautiful things, even with slopes/half-slabs. *It's enjoyable/fun. *It has a lot of different mobs and items, some rare. *Hilariously sad things can happen if you don't pay attention to where you're going. *Plenty of caves to explore. *No durability on items! *'Background' animals that you can (sort of) interact with...... *Doesn't take long to download. *The music is pretty cool. *Quite a few bosses (though more couldn't hurt...). *The jokes and puns hidden in the game. *The graphics/art are easy to look at.  Cons: *Not possible (to my knowledge) to zoom in ingame. *Can't really tell what your character looks like, as the creation screen (and everything else ingame) is tiny. *Sometimes there are more pools than islands... *Tiny worms who like to stalk you for 5 hours and only attack you when you're busy doing other things. *Panic attacks from /the quack/....  I do think that this game is definitely worth getting if you enjoy exploring and building things. I've gotten a lot of enjoyment out of it, especially after all the updates it's had. Hopefully, there will be many more updates.  8/10

This is a side-scrolling sandbox RPG. If you think this is Minecraft, you're going to have a bad day. It's massively different. First off it has tons of useful (especially after 1.3) NPCs, a lot of weapons, tools, materials, armor, blocks and BOSSES! I mean this thing is so big that if you could have infinite worlds you could play for your whole life. But it only has small, medium and large worlds but that doesn't mean it's bad. Also you can have characters that can go in all of your single-player worlds and/or multiplayer servers (either with friends via Steam (YASSSS, FINALLY!) or IP adress), with 3 difficulty levels (softcore, mediumcore and hardcore) and 4 world types (normal, expert, with corruption(purple)/crimson(red). It doesn't even need mods, it has a huge pile of end-game content and tons of community made challenges (like speedruns, or special goals (kinda like the pokemon nuzlocke challenge).  In conclusion it's a fun, awesome and (not really)  relaxing  adventure.

When you first start Terraria, one thinks 'Oh. This is literally Minecraft, minus a dimension.' and in the beginning, that's pretty much what it is. You scavenge for tools, armor, and weapons in the topsoil, and explore the area around you. Before long, though, nighttime will roll around, and those words spring up on the bottom lefthand corner: 'You feel an evil presence watching you...'.  Before too terribly long, you'll encounter your first boss fight with the Eye of Cthulu, which will start a trend of several intense boss fights, pressing you to go deeper into the world to find bigger and better things to fight. The boss fights are definitely a huge focus of the game, going through the Crimson (or the Corruption, depending on which one spawns in your world) and fighting the Brain of Cthulu, or mining straight to Hell and fighting the Wall of Flesh, but these are just the beginning.  One large perk of this game OVER Minecraft is the fact that your character and your world are completely seperate, meaning that your character can not only bring their armor and equipment to another world, your inventory also carries over, meaning you can bring building materials or items to trade with other players, should the need arise.   If there's anything bad to say about the game, it's the fact that there isn't a Creative mode, and there's really not that much to do post game, save for a few events such as the Frost Moon, and the new Moon Lord content. The good thing is that it takes about 20+ hours of gameplay to run out of bosses, but the game isn't over then. Oh no, the game is FAR from over, as there are hundreds of items to collect, hundreds of equipments to craft, and hundreds of places to discover and destroy. Not to mention that with the additions of the Steam achievements, there're more goals to reach than ever before.  All in all, Terraria is a game to get lost in. Those who don't like grinding for equipment might not enjoy it, but those of us who enjoy exploring a new world and losing hours upon hours of our lives to discovery will find a treasure trove of delight that we haven't experienced since Lego Island and the Minecraft beta.

I originally played Terraria when it was first released. I played for about 100 hours back then, collecting most stuff and defeated all the bosses there were at that point. In the meantime this game had (as far as I understand) 2 major updates with small-medium ones in between. The release of 1.3 made me curious and I already invested another 100+ hours in this game since 1.5 weeks.  This game is truly incredible. It merges the snes era with modern elements which create awesome, hilarious and stunning possibilities. The 2D sidescrolling is only amplifying the nostalgic feeling of games like Castlevania, Mario, Mighty Max etc. The combat is nice and solid. Currently there are 4 ''classes'' available you can work towards: The Summoner, Sorcerer, Ranger and Warrior. You simply focus on the pieces of gear and weapon to focus on a class. You might as well make a hybrid character and mix it up a little up to your taste.  Crafting is deep. Like ''Adele rolling in the deep'' deep. There are so incredibly many items which brings me to the one and only complaint: It are simply TOO many items. This causes your inventory to fill up rather quickly (auto loot is always on) and you either have to take a trip back to your base or start deleting useless items every 15 minutes or so. The only way to get this in order is to create chests, label said chests and start sorting. Once you have quite a collection of items you can simply click autostack items you already have in the chests, Before you arrive at that point it's quite the time investment to sort all important items.  The adventuring is just magnificent. 15 big bosses and various small bosses and a plethora of mobs await you. There are events like a Pirate invation, Goblin invation, Halloween event, slime event etc. which all cause unique mobs and bosses to spawn. Deal with them by smashing them, shooting them, burning them or create traps to lure them in and let your crafty traps do all the work for you. There is so much variety in this game, it's just amazing.  The friendly colours and looks when you stumble upon this game are deceiving. The game can become pretty hard and really extreme on Expert Mode. There is plenty of challenge to be had. This game is worth it.

This is my current experince with Terraria. Currently I am just review the multiplayer because i have never have gone all the way to end game alone.  + You cant put this game down because you always want to be ahead of your friends, an example is the whole game is a race for the next tier of items and ever time you get a new weapon or set of armor you are overwhelmed with accomplishment.  + I cant get enough of how much content is in this game, just look at my hours you can spend hours using an inventory editor and just see what ever item in the game does or fighing as many bosses as once. It takes a good 75 hours to beat the moon lord for me and every update they manage to squeze in a extra 20 hours of time to end game, I love it.  + There are Three main types of combat and later armor melee, range summoner and magic. Melee has the most defence but has a limited range unless you are using end game items. Range has a high dps and end game armor makes you have a lower chance to be spotted. Summoner has medicore defence but gives you many more minoins to do the owrk for you. Magic sets usually the least defence but the highest dps and unlike melee or magic you use mana as ammo.   + The style very colorful and the music fits the boime or event nicely.  + Building is simple but you still have a massive range of well anything you want to make. I spend more time making basses and boss areas than anyting else in the whole game.  - I have had many issues with the steam integration so I would recomend just port forwarding the game and then hosting the server.  - Many public servers are flooded with people who spawned in the best items in the game only to go around massacring the whole server.  After reading this review I hope you get the idea. Get, This, Game.

I loved it on my tablet and I love Terraria even more on my PC. Getting multiplayer to work with your router requires port forwarding. My router is a 3Wire and most guides were for Linksys routers. Basically I set it to TCP, DirectX, and used the default 7777 port. Made the mistake of creating the profile, but not adding it to the 'active' box on my router. But once I did it worked like a charm. I ended up setting up the dedicated server on my desktop PC so my whole family can play from their laptops together. plus my brother is an over-the-road trucker so he logs in when he has a hotspot to connect to.  Love this game!

Terraria is a wonderful sidescrolling game. Terraria has tons of mobs, hostile, and friendly. Along with many NPCs with their own traits and items they wish to sell to you. Tons of bosses, and weapons to fight them with. Events where you with be attacked by Pirates, Goblins, Halloween creatures, Christmas creatures, Full Moon events, Blood Moons, and other strange things. Character Creation: There ae many hairstyles, and many colors you can choost from, and many ways to make your character. Also, if your not happy with the hairstyles, make a game, find the Hair Stylist NPC, and ta-da, you have another huge selection of hair styles to try! There are also costume drops around halloween, Clothier NPC, and a Wandering NPC(who may have some vanity stuff). Hundreds, no, millions of weapons to craft, find, and slay monsters with. Many bosses to fight, Skeltron, The Eye, The Brain, The Devourer, The Wall of Flesh, Plantera, Golem, Duke Fisheron, The Twins, The Destroyer, Skeltron Prime(and the Optional 'boss' that one hit kills: Dungeon Guardian). The only limit to building is your imagination. Three world sizes of exploration(small, medium, large). Terraria also, doesn't just stop, once you've got the best weapons, or beat all the bosses. Like stated before, the only limit is your imagination. And if your bored of playing alone, play with friends, or find a community server. Play Capture the Gem, or Team DeathMatch, Every Man for Themselves, etc. I highly recommend Terraria for everyone.

Terraria is definitely the most fun I've had with a game in awhile. The first thing I noticed were the pixelated visuals, and they work so perfectly with its vast environment. The game's mechanics are really solid, and its replay value is substantial. It's especially fun to pick up with friends. It appeals more to the explorer than the crafter, however. There's always something to go out and search for or obtain in the game, and I love that feeling. Although you can build awesome, detailed structures in Terraria, it's fairly limited as it's a sidescroller. In the end, your main objectives are to explore and combat against the various bosses in the generated world.   Overall, it's a great game, especially with friends.

2D Magical Minecraft. 3 words that will turn off hundreds. Terraria is a simple 2D side-scroller, but beaming with content. Hundreds of items and weapons. Though hundreds of items and plenty of mechanics can become confusing, Terraria contains a wonderful tutorial that Don't Starve had. Not hand-holding, not dropping textbooks onto you, and yet requiring trips to the Wiki to find another item you say 'Woah! I need that ASAP!' to. But once you obtain all the items to make a wonderful loadout and the beautiful 2 story home, things can become boring. This dry period only lasts for moments, as Terraria has something Minecraft can never re-create. Things become boring, and you have a wonderful idea: GO TO THE RIGHT. To your left is a jet blue ocean, illuminating with the neon jellyfish and the sun's reflection. You make the bold decision to venture your way past the high busy trees you have seen out your window. You grapple and wall-climb your way across flat flowery fields, dark dingy caves, and sprawling snowy mountains. The adventure never ends, neither does the replay value. In the strange case where exploring and having fun aren't your things, the updates constantly released by the developers add even more reasons to buy Terraria. Minecraft fans may still remain unamused. To them I say, Terraria is Minecraft. Terraria is Minecraft with a few mods and supportive developers (Look back to Notch selling Mojang to Microsoft). I have left many points out because my fingers are hurting from typing this ♥♥♥♥♥y a$$-kissing review, but so be it. I have invested hundreds of hours into Terraria. I hope you, possible customer, will do the same. Looking back, Terraria is 3 words: 2D Magical Minecraft.

I haven't played all that much yet but in the time I have played I have THOROUGHLY enjoyed it.  To begin the game it's very simple: Choose language make a character,world size, etc. Very simple and to the point but there are lots of submenus to get lost it.  When you start the game you are placed in a world with some trees and maybe some water. There will also be an npc which will give you some tips on what to do. The combat system is very simple from what I've seen just a point and click but don't take my word for it. At night is when things get really hostile. You will most likely spend your first night hiding in a cave you've boarded up and hoping the zombies don't eat your face.   I don't want to spoil too much of the gameplay but I'll give you all the pros and cons   PROS +very in depth crafting system with no recipes, no memory required +neat graphics +good exploration mechanics +very tough if you like that kind of thing but there are options for people who don't +lots of different world sizes  CONS -simple fighting mechanics? -submenus are confusing at times -not newb friendly (it's still easy to get into though) -character customization is slightly limited

This game... Oh man. I've had this game for a few years now, and every game I've played since then I've found myself asking why it can't be as good as Terraria. Even games in completely different genres could learn a lot from Terraria, because it does everything right - things not just applicable to sandbox or crafing games, but all games in general.  For example,   1) Terraria has the perfect depth & pace of progression. Are you tired of playing games where your charater barely changes from the start of the game to the end of the game, or where equipment advancement is just an afterthought? Have no fear! Terraria has many tiers of equipment; each of which is generally necessary to get the next tier. However, advancing & acquiring new gear is certainly no boring grind-fest. There is so much variety in how to acquire ingredients & equipment, the progression is exciting, rewarding, and purposeful.  2) Everything in the game can be obtained in single-player. So although it might be more fun to play with others & showboat your awesomeness, multiplayer is not required to achieve said awesomeness, which is is a real plus to a hermit player such as myself. You can eventually get the Best-in-Slot equipment for your character, and it feels very rewarding to do so, satisfying those with completionist compulsions.  Seriously, if more games could just practice the two things mentioned above, I would be a very happy gamer

This short review goes to those of you enthusiasts of 2D RPGs: Terraria also adds crafting and building to this mix. Terraria and minecraft are often compared to eachother. And for obvious reasons. Both are sand-box, survival hunting games with crafting mecanics. But to me, terraria is the better game between the two because of how it handles the combat and the amount of things there are to do in the game. In minecraft, you have 6 ores. But in terraria, you have over twenty. And yes, i know the old saying. Quality over quantity. but terraria passes in the quality of its ores too. Minecraft armor looks the same aside from its color. But in terraria, each armor and wepon has its own style for each brand of ore. Not to mention, in terraria there is so much more to do then minecraft. Theres a dungion with a ton of new mobs and items, random events with awesome loot, tons of bosses and so much more. While minecraft has alot to offer, it just pales in compareason to terraria. To me, the only thing minecraft has going for it is the fact that its 3-D. I always believed that if terraria came out first and was marketed a bit better, then it would have the reputation that minecraft has. If you want a survival game that is more combat and exploration based, you play terraria. if you want a survival game that is more building based, you play minecraft. I dont know about you, but i'd pick terraria over minecraft anyday.

Terraria is a 2D adventure game that is sometimes compared with Minecraft. It is a completely different game though. In Terraria you don't have the excessive freedom like in Minecraft but you have more RPG-like elements in Terraria than in Minecraft (unmodded). You get different weapon types and boss fights for example. The game is quite challenging if you play alone especially when you enter the hardmode (figure out how you enter by yourself ;)). With friends it's much easier but still fun. Content is added by updates but not too frequent. Those are then very comprehensive though. It's cheap and definitely worth buying. Check it out!

Yes. Yes. Yes. Minecraft aint' got ♥♥♥♥. This game is mindblowingly amazing, and it deserves its 97% positive rating on steam. You play as a little pixel man (or woman) who chops down trees, mines, makes armor, AND KILLS THE HUNDREDS OF DEMONS OF HELL, COLLECTING EXPLOSIVE MAGICAL DESTRUCTIVE WEAPONS TO MAKE THE ENTIRE WORLD BEND TO YOUR WILL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! One of the best parts of this game is that you can play as different classes. You don't get to choose a class in the make a character screen, but there are so many different weapon types and armors to support it that you can really make your own character, instead of everyone using the same gear like in Minecrap.   Using an entire set of the same armor gives you a boost, whether it be health regeneration, defense, or mana points. Your gigantic arsenal of weapons and armor goes to good use, with 14 different bosses to fight, all with unique battles and different loot for you to use. There are also over 100 enemies, which piles on to that amount. Now for specifics.  -Graphics 8/10 You'd expect something lower, but this is the perfect game to have these graphics. With the weapons and bosses... it just works.  -Sound 9/10 Not only does this game have supreme sound effects, but it has fitting music for wherever you are playing too. Music changes depending on time of day, depth, biome or boss battles.  -Price 10/10 $9.99 For all of this? Hell yes! It may seem like another cheap little indie game that you'll waste your money on... but you'd be wrong. I wouldn't be surprised if they got away with selling it for 30 bucks!  -Gameplay 9/10 Amazing gameplay, with loads of ways to play and items to collect. The combat is great too, with accessories and healing items playing a large role. The only problem is that mining takes a long time, but that's a small price to pay.  -Overall 10/10 Outstanding game. If you're reading this thinking about bying the game, BUY IT! You will not be dissapointed.

This is quite possibly my FAVORITE game. Although, for the sake of a well-made review, I will indeed mention it's downsides. While many people describe Terraria as '2-dimensional Minecraft' it is far more in-depththan that. There is more of an adventure feel to it. Honestly, I like that. It does not please everybody with it's complexity, though. For a simpler game with a similar feel, I recommend Minecraft, another game, but more sanbox-esque. Terraria involves things like bosses, dungeons, and many countless species and subspecies of monsters. This game doesn't have a Pokedex, either, so you can't look up critters in your handbook. The NPCs are fairly simple, meaning they sell, heal, or help, in essence. The way the game plays is fairly exciting, but can be daunting at first. Keep in mind I haven't had quite an entire weeks-worth of of in-game playing. It is very interesting, but I find it a bit harder to mod than Minecraft, and I have trouble without mods. It is very creatively designed, and I have noticed that it has many more places than the standard world, including hell, the skyworld, and more. This combined with it's variety of biomes encourages exploration and discovery. I have fallen in love with this game and would give it a solid 8.5/10 as it is very enjoyable, but daunting to newer players and difficult to mod.

This game is unhealthily addictive. I've poured way too many hours into it, and by just finishing the game, I unlocked, without trying, all but one achievement. The Supreme Helper Minion achievement is absolutely terrible. it requires that you catch 200 fish for the angler, and by the time I had completed the game, I had only caught about 50. This isn't so bad, save the fact that you can only catch one fish per in-game day (24 real world minutes). Doing a little math, I calculated that I would need to leave the game on for approximately 60 hours (catching a fish every 24 minutes) to 'complete' the game.   Aside from the wonky final achievement, 9/10.  EDIT: Sensing that my computer would kick the bucket soon, I hit the little cloud thingy to upload my saves because I had all end game equipment. On my new computer, I was almost excited to catch the final few fish before I realized that my world and character no longer exist.   Rage. 7/10

I kinda thought Terraria would be a bit boring, a game quickly played and more quickly forgotten... But when it went on sale, and with such high reviews, I couldn't pass it up. I'm glad I didn't. Terraria is awesome, worth every penny (especially on sale) and deserves the high ratings. The devs add content for free, and the content actually adds depth to the game (ironic, considering it is 2D).  Also, I should note that the added content feels natural, rather than forced. Other games sometimes add updates just to keep things fresh, but the new content may be even harder to work with or understand than the original, or just be a pointless difference that takes time to adjust to with no real benefit. Not so here, at least as of when I wrote this review. 10/10. Who needs game-lagging graphics anyway?

Terraria is a 2D adventure sandbox game. There are so many things to do in Terraria, like exploring the underground, fight enemies in the dungeon, fishing, etc. There are so many items in Terraria, and you can craft so many things, like furniture, weapons, armor, potions, etc. You can build your house with almost anything. There are many weapons in the game, not just swords and bows. There are guns, rocket launchers, boomerangs, yo-yos, magical staffs, spell books, lasers and more. If you get the hang of it and would like some challenge, Terraria offers an Expert mode where the bosses will have more HP and do more damage.  I bought Terraria a year ago, I haven't played it much until now. I used to think it was boring, but I later found out that Terraria is an awesome game. The bosses in Terraria are quite challenging, but when you have the proper equipment, it will be easy to defeat them. You can play alone or play with friends in Terraria. Since the new update you can play with your Steam friends very easily. I recommend playing Terraria with a friend because fighting bosses will be a lot easier. The achievements in Terraria are fairly easy to complete. The soundtrack for Terraria is very nice. The Steam Cloud feature is very neat as I wouldn't be worried to lose my progress.  There are events that will happen randomly in Terraria where many monsters will try to attack you in your base which is very annoying most of the time. The corruption/crimson and hallow biomes are really annoying. I can't build peacefuly without worrying my world to be ruined by them, because those biomes will spread throughout the world and will spawn harder mobs too.  Even though the graphics look outdated, the gameplay is truly amazing and will give you hours of fun. I strongly suggest playing Terraria with friends as playing alone will quite difficult. I really recommend this game.

Terraria is a masterpiece. You start off weak and pathetic with no home or direction, then you strengthen yourself, live in a mansion, and strive to become the greatest warrior in the world. Or not! It's up to you. There are many things to do in terrarai and like the description, there is something for everyone. Enjoy a peaceful fishing experience, be a collector, builder, team leader, the choice is your's!  Gameplay wise, it is unlike most I have played. Everything, from progression to mechanics, music and house building, is made with all things in mind. The difficulty curve is great, and boss fights and events keep you on the edge of you seat!  In all, terraria is a must have for anyone who likes retro games, action games, adventure games, sandboxes, or anyone not mentioned who could give the the retro graphics a chance (I personaly like the graphics). What can I say about this game that hasn't been said before? The atmosphere is amazing, there's so much creativity and items that you can barely keep track of it all, and there's countless hours of fun to be had playing Terraria.   The gameplay is simple and leaves you wanting the next best set of gear and possibly that rare item you find once in a very great while. I have this game on the PC (Obviously) and the Xbox 360. The combined total of playtime would have to average out to at LEAST 500 or more hours. I absolutely love this game, there's nothing that's really wrong with it.   So in short here's the pro's of buying this game: +Amazing Gameplay +Thousands of items to find/craft +Hundreds of Enemies to fight +Over 10 unique bosses to conquer +Finding items and exploring feels... right.  +Outstanding Soundtrack +$10! Just 10, really. For over 200 hours I think everyone can spare $10.  Now the Con's: -Multiplayer can be laggy at times. -New players aren't taught much. (Is that such a bad thing that we have to figure stuff out for ourselves?)  That's really all there is to it. I've read some of the comments in the negative review section about people saying it's too hard or falling into caves is tedious and unfair, but they didn't even give it a chance. I saw so many reviews with BARELY any hours on the game, I saw two that had 0.5 hours on their playtime. Some people just don't know a good game if it came and slapped them in the face.  I really can't explain the gameplay in much detail, you really just have to experience this for yourself and see how you like it. Give it a chance and you'll see why over 12 million copies were sold of this game.   So if you haven't bought this game yet, stop reading this review and go get it already! What are you waiting for? ADVENTURE AWAITS!

I enjoyed the hell out of this game.   You start out with practically nothing.   For combat gameplay it's akin to starting a megaman game: your jump sucks, your speed sucks, your wall grip etc sucks. 5 accessory slots let you beef that up as you explore and find new items. unlocking double jump, higher jump, wall grip, grapple, and more (eventually wings). weapon styles are varied as well as the weapons within a style.  story? not really any story in this game. I played this game absolutely solo, and my own internal dialog of 'oh yeah, cthulu eye boss? you want to take me on in my own base? let's do this,' was enough story to accompany the crafting, rpg/gear collecting, and map exploration.  building and customizing your base to the aesthetic you desire is fun. building an 'arena' or 'area to fight monsters spawned during events' is also enjoyable. If you find a trap in a dungeon, you can mine it, pick it up, and place it in your arena, wire it to a timer, or a switch, or a pressure plate.   again. I enjoyed the hell out of this game. so many hours of fun for such a low cost (compared to say, dragon age 3).  edit: I made immense use of the gamepedia terraria wiki site. find an item? look it up, see what's up. Not sure what to do next? Look up the bosses and the unlock mechanisms. etc.

Great game that does 2 things very right.  - Exploration - Building  If you like these 2 things, this game is probably going to be awesome for you.  Pros  - Exploration - Building - Community - Multiplayer - Cute Pixel Graphics - Tough  Cons  - No story - No explanation of what to do - Mining can get boring if you don't switch to building every so often  Can highly recommend this game although exploration is done better in Starbound,

Minecraft 1.9 Update Additions, 15 New Items, 3 New Mobs, New Type of Tree, New Dungon, Remade A Boss And Shields. Terraria 1.3 Update Additions, Revamped Town NPCs, Chests open/close is now animated, Achievements are now available through Steam and in game, Expert Mode, The Goblin Invasion event has been graphically updated and will have a new mini boss enemy in Hardmode. The Pirate Invasion has a new mini boss, The Flying Dutchman. The Blood Moon has a new graphical effect as well as several new enemies. The Solar Eclipse can now be triggered with the Solar Tablet summoning item. This event also has several new enemies and rewards, There are over 800 new items to discover, Added several new mini biomes to world gen. New Biome - The Underground Desert. Liquid Visuals have been revamped. Sky Lakes now spawn. Added a light effect to the Glass Kiln. Slimes can now have items visible inside them that will drop when they die. Wall of Flesh will now spawn a cage of Crimtane Bricks when slain in a Crimson World. Accessory dyes now apply to particle effects spawned from them. Changed player animations to be less bouncy. Trees now drop Acorns alongside actual tree items (rather than either/or). Palm tree tops now drop Acorns. The Crimson now has aligned flora: Vicious Mushrooms, Vicious Powder, and Crimtane Thorns. Game default cave parallax is now 60 , rather than 0. NPCs will not climb stairs into another room anymore. Goblins now have gore unique to each goblin. Improved NPC graphics. Pigrons now appear in greater varieties. Sunflowers now glow at night and give a 'Happy' buff that reduces monster spawns and increases movement speed. Heads on the map stay the same size (regardless of map size). Updated Fountain Graphics. You can now find Marble and Granite biomes underground. Dirt Rod can now move through tiles when held and is cheaper. Pine Tree variations have been added to the Ice Biome. Honey Patches will now spawn during world gen in the Jungle. Ice Patches will now spawn during world gen in the Ice Biome. Abandoned Mine Tracks have been added to world gen. Added several new walls to world gen. There are now water, honey, and lava drips found in the world. They can also be placed with Magic Droppers. Take That Minecrafters. :D

That game. Exactly one year that i play Terraria. This game is really 3P1C! Smooth controls and graphics, if you read: 'Meh, sh*tty Minecraft copy, this is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.' <THIS IS ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T. There are many stuff that differs Terraria from Minecraft. Terraria is realistic, Minecraft is crap, man, you do a sword without hilt, and THROW A ORE INTO A OVEN AND TA-DA! A INGOT. Do Minecraft seems realistic to you? NO. Also, many kids play MC, so this makes tha game poor from decent public.  COMPARATION:ITEMS  Terraria: A f*cking thousand items without counting blocks.  MC: Somewhat 256 items, counting even debug stuff.  GAMEPLAY:  Terraria: Smooth and easy controls, more hotkeys, and stuff.  MC: Even better controls, many, MANY hotkeys, stuff taht help on a 3D world.  GRAPHICS:   Terraria: Heh, pixely graphics, simple stuff, simple but awesome. Detailed blocks, like dirt connecting with stone, colored and happy stuff on the screen, realistic, and AWESOME.  Minecraft: Simpler graphics, but still cool, but in my single opinion, its moody and sad, small color variation, the game's ores are stone with small rocks.  CONTENT:  Terraria: Many ores, tools, weapons, and even troll stuff, more bosses, enemies, and events, THATS why i have a thousand hours of playing this awesome game.  Minecraft: Simple stuff, many decorative blocks, but the thing i most like,on MC is the...  MODS, TEXTURES AND PLUGINS:  Terraria: Freaking hard to put extra stuff on Terraria, they dont even support mods, thats the biggest con on Terraria. Obviously, when you have did almost anything on the game, it gets boring, the solution: DOWNLOAD MODS! But, you cant do this THAT easy with Terraria.  Minecraft: While Terraria SUCKS at this, Minecraft relies, it gets boring sometime, then someone throw on your Skype: BAM! A wild minecraft mod appeared on your message! Minecraft totally supports mod and stuff like this, there is even servers based on modpacks, Technic Launcher is a totally safe launcher that permits you to download modpacks, i dont play MC vanilla by some years, i dont even know what to do anymore.  WORLD:  Terraria: A choice of small, medium and large, many biomes, diferrently from MC, that have only some biomes, Terraria have many, Underground Snow, Sky, Hell, and something like this, but the limitation of world is the crappy part, there should be an infinite option, but this would be very heavy for the RAM, at least a extra large, but no.  MC: The world is basically infinite, nothing more to say, the only thing that it lets me wishing its the lack of biomes,for rest, all ok.   Terraria: 19,5 \ 20 MC: 16 \ 20

This game is amazing, mostly for the fact that there's no one certain way to play. Sure, you could mine up some ore and get some equipment to prepare for that Skeletron boss fight in order to get that Necro Armor to kill the Wall of Flesh using your badass guns and lasers, just to end up scattering pixel art around your world and murdering anything that moves with a merciless onslaught of kittens and rainbows. Or, you could always just build houses forever with no one to live in them. It really is just up to you. There is no right way to play. Want to screw around with some items you hacked in? Cool. Want to play the game traditionally and become one of the many badasses to kill the Moon Lord? Cool. Want to build a bunch of pixel art for the whole world to admire? Cool. Want to spam the gender change potion? Cool, I guess. Want to stop playing after beating the game halfway through because you're stuck on one particular boss? No. Stop. That's the only wrong answer, here. If you want to start playing a game through the traditional route, you will ♥♥♥♥ing COMMIT. YOU DON'T STOP PLAYING. YOU NEVER STOP. GET BACK TO YOUR ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ COMPUTER. YOU AREN'T DONE WITH THIS, YET. Other than that, everything is accepted here, from quite literally painting the sky with rainbows, to hanging up skeletons in your house. Just remember, it's all up to you.

Terraria is a deceptively fun platform-y exploration and crafting game. At first glance, the graphics may deter you, but eventually, you'll come to love them; especially if you have a bit of nostaliga from the console games of yester-year. It's a delightful game that will charm, and lure you in for hours of enjoyment before you realize how long you've been sitting at your computer. I personally initially played the PS3 version with my son, and we conquered just about every aspect. The steam version is much nicer, and actually has better effects; coupled with the fact that I can also play with my steam friends that have the game, it's a definite win.

Terraria is awesome. You don't need anymore explanation. JUST BUY IT ALREADY WOULD YA!?  Do you want an explanation then? FINE!          Terraria is a sandbox game that has so many items in it! If you thought Minecraft has a lot of items, you've never played Terraria! The game has a lot of different things, and the things are divided into two parts. about 1/3 of them are in pre-hardmode, the rest of them are in hardmode. The game can have different ending objectives based on what the character chooses to do. Some goals are to defeat Waffles (Long story, i'll explain later in the text) and some want to defeat some big end game boss called the moon lord or gollum or something. Some players could care less about the zombies, cursed armor and the bride knocking at their door during a blood moon, they are just trying to figure out how to make a disco ball! The way you play the game varies on what you choose to do! Terarria presents something for everyone! Enjoy the blood and slaughter in GTA? You can choose to try to defeat Waffles! Enjoy building things like in Minecraft? You can try to build giant mansions fit for the best players or you can try to build a sandcastle! Enjoy inventing things and experimenting like in scrap mechanic? You can try to create a trap for monsters, or a challenging obstacle course, or a house that can fit all of the NPC's in one place? The game has something for everyone and i doubt that there isn't something for you!   EXPLINATION TO WAFFLES!!  The boss that sends you to hardmode is the wall of flesh.  Wall of Flesh abbreviated is WOF. Try to say WOF. What did it sound like? (Wawlf) Was does that sound like? (Waffles) Waffles= Wall of flesh or WOF   ---------------------------------------------------------- fin.---------------------------------------------------------------

Personally i think although the extra content added to terraria over the years has been a good thing. It has come at a cost. No longer do i feel a great satisfaction after obtaining a more powerful weapon or a faster pickaxe like in days of old. My reasoning is this, you always seem to be acquiring new items to your load out which is great dont get me wrong but it allows you to simply leave out large chunks of the game because there are other ways to do it, easier more fun ways.   Back in the day i used to love the jungle, the mobs, loot and genral feel. The jungle armour seemed like such a rare and great thing to have. It took my ages to get it and it was worth the weight. Now they have effectively knocked down item crafting costs to make the progression faster since there was a few patches after hardmode was added where it took absolutely ages for armour and weapons that would be absolite in 5 minutes. Like any game there is a great sense of achievement getting to the next armour and weapon tier. It is a great feeling but not as great. There's a phrase more is better but i cant help but think they went to far in some aspects.   It might just be me feeling this way but i have seen terraria evolve through many patches each brining new excitement and adventure but i think something changed. Maybe it was the charm, difficulty or the look. Im not going to list why i like the game because i could go on all day and make this review 17 pages long. Its just not the same anymore.

Terraria is an amazing game - action-sandbox where proper building is as integral to strategy as your reflexes, this game has a tendency to really make you think about the things you're doing. It also has a tendency to make you rage at random chance.   PROS +Bright and colorful, light mood +Simple crafting system +Easy-to-learn mechanics +Walking goldfish +Plenty of options for how to go about everything - building your house and character. +Generally intelligent world generation  +Flying fish +Semi-unique monsters - zombies are overused, but the different types of monsters - above and below ground - definitely keep you on your toes.  +So many things to do and get that you'll often get distracted with other things than what you actually planned to do.  CONS -What you should be doing isn't always clear if you don't do research outside the game -Actual melee weapons become useless for a large portion of the game, instead traded for 'ranged' weapons that do melee damage all the way until the end of the game - boomerangs, flails, yo-yos... Swords become a problem as mobility is more important than durability. You'll spend too much time running away from bosses to be able to use that flaming greatsword you just spent ten minutes gathering the materials for.  -Time consuming. Immensely so. A good majority of the game is spent searching for ores, both in the very early stages of the game and the near-endgame, and you'll spend so little time in the sunlight your character should be snow-white. Preparation for most boss fights, the first time around, will generally consist of you spending half an hour building a room and practically filling it with platforms. -Taking the time to do more than set up a teleporter or pressure plated for your doors is rather pointless with wiring, as most of the traps in the game are either expensive to maintain or are so quickly outclassed by your gear that you waste your time bothering. Though if you're setting up things for a server, they certainly add a bit of fun to the game.  -Once you've beaten the 'final boss' - there really is no such thing as a last boss in a sandbox - it may take you some time to want to play the game again, especially if you do the fight by yourself. The feeling of emptiness after such an epic and frantic encounter, knowing that you've effectively beaten all of the game's challenges, makes it difficult to keep playing beyond that. But, I also have no friends, so this particular one may just be a personal problem.

This is a great game for just about anyone. Do you like exploring, building, collecting, or just killing stuff? Its a more robust, 2D version of Minecraft, and better in almost every area. It should have been considered an expansion and cost money if anyone else had made it, but the developers put it out for free. They are putting out more small updates all the time, fixing bugs and adding items.  Pros: great exploration feel, great crafting system, great combat system, great building system. You can create anything Cons: bad inventory management system, have to create servers to play online (sometimes buggy), might not shower for a week when you start playing.

A soft-as-brie science fiction and fantasy destructible terrain ARPG/platformer, with tons of monsters to slay and loot to collect. It has some Minecraft-like elements but is much more fast-paced and combat-focused. There is no leveling system; your character improves with the gear you craft as you defeat incrementally stronger monsters. You can also deeply characterize the look of your character and engage in elaborate home decor if that's your cup of tea.  This game also has: - Bunnies - Harpoons - Grappling hooks - Homeless people that move into your house and sell you things - Wings - Unicorns - Hell - Gender-bending potions - ...and cell phones.
