I love this game. At the time of this review I have 200 hours logged into it.   Let's start with the updates to this game. Everytime I see an update I get excited. There was the massive 1.2 update that was just amazing, and added tons of new content to an already pretty fun game. There was a smaller update that added in great features I never new I wanted.  The gameplay:   The 'infinite' worlds is a very interesting concept. Each world you make you can carry over your inventory. This makes it so, you can get more items by making new worlds and deleting them when you're done, or if the the corruption starts to take over your world, start over and prepare better. You would have the tools to do so.  Another cool note on the world types, is being able to start in a normal and transfer to expert. If you don't want to get thrown straight into an expert world. You can try and beat the game in normal mode, and then after you've completed everything, you transfer all your items to an expert world and try and beat those bosses, and explore the new items. Or if you're up for the challenge, start in an expert world and never take your character to a normal world.  The items are super fun and awesome. Each time I have played I end up with different weapons, and other gear. This makes it a fun experience each time. There are tons of different types of weapons, and weapon tiers, so you can choose different fighting styles. You could try and make it harder by limiting yourself to certain weapon types or banning others. My personal favorite has to be the yo-yos.   TL:DR There are tons of items, weapons, etc. You can take your character from world to world and get new items. 10/10 would recommend. I mean... I am recommending it right now.   PS. Yo-yos are awesome!

Ok, where do I start. This game is insanely AMAZING! Heres a short guide, (would recomend buying).  This is if you want help on what to do (expert): When you spawn in, immediatly build a house for the guide. Although not useful, hes a guide wiki for crafting objects. You can try mining, but I'd recomend crafting the wooden long sword over the one you start with. You can try to mine or play it safe and wait to the next day. PROTIP: Dont try to go outside at night time unless well preped, dont open your doors, DONT. Mine until you get enough iron or gold, (or whatever ore, just dont try copper, its useless) Use these bars to make a better sword (pickaxe and axe comes later, stick with copper for now) Oh yeah, craft a wooden hammer. Once you have a better sword go to the desert, Put your money in a chest, you dont want to lose it! Head over to the desert, if your trying no deaths, bring recalls. Your going to most likely run into 'antilions' These demons are evil, if you see one, try to build over it. (it will hit you with sand, sand hurts.) Once you get over, you will probably see a pit and here some ch-ch-ch noises, these are antilion swammers and antilion chargers, AVOID AT ALL COSTS, these guys fly and charge, they're heavy hitters. Build over the pit, for know. Make sure your getting every cactus, once you have enough cactus, get 80 to be safe, go home, recall or run, then craft cactus armor and a cactus pickaxe, the pickaxe is the exact same power as the copper pickaxe, but its better.. trust me. Once you've done that, the only thing you can do is mine and explore, go far underground to find good chest that have accesories (ak Hermes Boots, Cloud in a bottle, etc.) Once you are geared enough, (mabye full tungsten/silver or platinum/gold. Go ahead and fight the eye of cthulu, you need a demon alter, aka the crimson alter, you have to combine 5 lends (craft) to make a spawner, when prepared use the potions you want and click the spawner at night, NOT DAY. After this, he will drop demonite or crimtane. If your lucky, you'll get a shield, 14.49% chance. it's a good weapon doing 30 damage, fight him 2-3 times till you can make demonite set, which includes pickaxe and axe, you will not need a better hammer yet. once you do that, fight the Eater of Worlds or Brain of Cthulu, your only doing this for 1)demonite/crimtane 2)making the metorite land. once you fight him. (it should be easy with full demonite) than you can wait for a metorite to land, this containes metor ore, what a suprise! I'd recommend using bombs to blow up the entire thing, once you've done that, craft a space gun and full demonite armor, space gun is insanely OP with full demonite, do it! Once you've done that, the next step is queen bee, but you dont have to, just fight here, its easy. Finally were at Skeletron, this is soooo easy, just kill him, explore the dungeon blah blah, done! Now, you dig an elevator to hell, hellevator ;3, literally just dig down. So hard. Once you reach hell, find a voodoo doll. Keep that, DONT THROW IT IN THE LAVA! This part may take some time, but its veryusefull, mine alot of hellstone, you want the full set, trust me. Also be making sure to pick up heart crystals! once you've got the full set of hellstone armor, your ready to go to hardmode, make sure you have good potions, like damage buffs and healing regen and other stuff. I would recomend getting alot of wooden planks and placing them across hell, so you dont burn in lava. fight wof, I recommend going for the middle first, dont know why, overall, WoF isnt that hard to beat the 2 eyes will shoot lasers at you, so watch out. once you've beat him. It's off to hardmode, now the real challenge starts ;) Good Luck Guys!

If you are the kind of guy that likes a game for graphics , then this game isn't for you. But who even cares , this game is the best thing that happened in my life. There are way more bosses , way more items.   But to be honest i like Minecraft too. This game also has Steam cloud saving. Not to mention that you can wear fancy things. AND YOU CAN DYE THEM. You can wear an actual armor and a vanity armor which is just for the look , you have dozens of weapons , you can go mining , like REAL DEEP and you can find the Underworld (bassicaly hell) , There are floating islands , events... there are too many things to mention them all. You just have to get this game and see for yourself what Terraria has to offer.

So this is a shoutout to both Steam and Terraria. I first played this game on my nephew's account, but quickly bought it for myself because I was at the mercy of his playing schedule, and I wanted MORE! (Thank you for your family sharing system, Steam! It got me to buy another amazing game.) I played for a couple of hours, died MANY times, and realized that this game is NOT 2-D Minecraft, the way many reviews seem to say.  First, content: Minecraft has only a few unique mobs. Terraria has over 100. Minecraft has about a 4-tier weapons crafting system. Terraria has at least 10 tech trees, each with 1-point tiers from ~4 to as much as ~30 damage (I have not discovered every level of every tier, but, for instance, the yo-yo tree (yes, you can kill things with yo-yos!) starts at about 7 damage. The basic wooden yo-yo can later be recrafted into a 30-point yo-yo. This happens in the latter half of the game.  Second, storyline: This is a sandbox game, much like Minecraft. It even has renewable resources like wood (at 4 varieties, each of which creates its own tier of weaponry.) On the other hand, there are summonable bosses, similar to the Ender Dragon, available from fairly early in the game. There is the Eye of Cthulhu, the Eater of Worlds, The Slime King, the Hive Queen... Yeah, that's all I've seen, because the bosses are scaled to their availability in the storyline. In other words, they are HARD when you run into them, but by the time you get to the end of their window of availability, they are no longer impossible. By the way, about that window of availability? Yeah, each early boss has a harder version available from the halfway point in the game.  Third, NPCs: One of the biggest reasons that Terraria is not Minecraft is the emphasis on NPCs. In Minecraft you are very much on your own, and the game is designed so that you can survive that way. In Terraria, the game is balanced around having a collection of NPCs, each with a single special function, that hang out at your house and wait for you to return from adventuring so that they can help you (for a price.) My favorite is one of the easier NPCs to pick up, the Merchant. He sells a miner's hat that emits light and obviates the need for torches, and a sickle, a very cheap HTA (hold to attack) weapon. Everything he offers costs money.  The final major difference between the two games is the economic system. In Minecraft, emeralds are hard to find, and villages to trade them in are even harder. The villages are not designed to be a central part of the gameplay, and therefore the economy is not central either. In Terraria, a major part of the storyline is the need to develop your village's capabilities by attracting NPCs who can do the things you need done. To do this, you must kill enemies for a small amount of coin, explore caves and mine ore as well as loot amphora and chests for important quest items, discover fully-equipped cabins in the middle of the cave systems (and typically loot everything in the cabin, to sell it to your NPCs,)...  Minecraft is a fun, challenging game, no doubt. It has a little bit of playability, but new content must be released frequently to keep player interest. Terraria has so much content that they do not need to add anything, ever - I am hooked for life.

If you don't like this game, you either... -Played another sandbox game with similar aspects (Minecraft, Trove, etc.) and you don't have the ability to like any other game. -Barely gave it a chance. Cheating makes it so nothing is rewarding in this game.  Now, some people say it makes it no fun to get items from other people. I don't think so. I would recommend this game if you are able and willing to memorize where you can get every item, what you need to craft it, how good it is, etc, and there are tons of items, so this might take a while for new players. At the game's current state, I wouldn't recommend it. I'm not at all against the content of the game, its exciting and all and its content is fantastic, but if you don't have a website of constant spoilers or just happen to know to use the guide every step of the way, while also happening to trigger all the bosses by accident before being bored of it and calling it a Minecraft clone, you can semi-muster a blind playthrough. I respect the game for much more than that but too many of my friends have played it for 1 hour and called it bad based on a bunch of spoilers versus their immediate experience.  There NEEDS to be more in-game documentation so that these spoilers dont get through. even some of the crafting items that show up, like the frost moon present shows it on the tooltip. It also shows ectoplasms as a crafting ingredient, which may prompt people to look it up and it just spoils everything too fast.  A game like this shouldn't need to be spoiled so quickly. That's my only real reason for not recommending the game at its current state. I'll change it if they fix this. Hopefully Terraria Otherworld addresses this glaring issue.

When people first told me about this game. I thought 'it's just a cheap rip-off of Minecraft in 2D!' if you think that, and even if you don't I urge you to keep reading. This game although similar to Minecraft, is only similar because it's an open world sandbox game that is procedurely generated and there is a lot of mining and a lot of crafting. But to say this game is cheap is stupid (although it is cheap in price :D) and to say it's a rip-off of Minecraft, although it technically rode off the success of Minecraft when it was first released it has since become a complete game, and it's own entity to rival that of Minecraft, it is not a rip-off, just similar like previously stated.  Now you might be thinking, well that's great an all but what do you think about the game? Simply put, I LOVE IT. It's amazing, and filled to the brim with content and items, enemies, bosses, biomes, blocks, items, powerups, items, potions, items. Oh did I mention it has a LOT of items? Didn't think so, in that case: it has a lot of items. If you like Minecraft PLEASE download this game, if you don't like Minecraft, still give it a try you might find a Diamond in the rough. (And yes the pun was fully intended)  Note to Re-Logic: Thank you so much for this work of art, this is an amazing game. Keep adding awesome stuff to it, and don't play it safe! Remember to experiment with new ideas, and if people don't like it, just change it back. <3  5/5 Stars. Final rating.

I got this game for mobile around three years ago, and even back then, it was worth EVERY PENNY I paid for it and so much more. There are dozens of armor sets, hundreds of weapons, and even more enemies and bosses. The progression in this game is great. Sure, it can get a little grindy at times, but once you FINALLY defeat Skeletron or the Moon Lord, the feeling alone makes those dozens of minutes of mining and farming bosses worth it. Not to mention the unique loot and items that you can get, including: A Nyan Cat sword of death, a rainbow beam of death, a SPACE DOLPHIN, and more. You can fire galaxies and stars at your enemies, chop them up with swords twice as long as your player, gun them down with a hail of bullets, or run away and let your minions do the work for you. With so many ways to play, Terraria never gets old, with amazing amounts of replayability. It can get a little old, at times, if you play singleplayer, but if you do a multiplayer playthrough, the fun doesn't stop... at least until you log in one day to find your Terra Blade or Last Prism missing.

Ok, here's a note:   Terraria is not a Minecraft ripoff.   Both games are similar, sure, but Terraria focuses more on combat, as shown with the large amount of enemy types (including about 29 bosses, counting ones from events and console/mobile exclusives), as well as the various armors, items, and weapons available.  So...Terraria, what can I say about it? You have many options, Building, Fighting, Fishing, Mining, Collecting (and possibly some others.)  The game also has a lot of replayability. Finished the game using whatever weapons you found cool? Stick to certain weapon types. Want a challenge? Expert Mode. Want even more of a challenge? Hardcore.  Also, this game is great with friends, even encouraging it in some aspects. Well, great until someone gets a bit salty for you taking their drops. (I totally don't do that heh...)  Overall though, the game is good, it's a fun sandbox/action game that is great with friends (It is also good solo if you are a sad loser.)    My Rating : 10/10

The introduction of 1.3 made Terraria totally amazing. Before then, it was still pretty amazing. I bought this game on a whim on Xbox 360 a few years ago, and it was probably the best decision in my life. I had to get it on PC after hearing about the Moon Lord's addition to the game. I would HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone. If you're confused about controls, you can check the options, they'll tell you. And most important of all, Terraria is NOT a 2D version of Minecraft; the similarities stop at the ability to mine and build the environment, that's it. Terraria is more geared toward combat and progression, but still gets points for exploration, and you can still build pretty cool things in Terraria as well. The wiring system is far easier to use, and is getting improved soon in an update. The only real issue is once you defeat the last boss and do everything you want to do, the game is essentially over. However, this game is LOADED with content, from all sorts of crazy weapons and enemies to different armors with different abilities, and the game has very high replay value; just make a new character and start all over again! Even not compared to Minecraft, it is still a great game on its own. The $10 is worth it, trust me. If you're thinking about buying this game, then proceed.  EDIT: The wiring system is now improved with 1.3.1, and the game will continue to be updated and improved.

TL:DR I. Love. This. Game.  =================================================================================== I've had this game from around the 1.1 update, and as of this review almost logged 700 hours on the game, beaten every boss, and gotten most items available, and I still find fun things to do and create. From the absolutely insane amounts of things to do that all help you, like how simply fishing can get you crates that give you materials, to how farming plants like Dayblooms can help with crafting potions, everything is useful and everything can be done.  Updates 1.2 and 1.3 were some of the biggest updates I've ever seen from a sandbox game, adding many bosses and the Hardmode bosses after Wall of Flesh which was also included in 1.2. Even a semi-small update like the most recent 1.3.1 update which, from what they said, added only wiring stuff but added awesome small stuff like little beehives that spawn bees when knocked down. There is plenty of love shown in this game.  The developers, despite their efforts being moved to Terraria Otherworld, still show plenty of love and care for this game, and continue to see it grow into the wonderful game we have now. From the deepest extent of my heart, I do reccommend this game to anyone who loves sandbox games.   Also, if I hear another person compare this game to Minecraft, I'll skin them alive. Enjoy your day, fine people!

Terraria, In my opinion is going to be one of those 'Timeless Gems' for the PC. Still now after this game has been out for around 5 years the player still stays strong strong with Tens-of-Thousands of players playing every day! And I think alot can be said about that.  Lets face it, if you don't own Terraria by now you are one of two things; 1) North Korean 2) Brand new to the PC/ Steam scene. Terraria should be on a list of 'Starting PC games'. The reason I say this is because for the price tag on this game, the ammount of content and hours you can get out of it are staggering. With the game often on sale, I can honestly say that if you enjoy it, it will give you the best game time per money spent out of almost any other steam game.  For example if bought this game for £6.99 and at the time of writing this I have 402 hours so with a simple calulation we can work out that I spent 0.02p per hour played. Pointless to know, but I think it demonstrates the value for money quite well! Pick this game up if you are looking for cheap entertainment

With over 350 hours on it at the time of writing this review I feel like its almost insulting not to write a reveiw on this yet. This game was one of the first I ever got wayy back when it first came out. I remember getting annoyed at fighting some bosses (Even though now they seem easy) and even after 350 hours played I seriously can still get frusterated as all f*** on this game. Not in a bad way dont get me wrong. In a way that makes you want to keep going and go that extra mile. This game is rewarding when you work a goal to something and SUPER satisfying after beating bosses or getting a new item. I have sighed and gasped in releif many times at the addictiveness of this game. The gameplay is what people call a 2D minecraft. Thats very insulting! Mincraft cannot compare to the glory of such an amazing game. Even the soundtrack is completely amazing! I'm a person to like rock or metal but wow, the soundtrack in this game just couldnt be any better! I hate to say it but its even better than the Payday 2 soundtracks! Each mode in a world is set for what experience you want in this game. Want to go through casually without a care in the world and see what there is to offer? Normal mode and softcore is good for you! Want a bit of a challenge that will make you cry yourelf to sleep and have to actually have a TON of strategy to beat a simple cave bat? Expert mode! Last not not least, Try some hardcore expert mode. This mode will make you die on the inside everytime you hear that slightly highpitched 'Ouf!' from your character. This mode takes skill to a whole new level that I will forever be to scared to try. This mode will put Dark souls to SHAME. This is possibly one of my most favorite games out there coming out with few major updates but when it happens they add SOOO much more stuff to do! Every time I come back I bring along a friend and get very nostalgic. This game is a must have and seriously should be in everyones library. Thank you Re-logic for making such a well made game! I will certainly be playing much much more in the future.
this game should be in every consle because this game is way to good people who hate this game are cRaZy

Terraria is a great game that has nothing to do with Minecraft, and literally couldn't be more different. One of the texts when you sart up Minecraft is, 'Don't play clones!' it also says, 'Try Terraria!'  This proves it isn't a clone. With nearly 400 hours of playtime in Terraria and having nearly all of the achievements, I think I am finally qualified to give a review!  The game is great. I love it.  Mine, create, build, mine some more, plant trees, kill slimes, mine some more, build some more, run out of inventory space, craft some chests, do some creative inventory organizing, kill some more slimes, craft some torches, chop down those trees you planted earlier, plant some more trees, kill some more stuff, mine for some more ore, craft a better pickaxe because the one you started with is too slow, make a hammer, get tired of reading my review, wonder if I will be ending anytime soon, I will be ending soon, breathe a sigh of relief, mark my review as funny, and so many more things to do in this game!  If you like to mine, build, create stuff then this game might be for you!

Well than,  Here we have a game that at first I thought I would hate every peice of code and artwork in it.  I think it's fair to say I'm wronng in that considering my play time and the fact this review is in the positive section (unlike some reviews *cough* almost half the entire negative section *cough*)   I'm not going to talk about my experiences with the game, and defientely am not going to bore anyone with me saying what happened the first time I played (that is saying people will probably not read this, and people who do will get bored half way through it, cause I can get pretty boring). So, i'll just move onto the pros and cons list (like as if that wasnt a cliche or anything).  Pros to Terraria: -Wonderful graphics and beatiful color pallet -Great Soundtrack that fit the tone of all the areas and events (except the snow biome song, not a big fan of it) -Controls feel nice and easy to use, all the original binds are easy to reach (except for mana potions [why J as the quick bind]) -Gameplay is nice and smooth, with a difficulty curve that goes from easy to medium to hard (beginning of game, hardmode, and post-Plantera) -Customization to almost everything (still waiting for dyable weapons Re-Logic)  Now onto the cons: -Barely any instructions before the achievements were made (I personally liked it that way, but others weren't to happy) -Sometimes (during an update) characters would be deleted/ corrupted, and so would worlds -Medusa (yes I know, she was moved into hardmode, but she's still on the cons list)  And that concludes the short cons list (these are things I could find and of course my OPINIONS [some people don't understand opinions for some reason] about the game), so if you are still awake after reading this, than either A. buy the game now, or B. buy it during a steam sale.

Now, at more than 15 1/2 full days into the game i have beaten 2 normal worlds solo, 2 expert worlds solo, and one of each with a friend. There are other programs that will let you cheat, but i urge you NOT to do this. As others have said, it ruins the game and makes an otherewise fun and time-consuming game become boring. For $10, this game is worth everything that it cost and more.

Great game! Honestly turned out to a have a lot more to it than I expected. It's like Minecraft, but with a lot more added to it!   The music is great and the controls and graphics are also great.   There are many different ways you can fight--ranged, melee, or summoning your own minions to fight for you! There are also lots of bosses to fight which each feel special. Worlds are huge, and there are many different environments to discover (15+ as far as I know).   The crafting allows for endless possibilities, and past all of this the game has an expert mode which allows for lots of replayability (monsters are a lot harder, have a lot more abilities, and bosses drop more items).   Multiplayer is also very friendly! You can have maybe a small world for just 2 friends, small for maybe 3-5, and large for 6+ (these are what they fit--you could have 6 in a small world but it would be a tight fit). I'd   10/10 for rating, not sure of too much lacking except you need to find friends from outside sources to play with. :(

OT though; In my opinion you will completly hate it, or you will completly love it, it is a great game with a lot of content, bosses and things to fight and discover, it has a variety of things that one can do, whenever it is to do events, fight bosses, fish or even stand by a campfire and cook a marshmallow, I personally like everything about the game, even though there a lot of games like itself, I think Terraria is very unique with its content, and even its beautiful pixel art style; it is very eye appealing and that's one of the best things I like about Terraria. I love the fact that you can customize your character in anyway you like, choose the exact colour for your hair, shoes, even your eyes, get armor, customize the armors dye in the way you like and you can make yourself look like a complete beast, there is a ton of stuff to do in the game, getting one item can take hours of farming which I believe is really nice, because that just brings the idea of well, the game is not all that easy, it doesn't bore you, it might not always give you what you want and I think that's a great concept.  I think the game is also very greatly optimized, so it is surely nicely playable on older machines too, it has Linux, Windows and Mac support, which I think is a great thing about it too as not much new games (and older obviously) offer that.  I've only gotten 500 hours so far, but I could quite surely make that a 1000 without getting bored of the game. Terraria is kind of my favorite game.  Pros: -TONS of contents -Doesn't need mods to be fun -You choose your fighting style  -You can have a class, but it's up to you to decide, you can even be everything -Almost everything is useful, even that little flower that jumped in your inventory -Lots of fighting, LOTS -No DLC to make the game better, everything is free (you only buy the game, eh, and it's cheap) -Events!  -Most stuff is player-oriented while map makers can still make neat maps.  -You can keep the same character everywhere. -There's so much pros I can't even say them all -Oh and be careful with the bunnies  Cons: -It's hard to understand for new players, I though we had to craft by clicking on the work table, furnace, etc. when you actually have to press esc then you have the stuff you can craft with nearby furnitures -The thing that will kill you the most is either fall damages or bats -NPCs have the right to sit, you don't -Character customization is not the best thing, I wished there was more than humans, but I understand, with all these items, it'd be hard to make stuff for other species. Welp, I'll just stick with being a naked werewolf. -Sometimes you may be unlucky and get the corruption/crimson close to your spawn, you must rush to block it once in hard mode. -Building isn't an option. -People may give you OP stuff in multiplayer. If you don't want to get OP stuff now, just throw it away. -Going to hell is the most painful thing.   So yeah, I STRONGLY recommend this game to anyone that likes adventure, fighting tons of mobs, having control over what you want to be, etc.

(I try to be 100% honest in all my reviews. Enjoy!)  Terraria is an open world survival game that takes the idea of a normal survival game and absolutely perfects it. That is, if you don't mind the lack of 3-D graphics being replaced by side scrolling pixels. In a lot of ways, Terraria gets things right where a lot of games similar to it weren't enough. But at the same time, there is so much to do in Terraria and some of it is seemingly impossible without friends helping you, so you'll want to have some online games for boss battles as well.  The first thing Terraria gets right where lots of other survival games doesn't is the overall appeal. There is actually some structure to how you play the game. You have to know how to build you house to support the funny characters that spawn and will try to live in your house. There is a series of bosses that, if lableled properly, you can see are more powerful than others. Certain pickaxes will only break certain things and run at a certain speed, while certain weapons are more powerful than others. Which brings me to my next point, the WEAPONS.  One of the best things about Terraria is the weaponry. By just a few hours into the game, you can find a cave easily and head down to get some serious loot. (Note: You may not get the BEST weaponry just starting to play the game, I played the Xbox version for quite some time and I had a lot of things.)  The only major problem with Terraria is the boss-fights. I'm not saying they aren't completely awesome, I'm saying that depending on the player's skill level, as I believe mine is kind of low, it may be hard to defeat certain bosses without friends to help you. And even then, if you are having trouble defeating a boss, you have to constantly be finding boss spawners so you keep trying. After a lot of failures, it may seem like a waste to keep using them.  One last thing: I did have some framerate issues when playing the game. It was nothing major, but for about a minute the world would slow-down and I looked like I was in bullet-time. It isn't game crippling, however.  All in all, if you enjoyed a game like Minecraft, Terraria is for you! It definitely outshines most survival games and only dips down by the hardness of boss-fights. (Which may not be that hard for a skilled player, so if you are a skilled player, this game has nothing wrong with it, aside from some framerate issues.)  9/10 Lots of Content Interesting Equipment Possibly Hard Boss Fights Small Framerate Drops  I hope this review helps you make your decision!

Amazing Game, and I completely reccomend it.  Terraria is something very unique.  Terraria is a game about mining, fighting, adventure, building, and crafting.  Let me go into it.  In terraria, you design your character, and a map is randomly generated for you. However, the map has a 50% chance of spawning a biome called \'The Corruption\' and a 50% chance of spawning a biome called \'The Crimson\'. Most new players don\'t know it yet, but simply by creating a new map, you have already made a unique decision that will permanently change your game forever.  For the people who don\'t know, Biomes are basically different areas with a theme. Like a desert, a jungle, a snowy area, etc.  When designing your character, you are offered three modes, softcore (drop money on death), mediumcore (drop everything on death), hardcore (permanent death).   Once you enter your world, the place you spawn will be your respawn point permamently, unless you\'re hardcore, so it\'s best to build your house near this spawn or even directly on it.  A thing that terraria does well is bosses. There are many bosses to fight.  Another thing terraria does amazingly is content. This review is actually getting hard to write, because there\'s so much content in this game that I can\'t even explain it. And I\'m literally just 46 hours in!  Let me cut it nice and simple:  Get Terraria. It is a good game. Trust me, you will not regret it. It\'s not your basic platformer, and it has much content.

A friend recommmened this game to me. I got the game. Here's what i think: PROS: You will be occupied with this game for a while. 9/10  Hardmode. When you think you beat the game, BOOM, a little thing called hardmode comes in and adds many new items, mobs, and biomes anto your world. 10/10  Got lost in the first few hours of playing because of so much content. 10/10  Multiplayer 9/10  A huge game, but doesn't hog all the memory on your computer! 10/10  Flying foxes 11/10  Doesn't need a good computer to run it. 10/10  LOTS AND LOTS of weapons, tools, armor. 10/10  No limit of how you can build. 10/10  Hundreads of ores you can mine. 10/10  Incredibly fun. 10/10  Customization of character, house, etc. 10/10  CONS: 2D (my opinion)  Hackers. This game has no hacking protection. And servers are overrun with people who are invincable and kill you instantly. One time i was wandering around servers and found a server with chests with an infinate supply of all the items in the game. (Even the items that are still in development) I couldn't stop myself from taking the best items in the game. Including a SDMG, a item still in development. And with enchantments and accessories, it does 100 damage (a lot) and shoots like a freaking laser beam. The average player has about 300 health. Beware of these hacked servers/players. It will ruin this game for you. I still cant get rid of my sdmg no matter how hard i try.  EDIT: The SDMG is no longer in development as of update 1.3  Overall: This game is a masterpiece. Buy it now. An outstanding 20/10 So what are you waiting for? Buy this game and even buy a 4 pack of the game for your friends NOW!

THIS GAME IS AMAZING! I would say something very vulgar about Minecraft right now, but we Terrarians are civilized people (unlike most Minecrafters).  Terraria is a 2-dimensional adventure game. As you explore your world further, you will find more materials that will allow you to make better armour and weapons. There are hundreds of different enemies, plus around 18 boss monsters. The multiplayer aspect of this game is really fun, because you can open up your own world to your friends (yes, you can invite friends only if you like) even if they are far away. Character customization is really great, with infinite possibilities of how to shape your character. This is a really great game. I would reccomend it to anyone.  Note to parents: There is no gore in this game, though some of the SFX can seem a bit too realistic; If you are worried about strangers in multiplayer mode, it is easy to set up the world so that only friends on Steam are invited; there may be some very small suggestive themes with the NPC (non-player character) dialogue.

In my opinion, this is better than Minecraft. That's not to say I didn't enjoy it, I think it's still a great and vast game. But Terraria seems to have more content than Minecraft. Now, you could argue that it's like that because Terraria isn't as big as Minecraft but my statement still stands. More ores, enemies, pretty pixel graphics, and lovely music to boot.  My one complaint is the crafting menu. Unlike the console version, you're not told what you CAN'T craft in the PC version. It only tells you what you can make if you andrguemenlready have everything you need for the desired item. So you'd need a lot of outside information (wiki and guides) to craft the more advanced items.   Regardless, I still enjoy it. And, like Minecraft, it's a blast with friends. And with the 1.3 update released, it's even better than when I first played it before I took a long break from it. It's like leaving your town that had a nice comic store and you move back to it after a few years and that comic store looks has a bunch more stuff in there including a game room and card game tables.   Bye this game, dang it!

This game is like minecraft, except a focus on combat rather than building. Obviously, in a 2D world, you'll be more limited, especially with a limited map size (just hope you're not building something ♥♥♥♥ing giant). However, there are things which are for other people as well.  1) 78 different swords, with more special effects as you move up, and 66 other different melee weapons in categories such as yoyos, flails, and spears.  2) 84 different ranged weapons, from categories such as bows, guns, and launchers.  3) 76 different magic weapons, each with different unique effects.  4) 18 other weapons, such as grenades and traps.  5) 65 different armor sets (3 pieces each) which offer unique special bonuses that help for specific builds in the game.  6) 18 different bosses, which go from basic and easy to ones I've never beaten before, along with 10 other events which force you to develop strategies to defeat them easily.  7) A surprisingly deep character customization.  8) An expert mode for you masochists.  9) A multiplayer which is very fun in small amounts (large amounts make loot difficult to split and hard to find- not everybody will get everything they want).  10) However, you can have one character cary over to a different world. Therefore, rather than generating a more world, you can generate a new one, which is very helpful. It means you don't have to go on long adventures to go find some more materials.   Even if you don't seem like you would be a fan of it, and are a more builder type, there is a wiring system you can mess with. You can try to be creative and make new ways to defeat bosses, or combine different armors and weapons to see how they work. It's a fantastic game (my most played game on steam). I recommend it to anybody and everybody.

I like the combination of styles in Terraria. You can really make the world your own, even on such a small map (compared to some other pixel-art side-scrollers *cough* *Starbound* *cough*), and there is a hell of a lot to do within it, but the small map and changing landscape keeps you on your toes and makes you appreciate the space you have while giving a lot of goals to work towards. Warding off the Crimson or Corruption becomes a big part of the game, especially after entering hardmode, and then the whole game dynamic changes. It's a very fun experience that's fun over and over. From house-building to raid bosses, it really is endless fun.

So this is how i discovered this game, not gonna leave out the part where i pirated it  Friend keeps telling me to get this game - i'm like 13 at that point... no money, no way to put money into steam Decide to pirate it Turn on the game.... right, there's a tree *chops a tree* okay................ ooo, a pickaxe! *digs a small hole into the ground* *crafts a workbench* *crafts a door* *places door* *realises the door can't open at that angle and position* *mines out more* well.... i think i've reached the game's potential now, i mean, i mined, i cut a tree, i killed a slime *quits game* telling my friend the game was pretty darn boring, all i did was make a small hole     ~lots of boring stuff later~    decide to give the game another chance - the moment that changed my life Back then there were 3 bosses, and no slopes I've never loved a game more than i did Terraria, it was amazing even when it barely had anything to do How far the game has come now is beyond my imagination... WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD!   *I'm just gonna say right now, Minecraft is garbage compared to this. Now Minecraft is ceratinly a good game, but taking the graphics of an SNES platformer, Minecraft's gameplay, and way more items, you have this game. Lots of combat and bosses in this one as opposed to Minecraft's creation-based gameplay. And unlike Minecraft, you actually have to kill these bosses to progress. Yes, you could go without killing a single boss, but that playstyle won't get you anywhere.  *One of the things about this game are the NPC's. You can get them to move in to houses you build(Enclosed space, door, table, chair, light source, background walls is all you need for a structure to be considered a house). For example, you can get a merchant by collecting 50 silver coins, and you can get a cyborg by killing Plantera (A late-game boss).  *Now, read this paragraph carefully. This game IS NOT for young kids. First off, you can obtain alcoholic drinks. There's blood and minor gore. The first boss you fight is a giant bloody eyeball (Although the graphics don't make it too bad). Heck, not too long after that you fight a giant skull with two skelton arms (With blood involved.) And right as you 'release the ancient spirits of Light and Dark' and change your world forever, THE BOSS IS NOT ONLY HORRIFYING (Even your in-game character gets a 'horrified debuff, though that just prevents you from escaping) IT IS FOUGHT IN HELL ITSELF. YES, YOU CAN DIG DOWN TO HELL. AND THAT BOSS IS SUMMONED WITH A LIVING SACFRIFICE. So yeah, definitely T for Teen (That's about the same as PEGI 12).  * The game has 'Suggestive themes' on its rating by the ESRB, but that's probably the fact that some characters have relationships, and a few item names. It's not much to worry about.  *H.P. Lovecraft references (Eye of Cthulhu, Brain of Cthulhu, True Eye of Cthulhu, and possibly some others). Big win in my opinion.  *In the Steam version I BELIEVE (But am not certain) you can turn off the blood.  *This game is hard. just warning you. Try killing Moon Lord(The 'Final Boss' with anything less than the Beetle Armor and you'll probably regret it)  *NO DLC! Yessssss.  * Epic soundtrack. Like, MEGA MAN good (Well, almost.)  *Lastly, the community. you probably know Minecraft's fanbase is now, unfortunately almost all little kids. That wouldn't be sou bad, but even the '10 year olds'(Yeah, right) act like they are 3. But not in Terraria! The fanbase is really nice and onece a person I know was even given a LEGENDARY(The best modifier for a sword.) Terra Blade(A very good sword by another player(He was 'farming' Terra Blades to get money in-game) for NOTHING! The same person I know went on a server which just gave you an Excalibur(The Terra Blade wasn't out) for joining!   Oh yeah. Choose you playsyle wisely.

one of the first games I purchased on my account. In fact, I have this steam account right now because of Terraria. Terraria is my all-time favorite game. Now now, let's not be fanboys and point out it's flaws. First of all, there's barely any flaws, and that's not good. It won't get better unless something needs to be changed. Second of all, the game has server support, and that means you could get free items from servers, and knowing that you can get free items on your play through can ruin the experience, but then again, if your stuck on a boss or you feel underpowered, you can just get some free items I guess?  The bosses are awesome, and the soundtrack is amazing, especially with the 1.3.4 update with the Dungeon Defenders crossover, but those items are more of the Mechanical Tier. I have played terraria on Mobile, console, and PC. Terraria is a great game with a great community. However, entertainment is a block on the road. It only attracts thousands of views, so if your going to buy it to make videos, don't expect to get a bundle.  There are lots of things to keep you busy, and grinding for, which is not sorta fun, but IT'S WORTH IT OK There's lots of items that can help you, and items that can carry you, like Vampire Knives, Terra blade, and so on forth to Post Golem tier, but the best part is that they're hard to get, but it takes variety.   Terraria is my favorite game, and other people's favorite game. I would recommend this game to anyone who loves survival games and bosses that are hard. 9/10

I Do Not Know Why I Have Never Made A Review About Terraria. Here It Finally Is After 1k Hours Of Gameplay:   Terraria Is A Great Game And I Really Enjoy Playing It. The First Few Times I Had No Idea What I Was Doing But I Just Made A New Character And World Everytime I Beat The Game. You Could Play For Hundreds Of Hours Before Getting Bored. And When You Finally Did Get Bored You Would Just Turn To Mods. Terrarias Modding Community Is Great And There Are Some Amazing Mods Out There Which Make The Game Playable Hundreds Of Hours After You Got Bored In Vanilla. Now I Have Begun Playing it Less And Less. But Then Again. Terraria Is At The End Of Its Life-Time For Me. I Just Hope That Games Like Terraria Otherworld Will Be Just As Great As Terraria Was.  (If You Have Not Already Bought The Game... DO IT... It Is Simply An Amazing Experience To Play.)

Terraria is in my opinion more addicting than Factorio, especially in early game. It can also be compared to a heavily modded Minecraft. Why? Well, obviously the game holds a far larger base of content than Minecraft. Things that Terraria has that Minecraft DOESN'T have: Giant flying eyeballs Robot flying eyeballs Halloween/Christmas events Winter events Blood Moons Solar Eclipses variety to zombies giant flying skeleton heads with flying arms giant flying robot skeleton heads with flying arms Slime Variety Hamaxes Drills Pickaxe Axes Jackhammers Giant worms Giant corrupt worms Chainsaws Lasers Aliens Dragons (Minecraft has them too, but Terraria has better dragons/wyverns) Miniguns Guns in general Variety to bows Realistic fishing Quests to follow said fishing Flying Pirate ships Normal pirates that come from said ships Giant flying pumpkins with swords Repeating bows an excalibur Giant robot worms A Slime King Variety to minecarts Rockets Rocket launchers Grenade launchers I lost track, there's far too much stuff.  So, if I had an opinion of a star rating based on the amount of content in the game: Minecraft: 37/100 Terraria: 85/100  *Dont forget that Terraria is 2D and STILL holds more content than minecraft*

You haven't heard of Terraria and you're reading the reviews? Well here's one:  Terraria is a 2D Sandbox-Adventure.  Yep. But that's boring just saying that.  Terraria is a game that I have now sunk *check library 1200+ into and I've loved every second of it. From when Skeletron and the Dungeon were endgame, to now where now   cthulu   is  literally[i/] the final boss, Re-Logic have provided many new updates each more bountiful than the last.  So if you came here because of Starbound, Edge of Space, Minecraft or because of Steam's weird algorithms (I don't blame you) get Terraria, on sale or not. Because even as a long time player, I am still finding new ways to have fun, whether it be with the harder difficulties or the many details and little secrets, as just today I learnt about the secret Master Sword hommage.  TL:DR Terraria is a 2D Sandbox-Adventure, that I hope you will enjoy as much as I have and still am 1200+ hrs strong.

This game is one of those games you will never wish you never bought. Every time I have stopped playing this game I have come back for more. There is never a point when you are completely done, once one part ends another starts. The amount of time put into the game really shows. One great thing about this game is the amount of creativety the player is allowed to have. I have made snowmen, castles, houses, skyscrapers, etc.. Every time I played this game I have been able to play it in a different way, whether it be changing the type of weapons I use, the type of armours I use, the mount I use, etc.. Terraria is a great game to play with freinds and includes a lot of features that can be used if there is another player in the game, for example the wormhole potion that can teleport you to any player on the team you are currently on. The PvP experience is great and the amount of different types of battles you can have with different people are amazing. There are so many things in this game that make it my number one choice for a game, and if I did have to choose any of the games in my library to keep, I would keep Terraria. If I had to rate this game I would seriously give it an 11/10. I have played since it came out and have not stopped playing it. Thank you for reading this and I do hope you consider purchasing this game because it is so worth it, I have certainly got my money's worth.

Terraria is that game you thought you finished years ago, but then get thrust back in and do the whole thing again. The adventure is long and tedious at times, but the glorious laughs between you and comrades are well worth the time. The feeling of excitement upon accomplishing your goal is further developed upon getting some sweet loot and fighting over who gets to keep it (unless you are playing on expert). If you are thinking of getting the game, I would definitely recommend it! It goes on sale frequently but is well worth the $10. If you are bored of the main game and have already collected all the items, then play through again. Grab some friends or download mods through the easy to use features made by the community. Or just wait a few months to get an update filled with hours of more content. Good luck in your adventure!

(may make a more indepth and cleaner review in the future but i felt i had to write this seeing how many hours I have in this game)  An Absolute must have game, and dont let the '2D side scroller' put you off. one of the most entertaining and content filled games ive play'ed.  9/10 - the only complaint i have is there isnt too much farming(used mainly for alchemy) and that its at its final stages of life, but that was to happen anyway with 'Terraria: Otherworld' on the way but a note, but its well worth a buy. usually goes on sale for around 3 ameriburgers during christmas so keep an look out and buy it!  open world, exploration, collecting, combat, building, and logic in that you can use ingame wireing and blocks to help with certain events and such.  mostly combat and building but has some farming and fishing. gear-based class system (magic, ranged, melee, summon, very small 'pre-hardmode' throwing)  and the feature I wish more games had, and makes me love this game more, the character you make isn't tied to the world you make, you can bring him to other worlds and keep your gear, along with some storage devices that let you hold more on your character (personel storage).
Best singleplayer experince, and it gets better in multiplayer, cant stop playing this game, never get boring!

+ Sensible controls and clear UI, minimap + Biome and monster variety + Difficulty settings, also triggerable within the game (hardmode) + Bosses, invasions, seasonal events + Robust and easy crafting system + Equipment: various armors, weapon categories, accessories, wings, mounts, wardrobe system + dyes + Fully customizable housing and NPCs + Basic machinery, wiring, spawners + Characters are saved independently from the maps (can swap worlds) + Well-made pixel graphics, customizable lighting, low system requirements + Good, biome-themed soundtrack  - Due to nature of corruption/crimson/hallow players need to dig trenches to preserve neutral biomes or spend gold on restoring them later - No blueprints for buildings, requires use of third-party programs for big map changes - No mod support

Ten dollars well spent. This game offers HOURS of gameplay. With the four different classes (Melee, Range, Magic, and Summoner), and the mini class (Throwing), You can play the game over and over again. If you think you are the best, attempt Expert mode, all enemies have more health/damage. If you're in to survival-like games, where you can also power your imagination, Terraria is for you. I started on Console. After I did everything, 1.3 for PC released. I was like, 'More Bosses? More events OVER 1000 New items? I need it.' I recommend this game for people like that. With over 10 bosses, about 3000 items, excellently detailed graphics, Over 20 NPC to move into your house, AND a harder mode, it's DEFINETLY worth it.

You can kill the god of the moon with a sword that shoots cats. You can build a super secret underwater volcano lab, in space. You can ride on a flying purple pig. You can turn the jungle into a blue glowing mushroom cave, it’s not like you need the jungle to progress through the game anyway. You can kill a giant bee with a shark that has a minigun shoved down its throat. You can you can accidentally fall into a dungeon and get insta-killed by seventeen massive skeleton heads flying at you from all directions. You can fight an army of gangsta snowmen with tommy guns. You can cut down every tree on earth with a flying v guitar. You can get a prostate exam from the nurse npc (not really). You can kill a world-eating worm with rainbow fireworks. You can dress up as a creeper from minecraft, whatever the hell that game is. You can ascend to space by farting. You can be turned to stone by medusa and die from falling 3.7 feet. You can summon a mini minotaur pet with a bottle of tartar sauce. You can earn a golden fishing pole from a homeless kid you find on the beach. Why are you still reading this, go buy the game right now. I’ve spent well over 400 hours in this game and I still find new things on every playthrough. Thousands of items and weapons, over 20 bosses and minibosses. Excellent class system, with a huge variety of melee, ranged, magic, and summoning weapons and armor with some mini classes like yoyo and throwing. Endless building possibilities with tons of tools to make everything fast and easy. FREE updates. Immersive worlds with tons of dungeons, caves, and other structures to explore and loot. This IS the best sandbox game I have ever played and is well worth the $10, so much so that i bought this on iphone and ps4. If you are looking for a game that you can do anything in, weather you want to build, fight, explore, or collect, you need to get this game. 10/10 would fart too space again!

Good, but needs a lot of improvements and changes in my opinion. There's a lot of things that don't make sense and spawns can sometimes ruin the fun. Often, if you get caught up with too many enemies, you might as well take a break, because everytime you die, you're usually spawned with them. Would make sense if the game spawned you in a completed stucture/house when you died or somewhere relatively safe. And that's just getting started at the beginning.  Personally, I've never expereinced anything that is shown in the videos. That is not to say it's not possible, but I think what they show you is rather advanced level stuff--the game, for the most part, doesn't seem to have near that much action or excitement when you're just getting started. I imagine you'd have to be playing for a really long time, within the same world, to experience any of that.  I do recommend the game though. It's pretty solid even though I've been experiencing some random slow down and cannot figure out what to do about it. Turning down graphics (not the issue), frame skipping, window mode/fullscreen, updating XNA... nothing seems to fix the issue. I don't recall it being an issue before, so it may have come with an update for all I know.  None of this is indicative of what you may experience, so take it all with a grain of salt.

My 'I Thought This Game Was Cool Before it Won an Award' Award nomination.  This game is dope. It's a 2D sandbox action game artfully stitched together from references to movies, TV, and other video games. You start with nothing but a few basic tools and use them to explore a randomly generated world full of juicy, delicious secrets and craft weapons and armor to fight eldritch abominations – all set to an exquisite chiptune soundtrack.   The game does its best to provide variety by giving you several different playstyles to choose from. You can use melee weapons, magic, guns, or minions to strike down your enemies. Build purely utilitarian houses or let your imagination run wild with more building materials than you can shake a stick at. Have a patriarchy or a matriarchy. Do anything you want, really. I read on Kotaku that it's better than Civ 5 with the Brave New World expansion pack.   And I'm not going to compare it to Minecraft. I'm only bringing it up because so many people write Terraria off as a clone. Whether or not it is a clone – and you can make that judgement for yourself – is irrelevant. If you're not willing to try it because you think it is, that's your loss. Because this game is a rooty-toot-tootin' masterpiece.

The first time I saw this game was about 2 weeks prior to it's release and it got me pretty hyped. Upon it's release I realized this game has much more to offer other than being a 2D Minecraft. It had great music that makes you 'feel' the atmosphere of what you're doing and the combat was also more than I expected. Back then, when a small indie company made a game, they rarely added content to it because the games were complete, Terraria on the other hand got updated throughout the years and it has multiple times the content it had originally. I totally recommend this game for being as fun as it is and rich of content, do yourself a favour and play this with your friends.

Pros and Cons   +Lots of fun things to do +Lots of achievements  +Easy multiplayer setup +No falling straight down into lava +Tonnes and tonnes of amazing items, mobs, NPCs and bosses -The jump from Normal to Expert is unbearable; bosses and mobs are overwhelmingly tough -Sadly, not much replayability

Sunk over 300 hours... Yeah, the game is fun, I dare say. Something about spelunking for precious minerals and near constant discovery of new stuff, progressively getting better and stronger, I guess. You also get to watch and build your house/stronghold/complex (really, whatever shape you want it to be) become more sophisticated and crowded as the items and bricks pile on and your mind constantly races for the next thing you have to do in the game, whether for fun or for some serious upgrades to your old gear. Honestly enjoy some of the dark fantasy themes of the enemies, even though it's not really that scary.  Want a game to generate a new world for you to explore? Might be for you, I'd say.

However, the game could be seen as repetitive to some, especially when you start a new character after getting to end game. Terraria is a sandbox building game in the broad genre Minecraft has spawned. But unlike Minecraft Terraria has more meat on it's bones. Whereas Minecraft's main focus is on it's mechanics and building with a survival mode on the side, Terraria puts a bit less in the hands of players by adding progression based on what bosses have been beaten. Terraria makes up for slightly less freedom of control over the world by adding so many different weapons and items to the game that your options for customizing a play style are virtually limitless. A broad spectrum of enemy types and ways to interact with and travel around the world you create makes Terraria stand out among other games of its type. But while Terraria has many contemporaries, it has no peers.

Most people including myself before diving too far into it considered this as a cheap Minecraft clone. The game isn't one, sure there are simalarities, however sence there are in truth no bosses of the overworld to Minecraft (save for the use of mods), this is a game that has bosses that one must beat in order to progress through the game. The first one is just a nusence and not tough at all The Eye of Cuthulu, equaly during the Slime rain (requirments I think are Heath at 160, and you have blue and green slime banners) Slime King. EoC (Requires 200 heath and at least 3 npc's) I feel is best to at least have Iron/Lead armor before taking him on. The Destroyer of Worlds/Brain of Cuthulu I suggjest Silver/Tungston armor, this boss requisres you to destroy Shadow Orbs/Crimson Orbs 3 times to awaken. Just make sure you are ready to face it. One is a gigantic worm like creature and roughly you need a wepon to stirke multiple times. The other is you guessed it A giganitic brain that flys around shooting out fleash colored blobs. Each are around 8000-16000 health again not very though. This is just an example of what you are looking at while playing this game and these are just the first 2 bosses that one faces in the game. I think there are 3 more bosses in normal mode and 15 in hard mode (not to be confuzed with expert mode). Is it worth getting I'd have to say... Yes

Terraria  is a 2D adventure sandbox game centered around surviving in a desolate world ruled by monsters. The game is a kind of 2D Minecraft when it comes to mining, building, and crafting, and a 2D Dark Souls when it comes to monster fights. Basically, almost anything that moves wants to kill you. Terraria has a plethora of items and an extensive crafting system which aid the player in progressing through the game and battling tougher monsters. The player will need to have the best armor, weapons and accessories if they want to stand a chance against bosses, each boss being stronger than its predecessor.   Terraria has excellent 2D pixelated graphics and item designs, accompanied by a good and diverse soundtrack. The maps can be very large and are a miner's dream come true, although exploring can become frustrating due to the frequent monster spawns around the player. In some cases it is necessary to switch the pickaxe with he sword every 5 seconds to deal with a new monster that has spawned nearby and is heading towards the player with the intention to eviscerate them.  I truly recommend this game to anyone that has played  Minecraft  or  Don't Starve  and wants a challenge, as I can assure you this game will give you enough 'opportunities' to die. Mining, exploring, battling, Terraria has them all, and is still being updated with new content, as of the writing of this review. The only reason I am not giving it a full  10  is because of its annoying monster spawn rate, which is especially frustrating while building underground structures. 9/10
More interesting than it seems...  EDIT: And 5 years later, it is still good! Never would have thought this game would change so much during that time and still be better for it! Highly recommended!

Now if I could have figured that I would have ended up with 2400 hours (At the time of the review) in this game when I first got it, I would have called you crazy. Well, atleast until 1.2 came out (Which was a week or so after I bought it). When I first started playing, I'll be honest and say that I knew how a few things worked going in, knew that I needed to make a house, knew I needed to fight 3 bosses.   Lucky to say that within that week, I was thrown out on my ♥♥♥ from that bit I knew and was better off for it. 1.2 and onward made for some of the most fun I've ever had in a game, and I got to discover new stuff all over the place.   Nowadays we're post-Red and while I don't agree with some of the practices (Would have rather had 1 or 2 updates instead of 4, would have made the updates more exciting) and while looking at two sequels , I'd honestly say that I'd be satisfied with the game as it is now. If you like Minecraft’s basics, but wanted the ability to be a rocket boot wearing, gun slinging, demon scythe throwing baddass at the same time, then this is for those who like to work for what they eat.

Terraria is, in my opinion, the best balance of open-world and goal-based gameplay. Once you create a world, you are spawned in the center of that world with your to-be companion who tells you how to make anything you want. You gather resources, build, mine - all while defeating bosses and trying to cleanse your map of 'Corruption' by defeating the final boss. You can play it single-player, but this game truly shines when you play with your friends online. You can spend weeks on the same map together just doing whatever. Fantastic game; (9.5/10)

Now before I start even though I have not put as many hours into this game as everyone else, I am certainly not a noob as I have played this on iOS and Xbox 360 before.  Terraria is a 2D side scrolley game mad by 505 Games for the PC in 2011. The graphics are good - I can run the game with everything turned up, on my Intel HD Graphics 4000, on a Medium World at 30fps. The replayablitily is non existent, there is no real 'End Game' compared to other games. There is a slight one - But this one is not needed to complete the game (it is to defeat all the bosses and to get the best weapons and armour) The Multiplayer for this game is OUTSTANDING! It is near seamless to connect to other people via steam - the one downside to the Multiplayer is if you have bad WIFI you may want to create a small world otherwise the game may not load, crash or lag. This game is harsh to beginners, when it is night, when you start, your basically toast - Unless you have a friend when your both toast.  Thanks for Reading   Potatoman426 - November 2016    P.S. If you are really lazy search up on the internet 'Builder's workshop' - It has every item in terraria, ever! (I take no credit for the map.)

I am hopelessly addicted to this game. I spend too many hours endlessly shaping and reshaping my base, with the quests forming minor distractions for me. This kind of fun game should carry a government warning as I've started playing before now on a Friday and the next thing is it is Saturday night and I am struggling to keep my eyes open.   The only thing that really lets down this 2D, minecraft alternative, is the lack of expansions. Sure - it has a great community that produces mods, and there are many hacks out there - but somehow I feel this is all cheating. By now - I feel that a full map should be visible in game. Instead I get a small window or a transparent overlay. Neither of these options have a full-world map or give any indication of how big things are.   The challenge is in figuring out how to reach the next part of the map and how to summon the next boss. There are many tasks to keep you busy. For example, recently I spent 20 hours relocating my base so it was elevated to prevent zombies and other mobs from invading. It worked well but the sheer amount of time and patience needed was enormous. However, this makes me love the game when I am playing it. It is very much a labour of love when playing this game, and the seemingly endless recipes and resource requirements make for the 'just one more hour' mentality. The online wikis and guides make the game easier but there is still so much to do.   Microsoft should have bought this one instead of Mojang's effort. Due to it being undeservedly less well-known than Minecraft, it would most likely have cost less. Instead they've bought a game with a questionable amount of horizontal instead of this game with which there is still so much scope to extend. I can think of at least a dozen possible enhancements to the game - not least of which would be online shards, infinite maps, and more elements to create things from. With any luck, they'll release Terraria 2 one day.

In my review I will be listing the pros and cons about the game and I will also discuss why it's amazing and what could become potentionally better or can be fixed  Pros: -simple, smooth, basics, easy to understand -variety of mobs, NPCs, creatures and enemies -variety of terrains and events -farming can't get boring -map is huge and is worth exploring -lots of secrets and easter eggs to be found -huge possibilities with armors and weapons -bosses can't get boring (unless you fight them too often) -fun in servers -easy to play with your friends now (they fixed servers) -great character customisation  -community is nice and for everyone -you can role play with your friends or with other people on servers (:D I love role play) -they keep adding good events and new interesting additions to Terraria  Cons: -no real story -no real lore -possible hackers on servers  I can't think of any more cons. Terraria is amazing, in my opinion, it beats Minecraft. Not only does Terraria have more to offer, it has less of a toxic community and bad server system like Minecraft. I will finish my review by saying that Terraria is for everyone, it's not just for people that are young, but for people that look to express themselves through pixels and to have fun with other people, and of course, to explor forever!

When I first got this game, I bought it because it was on sale for $2.99 on Steam and I saw 8 friends had played it. I loved Minecraft and thought, like many, that this is just a 2D Minecraft.  If you just wade your feet into the shallow waters, yes, it's a 2D Minecraft. That's probably a good 5% of the game and nothing more. The remaining 95% of the game is a bit of a learning curve, but in an extremely satisfying way. You need to craft items to progress, you need to beat bosses to progress, and once you beat what seems like the final boss, you turn your world into hard mode. You need to beat 5 bosses JUST to get into the heart of the actual game, and that's easily a good 10 hours that have flown by by that point. Once you get hard mode you get more enemies, more loot, more events, more magic, more blocks, MORE BOSSES. I put 100+ hours in JUST trying to beat all the bosses with a friend and we're still learning new things. Throw in new updates every few months and there's always more to come back to.

This game isn't too bad with the amount of content available, and for being a game that is over five years old, it's still going strong with updates adding content and patching bugs often enough to keep the game playable. It's come a long ways from the beginning, and while there is no actual story, the progressive system in this game keeps you going from boss to boss, equipment to equipment. There's quite a bit of equipment too, with a variety of weapons to keep playstyle interesting. From summoning, ranged, melee, magic, and even yo-yos, there's something to keep you entertained. With the exploring aspect, it may be a little difficult to begin with, but as you gain more accessories, exploration gets easier. From caves to difficult to navigate terrain, namely the jungle, there's a lot to see. There's also three different map sizes to pick from, so if you want a smaller map, you can. As for all the blocks, equipment, furniture, npcs, wiring, ores, and liquids, there's a variety of things that you can build. The world is completely changeable, some blocks requiring good tools to remove the blocks, the variety of buildings, structures, and whatever you want is available after some clicks... and however long it takes to build. But that doesn't mean you have to build alone. The multiplayer feature in Terraria is simplistic. You can connect with your Steam friends playing just by going through Steam itself. If you wanted, you can also connect via IP address, which is easier than it sounds. You can just keep your game running to allow people to join you through IP, or the game now comes with a simple server file to keep your world up for your friends if they want to keep playing while you're done. The only downside to that is that you have to open a port in your firewall. Even if you don't want to mess with server running yourself, there's plenty of servers out there to mess around on. Just make sure you have a good internet connection. Overall, it's not a bad game. It has replayability, items fit to just about any play style, pretty good multiplayer features, and an adequate building system and enough wiring to satisfy just about anyone more interested in technical aspects of games. If the kind of games you enjoy are more sandbox, equipment gathering, kill everything to progress, and/or building pixel homes and structures, you might enjoy this game. Those that enjoy playing Starbound, Don't Starve, or Edge of Space might enjoy this game if you don't mind a pixel style 2D game. Pros- + Can fit just about any play style with the variety of equipment, accessories, and mounts + Building is fun with the amount of blocks and biomes + Bunch of bosses and events to beat and gain loot + If normal mode is too easy, there's an expert mode with increased difficulty + Pretty good soundtrack + When you get bored, you can mod the game to cater to your experience  Cons- - Can be grindy at times - Multiplayer requires a good internet connection to not be a bad experience - If you're not a fan of 2D pixel sidescrollers, then you won't like this  Overall, I'll say that this game is a 9/10. For the $10 price, just pick this game up if you're interested.

This game is easily one of the best games I have ever played and is the best 2D game I have ever played. The massive amount of content will give you hours of enjoyment; there are tons of unique bosses to fight (with their own unique loot), a large variety of weapons and items to use (you can get wings!), and so much more. (Items and weapons include cannons, spellbooks, miniguns and other guns, rocketboots, shields, etc.) One feature that really seemed cool to me was the fact that you can get different tenents to move into buildings that you create that sell some pretty cool stuff or can upgrade your gear (the cannon is my personal favorite). The multiplayer feature is easy to use and has lead to hours of enjoyment with my friends, testing out the Expert mode which also has its own unique gear for going through. There are also holiday events such as invasions and cool pets and costumes to get during these times. There is so much awesome content in this game that I have only scrached the surface of what you can do.
